HEADLINE: Companies Capitalizing on Worker Diversity

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
From the palm-fringed Burger King headquarters in Miami to the Towers Perrin offices on Park Avenue in Manhattan, corporate managers and employees are playing the diversity game, literally and figuratively. They are trying everything from board games to real-life case studies to learn how to turn diverse groups of workers to their advantage.
The games and case studies are the brainchildren of consultants -- anthropologists and psychologists, as well as M.B.A.'s. Such consultants are increasingly being hired by employers who need help managing a diverse work force, in which members of minority groups, immigrants and women now hold more than half the jobs. 
 Managing diversity, or multi culturalism, has been defined as a desire to recognize, respect and capitalize on different strands and backgrounds in American society, like race, ethnic origin and gender. Over the years, the definition has been broadened to incorporate age, sexual orientation, physical disabilities, socioeconomic background and ways of living.
Only a few years ago, the idea of diversity in the work place was being dismissed by employers as an amorphous theory with little or no relevance to production and profit. Many employers believed that changing the corporate status quo would alienate their predominantly white, male work force.
Today, more and more employers view diversity as good business as well as good public relations. The executives who set aside company time -- and money -- to cultivate diversity hope the results will be fewer costly discrimination suits and a more tolerant, innovative work place.
What's more, dealing with diversity, one of the most popular management concepts of the 90's, is becoming a booming multimillion-dollar business.
"In the next two to five years, diversity might very well be a billion-dollar industry," said Dr. Ron Brown, the president of Banks Brown and a San Francisco consultant, whose firm specializes in fostering and managing diversity in the work place.
Neil Pickett, director of program management at the Hudson Institute, said, "Diversity has created a new career, a new vision of service."
But Mr. Pickett, along with many others who have witnessed the rapid growth in the industry, fears that some consultants may be entering the business primarily for the money. Dr. Sondra Thiederman, a consultant from San Diego, said, "Some are in it because they want to do good, others because they see it as a lucrative business."
Dr. Thiederman said she receives three or four queries a day from people asking how to get into the business. Many of these requests, she added, come from people with little training in work-place diversity, including former Peace Corps volunteers and spouses of corporate executives who have worked overseas.
And, she went on, some of those touting themselves as experts on managing diversity are minimally qualified to advise a company on the subtleties of issues involving race and gender in the work place. Of equal concern to some industry experts is the unsettling reality that some companies are hiring diversity consultants merely as window dressing. Reducing the effort to pure public relations, they argue, subverts the whole idea of diversity.
In 1987, the Hudson Institute produced "Workforce 2000," a study on work and workers for the 21st century that is credited by advocates of work-place diversity with giving an important impetus to the turnaround in the industry.
The study, which was done for the United States Labor Department, concluded that the overall work force would increase to 150.7 million in 2005, up from 124.7 million in 1990. Of the 26 million new workers, 85 percent would be members of minority groups, women and immigrants.
As one indication of the demand for specialists in managing diversity, Diversity Consultants Inc. of Atlanta, one of the nation's leading authorities on the subject, has seen its revenues double since 1989. In February, Towers Perrin, an international consulting firm, acquired Diversity Consultants. Diversity Consultants, founded in 1984 by Dr. R. Roosevelt Thomas Jr., has already trained several dozen Towers Perrin employees in diversity planning and strategy. The revenue figures were furnished by Robert L. Lattimer, the managing director.
 
Problems Followed Affirmative Action
 In the 1960's and 70's many corporations adopted affirmative-action programs and hired professionals in human resources to find, hire and promote blacks and women in fields that were previously closed to them. But then many companies failed to deal with the internal problems that arose after these hirings.
While programs dealing with diversity incorporate the traditional approaches, consultants also try to help a company and its employees to adjust psychologially and emotionally to the changing work force.
Consultants agree, however, that they can only do so much to overcome years of ingrained organizational behavior and established management patterns. Indeed, several conceded that they are sometimes temporary crutches for a company and that unless a company's management accepts what it has learned and applies it daily, the impact will be negligible.
Many consultants first conduct what they call a "corporate audit." They interview groups of employees about the company's corporate culture: the ways employees are selected, assigned jobs and promoted; whether extroversion is valued over introversion, and whether employees' ideas are routinely sought. Managers are asked to review the information to identify perceived or real obstacles to advancement.
Besides these audits, some consultants have managers and employees take personality tests like the Myers-Briggs Test, which helps determine how certain personality traits lead to race or gender stereotypes.
Nancy Hutchens, an anthropologist who has conducted numerous diversity workshops with Dr. Benjamin Reese, a clinical psychologist, said, "People tend to react to each other based on race and gender without realizing that what they were responding to was personality characteristics."
 
Diversity Programs And Individuals
 Trainers can also do fine tuning with specific employee problems. In one instance, Dr. Thiederman, was able to convince a white male manager that an Asian employee's reluctance to give an oral presentation was motivated by cultural differences, not caused by a professional inadequacy.
Dr. Thiederman suggested that the manager team the Asian woman with a colleague and have them present the project as a team. The manager agreed and, in Dr. Thiederman's word, the Asian employee was "eloquent."
Diversity programs appear to be having an impact. On the advice of Dr. Thomas, Avon Products, for example, capitalized on its own diversity. It gave black and Hispanic managers substantial authority over its unprofitable inner-city markets. The result: these markets are now among Avon's strongest performers.
Meanwhile, the Burger King Corporation, a unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., is using everything from "The Diversity Game," a board game, to three-day training seminars and has expanded the percentage of blacks and members of other minority groups in its work force to 28 percent last year, from 12 percent in 1986. And it has increased its business with suppliers owned by members of minority groups to $74 million this year, from $2 million in 1986, said Ray Hood-Phillips, vice president of human resources and diversity affairs for Burger King.
 
A Training Method: Ruffling Feathers
 "Upper-level white managers in charge of large numbers of people that include minorities can be taught to lead and manage those below them in a way that gets better business results across racial, ethnic and gender lines," said Floyd Dickens Jr., who with his wife, Jacqueline, founded 21st Century Management Services, in West Chester, Ohio. "But you first have to get inside people's heads and change behavior, and you can't do that without ruffling some feathers."
Around the country, conferences on diversity are attracting hundreds of managers from government and industry. Several colleges and universities now offer courses on diversity awareness, and a body of literature, including how-to books, has blossomed.
Among the most popular new training tools are videotapes, in which actors play out work situations illustrating everything from "exclusive old-boy networks" to racial and sexual discrimination.
According to various industry reports, 40 percent of American companies have some form of diversity training. One-fourth of some 1,400 companies polled last January by Haygroup of Philadelphia said that "adapting to work force diversity" is "a priority."
Of 645 national companies surveyed in 1990 by Towers Perrin, 29 percent offered programs in managing diversity. A 1991 follow-up of more than 200 of the same organizations found that work-related programs had increased since 1989, recession and economic woes notwithstanding.
 
Is It 'Touchy-Feely' Or the Real Thing?
 But more than a handful of blacks, Hispanic people and women express doubts about whether employers are sincere in their efforts to understand diversity or are merely paying lip service to it. These skeptics say that most employers have training in diversity awareness, but stop short of making extensive systemic changes.
"It's all this touchy-feely stuff -- 'I'll respect you, if you respect me,' " said a black woman, an account executive at a large consumer-products company in New Jersey, who spoke on condition that she not be identified. "Once you leave the room, it's back to business as usual. Nobody wants to hear about your day-care problems or your sick parent."
Indeed, a few employers acknowledge that the change of heart in favor of diversity came more from the business imperative than from altruism.
"There is some variation in the degree of commitment to diversity," Mr. Lattimer said. "Nearly all companies report that progress is occurring. However, results are not improving as quickly as had been previously anticipated or desired."
Of 11 companies -- among them Aetna Life and Casualty, A.T.& T., Gannett, Eastman Kodak and Mobil -- that participated in a Towers Perrin study of diversity, every one cited bias as a primary obstacle to upward mobility.
"Bias is reported to be particularly acute among middle managers who have not bought into the vision of senior management and are ignorant of the cultural issues of concern to women and minorities," Mr. Lattimer said. "One company found that managers are perceived as not believing upward mobility was a problem, or that discrimination exists."
Nevertheless, many consultants say, most employers are gradually facing the fact that the future of America in a global economy will rest with people who can understand cultural differences and can function across racial, ethnic, cultural and linguistic lines.
 
Diversity Leads To Better Performance
 "There is also a growing sentiment that diverse employee teams tend to outperform homogeneous teams of any composition," Mr. Lattimer said. "Managers tell us that homogeneous groups may reach consensus more quickly, but often they are not as successful in generating new ideas or solving problems, because their collective perspective is narrower."
Among the early converts was Burger King, which tells its customers, "Have it your way."
Since 1986, the 170 senior managers and 700 employees at Burger King's headquarters have gone through what is now described as their "basic training" in diversity awareness: a three-day session, including three hours playing "The Diversity Game."
The creator of the game, Dr. Alan Richter, vice president of Quality Educational Development in Manhattan, said: "The game tests players' knowledge while raising their awareness of diversity issues. Four teams of up to 20 players compete to answer multiple-choice questions in different categories, including demographics, jobs, legislation and society."
Mrs. Hood-Phillips said, "It's a wonderful way to learn, because it's interactive." After playing the game, she ordered 20 copies (retail price, $395 each) for franchise managers.
Dr. Lawrence G. Flores, designer of the Multicultural Promotional Track Game, uses a game strategy different from that of Dr. Richter. Players choose roles opposite to their own sex, racial or ethnic identity and try to reach the top of the corporate ladder, not necessarily by answering correctly, but by most closely simulating the methods, including office politics, traditionally used to advance in their own work places.
Dr. Flores, a former social worker who now works as a consultant, said, "I felt I wanted to take people to the action level to begin to see what it might feel like to be black, Hispanic or female and work your way up the promotional ladder."
 
Humor, and a Quest For Standards
 While some consultants use games, others use humor.
"I usually start out by telling an audience to impulsively raise their hand or keep it down," said Donald Kao, an Asian-American who is a New York City youth worker. "Then I ask, 'How many racists are in the room?' and then I immediately raise my hand and people are confused."
He conducts what he calls "supportive confrontation" workshops on college campuses. "I see the confusion on their faces," he continued. "Then I say, 'For the next two hours we are not going to worry about who is or isn't racist, but who is going to do something about racism and who isn't."
Dr. Sylvia S. Wagonheim, director of the Center for the New American Workforce at Queens College of the City University of New York, a resource network for business, education and government, said the center hoped to cut down on the confusion by creating minimum standards and criteria for professional trainers and consultants in diversity.
"Because diversity in business is so relatively new and there are so few hard facts, you have to sell it from a standpoint that it is competitive, effective and efficient," Dr. Wagonheim said. "Everybody has gone through the sensitizing stage, where there is an awareness. Now what? How do you resolve conflict? How do you try to make sure that person is happy in his or her work, that they can move ahead to fulfill their self-actuation?"

HEADLINE: ConEd Request Faces Challenge

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Consolidated Edison will seek a 6.5 percent increase in electricity rates in hearings that begin today, and the request has won preliminary approval from the Public Service Commission as the second of three increases over three years. But two consumer advocates are preparing to challenge the request and the concept of a three-year rate agreement, contending that they are harmful to consumers' interests.
The challenge comes from Richard M. Kessel, executive director of the state Consumer Protection Board, and Peter L. DiCapua, president of the Owners Committee on Electric Rates, a group of large commercial customers. Mr. Kessel said yesterday that if Con Ed had to ask for increases annually, it probably would not have asked this year. 
 The increase, he said, is twice the rate of inflation and comes as the company's service territory -- New York City and most of Westchester County -- struggles with a recession.
 
18.9 Percent Over Three Years
 The deal, announced a year ago, would give the company an increase in electric rates of about 18.9 percent over three years. The first increase, 5.1 percent, took effect in April; at issue now is an increase that would be effective in April 1993. It was originally supposed to be 6.7 percent, but Con Edison said yesterday that it would be 6.5 percent, or about $330 million.
At the company, Richard Robinson, the manager of rate design, said the increases were being driven by two factors: paying for efficiency programs and buying power from outside sources. The efficiency programs include rebates to customers who buy lamps, motors and air-conditioners that do the same work with less energy, and reimbursement to the company for the drop in electricity sales that result. The purchases come from independent generators, which Mr. Robinson said were needed as demand gradually rises and the company's own plants age.
Mr. Kessel argued, however, that economic conditions mean that no increase is justified. The company's allowable return on equity looks higher and higher when compared with prevailing interest rates, he said.
But Joan Freilich, Con Edison's vice president and controller, said the return on equity was "below the average rates being allowed in other states" and about average for utilities in New York State.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
The U.A.W. agreed to sweeping early-retirement incentives at General Motors. It was not immediately clear how many workers would retire early, but the package is one way the auto maker hopes to shrink its hourly work force about 13 percent by 1995. [Page A1.]
Boeing will impose a contract proposal rejected by employees. The move set the stage for a strike by engineers and technical employees, possibly as early as today. [D1.] 
 California banks will face serious problems in the coming year because of weak real estate markets and a stubborn regional recession, as well as tougher national banking regulations. There may be 30 fewer banks in California next year as a result. [D1.]
Wall Street firms in several low-lying buildings were disabled when water from rising tides found its way into basement vaults holding electrical transformers and telephone equipment. [D1.]
Managers and workers are learning about workplace diversity through everything from board games to real-life case studies. Their companies hope the exercises will result in fewer discrimination suits and a more tolerant workplace. [A1.]
Cincinnati Gas and PSI Resources plan to merge next year. The new entity, the Cinergy Corporation, will be the 13th-largest investor-owned utility as measured by generating capacity. [D5.]
Litton received a $760.9 million contract from the Navy to build its sixth ship in the Wasp class of amphibious assault vessels. [D5.]
Ronald O. Perelman will pay $180 million to buy back Consolidated Cigar from Vestar Capital Partners Inc. He sold the nation's largest cigar maker for $128 million in 1988. [D6.]
National Semiconductor will join forces with Toshiba to enter the hot market for a new chip called flash memory. The chips do not lose their contents when a computer's power is shut off. [D6.]
James W. Kinnear will retire as Texaco's chief executive. Alfred C. DeCrane Jr., the chairman, will succeed him. [D6.]
Edward W. Harbert was appointed president of ABC Entertainment, replacing Robert A. Iger. [D21.]
 
The Economy
President-elect Bill Clinton led an elaborate seminar in which prominent economists and business executives presented the case that the American economy is badly crippled. [A1.]
The Small Business Administration is short of cash because it has been guaranteeing so many loans. It is one sign of the wariness of banks in making loans, and many are waiting for the Clinton Administration to show how it will ease the credit crunch. [D1.]
The Supreme Court will consider banks' sales of insurance. At issue is a Federal law that an appeals court found had been repealed 74 years ago. [D1.]
 
Markets
The stock market settled lower at the end of a dull, seesaw session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials lost 11.88 points, to 3,292.20. Volume on the Big Board was 187 million shares. [D8.]
A $1 billion issue is putting pressure on bond underwriters. The sale was scheduled for today on short notice by the T.V.A. In the Treasury market, prices of bonds and notes fell. [D16.]
Cattle prices soared to eight-month highs as a storm stalled over the Great Plains, endangering large cattle herds. [D17.]
The dollar ended mixed against key currencies. [D17.]
 
Today's Columns
People may feel better off than they actually are in the wake of the election, and consumer confidence surveys in the next six weeks will be very important. Louis Uchitelle: Business Scene. [D2.]
Arkla's chief executive is leaving for a White House job, even though investors in the company's shares are worse off than they were four years ago. Kurt Eichenwald: Market Place. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Will Jawboning Ease U.S. Credit Squeeze?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Last Thursday, the Small Business Administration ran out of money and stopped issuing approvals to guarantee new bank loans to businesses until after Jan. 1, when more funds become available. The agency is still encouraging new applications, but at its recent pace of lending -- $25 million a day -- it will exhaust the $817 million loan quota for January through March well before that quarter ends.
During the recession, the S.B.A. has stepped in as banks became more wary of lending. And its budget shortfall is just one reminder that after two years of clamor about how the credit crunch has hurt the economy, there is not a cohesive Federal program to address the issue. 
 Clinton advisers have not tipped their hand about what banking changes they may recommend. But bankers hope that any proposal that emerges during President-elect Bill Clinton's economic conference in Little Rock this week will include more carrot than stick.
For the last two years, banks have been accumulating deposits and have the capacity to issue more loans, but they have been waiting for the economy to improve and bring with it increased loan demand and financially stronger borrowers. With those improvements still shadowy, many think lending is unlikely to pick up without jawboning of bankers or examiners or an increase in funds for the S.B.A.'s Government-guaranteed loan program.
For bankers, an attempt to increase lending by fiat is the least desirable of any near-term solution. "There is a lot of room for banks to change their behavior and do more lending, but I would hesitate before letting Congress legislate limits on where and how much banks should lend," Michael Forbes, the departing regional administrator of the S.B.A. in New York and New Jersey, said. "If the President and the Secretary of the Treasury make it a priority, they could jawbone the banks and embarrass them into lending more to small business."
Others say that the jawboning could be more effective if directed at bank regulators and examiners rather than at banks. Bankers widely agree that examiners have not become any kinder or gentler in their treatment of banks, despite the exhortations of the Secretary of the Treasury and other officials in the Bush Administration. The promptings of politicians have carried little weight because examiners still wince at the memory of testifying before Congressional committees to explain how they could have tolerated the practices that led to the failures of the Bank of New England and the National Bank of Washington.
 
 
Real Estatge Loans
 Top-ranking regulators were also blamed for letting banks get into trouble with real estate loans during the mid-1980's. Robert L. Clarke, Comptroller of the Currency, in charge of regulating most of the country's largest banks from 1986 till early this year, was blamed during his reconfirmation hearings in 1991 for controlling banks too loosely while other members of Congress and bankers were calling him the "regulator from hell." Mr. Clarke, who was not confirmed, disavowed the title, saying he was from Texas.
Another problem with jawboning is that it is uneven in effect and can lead to another cycle of excessive laxity in bank lending standards and examinations that would lay the seeds for heavy bank losses when the economy next weakens.
Christopher L. Snyder, president of the Loan Pricing Corporation, a company that works closely with banks to develop procedures for setting interest rates on loans that accurately reflect the risk of default, noted that previous episodes of jawboning had had unfortunate consequences. "In the early 1980's, Congress admonished bank examiners to lighten up and encourage business loans to flow," he said. "The message got through, and for several years the bank examination amounted to little more than a pleasant encounter."
Ira Stepanian, chairman of the Bank of Boston, recommends that jawboning be supplemented by a 50 percent reduction in the amount of capital banks must hold for loans to small businesses. By counting only half of small business loans -- the same percentage as for residential mortgages -- "regulators would free up a substantial portion of the capital base of banks, enabling them to do additional small business lending," he said.
Some analysts doubted Mr. Stepanian's recommendation would be accepted because it would undermine efforts to apply uniform capital rules on large banks around the world. They also worry about setting a precedent for using the capital adequacy rules as a tool for allocating credit to different areas of the economy.
Increasing the scope of the Small Business Administration is another widely prescribed remedy for tight credit. Last year, Congress twice increased the S.B.A.'s lending, so that by the end of the fiscal year on Sept. 30, it had guaranteed $5.62 billion of loans, up from $4.15 billion the previous year.
Last August, Congress voted to authorize a $6.2 billion increase in new loan guarantees, but failed to make needed appropriations; the agency is currently authorized to guarantee only $3.27 billion of new loans this fiscal year, plus the $368 million in unused authority left over from the previous year.
Even if money were available for all $6.2 billion, some bankers say the amount is small relative to the need.
 "You could hardly call these budgets a serious effort to end the recession," Louis J. Cappelli, chairman of the Sterling National Bank and Trust Company in New York, said. Mr. Cappelli added that local governments could double the budgets of various business loan guarantee agencies, which would make it easier for banks to find partners to share the risks of loans to businesses that might be weak now, but have potential.
But before the S.B.A. and local government agencies can be put to work, banks must be willing to make the loans. Among the nation's nearly 12,000 banks, only 157 are "preferred" lenders that have authority to make Government-guaranteed loans without prior approval by the S.B.A. Only 670 banks are certified lenders that use the program often enough to receive notice within three days about whether their loans are acceptable to the agency.
Mr. Stepanian of the Bank of Boston said that the credit crunch in New England was lifting, thanks in part to the initiatives of bankers. His bank, for example, recently changed its rules so that a single lending officer can approve a loan, but two officers are needed to issue a denial.
These are other ways to encourage more bank lending:
*Quick action by regulators to adopt a provision of the housing bill passed this fall that would eliminate the current requirement that there be an appraisal for any loans above $100,000 that are backed by real estate.
*New procedures to make S.B.A. programs easier for banks to use.
*Enactment of a Federal law that would protect banks from the costs of cleaning up environmental damages caused by a bank's customer in cases in which the bank did not knowingly contribute to the problem.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Leaving Behind Problems at Arkla

BYLINE: By Kurt Eichenwald

 BODY:
JAN. 20, 1989. In Washington, George Bush was being sworn in as President. And on the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Arkla Inc., a gas pipeline company, closed at $20.875.
Almost four years later, fortunes have changed. Mr. Bush is getting ready to leave the White House as the country's chief executive, having lost the election on concerns about the economy. And at Arkla, the chief executive is also packing, leaving behind investors who have seen their share price collapse by more than 50 percent since then, closing yesterday at just $8.25 a share. 
 And where is that chief executive, Thomas F. McLarty 3d, going? To the White House, to take over the job of chief of staff for the incoming Clinton Administration.
Mack McLarty, a boyhood chum of Bill Clinton's and a virtual unknown to Washington politics, ran Arkla for almost eight years, leaving behind a company that is struggling to pay down its debt, regain its profit margins and reorganize itself into a leaner, more effective corporation. People looking for signs of Mr. McLarty's potential in running the White House may not be pleased with what they see at Arkla.
"They have been doing pretty lousy, no question about that," Foster Corwith, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds, said of Arkla. "They are barely earning any money right now."
The problems at Arkla are multifold, running from too much diversification to organizational problems in critical businesses like gas pipelines to a $530 million lawsuit brought against the company in October by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal regulator for savings and loans.
Some analysts also criticize Mr. McLarty's hands-off management style. For example, they noted that even though the company's headquarters were in Shreveport, La., Mr. McLarty lived in Little Rock, Ark.
Wall Street appears worried that Arkla's problems may continue. Early yesterday, investors and analysts, hopeful that Mr. McLarty's resignation would be used by Arkla as a chance to focus on its profit troubles in its pipelines business, bid up the stock to as high as $8.875. Analysts said they expected the company would elevate Daniel L. Dienstbier, the former chief executive of Enron, the nation's largest pipeline system, who was named to a top post at Arkla in July.
But, when the company announced that T. Milton Honea, Arkla's vice chairman, would take over as chief executive, while Mr. Dienstbier would continue as president and chief operating officer, a disappointed Wall Street started selling, driving Arkla's stock price down 62.5 cents to its closing price of $8.25. It was the most active issue on the Big Board yesterday, with almost 3.5 million shares traded.
Company executives said yesterday that Wall Street's initial chill came because analysts knew Mr. Dienstbier better. "As the result of his background, Dan is quite well known to the analyst community, and Milt is not," said Michael B. Bracy, executive vice president for finance.
But regardless of who is in charge, Arkla's challenges are immense. According to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Arkla has been paying dividends to shareholders in excess of its earnings. This means that Arkla increased its debt just to keep its dividend, which was finally cut this year. The company's trend for years has been increasing interest payments on more and more debt.
And yet, Arkla's ability to service that debt has grown more shaky, as profit margins for its various businesses have been squeezed. Even as its strategy has caused an increase in revenues, it has failed to see proportionate increases in operating income, S.E.C. filings show.
One area where profits have been disappointing is an important pipeline, known as Line AC. The line moves gas out of Oklahoma producing areas to other parts of the country. But that strategy depended on a price differential with gas from the Texas Gulf Coast of about 25 cents a million cubic feet, according to Carol Coale, an analyst with Howard Weile, Labrouisse, Friedrichs. That spread has been much narrower, sometimes about 8 cents to 10 cents a million cubic feet.
The company must also fight the lawsuit from brought by saving and loan regulators. The suit stems from the failure of University Savings Association, a Houston institution owned by Entex Inc. before Entex was purchased by Arkla in 1988. The suit contends that Entex failed to disclose the condition of the association when it was sold. Arkla denies the charges and plans to fight them.
With all of these troubles, Arkla announced a sweeping restructuring last month. Arkla will sell several of its companies, including its exploration unit, to reduce debt.
With top executives frequently replaced as part of major reorganizations, some on Wall Street openly wondered whether Arkla was taking advantage of the election of Bill Clinton to part amiably with its former chairman. But Arkla executives say no. "The timing is coincidental," Mr. Bracy said. "But in some ways, it is fortuitous."

HEADLINE: Trenton Senate to Let Voters Decide on Sports Gambling

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Without a vote to spare, the Senate approved a resolution today that would allow voters to decide whether to permit sports wagering at Atlantic City casinos.
The vote today, a victory for the powerful casino industry, begins a complicated legislative process aimed at placing the issue on the ballot in November 1993. If voters approve the measure, New Jersey would become the second state after Nevada to allow casinos to offer wagering on professional and college sporting events. 
 The amendment would ban wagering on sports events involving New Jersey colleges and universities, but there would be no prohibition against bets on professional teams in the state or on out-of-state colleges.
 
Called Crucial for Economy
 "The exclusion of New Jersey colleges under this proposal is a weak bid to pour bad chlorine into the betting pool," said the Assistant Senate Democratic Minority Leader, Richard J. Cody. "It won't clean up the stench that permeates this entire plan to make a bad scene worse."
Supporters of the resolution argue that it will allow the state to create new jobs and raise money for programs for senior citizens and the disabled by diverting to the state much of the $2.5 billion that officials say is bet illegally in New Jersey each year.
New Jersey voters legalized casino gambling in Atlantic City in a 1976 constitutional amendment. While the amendment did not specifically prohibit sports betting, the amendment's supporters said it would not be allowed.
Some of those same proponents and their new allies argue that sports wagering is now vital to the survival of the gambling industry in Atlantic City, which faces competition as diverse as riverboat gambling on the Mississippi River and casinos on Indian reservations in Connecticut.
Opponents of sports wagering, including the commissioners of every major professional team sport and officials of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, have based their campaign on the specter of criminal influence on players or game officials and on its potential to increase gambling addiction.
 
Facing 1994 Deadline
 Trenton is now caught up in a make-or-break debate over the issue, working under the pressure of a deadline imposed by a new Federal law that banned sports betting in most states but gave New Jersey voters until January 1994 to decide what to do. Four states other than Nevada have state-sponsored sports-betting lotteries.
In the Assembly today, members of the Financial Institutions Committee decided not to vote on the measure in order to allow time for more testimony.
In the Senate, intense lobbying efforts had placed the outcome of the vote in doubt up to the last minute. Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco had to take two roll-call votes before two of his Republican partymen who had abstained -- Senators John O. Bennett and John E. Dimon -- cast "yes" votes, providing the margin for victory. The vote had stalled at 19-16, two shy of the constitutionally mandated 21-vote majority. The final vote was 21-16.
"At last, the people of our state will be allowed to cast their vote on sports betting," said Senator C. Louis Bassano, a Republican from Union who sponsored the bill. "I am confident that our citizens will vote in favor of legalized betting, particularly in the light of our dire fiscal times."
 
Sports Officials Assailed
 Holding aloft copies of a newspaper's sports page turned to betting lines and picks of games, Mr. Bassano called the opposition by professional sports officials to his resolution hypocritical.
"The leagues that have been campaigning so vigorously against this bill, spending millions of dollars in the process, have never once raised a note of protest about the daily promotion of illegal gambling on sporting events that takes place in this country," Mr. Bassano said. "You can hear it on the radio, see it on TV or you can read it in the newspapers."
Today's Assembly committee hearing made clear the intensity of the fight, with a witness list that included the developer and casino owner Donald J. Trump, commissioners of professional sports leagues and representatives of other interest groups.
"Atlantic City is in very deep trouble," said Mr. Trump, who owns three casinos there. "This industry may not exist if it's not allowed to continue to grow."
 
Fierce Debate
 The commissioner of the National Basketball Association, David Stern, was among those speaking against the idea.
"The issue here is whether the state should lend its seal to teaching kids about gambling and turning them into gamblers," he said. "You don't legalize something just because there's illegal activity."
Earlier this year, backers of legalized sports wagering failed in an attempt to place the issue on the ballot. The opposition included United States Senator Bill Bradley, a former N.B.A. star for the New York Knicks.
Yet it was an attempt by Mr. Bradley to quash legalized sports betting nationally that led to the new effort to put the issue on the New Jersey ballot. Mr. Bradley was chief sponsor of Federal legislation that would have banned sports betting anywhere.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The New Jersey Senate approved a resolution to allow voters to decide whether to allow sports wagering at Atlantic City casinos. In Trenton, Donald J. Trump congratulated Senator C. Louis Bassano, right, of Union, N.J., who sponsored the bill. The man at left was not identified. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Tension Over Europe Eases; Trading in Dollar Is Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed yesterday against leading foreign currencies in subdued year-end trading. Tensions in the market eased somewhat after progress was apparently made toward unity at the European Community's weekend summit meeting.
Gold prices rose marginally in Asia, turned mixed in Europe and fell slightly in the United States. At the Commodity Exchange in New York, bullion for current delivery fell 60 cents an ounce, to $334.60. At the Republic National Bank, the spot price was $334.60 as well, down 50 cents from Friday. 
 Foreign exchange traders said some of the anxiety in the market on Friday before the European Community meeting in Edinburgh, Scotland, had faded. Leaders of the 12 community nations said after the meeting that they had successfully revived a flagging movement toward economic and monetary unity.
Doubts about Europe's ability to evolve toward a single-currency economy have played a crucial role in the foreign exchange turmoil sweeping through the market in recent months. A prime beneficiary of that turmoil has been the powerful German mark.
The mark continued to gain value yesterday. Traders ascribed the rise to the German central bank's strategy of keeping interest rates high, making investments denominated in marks worth more.
Traders said the mark's strength was putting pressure on some weaker European currencies, notably the French franc, but having no significant impact on the dollar.
"For the rest of the year, there's really no direction for the dollar," said Peter Iversen, assistant chief dealer at the foreign exchange desk of Shawmut Bank in Boston.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 123.88 Japanese yen, up 0.10 yen from the Friday close. Later, in London, it rose to 123.70 yen. In New York, the dollar fetched 123.765 yen, down from 123.90 late Friday.
The British pound strengthened in London at $1.5650, up from $1.5585 late Friday. In New York, 1 fetched $1.5665, up from $1.5570 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Friday, included: 1.57025 marks, down from 1.5785; 1.4090 Swiss francs, up from 1.4085; 1.27475 Canadian dollars, up from 1.27425, and 1,394.25 Italian lire, down from 1,396.50.
In Hong Kong, gold rose 39 cents to close at $335.51. Later, gold traded in London at $335.15 an ounce, up from $335.10 late Friday.

HEADLINE: Bad Tidings for California Banks

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Even without tougher national banking regulations that take effect on Saturday, California banks face serious problems in the coming year because of continued weak real-estate markets and a stubborn regional recession.
Federal regulators, banking analysts and officials of small and large banks agree that -- new rules or not -- there may be as many as 30 fewer banks in California next year as a result of the current problems. 
 The new rules require regulators to start closing a bank or savings and loan if its shareholder capital drops to less than 2 percent of its assets. The rules are intended to reduce taxpayer and deposit insurance losses from failed institutions by allowing regulators to seize them before they are insolvent.
 
Rules Known for a Year
 During the Presidential campaign, the independent candidate Ross Perot, among others, charged that the Bush Administration was hiding bank problems and that once the new regulations took effect the problems would suddenly flood the nation. But most banking experts contended then, as they do now, that there would be no such "December surprise."
The banks have known about the new requirements for a year, the experts say, and have been raising capital to comply with them. Indeed, nationwide, the condition of many banks has vastly improved in recent months, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said last week.
In California, banking troubles are particularly acute in regions where real-estate values dropped sharply and the military and aerospace industries retrenched, eliminating hundreds of thousands of high-paying engineering, manufacturing and construction jobs.
A bank's health mirrors the economy the bank serves. Most economists here say that California's economic slump has not bottomed out and that it may grow worse before the earliest projected recovery, in 1995.
"This is Armageddon for California banks," said George M. Salem, a banking analyst for Prudential Securities. "There will be great pain, and by the time it's finished banks will be forced to close or to merge, or they will be taken over by the F.D.I.C."
Banking experts maintain that small, independent banks in the southern part of the state are most vulnerable because they operate primarily in a region where the recession hit hardest and where bankers relied too heavily on loans backed by real estate -- an assertion that many small banks dispute.
The regulators and people in the banking industry see one positive aspect to the bank closings: they will eliminate overcapacity and ultimately reduce the cost of doing business.
F.D.I.C. officials point to a number of trouble spots in California's banking system that have caused regulators to view the state with great concern. As of Sept. 30, for example, 29 percent of California's 462 banks were showing losses for the year to date, compared with 6.5 percent of banks nationwide.
These losses were due in large measure to bad real-estate loans, particularly loans for the development of commercial buildings. At the end of September, 37 percent of all banking assets in California were tied to residential and commercial real estate, compared with a national average of 25 percent.
At the end of September, 63.7 percent of California's problem loans -- those that were more than 30 days past due -- were tied to real estate. That compared with 53.6 percent for the entire country, according to the Federal agency. The reason: commercial property owners are struggling to make loan payments because of high vacancy rates and pressure from tenants to lower rents.
 The F.D.I.C. estimates that problem real-estate loans totaled $7.5 billion in California at the end of the third quarter and $37 billion for the nation.
"We are watching California's banks more closely and have instructed our examiners to be sensitive to individual banks' performance and their real estate exposure," said Allan Whitney, the F.D.I.C.'s director of corporate communications. "But we also do not want our examiners to overreact."
 
'Troubled' Banks Quadruple
 As a matter of policy, mainly to prevent bank runs, the F.D.I.C. does not disclose information about the health of specific banks. But F.D.I.C. officials said the number of banks in the West, particularly in California, that were classified as "troubled" more than quadrupled from June 1990 to March 1992.
F.D.I.C. officials say that there have been 110 bank failures nationwide this year, involving $38 billion in assets, and that they expect a similar number of failures in 1993. But those failures will involve twice the amount of assets, or about $76 billion, and the largest number will occur in California, the nation's most populous and economically productive state, the regulators say privately.
Students of American banking say they think that generally speaking, the industry is prepared for the new regulations. "The 2 percent rule is similar to taking a final exam where the questions have been announced a year in advance," said Warren Heller, research director for Veribanc, a bank research firm. "You would have to be pretty stupid not to pass the exam, and banks would have to be in very bad shape not to meet the new rules."
Mr. Heller predicts that about 20 California banks will be closed next year because of bad real estate loans and a weak economy, especially small and medium-sized banks in Southern California, where the recession has hit hardest.
A recent study by the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco found that California's small banks, those with less than $300 million in assets, were more vulnerable than larger banks because they had relied more heavily on real estate loans that later turned sour. About two-thirds of all loans at the state's smaller banks were backed by real estate, and three-fifths of all real estate loans were for commercial property and construction, the study found.
But the independent banks say that they are not down for the count and that in some ways they are in a better position than larger banks to ride out the recession and the real estate decline. They say they are more flexible, less bureaucratic and easier to manage.
"I'm not minimizing the problems that we are facing," said Craig Hudson, director of the western region for the Independent Bankers Association of America, representing 260 small banks in California. "And yes, most of the closures that do take place will probably be smaller banks, but I don't think there will be a tremendous upsurge in problem banks."
Richard Korsgaard, president of Mariners Bank in San Clemente, which has $90 million in assets and is considered healthy, disputes the notion that smaller banks are worse off. He maintains that the independents are being hit hard by a wave of more stringent regulation, creating the appearance that they are poorer than they really are.
 
 
Strength of Large Banks
 California's large banks are not as susceptible as smaller ones, industry analysts say, because their business is spread throughout the state, they have been more closely scrutinized by regulators, and they have set aside larger reserves to cover potential loan losses. But the big banks are still feeling the bite of the recession.
Of the state's three largest banks, industry analysts say that Wells Fargo is perhaps the most vulnerable because it has the highest concentration of commercial real estate loans in Southern California. Still, Wells Fargo shares have performed well, partly because of large stock purchases by Warren E. Buffett, the prominent Omaha-based investor.
Bank of America, which recently merged with Security Pacific, did not become heavily involved in commercial real estate loans because of its problem loans in Latin America. But Mr. Salem of Prudential said he thought that cost savings achieved from the merger would be more than offset by losses from bad real estate loans at Security Pacific.
First Interstate has become the darling of the state's big banks because it recognized early where the state's real estate lending market was heading and bailed out, selling off assets and taking a huge charge that reduced its earnings. "Our bad experiences with real estate markets in Texas and Colorado in the 1980's taught us a valuable lesson," said Bruce Willison, chief executive of First Interstate Bank of California. "The usual path for bankers during a rolling recession is a prolonged denial phase, but this time we didn't stick our heads in the sand."
 
 
Rumors About Hollywood Bank
 City National Bank, known as the bank to the stars, was forced last month to increase its capital by $65 million as a cushion against losses, largely from real estate loans. The bank's parent, the City National Corporation, lost $60.2 million in the nine months that ended on Sept. 30.
For weeks, rumors have circulated in the entertainment industry that the bank, which is still strong enough to meet Federal capital requirements, is ripe for a takeover by regulators. George Benter, the president of City National, said that top bank officials had been holding meetings with concerned customers to assuage their doubts. About 40 percent of the bank's loans are in real estate.
Mr. Benter said he thought City National now had a "more than adequate" reserve to cover losses from real estate loans. The bank is concentrating on cutting costs, expanding its medium-size business and serving wealthy individuals.

HEADLINE: 25 Years to Life in Slaying

 BODY:
An unemployed handyman received the maximum sentence of 25 years to life in prison yesterday for the murder of a Hasidic woman who was stabbed to death in February in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. The defendant, Romane LaFond, was convicted on Nov. 11 of slaying the woman, Phyllis LaPine, who was killed during a burglary in her apartment on Feb. 6. The crucial evidence in the eight-day trial was the defendant's bloody palm print, which was found on a wall next to Mrs. LaPine's body. Justice Francis X. Egitto, who conducted the trial, imposed the maximum sentence on the 24-year-old defendant in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Consumer Surge Is Facing Tests

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
CONSUMER confidence is a fickle thing. The economy has surged since October, in large part because Americans seem to be feeling more confident about their jobs and their incomes. So they have gone shopping. But sometimes a major event, like a military victory or a Presidential election, can cause people to feel better off than they actually are. And after a while, the optimism disappears, along with the surge in shopping and economic growth.
That possibility makes the consumer confidence surveys that will be conducted over the next six weeks very important in gauging whether a strong recovery has finally arrived after nearly four years of weak growth or outright recession. Consumer confidence has shot up since Election Day, but that is also the problem. Is Bill Clinton's election the only reason for the surge in optimism about jobs and higher wages? If so, can the optimism endure? 
 "Without doubt, there has been a Clinton effect on the polls, just as there was a Persian Gulf effect," said Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan Consumer Surveys, referring to the brief surge in consumer confidence and economic growth in 1991, after the gulf war ended. "People have a firm expectation that Clinton will do something to steer the economy to better times. It is the anticipation of the change that has provided the initial stimulation, and it can wear off quickly."
What the anticipation has done is to encourage people to increase their spending by more than the rise in their incomes. To cover the shortfall, people have cut into savings or they have borrowed more. The hope is that the increase in retail sales, particularly for Christmas, will push up production as stores are restocked. And companies will finally hire more workers to produce the extra goods, spreading fresh income through the nation that can be used for more spending, thereby sustaining a recovery.
The increased hiring did not happen during the surge after the gulf war. Nor did it happen during another brief surge in consumer confidence and the economy last spring.
Corporate America, bent on becoming more efficient and cutting costs, has managed to increase output, when necessary, without raising payrolls. And that resistance to hiring or raises, still in evidence, soon saps public confidence and takes the pleasure out of shopping.
"The problem is that we have been burned twice and people are nervous that they might get burned again," said David Wyss, chief economist at DRI/ McGraw-Hill, which produces economic forecasts.
Nothing seems to catch the public's swings between hope and disillusionment as clearly as the monthly consumer confidence surveys conducted by the University of Michigan group, which polls people by telephone, and the Conference Board, a business group whose results are obtained from mailed questionnaires. The index tabulated from the Michigan polls reached 91.4 in early December from 73.3 in October, while the Conference Board's index jumped to 65.5 by late November from 54.6 in October.
What the polls try to capture is not some abstract view of the economy, but a citizen's own "economic environment," Fabian Linden, director of the Conference Board's survey, said. "Their companies are either hiring or firing, cutting back hours or adding work, and their own behavior is sensitive to these changes. They have friends and neighbors who are hired or fired, and that affects their purchases. They talk to local merchants who say business is better or worse, or they walk down Main Street and see another store closed."
The surveys try to capture two aspects of this personal experience. One is the present situation. Are jobs becoming more plentiful or are they harder to find for the people polled, and what is happening to their incomes? The second aspect measures expectations. Will jobs be easier or harder to get six months from now? Does the person think his income will be higher? Does he or she plan to purchase a car or a home or a major appliance by June?
The most recent surveys reveal that people do not consider their present situations much improved. Indeed, Albert Sindlinger, chairman of Sindlinger & Company, who tries through a telephone poll to measure household liquidity, or a family's purchasing power, finds that liquidity has risen lately in only six states, all in the West.
But when it comes to expectations for the future, all of the polls show a sharp improvement, apparently in response to Mr. Clinton's campaign promises to create jobs and improve wages. In each case, this optimism for the future has pulled up the overall consumer confidence index.
That saddles Mr. Clinton with a critical decision. To maintain people's hopes, should he push for quick approval of new public works spending or some other job-creating stimulus?
"The consumer confidence numbers are going to be critical in making that decision," said Lawrence H. Meyer, an economic consultant.

HEADLINE: Medical Research Boosts New York Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was delighted, at long last, to see mention of the contribution of medical scientists to the economic health of New York City (news article, Nov. 17). It is unfortunate, however, that the first mention of the vast sums that individual scientists, directly and indirectly, bring to the city was in an article with a negative cast. 
 Each year scientific investigators in New York City are awarded hundreds of millions of dollars in competitive grants. In addition, we attract large amounts of research money from private foundations, organize large international and national scientific conferences in New York, and attract thousands of scientists from other cities and countries to visit or work in our laboratories. These activities bring both funds and jobs to New York and great prestige to our city.
Despite these enormous benefits, the contribution of scientists to the economic health of New York City is virtually unknown to the general public.
Governmental organizations spring into action when a business with 50 or 100 employees threatens to leave New York; however, to my knowledge, no incentives have been given to attract scientists to New York or to retain those already here despite the fact that scientist-initiated medical research constitutes one of the largest enterprises in the city.
 
ARNOLD J. FRIEDHOFF, M.D.
New York, Nov. 25, 1992
 
The writer is professor and director of the Millhauser Laboratories, New York University School of Medicine.

HEADLINE: German Asylum: Too-Liberal Policy?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Our German Crisis" by A. M. Rosenthal (column, Nov. 24) warns of one side of the German crisis: rising Nazism. But he fails to show that in contrast to the 1930's, the crisis in large part stems from Germany's policy on political asylum, the most liberal in all Europe. 
 The population of Germany is almost one-third that of the United States, while its geographical area is less than the state of Montana. Yet the U.S. is fearful of an invasion of tiny numbers of Haitians, many of whom have been terrorized and need political asylum. Moreover, Germany agreed to let in 220,000 Bosnian refugees when it was under siege from refugees all over Eastern Europe, Africa and the Middle East. The U.S. has agreed to the magnanimous quota of 1,000 Bosnians.
Perhaps Germany was too liberal in its political asylum policy. Clearly it has led to conflict between unemployed Germans -- especially East Germans -- and the rising number of refugees.
Mr. Rosenthal's solution of creating permanent international machinery to combat Nazi organizations is zealously single-minded. Instead of throwing stones, let us be consistent with our own ideals. If countries are to coordinate policy, should it not include coordinating refugee laws?
 
MARJORIE HOPE YOUNG
JAMES YOUNG
Wilmington, Ohio, Nov. 29, 1992

HEADLINE: I.B.M. AIMS TO CUT 25,000 MORE JOBS; SEES RECORD LOSS;
Shifting Role In Technology

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
The big cutback that I.B.M. announced yesterday has underscored what some of the nation's experts on technology have been saying for several years: While the world's largest computer maker remains a huge enterprise, it no longer can be expected to set the pace for technological innovation in the United States.
I.B.M. will slash its development spending by $1 billion, or 17 percent, next year, an amount unprecedented in its history. The company spent about $6.6 billion in 1991, the last year for which figures are available. Analysts believe it will spend a similar amount this year.
 
Role of Follower
 "I.B.M. as the I.B.M. that defined computing is over; it's gone," said Nathan Myrthvold, the Microsoft Corporation's vice president for advanced technology and business development. "As a result of new technology developments during the past 10 years, I.B.M.'s role in the computer industry has fundamentally changed." 
 The consequence is that what was once one of the world's most vaunted high-tech companies has been reduced to the role of a follower, frequently responding slowly and ineffectively to the major technological forces reshaping the industry. It has become increasingly clear that I.B.M. will no longer be the technological bulwark against foreign economic competition, a role it often played in the past with such inventions as the Winchester disk drive for data storage, a seminal achievement in 1973.
But rather than being a sign for despair, some technology experts say that I.B.M.'s decline may instead mark the emergence of a new model for computer and technology development in the United States that will become powerful in its own right. Alliances of smaller, more innovative companies -- sometimes working with Government support and sometimes on their own -- will come together quickly to attack crucial problems.
"We have watched while a small number of very important development organizations in the United States, including I.B.M., Bell Laboratories and Xerox, have slowly taken apart the engines behind their innovation," said R. Andrew Heller, a former I.B.M. engineer who now runs a Silicon Valley start-up company. "But we're seeing new centers of innovation emerge."
This year, for example, the United States will recapture the lead in market share in the world semiconductor market after lagging behind Japan for several years. And the Intel Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., is poised to reclaim its title as the largest and most successful chip maker.
Moreover, despite fears of overwhelming international competition, American personal computer and disk drive companies have largely held the line against Asian and European competitors.
 
Sematech Given Credit
 A share of the credit for the semiconductor industry's remarkable turnaround is being given to Sematech, the industry-Government research consortium created five years ago to revitalize the country's chip makers. The consortium, based in Austin, Tex., developed new techniques to make chips to counter strides by Japanese competitors.
Sematech's success could point the way for further alliances in areas where in the past giant multinational corporations like I.B.M. and Digital Equipment would have carried most of the financial burden.
"It's fortuitous that the Clinton Administration has arrived when it did," said Samuel H. Fuller, vice president of research at Digital Equipment. "It's important that we have these underlying technologies and when companies like I.B.M. can no longer entirely fund development, its important that the Government step in."
This new alliance-based model of development and competition is one that I.B.M. has had a large hand in creating. As it found itself increasingly unable to compete and simultaneously sustain the burden of new technology development, the computer maker has reached out and built hundreds of alliances in recent years, ranging from one with Apple Computer to develop software to one with Supercomputing Systems Inc. in Eau Claire, Wis., to make supercomputers. And while some of these alliances have been successful, they have not been enough to turn the much greater tide of competition and shifting market forces.
But despite optimism about future research and development alliances, a deeper, more troubling issue still remains: Has I.B.M.'s technology spending nevertheless translated into an American advantage that will now be lost? The answer coming from many analysts and computer industry executives is no.
They now argue that the company's vast laboratories have frequently done much to bottle up needed technologies.
"We need to invest differently and what I.B.M. didn't do is figure out how to invest in things that paid off," said David Ditzel, director of advanced systems at Sun Microsystems, now a giant but a few years ago a tiny company that through quick moves came to dominate the engineering work station market that I.B.M. was slow to enter.
I.B.M.-watchers also argue that by spinning off tens of thousands of engineers and programmers in the last five years, the computer maker has increased the pace of innovation.
For example, while I.B.M. invented a way of speeding up computer hardware called reduced instruction set computing, or RISC, it was commercialized elsewhere first, in part by former I.B.M. researchers who left to join other, more nimble companies.
The company developed a fundamental data base computer technology called SQL, but it was the Oracle Systems Corporation in Belmont, Calif., that took the technology and turned it into a company with sales of $1 billion a year, eclipsing I.B.M. in the data base market.
Underlying I.B.M.'s collapse is simply what the economist George Gilder has called "the law of the microcosm." That is, every three years the world's chip makers have been able to put four times as many transistors on a single piece of silicon, leading to vast increases in power and miniaturization.
Each new powerful generation of microchip has created a new computer industry and overthrown the previous one: mainframe computers in the 1960's gave way to minicomputers in the 1970's, then personal computers, work stations and now palm-sized personal digital assistants.
Although over the years I.B.M. often became a significant, if not dominant, player in new computing businesses, the pace of change has been so swift that the company, growing ever larger, could not alter its course fast enough.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Clinton Economic Session Yields Clear Goals, but Solutions Clash

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 15

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton's economic conference ended today with a consensus on the need to spur growth in the short term and reduce the deficit over the long haul, but with a welter of contradictory advice on how to achieve these goals.
The President-elect took in all the comments from the economists, business executives and labor leaders gathered here. But he refrained from tipping his hand over what approaches he intended to take at first.
 
Toughest Issue Ahead
 Participants at the conference proposed solutions ranging from spending a few million dollars to spending $60 billion on roads, bridges and education training to help create jobs and jolt the economy. And they suggested various timetables for reducing the deficit; some would start at once, others would phase in cuts starting several years from now. 
 But with all the give and take of the last two days, Mr. Clinton has still not addressed the most difficult economic issue and perhaps the hardest political question he will face as President: Which Government programs should be cut and which taxes should be raised to lower the deficit? [Page A27.]
Today's session at the Robinson Auditorium was a rare, although staged, glimpse of the President-elect and his top economic advisers thinking aloud about their choices. Whereas on Monday Mr. Clinton and his advisers mostly listened, today they probed the specialists who offered their wisdom. [Excerpts, page A26.]
The give and take disclosed how much the Clinton team is still groping for answers, and how experts in basic agreement with Mr. Clinton's general views could still disagree sharply.
At a news conference following the 19 hours of discussions over two days, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that "no two participants agreed on the details." But at the same time, he insisted, there were several areas of agreement that he would take into account as he makes the "tough choices" in shaping his first budget.
For instance, Mr. Clinton said there was an "absolute consensus" on the need to increase investment, not only in roads and bridges, but also in education and training, to improve the long-term productivity of the work force.
He said there was also accord that the Clinton Administration must "increase access" to bank loans and other capital so that small businesses and entreprenuers can flourish. This could be done to some extent through deregulation. Finally, he said, there was a complete consensus that there is a "huge undercapacity" in the economy so that the threat of inflation from some increased government spending is minimal. Therefore, he added, the Federal Reserve should not raise interest rates as soon as growth picks up, but should wait instead until there are real signs of inflation.
These were the President-elect's most pointed comments yet about Federal Reserve policy, and they were in line with the views of many of the bank's governors.
About the only policy issue on which Mr. Clinton committed himself was his intention to make health-care costs his top priority. Without controlling them, he told the gathering, none of the advice about deficit reduction or spending would be relevant.
 
Pounding His Fist
 "We are kidding each other," he said, pounding his fist on the table. "We are all just sitting here making this up if we think we can fiddle around with the entitlements and all this other stuff and get control of this budget, if you don't do something on health care. It is a joke. It's going to bankrupt the country."
Mr. Clinton, who conducted the 10 hours of discussions on Monday, sat at the helm for all nine hours today, dispensing with a flick of the wrist calls from his aides to cut off by 4 P.M. so his closing news conference would make the evening news.
If Monday's session was economics 101, today's often sounded like a postgraduate seminar for economists. At one point, a political scientist interrupted to remind Mr. Clinton and his advisers that they may have only a little time before the President-elect's honeymoon expires.
"There are two topics on the table: short-term stimulus and long-term deficit reduction," Elaine Kamarck, a political scientist from the Progressive Policy Institute, a Washington-based research center, told Mr. Clinton. "The first one requires very little political capital. The second one requires enormous amounts of political capital.
 
Window of Opportunity
 "What we know historically is that Presidents come in and they have a honeymoon," she added. "That honeymoon last six months, if they are lucky. You have a window of opportunity to achieve real progress on the long-term problems that we have heard about in the last two days."
Despite that caveat, deep and longstanding differences were manifest throughout the day. Isabel Sawhill, senior Fellow of the Urban Institute, said slow productivity growth was the "cancer" killing the economy, while economist Henry Aaron of the Brookings Institution said the soaring deficit was the "slow, wasting disease" sapping the economy.
James Tobin, a Nobel Prize-winning economist who served on President John F. Kennedy's Council of Economic Advisers, told Mr. Clinton he should opt for tax cuts or spending programs totaling $50 billion to $60 billion for each of the next two years. During the campaign Mr. Clinton spoke about $20 billion in public-works spending over four years.
But Mr. Tobin contended that only an injection at the higher level would be able to create about nine million jobs that will be needed over the next four years to absorb new workers entering the marketplace, bring down the unemployment rate and lure back those workers who have simply dropped out.
"Almost every recovery since the Second World War has been helped by fiscal stimulus," said Mr. Tobin. He said such prodding raises the deficit "temporarily."
"We're fooling ourselves if you think there's a way of having a fiscal stimulus that doesn't have that result," he said.

HEADLINE: Bush, in Texas Valedictory, Defends His Foreign Policies

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Dec. 15

 BODY:
President Bush flew to the Texas heartland today to begin staking a claim to history, arguing in an occasionally vivid speech that he correctly spent his four-year term asserting America's global leadership in an era of change.
Mr. Bush said the crises of his Presidency -- in the former Soviet Union, in the Persian Gulf and now in Somalia and Bosnia -- proved that American military and moral force were "indispensable" to the spread of democracy and political stability. 
 And in passages that seemed aimed at his Democratic successors, who captured the White House last month by dwelling almost exclusively on the nation's domestic problems, he warned that future leaders could shun the United States' unique global role only at the nation's peril. [Excerpts, page A25.]
 
'Frightening' Price
 Dismissing those who "assert that domestic needs preclude an active foreign policy," he asserted that "the alternative to American leadership is not more security for our citizens, but less; not the flourishing of American principles, but their isolation."
"Destiny, it has been said, is not a matter of chance," Mr. Bush warned. "It's a matter of choice. Our choice as a people is simple: We can either shape our times, or we can let the times shape us. And shape us they will, at a price frightening to contemplate -- morally, economically and strategically."
American leadership is not only an imperative in a world that lacks any other dominant force, Mr. Bush said, but it is also a "hard nosed" calculation of what is in the nation's own interest. Otherwise, he said, the United States risks being overwhelmed one day by the global forces of despotism and anarchy that it now leads the fight to contain.
In effect, Mr. Bush's 34-minute address at Texas A&M University played the political ace -- his dominance of foreign affairs -- that some advisers had urged him to lay down during his autumn campaign against Bill Clinton. Beyond boilerplate allusions to foreign affairs in his standard campaign speech, Mr. Bush seldom made the case for his importance as a global leader during his campaign, largely because opinion polls suggested that the public was not interested.
Today's forceful endorsement of America's worldwide role came 36 days before the end of Mr. Bush's Presidency, in a coliseum near the flat expanse of horse pasture where Texas A&M plans to erect a library and museum memorializing his four years in office.
The address was a valedictory of sorts, not just for Mr. Bush's role on the world stage, but for an entire generation of World War II youths, beginning with John F. Kennedy, who maintained America's role as the free world's bulwark during the tense moments of the cold war.
Mr. Bush made that point several times, with some passion and often with evident pride, as he outlined his argument for a United States anchored firmly at the forefront of worldwide change.
 
Images of Cold War
 "Steadfast and sure," he said, "generations of Americans stood in the path of the Soviet advance, while our adversary probed for weaknesses that were never found. Presidents from both parties led an Atlantic alliance held together by the bonds of principle and love of liberty; facing a Warsaw Pact lashed together by occupation troops."
Now, with the world facing new threats from ethnic strife, nationalism and the spread of hugely destructive weapons, Mr. Bush said the nation must summon the same resolve to consolidate the victories it won with the collapse of the Soviet empire.
Early in his term, Mr. Bush often suggested in self-deprecating fashion that he was a pragmatist who lacked what he called "the vision thing." Today, by contrast, he appeared to say that he indeed has a vision, and that it is of a world led by the United States to global peace and the rule of law. He did not hesitate to list his contributions toward that goal.
"Some will dismiss this vision as no more than a dream," he said. "I ask them to consider the last four years, when a dozen dreams were made real." Among them, he said, were the spread of democracy in the East; the fall of the Berlin Wall and the reunification of Germany; the victory in the Persian Gulf war and the start of peace talks between Israel and its Arab enemies.
 
U.S. as Moral Force
 "Each one of those once seemed a dream," he said. "Today they are concrete realities, brought about by a common cause: the patient and judicious application of American leadership, American power and American -- perhaps most of all -- American moral force."
This was Mr. Bush's first substantive speech since his Nov. 3 election loss to Bill Clinton, but aides said he could deliver one or two more before his term ends, all on major issues facing the nation. The next, if it occurs, is likely to be at a military service academy, probably West Point.
The genesis of the addresses is intriguing, if not entirely clear. Mr. Bush had seemed to shun public appearances after his defeat, and some advisers say the speech was suggested to him in mid-November in an effort to remind Mr. Bush that, defeated or not, he had responsibilities and a place in history worth noting and defending.
White House aides said the speech was roughly modeled after the famous farewell address delivered by President Dwight D. Eisenhower in January 1961, as Kennedy prepared to assume power. Eisenhower elevated his place in history, coined an enduring phrase and helped set policy for a generation of leaders by warning "against the acquisition of unwarranted influence, whether sought or unsought, by the military-industrial complex."
