HEADLINE: Connecticut and New Jersey Seek Disaster Aid for Storm

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
The Governors of Connecticut and New Jersey yesterday formally asked the Bush Administration for Federal disaster relief for last weekend's winter gale, citing preliminary estimates of well over $130 million in storm damage to their two states.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York is expected to make a formal request for Federal aid sometime next week, officials said. Yesterday, as teams of inspectors began visiting some of the state's worst-hit neighborhoods, officials said they had already accounted for over $100 million in damages -- a figure they predicted would more than double before final damage assessments were completed. 
 "The figures are just mushrooming," said Donald L. Maurer, a spokesman for the New York State Emergency Management Office. "When you talk about the economic impact, the loss of Christmas shopping, the damage to property, the number gets huge."
The Governors' letters to President Bush are the first official step toward obtaining Federal grants and low-interest loans for home and business owners in storm-ravaged communities.
 
Approval Called Likely
 The requests must be reviewed by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which will make a recommendation to the President. State officials said they did not expect any action by the Bush Administration for at least a week.
New York State officials said they wanted to compile better information on storm damage before they file their formal aid request. Mr. Maurersaid the magnitude of the damage in New York State and the fact that many neighborhoods remained under water had made it difficult to complete damage estimates.
But he said the state was not behind. "We're going ahead," he said. "I can't recall anything that has worked as well as this has."
State and Federal emergency management officials said it was uncommon for a state's request for disaster aid to be rejected. "Most of the time, the recommendation is for relief," said Stan Losak, a federal emergency agency spokesman in New York City.
In a letter sent to the White House yesterday, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut said that the coastal counties of Fairfield, New Haven and Middlesex had sustained $60.1 million in damage from two days of bruising winds, rain and snow.
In addition to $53.8 million in damage to 3,700 homes, he said, state roads, bridges and sewer systems had suffered $4.3 million in damage. The Governor also said that the state's shellfishing industry had sustained more than $2 million in losses because the storm had overloaded sewer systems, causing raw sewage to be dumped into the Long Island Bay. State health officials suspended shellfish harvesting.
In New Jersey, where damage assessments are still under way, Gov. Jim Florio said inspectors had found $76 million in damage to roads, bridges, beaches and other state-owned properties in the three worst-hit counties: Atlantic, Monmouth and Ocean.
Estimates on damage to private property in those three counties had not been finished yesterday. But in his letter to President Bush, Mr. Florio said that 166 homes had been destroyed, 1,353 had been seriously damaged and 24,662 had suffered minor damage.
Jon Shure, a spokesman for Mr. Florio, said New Jersey would be seeking Federal aid for other storm-damaged counties as well.
Despite the clear skies yesterday, scattered neighborhoods in Long Island and along the New Jersey shore remained under water, slowing efforts to estimate storm damage.
The American Red Cross said it planned to open emergency relief centers today in Sea Bright and Highlands in New Jersey, in Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island in New York City and in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
Problems on the PATH Hoboken line persisted yesterday, and Port Authority officials said that service would probably not be restored until later this week because of damage to electrical wiring and safety signals. About 40,000 people use the Hoboken line each morning.
Until service is returned, PATH will provide free shuttle buses from the Hoboken terminal to the Newport-Pavonia PATH station, where commuters can take trains to the World Trade Center or West 33d Street, said D. Joy Faber, a PATH spokeswoman.
In New York City, the Dinkins Administration said it would not fine business owners who filed their quarterly tax returns late because of the storm and that tax inspectors would visit flooded neighborhoods to adjust tax assessments for storm damage.

HEADLINE: Zuckerman Discussing Terms on Coliseum Sale

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Rather than forcing the developer Mortimer B. Zuckerman to come up with the $338.6 million purchase price for the New York Coliseum site, city and state officials are trying to strike a new deal with him.
Through the development concern Boston Properties, Mr. Zuckerman is under contract to buy the 3.4-acre site on Columbus Circle, where he is to build a 2.1 million-square-foot, multi-towered office, apartment and retail complex called Columbus Center. 
 A closing could have been scheduled as early as this month. But officials have not set a date while negotiations are under way.
All that the participants will say is that Boston Properties is still committed to the project and that the talks concern an extension of the deal.
It may be that officials do not wish to force Mr. Zuckerman's hand at a time when he is also trying to buy The Daily News, which could be an economic boon to New York if he decided to build a new color printing plant in the city.
It is unclear whether a new arrangement would simply delay the Columbus Center project until the real-estate market improves -- as happened with the Times Square Center project on 42d Street -- or whether the size and nature of the development would change again.
Columbus Center was announced in 1985. Salomon Brothers, which was to have been the main tenant, withdrew in 1987. After lawsuits and public criticism, the building plans were significantly modified in 1988 and 1989.
The last legal obstacle to the project was removed in June when a Federal appeals court ruled that the development would not violate the Federal Clean Air Act.
 
Letter of Credit
 Since Sept. 21, when the deadline passed for further legal appeals, officials have been in a position to schedule a closing on the Coliseum and its adjoining office tower, 10 Columbus Circle. Should Mr. Zuckerman be unwilling or unable to purchase the property, officials could draw down a letter of credit at Citibank that served as a deposit. The letter of credit is worth $33.8 million, or 10 percent of the purchase price.
Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge, who represents the area, said of Mr. Zuckerman: "He doesn't have financing. He lost his tenant. He's obviously not going to build the building. So he owes us $34 million."
Boston Properties is committed to "proceed as soon as it is economically feasible," said Robert Selsam, vice president of the concern. Mr. Zuckerman's partner in Boston Properties is Edward H. Linde.
"The objective of both parties is for the project to proceed, not to create arbitrary deadlines for each other," Mr. Selsam said. "We have, in fact, an approved project, with years of litigation having been cleared away."
The director of real estate for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Susan Fine, said the discussions concerned "whether, and under what terms, we'd extend the transaction, in light of today's real-estate market."
The M.T.A. owns the Coliseum through its subsidiary, the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.
The delay in resolving the Columbus Center deal effectively inhibits all but the most temporary re-use of the Coliseum, which has been largely empty since 1986.
 
'Tough Budget Year'
 Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, who advocates reopening the Coliseum, said: "We're about to enter a tough budget year. It would be nice to know whether we're going to have these monies, or some alternative, or some revenue-generating use for this site."
Ms. Eldridge, whose district office is at 10 Columbus Circle, said she understood that the Coliseum talks hinged in part on what happened at The News. But Ms. Fine said "there is no connection, in my mind," between the two issues.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Clinton Chooses Arkansan for Surgeon General

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 15

 BODY:
The top Arkansas health official, Dr. Joycelyn Elders, has been asked by President-elect Bill Clinton to be the new surgeon general, according to transition official.
Dr. Elders, a 59-year-old pediatrician here and the director of the State Health Department, was offered the position over the weekend and accepted it immediately, the official said on Monday. She would become the second black and fifth woman to be named to a top post in the Clinton Administration. 
 Dr. Elders's appointment was first reported by The Associated Press on Monday night.
 
'Conscience of Health Care'
 Dr. Harry Ward, chancellor for medical sciences at the University of Arkansas, said, "She has become the conscience of health care in our state, speaking out in a very candid way on every major health-care issue from teen-age pregnancy to poverty to violence."
If confirmed, Dr. Elders would replace Dr. Antonia Novello as head of the Government's Public Health Service.
Dr. Elders has battled with conservative groups in Arkansas for her advocacy of distributing contraceptives at school health clinics to combat AIDS and pregnancy.
"I really feel we must put our children first and I'm willing to do whatever we have to do to save the children," she has said when confronted on the issue.
Dr. Elders is the first black and first women to head the Arkansas Health Department. She came to the job in 1987 after a 26-year career in pediatrics at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences.
She is a 1952 honors graduate of Philander Smith College, a predominantly black college in Little Rock. She earned a master's degree in biochemistry and her medical degree from the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences, and did pediatric training at the University of Minnesota.
Dr. Elders and her husband, Oliver, a high school basketball coach, have two sons, Eric, 29, and Kevin, 27.
According to an article in The New York Times Magazine in 1989, Dr. Elders wrote or helped to write 138 published monographs, many of them dealing with growth problems and diabetes, the treatment of which first brought her to the attention of the state's medical community. Her level of expertise was such that doctors around the state routinely began to refer their juvenile patients with insulin-dependent diabetes to her.
On Saturday, Mr. Clinton named another black, Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic Party chairman, as his Commerce Secretary. The other women Mr. Clinton has named so far are Carol M. Browner, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency; Alice M. Rivlin, deputy budget director; Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Big Blue Bites Another Bullet

BYLINE: By Kurt Eichenwald

 BODY:
HOW low will it go?
That's the question that was being asked yesterday on Wall Street about the stock of the International Business Machines Corporation, which plunged to a 10-year low of $56.125, down $6.75 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange after it announced plans to take a $6 billion charge in the fourth quarter to cover the costs of 25,000 new job cuts.
Once the bluest of the blue-chip 30 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average, I.B.M. has been something of a religion among investors. And that faith has been hard to shake: some investors have been unwilling to accept the ferocity of I.B.M.'s tumble since July, when it was trading above $100. 
 In recent weeks, some money managers privately boasted that they were taking advantage of the computer giant's troubles to scoop up shares based on a certainty that the stock would bottom in the low 60's, close to its book value of $64.80 a share. It didn't.
Now, analysts say, with yesterday's changes the book value will drop to the low 50's, providing what they expect will be a new floor for the stock. That depends, of course, on a successful turnaround soon without more cutbacks. And the stock is likely to sink further if the company cuts its dividend, as its directors indicated yesterday they would.
Despite the repeated surprises for investors, the stock market has been signaling the troubles at I.B.M. for more than five years, dating back to the stock market crash.
For most companies in America, the 1987 crash proved to be an unimportant event, a trauma that ended up being a buying opportunity for investors.
But for the I.B.M., the 1987 crash marked the end of an era in the stock market. It ended a period in which Big Blue outperformed the stock market and ushered in one in which the company has been a drag on the market.
That performance has been so bad that it has wiped out I.B.M.'s gains since the early 1980's. For example, if an investor put $1,000 into I.B.M. stock on July 31, 1982, just before the bull market began, those holdings, not counting dividends, would have been worth only $857 yesterday -- the worst performance of any stock in the Dow. A similar investment in a stellar stock like Coca-Cola would now be worth $13,392, while an investment in a laggard like Sears, Roebuck & Company would be valued at $2,261.
The reasons for I.B.M.'s poor performance are, in retrospect, all too clear. As computers got better, customers were more likely to need smaller and cheaper ones. I.B.M., the dominant player for a generation in big mainframe computers, became a leader in personal computers but did so on terms that left it vulnerable.
I.B.M.'s worst move came in the early 1980's, when it chose to use semiconductors from Intel and software from Microsoft in its own I.B.M. PC. Soon, any computer maker with the phone numbers for those companies could boast of having a comparable, but cheaper I.B.M. clone.
Meanwhile, Microsoft and Intel raked in profits from I.B.M.'s design. Had I.B.M. developed its own operating system, the higher profits might have helped to swell Big Blue and helped keep the company a solid investment in the computer world of the 1990's.
The company's problems were also intensified by its own culture, which barred layoffs and made it hard to deal with a fundamental shift in the market.
As I.B.M. began to deal with its problems in recent years, there were often rallies in the stock as analysts cheered that the company had finally bitten the bullet. But it always turned out that there was one more bullet to bite.
Even yesterday, all of the job cutbacks announced were voluntary. That leads some analysts to believe that I.B.M. is following an optimistic scenario that a revived American economy will lift its sagging fortunes.
"I.B.M. is not going to shoot for anything other than the most optimistic side of the target," said Martin Ressinger, a computer industry analyst with Duff & Phelps. "Realistically, you have to expect further changes down the line."
The apparent reluctance to make more drastic changes at I.B.M. led some analysts to speculate privately that the company might see pressure to follow the path of General Motors and American Express and toss out its chairman, John F. Akers. Such an action might make the stock move up as much as $10 a share if it was part of a larger restructuring, some analysts speculated.
Without some additional changes, the chances are that job cutbacks will not be enough to turn things around. A recent study by the American Management Association found that fewer than half the companies that trimmed down since January 1987 reported increased profits, while 24 percent reported that profits decreased.
Yesterday's selloff may be the final signal that investors are no longer willing to be patient based on faith or to assume that the worst is over. To contrarian investors, that may again be a sign that I.B.M. is near a bottom. But it may also signal only that a stock that was one of the premier investments in the decades after World War II has finally lost its mystique.

HEADLINE: Neediest Cases Finds Counseling for a Jobless Mother and Her Daughter

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

 BODY:
After 15 years of working for the same company, Carol C. was laid off from her job as a clerk for Alexander's, an event that sent her into a dizzying fall from the reality and stability she had known for so long.
For years, she would take the train from her Harlem apartment to Alexander's warehouse in the Bronx, until she lost her job shortly before the company went under. Now, Carol spends her days applying for one position after another, or attending job-training classes. "Only one place called me, and then they said they'd get back to me," she said recently. "But they never did." 
 As unemployment continued to erode her meager savings and her self-confidence, Carol, normally stoic and self-sufficient, also found herself trying to cope with an adolescent daughter who was getting into the kind of trouble that drove her to tears.
But with the help of the Children's Aid Society, Carol has found solace. Every week, she and her daughter see a Children's Aid counselor from the mental health program at her daughter's old elementary school. Carol, who is 38 and trying to bring up her daughter on her own, has been trying to smooth out the rough edges of their life together, a life that has been tested by the twin effects of unemployment and growing up.
 
Counseling and Clothing
 Children's Aid, one of the seven charities assisted by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which pays for counseling for Carol and her daughter, has also helped Carol with employment referrals, and has provided money for food and clothing. For years the Neediest has used donations to help improve the lives of tens of thousands of New Yorkers. All contributions go directly to the charities because The Times pays for the fund's overhead. This year's Neediest drive ends Feb. 28.
Although Carol's daughter, Karlene, an eighth grader, is a good student and is considered very bright for her age, she was coming home from school later than she had told her mother, she was not completing her schoolwork and she was associating with young people her mother did not approve of.
"She's 13 going on 31," Carol said.
But their relationship worsened when Carol suspected that Karlene was taking money from her and her father, who also lives with them in their small apartment in Harlem. It was then that Carol went to see the principal at the elementary school, who referred her to the Children's Aid Society, where counselors help families with problems that can range from drug addiction to child abuse to stress.
Carol and Karlene's battle of wills has to do with the many unresolved issues that the two have never dealt with, said their counselor, Jenny Diaz. Those issues include Carol's trying to raise her daughter without a partner, she said. The unemployment "has overwhelmed her," Ms. Diaz said. "I don't know what's holding her back. She feels she isn't skilled, and she's having trouble completing the job-training courses."
Carol, who was born in Jamaica, has been in New York since she was 21. An independent woman, Carol has tried to instill in her daughter a respect for hard work and the value of an education. But while Karlene manages to come home with good grades most of the time, and is trying to qualify to attend a specialized high school, her behavior is sometimes disappointing.
It was the stealing that stunned her the most. Carol kept a jar of about $50 in bicentennial quarters under her bed, and noticed one day last year that they were missing. Her father told her that his coin collection was missing. When they asked Karlene about it, she denied taking the money, but later wrote her mother a letter saying that she would run away.
Karlene spoke of what her mother's unemployment has meant for her.
"When she was working, when I wanted stuff, sometimes, but not all the time, I would get it," she said. "But now I have to wait a long time. It's not like I want to be in style or nothing. When she worked I only got two pairs of sneakers a year. She's not working now, so I understand why I can't get them."
Karlene, who says she wants to be a pediatrician, conceded that it must be difficult for her mother to raise her alone. She referred to the "money problems" that led her mother to seek help, but she could not explain why she might have taken the money from her mother and grandfather.
"I would say I'm a good daughter," she said, when asked to describe herself. "Yeah, I'm a good kid. I'm not bad."
Ms. Diaz, their counselor, has hope for Carol and Karlene. In their separate sessions with her, they talk of responsibility and guilt, and they learn new ways to show affection for each other. She tries to help Carol see that much of Karlene's behavior is her way of getting her mother's attention. And she tries to show Karlene that she must not manipulate her mother by making her feel that she is responsible for every mistake she herself makes.
"A lot of our families have children addicted to drugs," she said. "This is one of our better-functioning families. The mother was actually employed for the longest time, unlike some of our other families.
"We don't always succeed," Ms. Diaz said, "but the more functioning the family, the more they get out of this."

HEADLINE: Sales of U.S.-Made Vehicles Maintain Their Strong Pace

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 15

 BODY:
In keeping with generally stronger retail activity, momentum in the automotive market carried over from last month as sales of domestically produced light vehicles surged 17.9 percent higher in early December compared with the corresponding period a year ago.
Sales of cars built in the United States and Canada rose 12.3 percent, to 148,079, while sales of light trucks, which include mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickups, rose 26 percent, to 113,890. Total light-vehicle sales during the period of Dec. 1 to Dec. 10 totaled 261,969. 
 The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales was 6.5 million, down from a strong 7.3 million at the end of November but significantly better than the rate of 5.4 million recorded during the corresponding period last year.
For months, car dealers have reported spurts of buying followed by quiet periods. But now, more dealers are noting a consistently improving trend.
"During this time of the year, things normally slow down, but we haven't seen that," said Mike Cody, new-car manager at Formula Ford in Barre, Vt.
Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York, said, "Early December sales keep alive the improving trend established in October and are consistent with better employment and consumer confidence statistics."
While sales of light trucks have been strong for some months, the latest results were noteworthy for the recovery in car sales. The Ford Motor Company posted a 49.9 percent increase over the corresponding 10-day period last year. Sales of the Taurus more than doubled as Ford discounted the model heavily in an effort to pass the Honda Accord, still the nation's best-selling car model.
Ward's Automotive Reports estimated a 30.1 percent increase for the Chrysler Corporation. Chrysler reports its sales only once a month.
But the troubled General Motors Corporation posted an 11.7 percent drop in car sales from last year. Part of G.M.'s slippage reflected a decision to sell less aggressively to daily-rental and other fleets. Particularly disappointing were big drops in sales of the Pontiac Bonneville, Buick LeSabre and Oldsmobile 88. Saturn sales remained brisk.
The Honda Motor Company, the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company each posted double-digit increases in the sales of cars assembled in the United States.
The Mazda Motor Corporation more than doubled sales of cars built in the United States to 1,545, while the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation posted a drop in car sales of 46.3 percent. to 692.
G.M.'s light-truck sales surged a robust 16 percent in early December, heavily influenced by demand for its Jimmy and Blazer four-door utility vehicles, Suburban full-size utility vehicle and full size pickup trucks. G.M.'s Lumina, Trans Sport and Sihouette mini-vans continue to sell poorly.
All of Ford's light-truck models with the exception of the Bronco fullsize utility vehicle posted strong gains compared with last year.

HEADLINE: Dow Eases 7.84, Depressed a Bit by I.B.M.

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks ended lower yesterday after heavy selling of the International Business Machines Corporation put modest pressure on the market.
The Dow Jones industrial average eased 7.84 points, to 3,284.36. Declining issues led gainers, 973 to 844, on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume totaled 227.8 million shares. 
 I.B.M., a Dow component, sank 6 3/4, to a new 52-week low of 56 1/8, on huge volume of more than 12 million shares. The computer giant said it was unsure it could maintain its annual dividend of $4.84 a share. It also plans a $6 billion fourth-quarter charge and 25,000 more job cuts.
 
Other Technology Issues Hurt
 Some analysts said the impact of I.B.M.'s steep fall on the blue-chip index was surprisingly modest. They sensed that the market was perhaps more influenced by profit taking and other corporate news.
But the setback in I.B.M. hurt other technology stocks. Apple Computer dipped 7/8, to 56 3/8; Microsoft dropped 3/4, to 86 3/8; Intel dropped 5/8, to 77 3/8, and Novell fell 3/4, to 26 3/4.
Traders said the market might also be preparing for another upturn. "The market has been consolidating for a few days, but I say the bias is still up," said Robert Caputo, director of research at an investment banking unit of the Swiss Bank Corporation. "The economic background is improving; interest rates are improving. I think we're in pretty good shape until the end of the year."
Analysts said traditional year-end tax-related selling contributed to the market's decline. People are taking profits because they expect the Clinton Administration to raise income taxes, one fund manager said.
The Nasdaq index of over-the-counter issues fell 3.98, to 650.75, on further profit taking after a recent rally that took it to record highs.
Three of the Nasdaq's top 10 most active stocks were initial public offerings: the Snapple Beverage Corporation leaped to 29 from its issue price of 20; the Purolator Products Corporation closed at 15, unchanged from its initial pricing, and Vision Sciences jumped to 12 from its offer price of 9.
 
Other Selloffs
 Several companies that reported disappointing earnings or issued forecast warnings found their stocks also drawing heavy selling. Gerber slumped 5 1/4, to 29 7/8. The company expects lower per-share earnings for the current fiscal year. Topps, the baseball card and bubble gum maker, lost 2 7/8, to 12 1/8, after reporting disappointing earnings.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks slipped 0.27 point, to 432.57. The American Stock Exchange index fell 1.90 to 390.66. The New York Stock Exchange Composite index of all listed common stocks fell 0.14, to 238.02; the average share eased 2 cents.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of New York Stock Exchange, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 4,232.632, down 4.557, or 0.11 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
American Agencies Are Lining Up for Vietnam's Business

BYLINE: By Adam Bryant

 BODY:
GOOD morning, Vietnam.
That may best sum up the optimism this week at many worldwide advertising agencies after the Bush Administration signaled it might ease the trade embargo with Vietnam and allow American companies to take the first steps to compete there.
Anticipating the move, many agencies, including Backer Spielvogel Bates; Dentsu, Young & Rubicam Partnerships and J. Walter Thompson have commissioned studies on the market, visited Vietnam and begun work to establish ties with agencies there. 
 By many measures, any long-term investment of time and money is probably well placed in the Asia Pacific region, which, with the exception of Japan and its sluggish economy, is the world's fastest-growing media market. Advertising spending there is expected to grow 8.2 percent a year in real terms between 1993 and 1995, according to London-based Zenith Media Worldwide, which shared its forecasts last week at the annual Paine Webber media conference.
Even so, advertising executives familiar with the Vietnamese market caution that the going is slow and tricky for reasons that stretch from Government policies to quirks of the local culture.
"The currency is a problem, the media is a problem, the market is still very difficult," said Gary Burandt, chief executive of Dentsu, Young & Rubicam Partnerships.
Carl Spielvogel, chairman and chief executive of Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide, learned this first hand during a B.S.B. regional managers' meeting in Ho Chi Minh City in November, an event that took three months to arrange with the Vietnamese Government.
The agency's regional clients include Heineken and British American Tobacco, although B.S.B. is currently not doing business in Vietnam.
Mr. Spielvogel said he was struck by, among other things, the prevalence of outdoor advertising. Because the Government allows only products manufactured in Vietnam to be advertised on television, billboards are the most popular way to introduce Vietnamese consumers to the foreign products and brand names they seem to crave. Information, product shots and company logos are most important for making an impression; romance and ambience are unnecessary. "Eye it, try it, buy it," is how Mr. Spielvogel described the dominant marketing strategy there.
With few advertising outlets, large companies often turn to such basic marketing techniques as hawking their wares at trade fairs and exhibitions with product displays that typically attract long lines, said Alex Hamill, B.S.B.'s director in the Asia Pacific region.
The Vietnamese Government also screened and censored advertising that B.S.B. brought into Vietnam for its October meeting. All advertising for broadcast must be approved by the Government.
One reel that did not pass customs contained pro bono commercials by B.S.B. for the Advertising Council that prod Americans to vote by showing the result if they don't: an American flag sheds its stars and stripes. The problem: "It was not their propaganda," he said. "The tape is now in the Marxist maw."
Advertisers and companies see in Vietnam what many believe is a great opportunity that they do not want to concede to other countries. To help make the case that the American Government should thaw relations, they point to a recent $380 million loan from Japan to Hanoi, as well as an offer by Japan and France to repay Vietnam's loans from the International Monetary Fund.
Credible statistics about Vietnam are hard to come by. But the country's attributes include a literacy rate close to 90 percent, and a youthful populace with few memories of the Vietnam War that is eager to embrace Western culture. Mr. Spielvogel said a 24-year-old Vietnamese graduate student serving as his party's guide pointed out the Hanoi Hilton and said to him in fluent English, "In the old days, this was a prison."

HEADLINE: Yields Mixed At Banks This Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered on bank money-market accounts and certificates of deposit for the new week that begins today are mixed, with gains occurring mostly outside the New York area, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.
Robert K. Heady, publisher of the rate magazine, says deposit rates are on hold for the moment as banks wait to see President-elect Bill Clinton's strategy on handling the economy. 
 "Depositors will see little change in the direction of C.D. yields, with the key Government decisions centering on what stimulants will be needed to spark economic growth and ways to deal with the national debt," he said.
At the Treasury's weekly auction of three-and six-month bills on Monday, average discount rates were mixed, signaling an end to a rise in short-term rates that began in early October. The auction is often regarded as a harbinger of bank deposit rate changes. The average rate auction was down slightly for a three-month bill, to 3.26 percent, from 3.29 percent the previous week, while the six-month bill rose to 3.43 percent from 3.37 percent.
 
Little Change in New York Area
 In the New York area, returns were mixed with no changes on an average money market account or six-month certificate of deposit while a slight drop was registered in the shorter three-month certificate.
Savings banks, which traditionally offer the higher yields, were most active in cutting back on certificates of deposit. The average yield on a three-month C.D. is down 2 basis points, from 2.96 to 2.94 percent, and a six-month certificate is down 3 basis points, from 3.13 to 3.10 percent.
Two of the largest changes in yields this week occurred at Home Savings of America, where the average money market account yield was lowered to 2.78 percent from 2.84 percent, and Carteret Federal Savings in New Jersey, which dropped the yield on a three-month certificate by 20 basis points, to 3.20 percent.
Outside the New York market, yields at 20 large banks remained steady as the average yield on a money-market account remained unchanged at 2.68 percent and an average six-month certificate is up a couple of basis points, to 3.03 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Closes Mixed In a Day of Slow Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mixed yesterday in light trading on world currency markets. Gold prices eased worldwide.
On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $334.50 a troy ounce, off 10 cents from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold had slipped 5 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $334.55. 
 Analysts said currency trading was particularly quiet. "This market's on holiday already," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
Much of the day's activity focused on the French franc, which continued to decline overseas. The German and French central banks stepped in, buying francs while selling German marks to prop up the French currency, Mr. Donney said.
The move appears to have been successful: the franc closed higher in United States markets.
The German mark's strength has been putting pressure on some of the weaker European currencies for some time, and now that pressure has come to rest on the franc. The German central bank's strategy of keeping interest rates relatively high has insured the mark's dominance on the foreign exchange scene.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 123.83 Japanese yen, from 123.88 yen on Monday. Later in London, it rose to 124.05 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 123.95 yen, up from 123.68 yen on Monday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5680, from $1.5650 late Monday. In New York it cost $1.5675 to buy one pound, more expensive than Monday's $1.5665.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.5685 German marks, down from 1.5703; 1.4105 Swiss francs, up from 1.4090; 5.3595 French francs, up from 5.3540; 1,403.00 Italian lire, up from 1,394.25, and 1.2788 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2748.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $334.95 a troy ounce, from $335.15 bid late Monday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $334.65 from $334.85. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell 28 cents to close at a bid of $335.23.

HEADLINE: Inventories Drop Sharply, While Sales Remain Strong

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Business inventories fell three-tenths of 1 percent in October, the steepest decline in nine months, the Government said today. Sales were unchanged, remaining at the highest level since July.
Analysts said the report portended increased production and job growth as businesses attempted to meet with the increased demand. 
 The Commerce Department said inventories held on shelves and backlots totaled a seasonally adjusted $832.9 billion in October, down from $835.4 billion a month earlier.
It was the largest decline since backlogs shrank five-tenths of 1 percent last January and the lowest level since inventories totaled $831.9 billion in June.
Before September's drop of two-tenths of 1 percent, inventories had risen every month since January, except for May, when they slipped back one-tenth of a percent.
The department said sales at the manufacturing, wholesale and retail levels in October totaled a seasonally adjusted $558.5 billion, statistically unchanged from $558.7 billion a month earlier. It was the highest level since sales totaled $559.7 billion in July.
The 1.1 percent jump in September was the largest since sales advanced 1.5 percent in June and nearly reversed a 1.3 percent drop in August.
Economists at Mitsubishi Bank in New York said the October decline appeared to be an involuntary decline -- that is, strong sales -- rather than one caused by pessimism among merchants.
If so, it would mean that consumers are buying goods faster than factories are making them and businesses are stocking them. That, in turn, could mean increased production and job growth as companies attempt to meet demand.
The combination of inventories and sales produced a inventories-to-sales ratio of 1.49, meaning it would take 1.49 months to exhaust the backlog at the October sales pace.
The ratio equaled 1.49 in July, which had been the lowest since January 1989, when it was 1.48.
Manufacturing inventories dipped one-tenth of 1 percent in October, while the wholesale backlog dropped six-tenths of a percent for the second straight month. Retail stockpiles plunged 3 percent.
Sales from factories slipped seven-tenths of a percent in October and wholesalers reported a 1 percent decline. But retailers registered a 1.9 percent gain.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Inventory-Sales Ratio" shows total monthe-end business inventories divided by total montly business sales, seasonally adjusted from May 1991-Oct. 1992. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Clinton and the Economy: A Round Table of Experts

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
The Bill Clinton two-day television spectacular gave good value. Although the number of viewers of CNN and C-Span who stayed with the whole show (longer than "The Civil War" and "Civilization and the Jews" put together) would not have made a Nielsen blip, even the intermittent watcher could find rewards. There was information, human interest, glimpses of the new Administration's movers and shakers and, presumably as programmed, star power in the form of the President-elect.
For the most part personages from prestige-ridden institutions like Harvard, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Apple Computer, the Brookings Institution and the World Bank laid out the nation's problems in a reasonably clear way, even if repetition set in early and their small jokes did not always earn the big laughs they received from Mr. Clinton. The man who resorted to "paradigm," 11 times in his 11 minutes and mouthed muddy formulations like "overall macroeconomic environment" and "economies of scale are obsoleted" was the exception. Taken together, these Clinton supporters got across in an audience-friendly way the general economic perspective of the incoming Administration and the dilemma of trying to cure one ailment without worsening another. 
 The appearance of John White, Ross Perot's sometime economic adviser, was a reminder of the proposed electronic town hall. Mr. Perot, so recently wooed by candidate Clinton, had not been invited to join President-elect Clinton at this first victory party, where supporters were paid off with a few minutes of tube time. Yet phrases like "world-class educational system," the use of colorful slides to display gloomy facts, the call-ins from just folks, the bringing together of experts at a round table that King Arthur would have killed for were perfectly Perotian. Blessedly missing was an instant vote from out there on whether to concentrate first on cutting the deficit or, as everyone says now, picking up from Paul Tsongas, "growing the economy."
The Clinton Administration economics team was sighted but left stage center to the boss. Senator Lloyd Bentsen dropped a few easily forgotten comments that foreshadow the bromides he will soon be offering on Sunday talk shows. Often, when the camera paused at Robert Reich, Labor Secretary designate, he was writing something, perhaps the book he can be counted on to produce about his tenure.
The camera also kept returning to Hillary Clinton. She said nothing, but her presence was felt in the appearances of Marian Wright Edelman, the head of the Children's Defense Fund, and, as the first day waned, other lobbyists in behalf of children, teen-agers and working mothers, whose presentations had more heart, if less analysis, than the economists who started things off.
The word "empowerment" got quite a workout. Sprinkled along the way were criticisms of supply-side economics and trickle-down theory. Present difficulties were laid to past precepts. But the most striking difference from the Republican Administrations was the meeting itself. The notion of Ronald Reagan or George Bush consorting with so many bleeding hearts and pointy heads of varying hues, many of whom Mr. Clinton greeted by first name, defies imagining. And the notion of either former leader actually making grammatical contributions to such an exercise is an instant gag.
Which brings us to the star of the occasion. Mr. President-elect and Mr. Vice President-elect sat side by side like the brightest kids in the class, the ones who are always first to raise their hands. But here Al Gore was outclassed. He tended to lob leading questions on the order of whether we need more training in the workplace. His interventions improved somewhat during yesterday afternoon's discussion of the environment.
For his part, Mr. Clinton turned in a virtuoso performance. In addition to sitting and listening for hours without yawning, he evidenced an acquaintance with details of everything from California's troubles to immunization against measles, Social Security to health-care costs, the pros and cons of a strong dollar to arms exports to cheap oil. He even had enough energy left at the end of the first long day to make an apt quip, "When somebody tells you it's not a money problem, they're talking about somebody else's money."
Although very much a show, the event was not fun and games. Yesterday morning Mr. Clinton laid out the country's sorry economic condition in a direct, plain-talking way. Since none of his guests proved eager to take issue with the new favor giver -- "I couldn't agree with you more," one assured him -- you could not really tell how deeply he had thought through any issue. But a ban on fawning is too much to ask at a production paid for by the Democratic National Committee.
Most notably, without explicitly disavowing any of the promises that had helped bring him to Washington, Mr. Clinton displayed a fresh seriousness along with the eyeglasses that had not been so noticeable during the campaign. In trying to get across to his audience a recognition of reality and an appreciation of complexity, he seemed to be asking Americans for intelligence and patience rather than just votes.
It is hard to say for sure when a politician is in front of a camera whether one is watching the real man or the performer, but at the very least the past two days demonstrate that it is much easier to be your best, even on the tube, after you have been elected President than when you are hustling for the job.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE PURPOSEFUL CHEF;
A Simple Dinner for Those Condemned to Holiday Indulgence

BYLINE: By JACQUES PEPIN

 BODY:
AT this time of year, as I begin to get ready for the holidays, I purposely keep my everyday menus simple and economical, serving seasonal products in easy-to-prepare dishes. This method gives me more time to work on menus for the holidays, and eating simple fare early in the month makes me feel less guilty about the richer, more elaborate meals I know I will be consuming later in the month with family and friends.
This menu begins with a salad featuring sweet potatoes, which are plentiful and inexpensive now. Tossed with a vinaigrette dressing and served on salad greens, the potatoes have an unusual and pleasantly distinctive flavor that makes them appealing both as a first course and as an accompaniment to a roast or other main dish. 
 The main course is a flavorful stew containing sweet or hot sausage, whichever you prefer. I use one sausage -- weighing four to five ounces -- per person, browning the sausages first and then adding small, peeled potatoes, onion wedges and, finally, green beans. Although I use string beans in my version of this dish, you can substitute wax beans if they are easier to find or less expensive.
This is not the type of dish where the vegetables end up being crunchy; it is more in the Southern tradition, with the vegetables cooked until they have absorbed the flavor of the meat and are soft, with the exception of the green beans, which retain a little crunch since they are added last and cook only 10 minutes.
To go with the stew, there is a spoon bread made with yellow cornmeal and scallions. This is an easy recipe, best eaten as it emerges puffy and souffle-like from the oven, although it is still moist and flavorful after it cools and deflates a little. The spoon bread also reheats well.
A good wine with this menu would be a red Washington State table wine, like Latah Creek, which is flavorful and inexpensive.
 
Corn and Scallion Spoon Bread
 
Total time: 50 minutes
 
 3 1/2 cups skim or regular milk
 1cup yellow corn meal
 8 to 10 scallions, cleaned and minced (1 1/2 cups)
 1/2 teaspoon salt
 1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
 1/4 teaspoon Tabasco sauce
 5 eggs
 1 teaspoon unsalted butter.
1. Bring the milk to a boil in a saucepan. Add the corn meal, and mix well with a whisk. Bring the mixture to a boil, and cook (partly covered to prevent splattering), stirring occasionally, for 3 to 4 minutes. The mixture should be quite thick.
2. Transfer the corn meal mixture to a bowl, and add the scallions, salt, pepper and Tabasco sauce. Let cool for 10 to 15 minutes.
3. Meanwhile, beat the eggs in a bowl as you would for an omelet, and then add them to the corn meal mixture. Mix in well with a whisk.
4. Preheat oven to 400 degrees. Butter a 6- to 8-cup gratin dish, and pour spoon bread mixture into it. Place on a cookie sheet, and bake for 30 minutes, until firm, puffy and brown. (If you prefer the spoon bread browner still, place it under a hot broiler for 1 or 2 minutes.) Cut into wedges or squares, and serve immediately.
Yield: 6 servings.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 195 calories, 6 grams fat, 180 milligrams cholesterol, 310 milligrams sodium, 12 grams protein, 25 grams carbohydrate.
 
Sweet-Potato Salad
 
Total time: 40 minutes

 2 pounds sweet potatoes or yams
 1 onion (3 ounces), peeled and chopped ( 1/2 cup)
 3 scallions, cleaned and minced ( 1/3 cup)
 3 cloves garlic, peeled and chopped (2 teaspoons)
 1 tablespoon Dijon-style mustard
 2 1/2 tablespoons red wine vinegar
 5 tablespoons corn oil
 1 1/4 teaspoons salt
 1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
 1 tablespoon soy sauce
 2 cups mixed salad greens, cleaned and thoroughly dried.
1. Wash the sweet potatoes and remove any damaged spots. Place the potatoes in a single layer in a saucepan with enough cold water to cover and bring the water to a boil over high heat. When the water boils, cover the pan, reduce the heat to low, and boil gently until the potatoes are tender (20 to 30 minutes, depending on size).
2. Drain the potatoes and, when cool enough to handle, peel them.
3. Combine remaining ingredients, except salad greens, in a serving bowl and mix well. While potatoes are still lukewarm, cut into 3/4-inch slices and toss with the dressing. Serve at room temperature on the greens.
Yield: 6 servings.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 240 calories, 12 grams fat, 0 milligrams cholesterol, 695 milligrams sodium, 3 grams protein, 30 grams carbohydrate.
 
Sausage, Potato And Green-Bean Stew
 
Total time: 30 minutes

 2 tablespoons corn oil
 6 Italian-style sweet or hot sausages (about 1 1/2 pounds)
 2 pounds small potatoes (about 15)
 2 onions (about 12 ounces), peeled
 2 pounds green beans, ends and strings removed
 1 teaspoon thyme leaves
 1/2 teaspoon salt.
1. Heat the oil in a large, deep saucepan. Add the sausages in one layer and brown, covered, over medium heat for 5 minutes.
2. Meanwhile, peel the potatoes and set them aside. Cut each onion into 8 pieces. Add potatoes and onions to sausage, cover, and cook for 10 minutes. Then add beans, thyme and salt, and mix until beans are under the potatoes and sausages. Cover, and cook over medium heat for 10 minutes. Stir in 1/2 cup of water to free solidified juices in the bottom of the pan.
3. Serve one sausage per person, with some potatoes, onions, beans, and a few spoonfuls of the pan juices.
Yield: 6 servings.
 Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 575 calories, 35 grams fat, 85 milligrams cholesterol, 1,235 milligrams sodium, 30 grams protein, 40 grams carbohydrate.

HEADLINE: Metropolitan Diary

BYLINE: By Ron Alexander

 BODY:
A FRIEND writes:
Glued to my television set during much of last weekend's storm, I found myself once again absolutely awed by the spirit, stamina and determination of people in this city. But my candidate for the title of Quintessential New Yorker -- no, make that All-Time Quintessential New Yorker -- is easily the woman from Brooklyn who was asked on the news how it all was affecting her. 
 "Do you have electricity?" she was asked by the TV reporter.
"Yes, we do," she said.
"And do you have gas?"
"No, we have no gas," the woman said sadly. "We have no gas at all."
"So you can't do any cooking," the interviewer sympathized. "What do you do for meals?"
"We sent out for Chinese," the woman said.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Dear Diary:
Sophie, our 3-year-old, has only the vaguest idea of who Santa Claus might be. But that didn't stop our baby sitter from taking Sophie to Bloomingdale's for an introductory visit to its version of St. Nick.
"And what would you like for Christmas, little girl?" went the usual query.
Not one to spurn any gift offer, Sophie replied, "We don't do Christmas, we do Hanukkah."
"That's O.K.," Santa said. "My wife is Jewish." -- KAREN VERSHBOW

 	 	 		. . .	 	Scene: Locker room of the Downtown Health and Racquet Club, New Haven.
Dramatis personae: Two muscle men, and David Nemerson, who overhears the following conversation.
Muscle man 1: So, how do I look?
Muscle man 2: You look great -- just like Adonis.
Muscle man 1: Madonna? Whadya say? I look like Madonna?
Muscle man 2: Not Madonna -- Adonis. He's a Greek god.
Muscle man 1: Oh yeah. That's what I want to look like -- a Greek god.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Dear Diary:
Shopping for toys in Herald Square this far into the holiday season is at best a harrowing experience. So I was slightly less than thrilled to be waited on by one of the most inept cashiers in all of Herald Square history.
She could not understand the concept of wanting to ship one, and only one, of several packages, so I had to tie it up myself. She was unable to locate her scissors, leaving me with a long piece of string trailing off the side of the box. She charged me for an item I had not bought. Finally, when it was discovered that she had neglected to give the promised 20-per-cent discount on one of the toys, she called her superior in desperation.
"What seems to be the problem?" he asked.
The cashier explained the situation, saying that she could see no other solution than ringing everything up again.
Seeing my impatience, he looked her in the eyes and commanded, "Put out your hand."
Dolefully, she obeyed, palm down.
"Bad!" he proclaimed, slapping it lightly. With that, he returned to his post. -- MICHELLE AU

 	 	 		. . .	 	Dear Diary:
The place is a Lexington Avenue subway; time, the other evening. At 14th Street, a young blond woman hops aboard. A seated woman, recognizing her, speaks excitedly.
Seated woman: I know you! Where are you from?
Me, thinking: Sweden? Denmark? Scotland?
Blond woman: "Days of Our Lives." -- CHANA FREIMAN

 	 	 		. . .	 	Notes from nostalgic friends:
It could simply be a coincidence, although it would be nice to believe it's more than that. An expression seldom heard in the last 20 or 30 years has recently been popping into numerous conversations, bringing with it memories of growing up. The expression is "When my ship comes in."
Irene Ashery of Great Neck, L.I., thought of the expression recently when the mailman handed her an abundance of holiday mail.
"I spent my childhood in Brooklyn," she said, "and when I was about 9 years old, I asked my father why there was so much mail for him and none for me. 'If you want your ship to come in, first you have to send it out,' he told me."
Lilly S. Ruttenberg of Clifton, N.J., heard the expression not long ago from friends she hadn't seen in years.
It also sailed back a month or so ago in "Kid Millions," a 1934 musical starring Eddie Cantor, which was shown on the American Movie Classics cable channel. The score, by Harold Adamson and Burton Lane, included a catchy ditty titled -- you guessed it. It was a song to be sung during a depression or recession. It was an assurance that better times were on the way. Maybe that's the reason for its revival.
Now, does anyone ever hear the expression "So's your Aunt Tillie"?

HEADLINE: Look Freshly at a Changed Korea

 BODY:
South Korea's next President won't be a general, unlike virtually all his predecessors since 1961. Friday's election will mark a new advance for Korean democracy, a gain for U.S. interests and a tribute to the outgoing Roh Tae Woo, whose reforms energized political life.
For Americans, the election is an occasion to reconsider familiar policies. There's now a strong case for shifting to a more regional approach to security, and for giving new emphasis to economic issues, especially trade barriers. 
 Americans needn't worry about any of the front-runners: Kim Young Sam, a veteran opposition figure now running as the ruling party candidate; Kim Dae Jung, long Korea's leading campaigner for democracy and human rights, and Chung Ju Yung, founder of Hyundai, the giant conglomerate. All three men favor democracy, markets and peaceful reunification with the North.
There as here, the economy is the main issue. Korea's 5 percent growth rate this year is down sharply from the recent double-digit pace. President Roh deliberately slowed growth to curb inflation and absorb wage increases. But Korea has stalled in its shift from heavily regulated, low-wage production to higher-tech, freer-market methods.
Kim Young Sam, the candidate of continuity, is handicapped by this economic malaise. He has had trouble articulating coherent economic policies. And he pledges to bar rice imports, inviting friction with the U.S. But Kim Young Sam also offers continuity with the Roh Government's Northern diplomacy: a combination of talks with Pyongyang and the embrace of old North Korean allies like Russia and China.
The heart of the North-South issue is now the timetable and format for reunification. The North, aware of its isolation, looks toward a federation to preserve what it can of its regime. The South, fearful of chaotic collapse, seeks to work with neighboring powers for an orderly transition.
Sustaining regional cooperation depends on Washington as well as Seoul. As America cuts back its military presence in the Western Pacific, it needs to foster new collective security arrangements. Otherwise, old conflicts between Japan, Korea, China and Russia could easily revive.
For 40 years, America has been South Korea's military guarantor against Communist aggression. An increasingly democratic, self-confident Korea calls for a different role: America as diplomatic linchpin of a regional security alliance.

HEADLINE: Mr. Gaidar Departs, Democratically

 BODY:
It's tempting to interpret the resignation of Prime Minister Yegor Gaidar of Russia as a startling rebuke to Boris Yeltsin and his program of radical economic reform. Yet even with the more- cautious apparatchik Viktor Chernomyrdin in the job, reform could still go forward, though at a slower pace and on a different trajectory. And though the infighting was brutal, the result was reached democratically.
That reaffirms the wisdom of not imposing a made-in-America brand of economic policy as the test for all United States aid to Russia. America's basic interest lies in consolidating democracy's tenuous hold on this vast and troubled country and preventing a fateful turn to ultra-nationalist demagoguery. 
 Some reform-minded Russians and American onlookers complain that Mr. Yeltsin might have showed a firmer hand, even a fist, in defending Mr. Gaidar. But it's also possible that Mr. Yeltsin concluded that Mr. Gaidar's austerity if left unchecked could lead to widespread disaffection and, worse, a turn toward authoritarianism.
Wherever the truth lies -- and it's hard for Americans to judge from so great a distance -- U.S. interests are plainly better served by a Russian government that doesn't have to invent the rules as it goes along. The compromise reached by President Yeltsin and the Congress over the weekend, if it holds, could open the way to more orderly procedures by providing for a referendum on a new constitution next April.
Given the gravity of the economic crises and the limits to popular patience, many pitfalls lie ahead. And the crude demagoguery and paranoia exhibited by some of Russia's parliamentarians do not inspire much confidence about the result. But as recent political developments in Latin America suggest, democratic procedures can create democratic politicians.
Sustained U.S. engagement and aid could help democracy along -- for instance, by subsidizing a social safety net for Russian pensioners and the unemployed, and providing technical assistance and a Democracy Corps of American volunteers.
Such engagement would show that what America wisely cares most about is not a particular blueprint but Russia's democratization.

HEADLINE: A Valuable Economics Seminar

 BODY:
The two-day economics seminar in Little Rock led by Professor Bill Clinton broke no new ground and settled no important policy debates. Yet it was doubly impressive. Several speakers delivered concise treatises on what ails the economy. And Mr. Clinton displayed a remarkable grasp of big themes and small details.
Teacher, student, preacher: the President-elect played all the parts well. The two-day spectacle taught Americans a lot about the economy -- and about their new leader. 
 Robert Solow of M.I.T. and Alan Blinder of Princeton delivered incisive five-minute discourses on the two problems plaguing the economy. The first is recession: The economy is operating well below capacity and recovering slowly. The second is stagnation, caused by a two-decade drop in productivity growth that has dragged down wages. Family incomes used to double every 30 years; at current rates, they'll double in 200.
The answer to recession, as James Tobin of Yale carefully explained, is a two-year package of Federal spending hikes and tax cuts. Despite the recent uptick in sales, the economy still isn't growing fast enough to bring unemployment down.
The deficit will have to wait. To fight it before the economy recovers would be fiscal suicide.
The answer to long-term stagnation is higher investment, especially in training and education. Investing in people would boost overall living standards and close the yawning gap in earnings between high- and low-paid workers.
America became rich by tapping its natural resources and building large manufacturing plants that imposed rigid work rules. But in the new global economy, speakers said, companies must be flexible and dynamic -- relying on workers who think and react. America needs to train workers, especially those without college degrees.
Mr. Clinton hovered over the proceedings. He listened carefully, posed challenging questions and answered questions from others with encyclopedic detail. Why, he asked, should government train workers if, as research shows, employers report little trouble finding adequately skilled applicants? The answer, he was told, is that once the economy recovers, employers won't have it so easy. He rattled off percentages of the Federal budget for investment and health care as easily as a teen-ager citing batting averages.
As scores of participants chimed in, the conversation turned confusing, contradictory, self-serving and boring. Few asked to be taxed more or volunteered to give up their favorite Federal spending program. Yet the conference provided a valuable national conversation, complete with call-in questions, on Topic A. Mr. Clinton promised voters that he alone would make the important economic decisions. Judging from this week's performance, he's up to the task.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Executives' Early Reaction to Clinton: Not Bad, for a Democrat

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 15

 BODY:
The way many executives here see it, President-elect Bill Clinton was inviting them on a blind date.
The business leaders at Mr. Clinton's economic conference did not fall head over heels, but many came away feeling warmer toward him than they had expected. Still, many of the executives had voted for President Bush, and they remained unsure today whether Mr. Clinton was a man they could live with. 
 "I have never voted for a Democrat in my life, but I must say I've been impressed," said John D. Ong, chairman and chief executive of B.F. Goodrich Company. "He has an obvious command of the issues, but we don't know what his program will be."
The executives, who came from dozens of large companies, including Citicorp, Colgate-Palmolive, Exxon and Sara Lee, were heartened that Mr. Clinton not only listened to their problems, but appeared to understand them. Hour after hour under hot klieg lights, he listened as they described the problems causing corporate America's headaches: anemic economic growth, spiraling health-care costs, cuts in military spending, the reluctance of banks to lend.
 
Hearts and Bottom Lines
 Still, after 19 hours of talking, the business leaders remained anxious to know what Mr. Clinton plans to do on issues close to their hearts and bottom lines, like regulations.
"We have a lot of Republican-oriented manufacturers, and I'd say they were impressed by the way he conducted himself," said Robert Cizik, chairman of Cooper Industries in Houston. "But they remain cautious. Is he really a different type of Democrat or is he more in the mold of the traditional Democrat?"
Mr. Cizik, who is chairman of the 12,000-member National Association of Manufacturers, added that "certain options" that Mr. Clinton might choose would "only exacerbate problems: more regulations, more taxes, more spending, the things we already worry about."
Despite the general tone of caution, some executives seemed pleased to shed their reserve about the President-elect. John D. Correnti, president of the Nucor Corporation, a steelmaker based in Charlotte, N.C., said, "He's like a sponge in absorbing information." John Sculley, chief executive of Apple Computer, said he was amazed that Mr. Clinton could discuss dozens of subjects in detail without any notes.
Although Mr. Clinton talked endlessly about subjects like health-care costs during the Presidential campaign, it was not until this week's economic conference that many executives appeared to give him a fair hearing -- perhaps because they no longer had the luxury of hoping they might never have to deal with him in the White House.
In some ways, the conference became a tacit conspiracy between Mr. Clinton and the business community. Both sides gladly turned the conference into an effort to force-feed the American public and Congress tons of information about what ails the nation's economy.
Mr. Sculley of Apple said, "We all walked away with the feeling that we're making progress getting the leader of the nation and the American people to recognize that we have serious problems."
For business executives, an invitation to the conference was something like induction into Bill Clinton's Corporate Hall of Fame. Many of the large companies invited were part of an elite, evidence by their rapid growth or success at meeting foreign competition. The invitees included American Airlines, Apple, A.T.&T., Coca-Cola, Ford, Intel, Johnson & Johnson, Merck, Xerox and Wal-Mart.
Noticeably absent were some of the troubled corporate behemoths that are laying off tens of thousands of workers, like General Motors and I.B.M.
Asked why so many superstars were invited, George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director, said, "We're always trying to put a spotlight on the success stories." Of course, Mr. Clinton might have taken some heat if companies that have angered their workers by huge layoffs had been invited.
Harold A. Poling, Ford's chairman, and other executives said they were especially pleased that Mr. Clinton appeared to be singing the same tune as they were over the need to rein in health-care costs. Mr. Clinton nodded sympathetically when Mr. Poling told the more than 300 participants at the conference how his company's swollen health-care costs put it at a $500-a-car disadvantage as against Japanese auto makers.
Edwin L. Artzt, chairman of Procter & Gamble, said the conference was in ways a chance to do some high-profile lobbying on vital issues, like the need to improve the skills of the American work force. "After the inauguration and the business of the Administration begins, it will be much more difficult to have an impact," he said.
Mr. Cizik of Cooper Industries said he backed Mr. Clinton's pleas to provide more job training for American workers, but he was opposed to the plan to require employers to spend 1.5 percent of their payroll on training.
"I think we need to do more job training, but we oppose mandated solutions," he said.
 
Tackling the Deficit
 Many corporate leaders were keenly interested in cutting the budget deficit, but like the economists who spoke at the conference, they disagreed about how soon and how vigorously that should be done.
"We must address this deficit problem," said Mike Sturdivant, president of the MMI Hotel Group in Jackson, Miss. "If not, there will be economic chaos down the line."
Mr. Ong of Goodrich, who is the current head of the Business Roundtable, a group of top executives from the nation's largest companies, said he might support a program that created jobs by modestly pushing up the budget deficit. But he said that such a package should be dedicated to investments like highways, railroads or airports that make the nation more efficient.
But he said he feared that a stimulus program might be too focused on consumption, might be too large and might come when growth was picking up. This could push up long-term interest rates, and that could hurt home building and business investment, he said.
"A short-term stimulus program," Mr. Ong said, "could have some real negative things in it that would worsen the Federal budget deficit and overheat consumption just when the economy is recovering."
 Another picture caption about the conference omitted the affiliation of Deborah Castleman in some editions. She is on the staff of the Rand Corporation.

HEADLINE: Top Israel Court Halts Expulsion Of Palestinians

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Thursday, Dec. 17

 BODY:
In reprisal for a recent burst of killings, Israel ordered the immediate expulsion today of hundreds of Palestinians linked to militant Islamic groups, but the attempt was temporarily blocked while the Israeli Supreme Court heard an appeal.
About 400 Palestinians from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip who had been rounded up by the Army in the last few days were reported to be on buses near the Lebanese border, ready to taken into a buffer zone that Israel has carved out of southern Lebanon, where they were to be left. 
 Government officials declined to say how many Palestinians were involved. But civil rights lawyers seeking a court order against the action put the number at 400 or more, and said it had no precedent, certainly not since the period immediately following Israel's occupation of the territories in the 1967 Middle East War.
 
Much Criticized in the Past
 In the past, Israel's deportations of far smaller numbers of Palestinians have been widely assailed overseas, including a resolution expressing strong condemnation that was passed by the United Nations Security Council early this year with United States support. That condemnation followed an order to expel 12 Palestinians, which Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin revoked soon after taking office last summer to improve the climate of the Mideast peace talks.
The United States has consistently condemned such deportations, saying they violate the Fourth Geneva Convention on 1949, which bans expulsions from occupied territory.
The Government's latest decision is likely to cast long shadows over the peace talks, the latest round of which ended this week in Washington with no real progress and expressions of disappointment by most of the parties.
Even before the new expulsions were announced, senior officials acknowledged that they were planning a crackdown on fundamentalist extremists that could bring foreign protests.
"From a legal point of view, some steps may be interpreted by some foreign observers as inappropriate," a senior defense official said, "but looking at the content of the steps, it will be seen as reasonable and serving a justifiable cause."
With emotions running high here after a spate of killings by Islamic militants, the Government decided it had to act aggressively to avoid appearing weak in the face of one of the strongest recent challenges to Israeli authority in the occupied territories, and the expulsions were approved by the Cabinet on Wednesday with near unanimity.
 
Target of the Deportation
 The deportation order is aimed most directly at Hamas, an acronym in Arabic for the Islamic Resistance Movement, which has taken responsibility for killing four soldiers and an Israeli border policeman in the last 10 days. A Government statement, which described the expulsions as a "temporary and immediate removal" for no more than two years, said strong measures against Hamas were essential.
"In light of the murderous acts of terrorism whose purpose is to attack residents of the state of Israel and sabotage the peace-making, steps must be taken against the murderous and terrorist Islamic fundamentalist organizations, the enemies of peace," the statement said.
Senior officials said their intention was to try to isolate Hamas from more mainstream Palestinian factions like the Fatah branch of the Palestine Liberation Organization; unlike Hamas, Fatah supports the peace talks. Tourism Minister Uzi Baram said Israel had to begin negotiating with the P.L.O., "the only force in the Arab world with which one can talk."
Thus far, however, Mr. Rabin has ruled out any formal Israeli approach to the Tunis-based organization, even though Palestinian delegates to the talks openly discuss strategy with Yassir Arafat and other P.L.O. leaders.
Mr. Rabin, who won election with a promise to push the peace negotiations forward but also to strike hard against Palestinian violence, implied that he, too, expected some foreigners to his anti-Hamas measures unpalatable.
"The world should not be surprised that Israel takes very serious steps to protect its security and insure the continuation of the peace talks," he told a conference Tuesday night.
Israel has rounded up many hundreds of suspected Hamas members and associates since Sunday, when attackers identifying themselves as members of a Hamas wing kidnapped a border policeman, Sgt. Maj. Nissim Toledano, and threatened to kill him unless Israel released the imprisoned founder of their movement.
On Tuesday, his stabbed and bound body was found along a West Bank highway. Autopsy results made public Wednesday said he was killed a few hours after the deadline set by the kidnappers for release of the Hamas leader.
 
1,600 Palestinians Arrested
 According to Israel television, about 400 Palestinians were arrested in Gaza and the West Bank on Wednesday, bringing the total being held to 1,600. In addition the Israelis, without offering a public explanation, are holding a Palestinian journalist, Taher Shriteh, who works for several foreign news organizations, including The New York Times and Reuters.
Since its formation five years ago this week, Hamas has become a potent political force, especially in Gaza, where unemployment and despair both run deep. Israeli officials fear that the recent attacks on soldiers, widely seen here as having shown skill and daring, will enhance its standing in the territories and weaken the hand of Palestinian leaders active in the peace talks.
The aim now, officials here say, is to clamp down on Hamas while depicting it as unalterably opposed to peace and therefore a threat not only to Israel but to mainstream Palestinians as well.
But there is a risk in this strategy, some Israeli commentators say, arguing that expulsions or other strong measures could invite more street violence. Such measures, they say, may also persuade Palestinian delegates to the talks that for their own political welfare, they have to withdraw.
 
Phased Pullout Discussed
 As it is, the negotiators have felt themselves on the defensive because many Palestinians believe that the talks are going nowhere after 14 months. Hamas, on the other hand, strikes many in the territories as having shown that it is tough enough to get some Government leaders talking publicly about the need for a phased withdrawal from Gaza. Mr. Rabin rejects this idea because, he says, it would look as though Israel was running scared.
More immediately, the Prime Minister must deal with an outraged Israeli public ready for sterner anti-Arab measures and with a right-wing opposition accusing him, as former Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir did Wednesday, of "steadily appeasing terrorism" with concessions at the peace talks.
Recognizing the public anger, Israeli liberals, too, are calling for a tough anti-Hamas policy. "Warlike measures are necessary against terror at the same time as we continue the peace process," Trade Minister Micha Harish, a Labor Party leader, said.
