HEADLINE: U.S. NAMES FIGURES IT WANTS CHARGED WITH WAR CRIMES

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The United States named President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia and other Serbian and Croatian political and military figures today as possible war criminals who should be tried someday by a "second Nuremberg" tribunal.
"We know that crimes against humanity have occurred, and we know when and where they occurred," Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger told delegates at a conference on the fighting in the Balkans. "We know, moreover, which forces committed those crimes, and under whose command they operated. And we know, finally, who the political leaders are and to whom those military commanders were -- and still are -- responsible." 
 Although once known for his close ties to Serbian leaders, in recent months Mr. Eagleburger has become the Bush Administration's leading spokesman for war-crimes trials, calling for such a tribunal since August. Mr. Eagleburger is a former American Ambassador to Belgrade. This was the first time that the United States has made public a list of those who it argued should be tried for the crimes.
 
Danger to Peacekeepers
 The call for a war-crimes tribunal to resemble the trial of major Nazi figures in Nuremberg after World War II was endorsed by Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen, the heads of a joint United Nations-European Community mediation effort. But the two mediators, who appealed for more time to negotiate a settlement to the war that has killed more than 17,000 and forced one million people from their homes, were clearly unenthusiastic about the American and French-backed campaign for a United Nations resolution enforcing a ban on Serbian flights over independent Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The mediators shared the British view that enforcement could endanger the lives of United Nations peacekeeping troops deployed on the ground and jeopardize the humanitarian effort. And they added their voices to the chorus of those who oppose lifting the United Nations arms embargo on all parties in the Balkan fighting.
 
More Forceful Responses
 The Bosnian Government has sought an exemption from the embargo on the ground that it favors the Bosnian Serbs, who have continued to be well supplied by the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Army. Mr. Eagleburger had said he favored exempting the Bosnian Government.
"It must never be forgotten that peace will only come to the former Yugoslavia through negotiations," Lord Owen said in a speech to foreign ministers and other representatives at the 29-nation conference. In his speech, Mr. Vance noted that the absence of evidence that the Serbs have used their warplanes and helicopters in combat missions "should be taken into account" in any enforcement resolution.
The Bush Administration, mindful of its legacy after it leaves office next month, has in recent weeks sought to give the impression that it is pushing for more forceful responses to actions by Bosnian Serbian nationalists trying to carve up Bosnia and Herzegovinia. The United States expects the Security Council to approve enforcement of the flight ban, Mr. Eagleburger said, but he acknowledged that he found virtually no support for lifting the United Nations arms embargo.
As for the American move on war-crime trials, it was unclear whether it was an exercise in oratory or whether the United States genuinely would seek to bring any of the alleged culprits to trial. Most of those named by Mr. Eagleburger were Serbian or Bosnian Serbian leaders.
"In waiting for the people of Serbia, if not their leaders, to come to their senses," he said, "we must make them understnad that their country will remain alone, friendless and condemned to economic ruin and exclusion from the family of civilized nations for as long as they pursue the suicidal dream of a Greater Serbia. They need, especially, to understand that a second Nuremberg awaits the practitioners of ethnic cleansing, and that the judgment and opprobrium of history awaits the people in whose name their crimes were committed."
Mr. Eagleburger named some Croats as probably guilty of crimes, and also noted that in September, Bosnian Muslims in Kamenica had killed some 60 Serbian civilians and soldiers. Among those he named were Borislav Herak, a Bosnian Serb who has confessed to killing more than 230 civilians; two members of a Croatian paramilitary force known as "Adil" and "Arif" accused of attacking a bus convoy of 100 Serbian women and children in August, killing half of them, and Zeljko Raznjatovic, leader of the Tigers, a Serbian paramilitary force accused of the mass murder of up to 3,000 civilians near the Bosnian town of Brcko.
 
Milosevic Is on the List
 He also accused Vojislav Seselj, leader of the Chetniks, a Serbian paramilitary group accused of atrocities in Brcko and other Bosnian towns; Drago Prcac, commander of the Serb-run Omarska detention camp, where mass murders and torture allegedly occurred, and Adem Delic, commander of the Croat-run Celebici camp, where at least 15 Serbs were said to have been beaten to death in August.
"I want to make it clear that, in naming names, I am presenting the views of my Government alone," Mr. Eagleburger said. "The information I have cited has been provided to the U.N. War Crimes Commission, whose decision it will be to prosecute or not. Second, I am not prejudging any trial proceedings that may occur. They must be impartial and conducted in accordance with due process."
Mr. Eagleburger listed Mr. Milosevic among those leaders who have special responsibility.
"There is another category of fact which is beyond dispute," he said, "namely the fact of political and command responsibility for the crimes against humanity which I have described. Leaders such as Slobodan Milosevic, the President of Serbia, Radovan Karadzic, the president of the self-declared Serbian Bosnian republic, and Gen. Ratko Mladic, commander of Bosnian Serb military forces, must eventually explain whether and how they sought to insure, as they must under international law, that their forces complied with international law."
 
4 War-Crimes Reports
 He said that the United States had concluded that Serbian authorities had flouted previous international agreements. That, he said, had not only produced "an intolerable and deteriorating situation inside the former Yugoslavia, it is also beginning to threaten the framework of stability in the new Europe."
Mr. Karadzic, who was one of those named by Mr. Eagleburger, was seen by reporters wandering through the corridors outside the main conference hall.
Mr. Eagleburger later told reporters that although there was no plan to bring the accused to trial at the moment, "Over the long run they may be able to run but they can't hide, that we're going to pursue them." But when pressed, he made clear that he was not calling for the forcible seizure of the 10 men he named for either committing or supervising war crimes.
President Bush raised expectations that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq would be tried as a war criminal after the Iraqi leader's invasion of Kuwait in 1990, but the matter was quietly dropped after the American-led coalition won the Persian Gulf war without capturing Mr. Hussein. The Pentagon has never released a long report prepared by its lawyers that documents Mr. Hussein's war crimes for a possible trial in the future.
The United States has already submitted four war-crimes reports to the United Nations that detail specific episodes of Serbian brutality, and Mr. Eagleburger described nine incidents of Serbian "crimes against humanity," including murders of men, women and children, mass executions, torture and the forced expulsion of civilians from their villages.
Other governments and human-rights organizations have documented other atrocities, including systematic brutality against women and children, including gang rape, the incarceration of women and girls impregnated by rape, the forcing of women into brothels and murder of rape victims and of children in front of their parents. Some soldiers who have refused to carry out orders to rape or murder their victims have themselves been shot or beaten to death.
There is universal agreement in the talks on Yugoslavia this week, which began in Stockholm and Geneva and will continue at the NATO foreign ministers meeting in Brussels on Thursday and Friday, that the Serbs have broken promises made at a similar international forum in London in August to lift the siege of Sarajevo and other Bosnian cities, dismantle detention camps and turn over heavy weapons to United Nations forces.
While delegates struggled to give the impression that they were doing something to respond to Serbian atrocities and aggression, at the same time there was also a universal disinclination to make decisions that could draw their own military forces into what is viewed as an intractable religious and ethnic war with no clear outcome.
Mr. Vance even sought to portray United Nations efforts to staunch the fighting as somewhat successful, saying in his speech, "The overall level of violence has been reduced, although not ended."
Asked about the remarks of a man who held his job during the Carter Administration, Mr. Eagleburger praised the United Nations effort but disagreed with Mr. Vance's basic premise, saying "The Bosnia Serbs have taken more territory, ethnic cleansing has proceeded, there are a lot of refugees who have been cleaned out of areas. There is by no means any end in view as I see it to the conflict itself."

The terrorizing of 30,000 Muslims in Banja Luka, including bombings, beatings and killings.
 
Destruction of Vukovar, a Croatian town, in the fall of 1991, and the forced expulsion of its population.

HEADLINE: Big Companies Cloud Recovery By Cutting Jobs

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
The economy may be expanding modestly, even adding some jobs at last, but big companies are continuing to cut -- a trend that promises to keep the pace of recovery slow.
A recent survey of more than 800 companies by the American Management Association found that one in four companies is planning work force reductions by the middle of 1993. That is the highest level since the research group began its survey six years ago. 
 On Tuesday, the International Busi ness Machines Corporation, for instance, announced plans to cut another 25,000 jobs next year. And the General Motors Corporation recently identified nine plants it will close over three years to eliminate 18,000 jobs.
 
 
No Increase in Efficiency
 While small and medium-sized companies are starting to hire, it is doubtful that they alone can bring job growth to the levels of previous recoveries. The 45,000 private-sector jobs added to the economy in November, excluding government workers and people employed in the fall political campaigns, were about one-sixth the monthly rate during the 1983-84 expansion.
Just as troubling to some analysts, large corporations are in many cases cutting jobs without using the remaining workers more efficiently -- one reason deep cuts have not always helped improve the companies' performance.
Analysts agree that embattled corporate giants must become leaner and less burdened by bureaucracy, and that trimming payrolls is an inevitable part of the formula. Yet slashing the work force, they warn, is too often a simple-minded answer to problems, a kind of desperate effort to show disgruntled shareholders and directors that management is taking action.
"The cuts began as a competitive drive, but they seem to have become a way of life for many companies," said Eric Greenberg, research director for the management association. The real issues that went unnoticed in the executive suites of companies like G.M., I.B.M. and Sears, Roebuck were shifts in customer demand, new technologies and new distribution methods that changed their markets -- changes to which the corporate giants were slow to respond.
"The traditional meat-cleaver approach of just cutting people is a strategy for decline," said Michael Hammer, a consultant based in Cambridge, Mass. "To succeed, companies have to change the way they work instead of just throwing people over the edge, and most companies are not making basic changes."
 Corporate America's penchant for layoffs raises doubts about whether there will be enough new jobs to strengthen economic growth. Consumer spending is rising, but mainly because people are dipping into their savings. "Consumers are spending money, but not earning it," said Ed McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "This expansion does not have the firm foundation of real job growth yet."
Few experts anticipate a robust job market anytime soon, even though the hiring outlook for the first quarter of next year is brighter, according to a survey of 15,000 companies by Manpower Inc. But with so many big companies not hiring or continuing to cut back, job growth will be meager.
"Business in general isn't about to rehire in large numbers yet," said Mitchell S. Fromstein, president of Manpower, the nation's largest supplier of temporary workers.
 The shrinkage of big companies has a variety of euphemistic labels -- "restructuring," "downsizing," "rationalizing" and "re-engineering" -- but whatever it is called, the trend causes concern even among some of its practitioners.
Lee A. Iacocca, who will soon retire as chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, put the auto maker through two rounds of wholesale cost-cutting and layoffs in the last decade. But in a valedictory interview on ABC's "Nightline" program last month, Mr. Iacocca said: "I worry, because as we all restructure, if we lay off enough people, there'll be nobody to buy the cars or the houses. So we've got to watch that this isn't a downhill spiral."
A management consultant who is credited with having coined the term "re-engineering," Mr. Hammer is nonetheless extremely critical of the way many companies try to streamline their operations. "Most companies are just shrinking, not changing how they do work," he said.
 
 
A Need to Reduce the Work
 Yet some companies are making genuine strides to improve efficiency. As one example, Mr. Hammer cites the Ford Motor Company's accounts payable department. In the mid-1980's, the North American operation for paying suppliers had 400 people, many of them unproductively chasing paper trails of invoices, order forms and the like. The task was simplified so that Ford arranged to pay suppliers when goods were received, eliminating much paperwork and three-fourths of the people in the department.
"If you remove people, it should be because you have found ways to do more work with fewer people, not because your business is dying and there is less work to do," Mr. Hammer explained.
But management experts are concerned that of the companies that cut back in an effort to become more nimble, competitive and profitable, few actually succeed in achieving their aims. The American Management Association survey found that fewer than half of the companies that made substantial work force reductions in the last six years were able to improve their operating profits.
A 1991 survey by the Wyatt Company, examining the results of cutbacks at more than 1,000 companies in the previous five years, found that two-thirds of the companies simply slashed their payrolls without trying to eliminate the amount of work. And more than 80 percent of the companies were later forced to replace 10 percent or more of the people they let go, because necessary work was going undone.
"The way that most companies handle downsizing has little effectiveness and little lasting value," said John Parkington, director of research at Wyatt, a consulting firm.
 
 
Domino Effect
 But the cutbacks have a domino effect, forcing changes on the suppliers to corporate America. Steelcase Inc., the nation's largest supplier of office furniture, notified 1,000 workers on Friday that they would probably be laid off in February because orders remained soft. The slashing of layers of white-collar workers at many big companies is a reason.
"We don't see this ending soon," said William Heyne, a vice president of sales, adding that Steelcase was increasingly focusing on smaller corporate accounts.
"The small and medium-sized companies are where all the growth has come from recently, and that will be even more so in the future," Mr. Heyne said.
A strongly rebounding economy and changed attitudes are two forces that could slow the erosion of the work force at big companies. The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company illustrates an approach that management experts say may become more common. As business declined in some of its 49 divisions over the last decade, 3M retrained and reassigned 3,500 people to other, faster-growing operations.
"It isn't altruism," explained Richard Lidstad, vice president of human resources. "These people are important assets in whom we've made substantial investment. They're well-trained employees of 3M, and we're not going to to just dump them."

HEADLINE: Council Set To Approve Trump Plan For Housing

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
The New York City Council is expected to approve Donald J. Trump's ambitious plan to build a huge apartment complex along the Hudson River today, but the vote does not mean construction will begin any time soon or that the financially troubled Mr. Trump will be able to build it, real-estate experts said.
Although a handful of Manhattan lawmakers have said that they will oppose the project because they believe it is too big, Council leaders expect the vast majority of 51 members, most from other boroughs, to vote for it. The Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, supports the project. 
 Council leaders say they are supporting the $3 billion project, called Riverside South, largely because the real-estate and construction industries are moribund and no one wants to thwart a large development that could lead to thousands of new jobs.
"I think folks have a sense out there that New York City is stagnating and this is a sign there is confidence in what is otherwise a difficult economic environment," said Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey of Queens.
 
'Will There Be a Market?'
 Paradoxically, the sagging economy that has encouraged support for Mr. Trump's scheme may make it difficult for the developer to build it, real estate experts said. The experts said that banks have been leery of making real-estate loans because the market for commercial and residential space has been dismal.
"I think a lender would have to get over the hurdle of 'Will there be a market?' " said Wilbur Ross, a bankruptcy and real estate specialist with Rothschild Inc. "I question whether near-term there is a market."
The 57-acre piece of land is heavily leveraged. Besides, Mr. Trump has promised the city to spend more than $359 million for roads, sewers and other infrastructure costs.
"Unless he's got a commitment for massive public subsidies I don't see how it is viable," said a prominent New York City real-estate executive who spoke on condition of anonymity.
For his part, Mr. Trump is sanguine that the real-estate market will improve and that he will be able to attract financing for the project from Wall Street. "When the market changes, this will be one of the great projects in the city's history," he boasted yesterday.
Stretching along the Hudson River from 59th Street to 72d Street on the site of the old Penn Rail Yards, the project would have 16 residential buildings, between 18 and 49 stories tall, with a total of 5,700 apartments, or 6.1 million square feet. There is also a 21.5 acre park.
The project would add about 10,000 people to the Upper West Side and generate about 2,700 construction jobs each year for a decade. Two office towers and a television studio that were in the original plan will not be considered today.
But some of Mr. Trump's critics in the Council have charged that he has no intention to build. They assert that Mr. Trump has lobbied for and won the zoning changes only to increase the value of the property, which he could in turn sell to help pay off his other debts, especially to bond-holders who financed the developer's three casinos in Atlantic City.
"We think the plan was approved too quickly in an effort to bail him out," said Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge, who represents the neighborhood. "I think he has to get approval for zoning for this land to trigger his refinancing of other properties to save his properties in New Jersey."
Since buying the property in 1985, Mr. Trump has borrowed against it and now owes more than $213 million to Chase Manhattan Bank, according to public records. Without the zoning changes he is seeking, the property would be practically worthless to developers, real-estate experts said. It was valued at about $85 million by city appraisers earlier this year.
 
Trump's Role Expendable
 Mr. Trump's supporters in the Council argue that even if the developer cannot find financing for the project, his vision of 16 apartment towers and a shore-side park makes sense for the Upper West Side. Anyone who buys part of the site from Mr. Trump would be bound by the plan.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Big companies are still cutting jobs, even though the economy is expanding. One survey found that one in four companies is planning work force reductions by the middle of 1993, and few experts expect a robust job market anytime soon. [Page A1.]
Two important economic indicators posted gains in November. Industrial production climbed 0.4 percent, and the rate that builders started new homes rose 1.5 percent from October's pace. [D1.] 
 The stimulative impact of bank deregulation was questioned by some bankers reacting to claims at Bill Clinton's economic conference that relaxing banking rules could provide a windfall. [D1.]
 
Companies
Ford will take a charge of $7.7 billion, which includes $7.5 billion for future health-care and retiree benefit costs in a single charge; it will probably have a '92 loss of over $6 billion. [D1.]
Institutional investors dumped I.B.M. stock, sending it down $4.25, to $51.875, its lowest level since 1981. [D1.] Local I.B.M. Employees are digesting the news of 25,000 more job cuts. [B6.]
Intel's stock soared $6.125 a share, to $83.50, after it predicted quarterly results would be well above analysts' estimates. [D4.]
Magma Power agreed to buy geothermal power plants and undeveloped properties for $225 million from Unocal. [D4.]
Commonwealth Edison named Samuel K. Skinner its president. At the nation's third-largest electric company, the former White House chief of staff will face substantial regulatory problems. [D4.]
Richard E. Disbrow will retire as chairman and chief executive of American Electric Power in April. [D4.]
Merck chose a marketing executive as its new president. The executive, Richard J. Markham, 42, becomes the favorite to succeed Dr. P. Roy Vagelos as chief executive in 1994. [D4.]
Regardie's magazine is closing. The founder of the 12-year-old monthly says he hopes to resume publication. [D19.]
 
Markets
Blue-chip stocks ended lower, led by heavy selling of I.B.M. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 29.18 points, to 3,255.18, and volume totaled 244 million shares. [D8.]
Municipal bond markets were stirred up by a voter revolt in Brevard County in Florida. Treasury bonds rose. [D15.]
Oil prices soared on a report that showed United States refineries curtailed output last week. [D16.]
The dollar finished lower in quiet trading. [D16.]
 
Today's Columns
Some are questioning Laura D'Andrea Tyson's selection to head the Council of Economic Advisers. But Bill Clinton may not want much advice. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Berkshire Hathaway is making an unusual offer to holders of its convertible bonds: receive the value of the bonds in cash or take Berkshire stock worth less. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D8.]
A lot is riding on Burger King's latest marketing campaign, which features a series of rapid-cut MTV-style ads pitching the fast-food chain's new table service. Advertising. [D19.]

HEADLINE: Ideology Seems to Doom Cabinet Contender

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
A senior official of the Clinton transition associated with the far left wing of American politics appears to have fallen as the first victim of a battle to shape the ideological character of the incoming Administration.
A week ago the official, Dr. Johnnetta B. Cole, president of Spelman College, was regarded by some in the Clinton organization as a strong possibility for appointment as Secretary of Education. Now, after a run of bad publicity, her chances of being named to any job requiring Senate confirmation appear near nil. The furor began last Friday with the publication in The Forward, a weekly Jewish newspaper, of an article detailing her association with Marxist-oriented groups, 
 The dispute over Dr. Cole arises from a fundamental conflict within and around the transition between centrist Democrats and a group that is pushing for a more aggressively liberal Administration. That faction is centered on and draws power from Hillary Clinton, the President-elect's wife.
Dr. Cole has been the subject of several critical newspaper articles and columns, including one by A. M. Rosenthal on Tuesday on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times. She found herself under intensive questioning by reporters this week while attending President-elect Bill Clinton's economic conference in Little Rock, Ark. She responded with outrage against what she called "vile" accusations dredged up by "right-wing extremists."
 
Sources of Criticism
 She did not elaborate. The public and private criticism of Dr. Cole has come largely on two fronts: Jewish organizations critical of her reported affiliation with a pro-Palestinian group and Democrats fearful of any sign of leftward leaning within a political organization that has gone to great pains to break with the party's liberal legacy.
Dr. Cole, a longtime friend of Mrs. Clinton, was appointed in November to run a group charged with reporting to the President-elect on the issues and organizational concerns facing Federal agencies involved with education, labor, and the arts and humanities.
That group's more powerful counterpart, which is developing Mr. Clinton's policies in those areas, is headed by Alan From, a prominent figure in the party's centrist faction. Mr. From has avoided any public criticism of Dr. Cole and did not return telephone calls for this article.
The Clinton transition's public position is that Dr. Cole's political history is, as the press secretary Dee Dee Myers put it, "something we're just not concerned about."
"I don't know anything about that stuff," Vernon E. Jordan, Mr. Clinton's transition chairman who is a friend of Dr. Cole, said in a telephone interview. "Assuming that it's true, I also don't care. What I've heard about seems pretty silly to me."
But the report in The Forward led to private and public pressure on the Clinton transition team to deal her out.
Privately, transition officials are assuring questioners that Dr. Cole will have no say in setting Administration policy and will not be nominated to any top Administration position.
An anthropologist who has edited several books, Dr. Cole is in many ways a figure of the corporate establishment, a board member of Coca-Cola Enterprises and the Atlanta Chamber of Commerce and a founding director of President Bush's Points of Light Foundation.
Dr. Cole, who once left herself open to the possibility of an Administration job, now says there "is no possibility I will go to Washington at all."
In an interview, Dr. Cole acknowledged that she had been for years a member of the national committee of the pro-Cuba Venceremos Brigades, known for sponsoring sugar cane-cutting expeditions to Cuba. The Federal Bureau of Investigation has maintained that the group was connected with Cuban intelligence forces.
Dr. Cole is also listed as a member of the executive board of the U.S. Peace Council in the program published by that group for its 1983 national conference in Chicago.
 
F.B.I. Finds Soviet Link
 The council, founded in 1979, was an affiliate of the World Peace Council. In testimony before the Senate Permanent Select Committee in 1982, Edward O'Malley, a top official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, called the World Peace Council "the largest and most active Soviet international front organization."
Dr. Cole, in the interview, said she had written for the U.S. Peace Council, but had not been a member of the organization, which is pro-Palestinian.
Dr. Cole was a featured speaker in a tribute held in New York in 1984 for Herbert Aptheker, a theoretician of the Central Committee of the Communist Party U.S.A. On Sunday, Dr. Cole said she had spoken on behalf of Mr. Aptheker in recognition of his work as a historian, not as an ideologue.

HEADLINE: New Breed of Ecologist to Lead E.P.A.

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
When she was growing up, Carol M. Browner spent hours hiking in the Everglades and once stayed home from school to finish a watercolor of an anhinga, a graceful and increasingly rare water bird that alighted in the pond outside her family's home in South Miami.
Now, as President-elect Bill Clinton's choice to be the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Ms. Browner, who turned 37 today, is about to step into one of the Government's most important posts for setting environmental policy. It will give her not only an opportunity to admire the natural world her family says she loves but also a powerful position to help repair it. 
 In her first interview since being chosen by Mr. Clinton, Ms. Browner, Florida's Secretary of Environmental Regulation, listed these early goals in the new post:
*Quickening the pace of E.P.A. decisions regarding issues like incineration, water pollution, development of wetlands and use of pesticides.
*Studying ways to end the waste of money and to improve the Government's management of the Superfund program to clean up toxic wastes, an effort that now consumes a quarter of the environmental agency's $7 billion budget
*"Restoring credibility" to an agency that has been buffeted more than most in the last 12 years by political conflicts between what the nation's environmental laws required and what the White House wanted.
 
Planning a Clear Course
 "The problem we have had in the states with the E.P.A., and one that the President-elect is very familiar with, is the lack of certainty in any of the agency's decisions," Ms. Browner said in a telephone interview. "The E.P.A. too frequently just does not bring an issue to a close. And that contributes to the lack of credibility with the public, with business and with others affected by what the E.P.A. does.
"You can't have environmental protection without having people believe in what you are doing. The public wants answers in a timely manner, and business needs answers for their planning. I've found business leaders don't oppose strong environmental programs. What drives them crazy is a lack of certainty. We can change that."
 
Working With Industry
 Ms. Browner is prominent among a new type of environmentalist who views economic development and environmental protection as compatible goals. Her supporters and opponents agreed that Ms. Browner, as head of the Department of Environmental Regulation, had rejuvenated a demoralized staff of 1,500 and had made the agency one of the most active in the Florida government.
She lobbied for and won changes in regulations that would shrink the amount of time the department takes to review permits needed to develop wetlands or to expand manufacturing plants. Business groups had long sought the changes, but they angered some environmentalists.
"The whole concept of it is to make it quicker, easier and cheaper for developers to get approvals," said Linda Young, the publisher of The Pro Earth Times, a Florida environmental newspaper. "We don't like it, because it removes opportunities for the public to get involved."
 
An Everglades Compromise
 Ms. Browner also helped persuade Gov. Lawton Chiles to negotiate a settlement in a lawsuit against Florida by the Federal Government intended to repair damage to Everglades National Park. She then became the state's chief negotiator and helped hammer out a settlement intended to purify and restore the natural flow of water to the park at a cost of about $1 billion to the state, the Federal Government and farmers.
The largest ecological restoration project ever tried in the United States, the settlement pleased environmentalists even as it angered Florida's sugar farmers, who will be required to bear a sizable portion of the cost.
"Having been on the opposite side of the table from her on the Everglades issue, I can tell you she is a formidable opponent," said Andy Rackley, vice president and general manager of the Florida Sugar Cane League, the industry's principal state trade group.
Ms. Browner also negotiated an agreement with the Walt Disney Company that requires the company to spend $40 million over several years to buy and restore an 8,500-acre ranch near Orlando in return for state and Federal permits to fill in 400 acres of wetlands for Disney development projects.
"This approach is so much more rational," Ms. Browner said. "We're not trying to mitigate the problem by creating a new wetland, which has a high rate of failure and is very expensive. In this instance, we moved to a restoration of what previously had been wetlands. Disney will provide the funding to restore and manage the land."
Ms. Browner said she believed that the Disney ranch would become the center of a wildlife refuge spanning tens of thousands of acres in central Florida.
Todd W. Mansfield, senior vice president of the Disney Development Company, applauded Ms. Browner's role in negotiating the agreement. "She is a tremendous environmental leader," he said. "She had a vision of protecting an entire ecosystem. She is a very, very long-term thinker."
Ms. Browner was raised in a home where television was tightly regulated, books were abundant and she and two younger sisters were encouraged to pursue their interests. Her father, Michael Browner, is an English professor, and her mother, Isabella Harty-Hugues, is a social science professor at Miami Dade Community College.
Ms. Browner was educated at the University of Florida in Gainesville where she earned an undergraduate degree in English and a law degree. The middle sister, Michelle Browner, is a biochemist at the University of California at San Francisco. The youngest sister, Stephanie Browner, is completing a doctorate in American literature at Indiana University.
Carol Browner started her career as an aide in the Florida House of Representatives in 1980 and later joined Citizen Action, a grassroots organizing group in Washington, where she worked on environmental issues. She met her husband, Michael Podhorzer, a specialist in health-care issues, while working for the group.
In the late 1980's she was an aide to Mr. Chiles, who was then a Senator, and in 1989 she joined Senator Al Gore's staff as a senior legislative aide. When she was chosen last week Ms. Browner traveled to Little Rock, Ark., with her son, Zachary, who will be 5 years old on Friday. 
"I want my son to be able to grow up and enjoy the natural wonders of the United States in the same way that I have," she said at a news conference. "I believe that that will now be possible, that we will be able to make the investment in our economy that we so desperately need, yet preserve the air, land and water."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carol M. Browner in Little Rock, Ark., last week as she was selected Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Ford to Cut $7.7 Billion From Net

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said today that it would account for its future costs for retiree benefits by taking a noncash after-tax charge of $7.5 billion in one huge swoop. The fourth-quarter charge means the auto maker is likely to have a 1992 net loss of between $6 billion and $7 billion, an American corporate record.
Ford's accounting decision was included in a package of bookkeeping adjustments, including the one-time cost of eliminating 10,000 jobs next year from its European operations, which are struggling in the face of a worsening sales slump.
 
Had Warned of a Loss
 In all, the nation's No. 2 auto maker said the special charges would reduce its 1992 income by $7.7 billion, which will be spread over the four quarters of 1992. Ford said results for the first three quarters would be restated to reflect the charges. 
 The company did not officially forecast a 1992 net loss, but it has reported a $681.4 million profit for the first nine months of 1992 and warned investors in November that it would probably have a loss in the fourth quarter. Last year, the auto maker had a net loss of $2.26 billion on sales $88.27 billion.
The record loss for any American company is $4.45 billion posted by the General Motors Corporation last year. On Tuesday, however, I.B.M. indicated that it would have a $4.75 billion net loss this year.
Ford's write-off of $7.5 billion is under an accounting rule adopted a year ago by the Federal Accounting Standards Board, companies can choose one of two methods for recognizing their obligations for medical and other benefits they will provide to current and future retirees. They can, as Ford did today, decide to take a single charge before the first quarter of 1993. Or they can spread out the charges over 20 years.
 
'Clears the Decks'
 "Basically, this just clears the decks for a recovery." said Terry Bresnihan, a Ford spokesman. "By taking the hit all at once, we avoid a $375 million drag on profit for 20 years."
Ford's write-down of $7.5 billion to cover retiree benefits is the largest taken so far, but the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said last year that it would take its charge in the first quarter of 1993 and that it might be as high as $7.5 billion. And these charges are only about half as large as the write-down that General Motors will eventually face.
G.M. and the Chrysler Corporation each said they would decide in the first quarter of 1993 whether to absorb one-time charges, as Ford did, or accrue their retiree benefit expenses over 20 years. G.M. estimates that it must account for $16 billion to $24 billion of benefits; Chrysler must account for about $4 billion.
By taking the charge in one lump, Ford is demonstrating that it has confidence that a jittery Wall Street will not overreact by trouncing its stock or hurting its credit standing. Ford also puts some competitive pressure on G.M. and Chrysler to match its move so that their future earnings will remain comparable.
Ford's shares lost 75 cents today, closing at $40.625 on the New York Stock Exchange. Today's announcement came after the market closed.
All of the auto makers and other companies could recoup some of the expenses if health-care cost containment efforts are successful. G.M., for example, recently required salaried workers to contribute more for health care, which might reduce future expenses by $1 billion, according to an estimate by Ron Glantz, auto analyst for Dean Witter in San Francisco.
The size of Ford's charge is further evidence of how expensive health-care and retiree costs have become for American employers. Though the auto maker will not be forced to lay out cash immediately, the charge will reduce the value of the equity owned by Ford shareholders by one-third, to about $15.4 billion.
Harold A. Poling, Ford's chairman, testified at President-elect Bill Clinton's economic conference this week that health-care expenses continued to be a large drag on growth. "We spend more on health care than on steel," he said. Ford spends an average $10,000 annually for health care on every worker and retiree.
In addition to the $7.5 billion, which covers all active Ford workers and retirees as of the beginning of 1992, Ford also absorbed an additional $440 million net charge against profits to cover future benefits necessitated by years of service accumulated by Ford workers in 1992.
A separate accounting change pertaining to the way Ford pays taxes will add $685 million to 1992 profits, the company said. But Ford said it would also charge $419 million against 1992 profit to cover the cost of cutting back the European work force.
Ford said it would trim its hourly work force in Europe nearly 10 percent, to 68,000 from 75,200, primarily at its plants in Britain and at its plant in Cologne, Germany. Ford said it would reduce its salaried administrative staff in Europe from 17,550, to 15,000.

HEADLINE: Bankers Split on Deregulation as Stimulus

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
Amid the hours of presentations at the economic conference in Little Rock, Ark., Monday and Tuesday and among the various programs offered for rejuvenating the economy, one of the ideas that seemed to whet President-elect Bill Clinton's appetite was bank deregulation. This involved the notion that banks could be expected to unleash an outpouring of new capital into the economy if the Government simply relaxed regulations on lending -- an $86 billion free lunch, so to speak.
"You heard the $86 billion figure; I've just been sitting here all day thinking about this," Mr. Clinton said, noting that such an amount dwarfs the $30 billion economic stimulus package that had been under discussion by many other speakers at the conference.
 
 
Many Doubts
 Many bankers, of course, are delighted that Mr. Clinton -- a Democrat, no less -- is interested in deregulation. But to many, the idea that it can replace Government spending is unrealistic. Most say they are trying as hard as they can to make new loans, and that however welcome the relief, it will not spur much new lending right away. 
 The prospect of cost-free growth is alluring at a time when pressure to slash the budget deficit is strong, as is the possibility of spending more to create jobs and improve productivity. "In the current situation, the biggest effort should be made looking for the so-called freebies, measures that help growth without causing the Federal Government to spend money," said Allen Sinai, chief economist of The Boston Company Economic Advisors, a unit of Shearson Lehman Brothers.
Relaxing bank regulations, he suggested, is the most attractive of the freebies: "If the regulators ease up, and the economy gets better, banks put out more credit, the country grows faster -- with no cost to the budget deficit. And as the economy grows, it generates more tax revenues that can actually reduce the deficit."
Not all bankers agreed that lightening up on regulations would spur more lending, but among those who did, estimates varied widely. The $86 billion figure was a rough estimate offered in Little Rock by William H. Brandon, Jr., president of the American Bankers Association and chief executive of the First National Bank of Phillips County in Helena, Ark. His calculation was based on the prospect that banks would move 4 percent of their assets into making loans, rather than placing them in other investments, such as bonds.
"The logic is that there are loans out there that we are not making that we would normally make," he said in an interview yesterday. "If we could move the regulatory environment from the most conservative back toward normal, we could generate 4 percent more loans in six months' time."
John S. Reed, chairman of Citicorp, said in Little Rock that the impact could be higher -- as much as $100 billion -- while Mr. Sinai, from The Boston Company, testified that the impact would be much lower, perhaps $4 billion to $10 billion. "The banking community may well overstate the impact, but my own off-the-head number was probably conservative," Mr. Sinai said yesterday.
Many other bankers, however, suggested that the immediate impact would be virtually nil. Much as they want less regulation, they cautioned that they aren't likely to boost their lending quickly when the rules are changed.
"We would lend more money if we didn't have all these regulations, but it wouldn't be an instant surge," John Medlin, chairman of the Wachovia Corporation in Winston-Salem, N.C., said. "I think it's a more gradual thing."
 
 
'Loan Window Is Open'
 Frank Lourenso, Chemical Bank executive vice president in charge of middle-market lending, was also skeptical. "The main reason for sluggish loan demand has been lack of demand by businesses, not that they find it tough to borrow or that the banks are too regulated," he said. "The loan window is open here, but I can't push my customers to borrow."
As a result, changing regulations would not increase borrowing, Mr. Lourenso said. "There are things that Clinton can do for banks to help their business in the long run," he added. "I don't think those things will help

HEADLINE: UNREST RAVAGING TOURISM IN EGYPT

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The tourist industry, a bulwark of the Egyptian economy, is in danger of collapse after a series of attacks by Islamic militants against foreign tourists, including one in November that killed a Briton.
The decline is being compared to that during the Persian Gulf war when Europeans and Americans virtually stopped traveling to the Middle East. 
 If tourism does not recover soon, the hold of President Hosni Mubarak's administration will be further eroded. Already it is struggling to cope with rising unemployment, a severe housing shortage and a huge public sector that has become a drain on the budget.
The tourist decline will push hundreds of thousands of people out of work, swelling the ranks of the dispossessed, and will accentuate the state's impotence in the face of the burgeoning militant movement.
 
Lasting Damage Feared
 Tourism is Egypt's largest source of foreign revenues and before the attacks began two months ago was predicted to bring in $4 billion this year.
The Ministry of Tourism contends that tourism has fallen by 40 percent since the attacks, but tour operators and hotel managers in Cairo and Luxor report a decline closer to 60 or 70 percent. They worry that the crisis may be prolonged enough to do lasting damage to their businesses.
"The gulf war had a beginning and an end," said Ramzi Gargour, managing director of Sunshine Tours. "We knew when the war was over things would return to normal. But here, even if they catch all the suspects, there may still be one fanatic 15-year-old boy who will be willing to machine-gun a boatload of tourists. The mood is gloomy."
The British, American and German embassies have all warned their citizens to exercise caution when traveling in Egypt and to avoid the southern cities of Asyut and Dairut, the area where gunmen twice attacked tourist buses in the last two months with automatic weapons, wounding five Germans and killing a Briton.
Islamic fundamentalists announced at the end of August that they would attack foreign visitors in southern, or Upper, Egypt until the Government ended a crackdown that included the stationing of thousands of troops and police officers in villages and towns where the fundamentalists are active.
 
Tourists Called Disrespectful
 The fundamentalists, who say they are fighting to create an Islamic state, criticize tourists for being disrespectful to Islam. They also denounce the Government for what they say is its policy of building luxury hotels for foreigners rather than public housing, schools and clinics for poor Egyptians.
President Mubarak, who met with foreign journalists today, said that while he could not guarantee there would be no further attacks against tourists, security forces had "crushed" the militant movement in recent roundups.
But the campaign against tourists could be stepped up after the deployment of 12,000 troops and police officers in the Cairo neighborhood of Imbaba last week. The house-to-house searches and nightly curfew, which for the first time has brought the campaign against the militants to Cairo, has so far resulted in the roundup of some 600 militants.
Egyptian officials say they are bracing for assaults against foreigners in Cairo and have provided additional security at sites frequented by tourists, like the pyramids at the edge of the city.
Cruise lines, in an ominous move, have begun to dry-dock boats. Dozens of charter and commercial flights have been canceled, hotels are laying off workers and tour companies are releasing guides.
In Luxor on Monday, a few dozen tourists milled around the entrances of the tombs in the Valley of the Kings. On the road leading to the main gate only three buses were parked, instead of the 50 or 60 vehicles that normally ferry tourists to and from the site.
"We visited the tombs by ourselves," said Stephen J. Collins, from Alexandria, Va. "It was like our own private tour. It was great for us, but it's terrible for the county."
Along the the Nile in Luxor empty cruise boats were tied up at their berths. One cruise boat owner, who asked to remain unidentified, said he had mothballed all nine of his vessels.
In Cairo six of the major hotels, including the Marriott and the Hilton, have occupancy rates of around 50 percent. At this time last year they had nearly 100 percent occupancy. Hotels in Upper Egypt, including the Movenpick in Luxor, said their occupancy rates had fallen by 70 percent.
The Siti First Travel Agency, one of Egypt's largest tour agencies, is handling 3 Italian tour groups this month instead of the 10 that were scheduled. The agency's Spanish tour groups have dropped from 15 to 3. And the groups have had so many cancellations that they have only 2 to 6 people instead of 15 or so. Siti First has already shut down 4 of its 10 Nile cruise boats.
"On my cruise boat there were only 24 people on a boat that could accommodate 120," said Heinz Schattin, a Swiss tourist, as he sat in a coffee shop at the base of the pyramids.
The Egyptian authorities have placed a soldier with a Kalashnikov assault rifle on all tourist buses leaving Cairo, a service that many owners say does little to dispel the worries of passengers.
"You put a man with a machine gun on a bus full of tourists," Mr. Gargour said, "and it only makes people more nervous."

HEADLINE: Fischer Said to Plan a 2d Match in Yugoslavia

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 16

 BODY:
A day after he was indicted in Washington for violating international economic sanctions against Yugoslavia, Bobby Fischer, the former world chess champion, was reported by a Belgrade newspaper today to be planning another match in Yugoslavia in March.
A Belgrade daily, Vecernje Novosti, reported that Mr. Fischer's promoter, Jezdimir Vasiljevic, would sponsor a match in Belgrade and Spain between Mr. Fischer and Yugoslavia's top player, Ljubomir Ljubojevic.
 
Facing Heavy Penalties
 The United States Government announced Tuesday that Mr. Fischer had been charged with violating the law for playing a $5 million match with Boris Spassky of Russia in Yugoslavia this fall. 
 Mr. Fischer, 49, who is reportedly living in a Belgrade hotel, is liable to be arrested upon his return to the United States. If found guilty, he would face a maximum sentence of 10 years' imprisonment, a $250,000 fine and confiscation of the $3.35 million he reportedly collected for defeating Mr. Spassky.
At a news conference in September on the eve of the Spassky match, Mr. Fischer spat on a letter from the Treasury Department warning him that he might face prosecution because the match amounted to "commerce" banned under United Nations economic sanctions imposed against Yugoslavia. Mr. Vasiljevic admitted that the match was intended to show Yugoslavia's defiance of the embargo.
Neither Mr. Fischer, who lives in tight seclusion, nor Mr. Vasiljevic, a banker who Western diplomats say makes huges profits financing such operations in defiance of sanctions, was available for comment.
The Security Council imposed sweeping sanctions on Yugoslavia in May because of its military support for the Serbian forces who have carved up Bosnia and Herzegovina and driven hundreds of thousands of Muslims from their homes.

HEADLINE: ROMANIAN LEADERS BATTLE AN IMAGE

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania

 BODY:
Nearly three years after the overthrow and execution of Nicolae Ceausescu, Romania's leadership continues to suffer from widespread mistrust, at home and abroad, of the sincerity of its efforts to convert the country to democracy and a free-market economy.
Typifying Western reticence, the United States in October renewed its denial of most-favored-nation trading status to Romania. The refusal is particularly resented by the Government of President Ion Iliescu because "the clause," as it is called here, was granted to the Ceausescu dictatorship and is enjoyed today by most other former Communist countries, as well as China. 
 Mr. Iliescu was re-elected in October with 61 percent of the vote in presidential and parliamentary elections that foreign observers said were generally fair. His first election, in 1990, gave rise to doubts.
 
President Rejects Accusations
 In an interview, Mr. Iliescu, a usually genial man, bristled and his voice took on an edge as he rejected the catalogue of accusations that cloud the reputation of post-Communist Romania.
"I see all of this as the result of ideological intoxication, which dominates all of us, here and abroad," the President said. Speaking of the violence of the 1989 revolution and the summary trial and execution of Mr. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, he said the dictatorship was the worst in the Communist world and "an explosion" was the only way to dislodge it.
"Compare the evolution now," he said. "After the 'velvet revolution,' Czechoslovakia is being dismembered. In Romania, progress was difficult and encountered problems, but I think Romania now is an area of greater calm, balance and stability."
Mr. Iliescu angrily rejected suggestions that his Government bears blame for rioting that took place in 1990, in which miners brought to the capital by Government transport attacked opponents to the Government and vandalized opposition offices.
 
Cites Other Ex-Communists
 He also reacted with bitterness against suspicions raised by his past as a top Communist official. "Why isn't Boris Yeltsin judged the same way?" he asked. He named Presidents Leonid M. Kravchuk of Ukraine and Franjo Tudjman of Croatia and said, "Everybody forgets their past."
A senior Western diplomat agreed with some of Mr. Iliescu's criticisms but said they were overstated. He said the bitterness of the country's political life is the principal reason why Romania's, and Mr. Iliescu's, past remain issues despite what many diplomats here view as progress toward democracy and economic liberalism.
"Romania is a pariah largely because of the hostility of the opposition," he said. "It paints the situation in solid black and Iliescu as an unredeemed Communist."
The harshness dividing election winners and losers was evident in interviews with opposition leaders.
"Iliescu is a crypto-Communist who inspires no confidence," said Corneliu Coposu, a royalist who led the Democratic Convention electoral alliance and heads the National Peasants Christian Democratic Party. "He has a nostalgia for the Communist structures and a Marxist-Leninist orientation. He has no credibility."
In a parliament in which no party or formal coalition can muster a majority, the small parties led by close associates of Ceausescu share significantly in the balance of power. The new Cabinet of Prime Minister Nicolae Vacaroiu, an economist who is considered a technocrat without close political ties, was approved with the support of the two radical parties.
 
New Premier Supports Plan
 Mr. Vacaroiu is charged with carrying out Mr. Iliescu's policy of slow reform, which seeks to minimize the effects of closing nonproductive state factories and withdrawing Government subsidies from essential goods on the long-suffering public.
"The continuity of Romania's reform can be achieved only at a bearable social cost," the Prime Minister said in an interview. He stressed the word "bearable."
The opposition asserts that this slow approach is a facade behind which Mr. Iliescu and his followers hide their unwillingness to change the still largely state-controlled economic structure.
"They can't stop reform but want to slow it, to keep their old privileges for a few more years," said Nicolae Manolescu of the Civic Alliance Party.
While the political leaders and the many parties vituperate in Parliament and through many new newspapers that contain far more opinion than fact, the 23 million Romanians seek with varying success to survive.
Private stores have sprung up offering a much wider choice of goods than was available under the Communists, but most Romanians still buy necessities in state stores with subsidized prices. Food lines, a regular feature of Romanian life for many years, are shorter but still exist.
Continuing pervasive poverty makes many Romanians uneasy about freedom. Those who rise above the average in a nation that was largely equal in poverty and repression are met with suspicion. Ordinary Romanians state with conviction that the small new class of entrepreneurs who succeed under the new freedom are either members of the former secret police or Gypsies, who are widely disliked.
"It is easier to free people than to free their minds," said Dumitru Ciocoi-Pop, rector of the University of Sibiu.

HEADLINE: ELECTION TURNOUT HIGHEST SINCE '68

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Turnout in the Presidential election reached 55.23 percent of the voting age population, the highest share since 1968, Curtis Gans, head of the Committee to Study the American Electorate, said today.
In 1968, nearly 61 percent of the voting age population went to the polls. 
 Relying on reports from election boards and other state offices in 50 states and the District of Columbia, Mr. Gans said 104,402,691 citizens voted for President. That was a sharp increase from the 91,594,805 who voted in 1988, when 50.11 percent of the population 18 and over voted.
Mr. Gans said the increase could be attributed almost entirely to the independent candidacy of Ross Perot. Except for a few Southern states, he said, "the Perot total equaled or exceeded the individual state gains." He said he believed that the increase was temporary and not very likely to change the generally downward trend of voting participation in recent years.
According to the committee, a nonprofit organization whose goal is to increase voting, President-elect Bill Clinton received 44,908,232 votes, or 43.01 percent of those cast. But his total was only 23.76 percent of the eligible electorate -- the smallest percentage since the election of John Quincy Adams in 1824, Mr. Gans said.
President Bush got 39,102,282 votes, or 37.45 percent of those cast. Mr. Perot got 19,725,433 votes, or 18.89 percent. Andre Marrou, the Libertarian candidate, placed fourth, with 291,612 votes.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Insurer Hit by a Voter Revolt

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The fallout from a voter revolt in Brevard County, Fla., reached Wall Street yesterday, pulling down the stock price of the nation's largest municipal-bond insurer. The reaction of stockholders may also be an early warning for investors in a popular version of local government borrowing that the voters in Florida are challenging.
The stock of the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation dropped more than $5 in early trading but rebounded a bit and ended $1.75 lower, at $61.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 The reason appeared to be the 4-to-1 vote on Tuesday by the Brevard County commissioners to have a referendum in March on a $23.9 million issue used to pay for the county's new government operations center in Viera. M.B.I.A. insured the securities, called certificates of participation.
 
A Major Political Battle
 Based on the preliminary wording of the referendum, the vote will be on whether to keep the county's operations in the new building. If the vote is no, then the county will stop making payments of interest and principal on the certificates of participation, and M.B.I.A. will pick them up.
The vote Tuesday also prompted the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the credit-rating concern, to put a $670,000 Brevard County bond issue used for a golf course on its credit watch until the referendum is held. The bonds are rated BBB+. S.& P.'s statement said the company was "concerned that future political or economic controversies might affect the county's willingness to repay its other financings."
The fight over the government building and over continuing to honor the certificates of participation has become a major political battle in the county. It goes back to 1989 when the then board of commissioners approved the financing and the new government building without a countywide vote. "That is the key," Truman G. Scarborough Jr., a county commissioner, said in an interview yesterday.
The threat of the county vote is also stirring a storm in the municipal bond market. Analysts have said a vote against honoring the certificates will hurt the county's creditworthiness. In addition, it could make investors wary of other such securities, which have become popular because they can be issued without approval by the voters at large.
The certificates of participation differ from general obligation bonds because they are not backed by the full faith and credit and the taxing authority of the local government from when they are issued until they mature. Instead, the payments of interest and principal come from appropriated income that the project built with the bonds can earn. In this case, it is the rent paid by the county for the office building.
 
Analysts See Obligation
 Because the interest and principal payments must be appropriated every year, the courts have ruled that unlike a general obligation bond, a certificate of participation is not long-term debt and does not have to be approved by the voters before it is sold.
Mr. Scarborough said he supported going to a referendum by the voters because it is the only way to resolve the issue. He said that financial analysts were arguing that the county had an obligation to make the annual payments. But if this is the case, then the certificates are in effect long-term debt and therefore the voters should vote on the whole issue.
A second question on the March 16 ballot will ask for approval of general obligation bonds to pay for the county office building if voters approve keeping the operations center there. This money, Mr. Scarborough said, would be used to pay off the certificates of participation. He said he was going to vote against keeping the county operations in the Viera building and for not honoring the certificates of participation. But he will vote for a general obligation bond issue in case the voters approve keeping the county offices where they are.
 
Treasury Market
 Treasury prices rose yesterday with yields falling. The 30-year 7.25 percent bond was up 6/32 to 102 11/32 to yield 7.43 percent, down from 7.44 percent Tuesday.
Barbara Kenworthy, portfolio manager of taxable fixed-income funds at the Dreyfus Corporation, said prices were pushed higher by buying from Europe and by local governments that are paying off existing high-interest-rate bonds.

HEADLINE: Losing the 'Home' in 'Nursing Home'

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y.

 BODY:
Some of the 26 elderly residents waiting in the nursing home's recreation room suspected that the mysterious meeting they had been asked to attend was really a surprise Christmas party. Then Jane Stewart, the home's administrator, announced that the Swiss Home would be closing at the end of January.
"I nearly had a heart attack," said Esther Liljegren, 89. "I couldn't sleep the whole night because it is a very big shock." 
 To Ms. Liljegren, the closing means that she must leave the clean, comfortable place where she moved five years ago and had expected to die.
But to some advocates for the elderly, the closing of the Swiss Home is part of a bigger picture, an unintended result of Federal and state policies -- intended to end gross abuses -- that have forced most small nursing homes out of business, and will soon make such places obsolete.
 
'Few Left, Only a Handful'
 "The freestanding nursing home is likely to become a thing of the past," said Carl Young, president of the New York Association of Homes and Services for the Aging. "There are very few left, only a handful in the state, and likely to become fewer."
Annemarie Gilman, president of the Swiss Benevolent Society of New York, which owns and operates the home, said the Swiss Home had been forced out of business by heavy financial losses. She said the problems stemmed from changes in Medicaid's reimbursement formula, new state and Federal regulations that necessitate costly renovations, and local opposition to a proposal to build a larger home on the same property.
State officials do not even consider licensing new nursing homes with fewer than 120 beds. Most nursing homes are now much larger, and many are adjacent to hospitals, so residents can move directly from assisted independent living to an intermediate care home to a full-service nursing home as their condition deteriorates.
"They want institutions" rather than homes, said Ms. Stewart, the Swiss Home's administrator.
 
Rules and More Rules
 The squeeze on smaller homes began in 1987, when the National Nursing Home Reform Act imposed new regulations and staff requirements, spurred by gross abuses in a handful of states that had little regulation, Mr. Young said. New York State soon came out with even more stringent rules, he said.
The Swiss Home fails to meet the new codes because it lacks the required physical therapy room, staircases accessible to the handicapped, and separate closets for clean and dirty linen on all floors. The home also lacks the staff to comply with new regulations that require team planning of patient care, which advocates for the elderly say is necessary in large institutions but an undue burden in small ones.
Also in 1987, Medicaid changed the way reimbursement is calculated. The change meant more money for places that cared for the very sick and a drastic drop in revenue for places like the Swiss Home, whose residents are healthy enough to get around on their own.
"With minimal care, you get minimal reimbursement," far short of actual costs, Ms. Stewart said.
 
Policies Called Inhumane
 Critics of the Medicaid reimbursement system say it has actually created an incentive to place patients in full-care nursing homes that are both more restrictive and expensive than their condition requires.
"These bureaucrats come out with policies that are inhumane and don't make any sense," said Anthony Monteleone of Mount Kisco, whose mother, Josephine, 84, lives at the Swiss Home. "So they'll put them in a debilitating situation with people in wheelchairs who call out all the time."
In 1923, the Swiss Home moved from West 67th Street in Manhattan to this porticoed 19th-century home atop Captain Merritt's Hill, the highest point in this town of 9,000. At that time it was a self-supporting farm, where older Swiss immigrants raised vegetables and chickens. Today only one of the 26 residents is Swiss, and half have spent most of their lives in Mount Kisco.
And for the last five years, the Swiss Benevolent Society, a charitable group in Manhattan, has kept the Swiss Home open at a loss of about $200,000 a year, Ms. Gilman said.
 
One Plan Goes Nowhere
 About 18 months ago, finances grew more dire when the state Health Department ended the designation of "health-related facilities" for places like the Swiss Home, where residents need some help but not full nursing care. Now, all such homes are held to the higher standards of full-fledged nursing homes, which the Swiss Home could not afford to meet, Ms. Gilman said.
As a way out, the Swiss Benevolent Society teamed up with a organization based in Brooklyn, Wartburg Lutheran Services, and planned to build a 200-bed residence on the same property as the old home, where they hoped that all the Swiss Home residents could be moved together, with a minimum of disruption.
But after waiting almost two years for Mount Kisco to approve the plan, the Swiss Home finally became convinced last fall that the town officials had no intention of rezoning the residential area to allow the construction.
Mount Kisco's Mayor, Richard Roth, who is one of the five town trustees, said opposition in the upscale residential neighborhood stemmed from concerns about a water shortage and potential traffic problems. "Naturally there was an uprising," he said. "We try to protect the quality of life in the neighborhood. It just didn't fit in with what the residents wanted."
 
'Sorry to See Them Close'
 Wartburg, which withdrew its original application about two months ago, is working on a revised plan that will be presented to the trustees in January, said Mr. Roth. But Ms. Gilman said the Swiss Benevolent Society could no longer afford to wait.
Mr. Roth said that town officials had not played any role in forcing the Swiss Home out of business. "I know we look like the bad boys," he said, "but it's the state that came in with their rules and regulations."
In October, members of the Swiss Benevolent Society traveled to Albany to ask state health officials what they could do to stay open, Ms. Gilman said. "But we were told, 'You have no business in business because you're too small,' " she said. "We had always thought that being small made us a better place because it was less institutional."
State officials also deny playing any role in the Swiss Home's closing.
"I'm pretty sure they didn't feel they wanted to adjust to the times," said Robert Beattie, assistant director of the State Health Department's Bureau of Long-Term Care Services. "They decided it was too expensive and are going out of business." He said only a few places as small as the Swiss Home were still in business, because simple economies of scale had long since forced them to close.
As the Swiss Home scrambles to find other places for residents to go, families and staff members who will soon be out of a job worry about how the closing will affect residents, whose average age is 84.
"The elderly need a stability and a consistency in their lives, and Christmas is a particularly vulnerable time for the institutionalized elderly," said Barbara Somerville, a social work consultant at the home.
Ms. Somerville said many of the residents had asked if they could at least be moved along with a friend from the Swiss Home and if they could stay at the home at least long enough to spend Christmas with their friends there.
The Swiss Benevolent Society has said it will, if necessary, keep the home open past Jan. 31, until all the residents have somewhere to go.
In the front parlor of the home, dimly lit by the last of the afternoon sun coming through a large picture window, a group of residents who had gathered to wait for a 5 P.M. game of shuffleboard on a recent day said they had become like family. And they spoke of their attempts to adjust to the idea of a new life in modern and unfamiliar settings elsewhere.
With its high ceilings, walnut wainscot and heavy wooden furniture like the enormous hand-carved, marble-topped buffet that Ms. Stewart says she is sure the home was built around, the white three-story home certainly evokes another time.
"It was just wonderful that there was such a place as the Swiss Home," said Adele Bolton, 85, already speaking in the past tense. Ms. Liljegren said, "Everything comes to an end."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Top Officer Set to Retire At American Electric Power

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Richard E. Disbrow, chairman and chief executive of the American Electric Power Company, one of the nation's largest utilities, intends to retire in April, after the company's 1993 annual meeting, it was announced yesterday.
E. Linn Draper Jr., American Electric's president, will succeed Mr. Disbrow. Mr. Draper, who is 50, joined the company last March after a 13-year career at Gulf States Utilities, the last five as chairman, chief executive and president. 
 Mr. Disbrow, who is 62, was named chairman earlier this year and president and chief executive in 1991. He has been with the utility, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, since 1954.
News of the changes came as no surprise to securities analysts, and in a prepared statement Mr. Disbrow emphasized he had agreed to take on the chairman's job only to help position the company for the next management transition.
"The company faces a number of new challenges and opportunities, and in my view it would be preferable to step aside now and let those who will manage through the 1990's and beyond have free rein in establishing the needed policies and programs," Mr. Disbrow said in the statement.
Mr. Disbrow elaborated on the challenges facing his successor in a telephone interview.
"We have many problems remaining in the environmental area," he said. "There will be some new initiatives from the Clinton Administration, but our position is that there has to be a balance between energy, the economy and the environment. I am concerned that we not desecrate the environment, but neither should we leap to Draconian solutions that would jeopardize the economy."
The profitability of American Electric, the parent company of seven electric utilities that provide service to seven million people in parts of seven states, has declined so far this year.
For the nine months ended Sept. 30, the company reported net income of $302 million on revenues of $3.75 billion. In the corresponding period a year ago, American Electric earned $382 million.
"This is a slow-growth company in a slow-growth part of the country," said Sanford M. Cohen, an analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company.
American Electric operates in Ohio, Indiana, Michigan, Kentucky, Virginia, West Virginia and Tennessee.
A graduate of Rice University, where he received bachelor's and master's degrees, and from Cornell University, where he earned a doctorate in nuclear science and engineering, Mr. Draper was an associate professor and director of the nuclear engineering program at the University of Texas before joining Gulf States.
His expertise in nuclear energy did not make life much easier at Gulf States. The company has been in financial trouble since 1986, when it completed a nuclear plant at St. Francisville, La., in the midst of a regional recession.
Mr. Draper spearheaded efforts to raise rates to cover the costs of the plant. Those efforts met with stern resistance from regulators.
