HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: Clinton Selects Ex-Mayor for H.U.D. and an Ex-Marine for Veterans Affairs;
Cisneros Achieves Career Comeback With Nomination

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
In the spring of 1989, as he prepared to leave the San Antonio mayor's office still bruised by disclosures of an extra-marital affair, Henry G. Cisneros looked to the future with subdued confidence, reminding a reporter that he would only be 53 years old at the turn of the century.
"History has a rhythm," he said at the time, reflecting on a career that had seemed headed for statewide or even national office before it was suddenly derailed. Not content to let history take its course, Mr. Cisneros set out with methodical zeal to resuscitate his personal and professional prospects. 
 In the last three and a half years Mr. Cisneros stepped back from the brink of divorce to reconcile with his wife, Mary Alice. He built a new career as an assets manager. He remained in the public eye with a relentless schedule of speeches and television appearances. And he extended his political capital by working hard for a few carefully selected candidates, including Bill Clinton.
 
Completing a Comeback
 Today, at 45 years of age, Mr. Cisneros completed his comeback when President-elect Clinton announced his nomination as Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Several friends who spoke to Mr. Cisneros shortly before today's announcement described his reaction at least in part as one of great relief. "He's the happiest man in America; it's like a great burden has been lifted from him," said George Shipley, an Austin, Tex., political consultant who is a longtime adviser to Mr. Cisneros.
Mr. Cisneros never left any doubt that he wanted to re-enter public life after he decided not to seek re-election to a fifth term, but friends and associates said he has never quite been certain when and how he would do it.
Then, in the last few weeks he was suddenly obliged to agonize over two possibilities. Even as his name was being mentioned for a Cabinet position, he became a likely candidate to run for the Senate seat Lloyd Bentsen is vacating to become Treasury Secretary. Despite the fact that many Texas Democrats were pressuring him to enter the race, last Sunday he called Gov. Ann W. Richards, who must name Senator Bentsen's replacement, to remove himself from the running.
 
Fascinated by Public Policy
 "I was very disappointed he chose not to run for the Senate because he had a good chance to emerge as a consensus candidate among the Democrats, but I wasn't surprised," said State Senator Rodney Ellis, a Houston Democrat. "Henry is very genuinely concerned about his family, but beyond that he saw an opportunity to help shape urban policy all over the country and decided it was in the world of policy, not politics, that he could best be of service."
Like Mr. Clinton, public policy fascinates Mr. Cisneros. Even while out of public office, he has been deeply involved with issues like teaching computer literacy in schools and improving the availability of credit to businesses in the inner cities.
A tall, athletic figure, Mr. Cisneros has proven abilities to translate his policy concerns into charismatic speeches. Having maintained his position as political leader of national repute despite his personal problems, he goes to Washington positioned to increase his standing a great deal.
"The cities and finding solutions to their problems are what really excite Henry," said Larry Macon, a lawyer in San Antonio, "and at this stage in his life he is ready and able to step forward as a high-profile spokesman on urban issues."
Henry Gabriel Cisneros was born in San Antonio on June 11, 1947. His father, George, was a civil servant. His mother, Elvira, was the daughter of a Mexican immigrant who owned a print shop in San Antonio.
Mr. Cisneros was raised in a tree-shaded neighborhood of clapboard homes. In 1968 he graduated from Texas A&M University as a member of the staunchly conservative, all male Corps of Cadets, having become the first Mexican-American commander of the Aggie band.
After earning masters degrees in urban affairs at Texas and at Harvard University he went on to get a doctorate in public administration at George Washington University in 1976.
Even before he had finished his doctoral work, Mr. Cisneros entered politics and won election to the San Antonio City Council in 1975 at a time when the city's growing Hispanic population was beginning to challenge the white business establishment that had long dominated City Hall.
Protests by Hispanic groups were regularly disrupting Council meetings when Mr. Cisneros was elected Mayor in 1981. A moderate, who maintained close ties to business leaders, Mr. Cisneros became a bridge between the city's increasingly assertive Mexican-Americans and its traditional power brokers.
During his eight years as mayor the city grew in stature, finally moving out of the shadows cast by Houston and Dallas to become a major business center in Texas. Mr. Cisneros aggressively courted corporations that were considering moves to San Antonio and oversaw a variety of large infrastructure projects.
Eventually gaining a reputation as brick and mortar mayor, he alienated some Hispanic groups who criticized him for focusing on big, splashy programs, like the Alamo Dome stadium now nearing completion, rather than efforts to improve life in poor and working-class neighborhoods.
After winning re-election in 1987 with 67 percent of the vote, Mr. Cisneros seemed like he could be Mayor for life or until he decided to run for higher office. But by the summer of 1988, San Antonio was swirling with rumors about the Mayor's private life.
On Sept. 12, 1988, Mr. Cisneros announced he would not seek re-election to the $5,000-a-year mayor's post the following year because he needed to tend to his family's financial concerns. His son, John Paul, required expensive medical treatments for congenital heart defects.
But, a month later after rumors of infidelity had made the local press, Mr. Cisneros was obliged to admit that he had been having an affair with Linda Medlar, who had worked on his political campaigns.
Seemingly undaunted by the public ordeal Mr. Cisneros set about building a new life. In June, 1989 he opened the Cisneros Assets Management Company, an investment firm based in Houston.
Even if he serves in a Clinton Administration for two terms, Mr. Cisneros will still be a relatively young man. People who have watched his career believe he is still planning for the long term.
"No one who knows Henry thinks that being H.U.D. Secretary is the last thing he is going to do," Mr. Macon said.

HEADLINE: British Air's World Is Growing

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
British Airways P.L.C. took another big step in its quest to become a global airline today by taking a 25 percent stake in Qantas, the Australian national carrier.
The Australian Government selected a $450 million bid from British Airways over a bid of undisclosed size from Singapore Airlines for the stake in Qantas, which the Government is selling in stages to private investors. 
 The selection came as regulators in the United States prepared to rule on whether the British carrier should be allowed to proceed with the centerpiece of its international strategy -- its proposed deal to acquire 44 percent of the USAir Group.
The deal with USAir, which must overcome strong objections from American Airlines, United Airlines and Delta Air Lines, would give British Airways the largest presence in the United States of any foreign airline. There has been growing speculation that the Bush Administration will reject the deal, though British Airways said today that it remained optimistic.
 
USAir Ruling Expected Soon
 Prime Minister John Major will meet with President Bush this weekend at Camp David, and British officials said he would push for approval of the USAir deal and for a related plan to allow carriers from the United States more flights to a greater number of cities in Britain. The United States Transportation Department has said it will rule on the deal, which could eventually cost British Airways up to $1.35 billion, before Christmas.
Even without the USAir link, British Airways has made a series of investments in the last year that gives it a presence in many of the world's largest airline markets and arguably give it greater reach and influence around the world than any of its competitors.
Air traffic worldwide has been depressed for several years by a combination of factors, including the Persian Gulf crisis and recession or economic slowdown in all of the big industrial countries. Moreover, it remains unclear how successful British Airways will be in taking advantage of its links to other carriers. Similar partnerships by other big airlines, notably between Northwest Airlines and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, have so far yielded few benefits.
Still, British Airways executives said global alliances should give the company a chance to profit from long-term increases in air traffic around the world. They said the deals would also provide opportunities to cooperate in feeding passengers from British Airways to its partner airlines and vice versa and to cut costs and generate additional business by meshing marketing, maintenance and other operations.
On Wednesday, French authorities gave the go-ahead for British Airways to buy a 49.9 percent stake in TAT European Airways, which serves 52 cities, primarily in France, for $108 million. British Airways also has an option to purchase the rest of the company in 1997, when European Community laws on foreign ownership of airlines will be liberalized.
Earlier this year, British Airways set up a regional airline in Germany, Deutsche BA, with three German banks, and took a 49 percent stake. With the deals in both France and Germany, British Airways is preparing for a gradual opening of the airline industry in Europe to greater competition under the European Community's single-market program and to gain an advantage over the national carriers in those nations, Air France and Lufthansa.
British Airways is also working with Aeroflot in Russia to create a new Moscow-based airline, Air Russia, that could be flying to Europe as early as next summer and to the United States and Asia within a few years.
 
Move to Privatize
 British Airways bid for the stake in Qantas as part of the Australian Government's plan to privatize the airline. The other 75 percent of Qantas is to be sold to the public by the Australian Government next year.
The link with Qantas gives British Airways a toehold in the rapidly growing South Pacific market, including routes between Australia and Hong Kong, Tokyo and the United States. British Airways executives said they would also be able to reduce costs for both airlines by merging some of their operations.
"It is an alliance that will create opportunity for competitive growth and expansion on a level previously unavailable to either airline," Sir Colin Marshall, British Airways' chief executive, said in a statement.
Under the terms of the deal, which still faces various regulatory approvals, British Airways would receive three seats on a reconstituted 12-member Qantas board. Qantas management would remain in place. But the companies would set up a committee to coordinate their activities and would develop a formal 10-year agreement to govern the cooperative ventures they develop.
Qantas, which is profitable, merged earlier this year with Australia's internal domestic carrier, Australian Airlines, which was losing money. As part of the deal with British Airways, and in preparation for the public sale of the rest of the carrier's shares, the Australian Government agreed to inject $925 million in additional capital into Qantas, more than doubling its net worth.

HEADLINE: Damage in New York State From Recent Storm Put at $234 Million

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
New York State officials yesterday increased the preliminary damage assessment from last week's storm to $234 million as emergency assistance workers for the White House to approve Federal disaster relief for New York and New Jersey. President Bush declared three counties in Connecticut eligible for Federal assistance yesterday.
A Presidential declaration of disaster is required before the Federal Emergency Management Agency opens telephone lines and centers to take applications for assistance. 
 No new flooding was reported following the half-inch of rain that fell on the metropolitan area yesterday, as communities continued to dry out.
Experts on insurance and taxes offered the following advice:
 
Insurance Claims
 A standard homeowner's policy covers damage to a structure and its contents from wind, fire and other occurrences but not rising flood water, and most policies pay "reasonable" costs of temporary shelter, food and clothing if a house is uninhabitable. If rain or water enters a structure as a result of wind damage -- a roof blown away, for example, or holes in walls caused by a fallen tree or flying debris -- the repairs will usually be covered. But ground and coastal flooding, which was extensive in this storm, is usually covered only by Federal flood insurance. But claims against a flood policy can usually be expedited by an adjuster representing the company that issued a homeowner's policy.
The Insurance Information Institute recommends that policy owners make temporary repairs to prevent additional damage before an adjuster can assess the damage. It suggests that policy holders videotape or photograph all damage and save receipts for temporary repairs and living arrangements. Most insurance companies will advance money for shelter, food and transportation.
The experts suggest that homeowners prepare lists of damage before an adjuster's visit. The insurance institute said most policies would cover payments for an engineer or electrician to inspect a damaged building.
Homeowners may hire professional adjusters not employed by insurance companies to help settle claims. However, such adjusters charge a commission that is a percentage of the settlement. Some unscrupulous ones inflate their estimates of what a homeowner will be able to recover, collect their fees in advance, then settle quickly with an insurer for less than promised. "If you do employ an 'adjuster for hire,' " the Florida Insurance Commission told victims of Hurricane Andrew in September, "do not pay them up front."
 
Flood Insurance
 Federal flood insurance policies contain a condition that subjects a property to local building code restrictions if there is a claim for more than 50 percent of the structure's value. In such cases, a flood-damaged house is treated like one being built; it is subject to the latest code requirements for elevation above flood lines or setbacks from high-water marks. The limitation on the claim relates to the value of a structure, not the land, and the land may represent most of the property's market value. A property worth $100,000, say, could include a house valued at $25,000 on a $75,000 parcel. In that situation, a flood claim of more than $12,500 could subject the homeowner to the 50 percent rule and require considerable expense to rebuild the house to elevate it above flood lines.
 
Fraud
 Disasters often attract unscrupulous contractors who overcharge or bilk people desperate to move back into their homes.
"We want to stress to consumers that even in their rush to make emergency repairs they should still take time to find reputable contractors and to make sure they've gotten several estimates and references," said Emma Byrne, director of the New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs.
 
Taxes
 Internal Revenue Service regulations allow the deduction of casualty losses suffered in storms. A casualty loss on nonbusiness property is reduced by $100 plus 10 percent of the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. If that total is more than the loss, the taxpayer is allowed no deduction.
 
Cleaning Up
 Spoiled food and other property that represents a health threat should be disposed of and listed in insurance claims, experts say.
Officials said that occupants re-entering flooded houses or apartments should insure that electrical wiring, gas lines and appliances are safe and in good working order.
The owners of homes without power should make sure that fuses, circuit breakers and thermostats are off and appliances unplugged, officials said. After electricity is restored, fuses or circuit breakers should be turned on but homeowners should wait two hours before turning on thermostats and plugging in appliances. Power surges that can damage appliances may be common in the first hours after restoration.
 
Federal Assistance
 If the region is declared a disaster area by President Bush, Federal assistance will be made available.
If a disaster is declared, residents may apply for grants to repair their homes and for rental assistance for temporary housing. They may also get unemployment assistance and crisis counseling.
Within 24 hours of a disaster declaration by the President, officials will establish a toll-free telephone number to accept applications. Within four days, centers should be established for applications for housing, grants, loans and other relief. Claims must be verified by disaster relief personnel.

HEADLINE: Trade Warrior Packs Briefing Books

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Carla A. Hills, the only economic official in President Bush's Cabinet to emerge with an enhanced reputation, has helped to forge more than four dozen free-trade agreements during nearly four years as the United States trade representative.
"You look at the economic achievements of the Bush Administration, and most of them lie on her doorstep," said Jeffrey J. Schott, a trade policy expert at the Institute for International Economics here. 
 Even her critics acknowledge that with the signing of the North American Free Trade Agreement today and an agreement with the European Community on farm subsidies last month, she has completed more of her agenda than her Cabinet colleagues. Their criticism is not so much of her, but of the Administration's agenda.
"She has been effective at the tasks that the Bush Administration expected her to carry out," said Robert A. Blecker, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington research center with ties to Democrats and organized labor and that advocates a more confrontational trade policy. "In a number of areas, the Nafta and probably the GATT, she tends to assert wildly optimistic predictions of what they'll do," referring to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which is overseeing broad global talks on easing trade barriers.
Mrs. Hills acknowledges that she has not met all of her goals. Even the farm-subsidy agreement seems not enough to have broken the stalemate in the broader global trade talks that have been her highest priority. With France reiterating its objections this week, the broader talks under the auspices of GATT are unlikely to be completed during her tenure.
On the Japanese front, a baker's dozen of agreements have been reached to open specific Japanese industries to American exports, but many trade problems remain. The American trade deficit with Japan has narrowed only slightly during her tenure, to an estimated $46 billion or $47 billion, from $51.79 billion in 1988.
That continued gap has prompted growing enthusiasm for Government aid to exporters and industries hurt by imports, and Mr. Clinton has named an advocate of such assistance, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, to head his Council of Economic Advisers.
 Mrs. Hills contends that cutting the trade deficit is not her job, because the deficit partly reflects broad economic forces, like a slowdown in Japan's growth rate.
Instead, Mrs. Hills said, her goal has been to seek equality of opportunity in every country for business people of every nationality. "The question is, can any entrepreneur go and sell its wares in Japan with the same ease as a Japanese entrepreneur can sell his or her wares into this market?" she said. "And the answer is not yet -- but in many sectors it is true that it is open."
In Congress, with the help of prominent Democrats, including Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the choice of President-elect Bill Clinton for Secretary of the Treasury, Mrs. Hills was able to fend off renewal of so-called Super 301 legislation, which would have forced the Adminstration into a more confrontational trade policy. Last year, she won renewal of the Administration's authority to negotiate trade pacts and submit them to Congress for quick votes, no amendments allowed.
Mrs. Hills's success on Capitol Hill has three roots, members of Congress said. She has been developing contacts there ever since she served as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Ford Administration and spends an extraordinary amount of time on Capitol Hill. And she has been willing to hire the proteges of Democratic lawmakers.
Asked to evaluate the Hills tenure, Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, immediately pointed to the corner of his office, where a large photo shows him dining four years ago with President-elect Bush.
During the meal, Mr. Rostenkowski said, he recommended one of his aides, Rufus Yerxa, as deputy United States trade representative with responsibility for GATT negotiations. Mrs. Hills quickly hired Mr. Yerxa and sent him to Geneva; officials of the incoming Clinton Administration say there is talk of keeping him there.
 
 
A Lecturer, Some Say
 But her style does not always sit well with some members of Congress. "A lot of my colleagues found her a lecturer," Mr. Rostenkowski said. "Instead of discourse, there was a lecture."
Another facet of Mrs. Hills's power has been her close links to President Bush, a family friend since the 1960's. Mrs. Hills's husband, Roderick M. Hills, a lawyer and former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is an occasional horseshoe partner of Mr. Bush.
 Her power also stems from her encyclopedic knowledge of trade policy and trade law, Administration officials said. It is a knowledge acquired by plowing through thick briefing books.
Mrs. Hills said her secret was skimming "a few hundred pages" each day. "I read it early in the morning and late at night," she said.
 
 
Winner of Turf Battles
 She has drawn on that information to win a series of interagency turf wars, steadily expanding her control over international economic policy. She persuaded President Bush that she -- not Robert A. Mosbacher, who was then Commerce Secretary -- should negotiate a free-trade pact with the Soviet Union. And despite occasional grumbling at the State Department, she dominated the North American talks.
"It's very difficult to undercut someone who knows their brief so well," one Administration official said.
Mrs. Hills, who will turn 59 next month, earned a bachelor's degree at Stanford and a law degree at Yale. While she says she has not thought about what she will do after leaving office, she is likely to become a sought-after corporate director. She quit six boards when she took her current post.
For all her successes, Mrs. Hills remains remarkably sensitive to even a hint of criticism.
Asked last week whether her successor should be another technocrat and lawyer, Mrs. Hills complained indignantly that neither label should be applied to her.
"Why do you want to pigeon-hole?" asked Mrs. Hills, who has not run for elective office since she won a seat on her high school's student council. "Having served as a Cabinet officer before, why don't you think of me as a politician? Why don't you? Who happens to be knowledgeable about her portfolio? Why is it either you're a technocrat or you have political sense -- why is it disjunctive and not conjunctive?"

Hills, United States trade representative, and Ambassador Gustavo Petricioli of Mexico. Mexican and Canadian leaders signed separately. (pg. D1); Carla A. Hills. HEADLINE: Crown Hts. Gets Offering From Mayor

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins went to Brooklyn yesterday for the second day in a row to meet with more religious and community leaders from Crown Heights in search of long-term racial and ethnic harmony. This time, the Mayor brought with him an array of relatively small initiatives intended to demonstrate what City Hall can do for the neighborhood.
The two meetings strongly suggest that the Mayor and many religious and community leaders in Brooklyn are trying to shift the debate from the broad, often bitter, accusations that have dogged Mr. Dinkins since the racial violence in August 1991 to a more specific, measured discussion on pragmatic questions of delivery of city services. 
 The Mayor and other city officials said they hoped that refocusing the discussion might demonstrate their commitment to the people of Crown Heights and help bring diverse people together.
Mr. Dinkins and nearly a dozen senior aides met in a lengthy private meeting yesterday morning at the Brooklyn Borough Hall with a coalition of about 20 black and Jewish community leaders from Crown Heights. The city officials laid out initiatives from a stepped-up police presence in the neighborhood to the reopening of a city recreation center intended to meet demands for improved city services in Crown Heights.
 
Protection and Jobs Urged
 The initiatives represented the Dinkins administration's formal response to a report issued in August by the local group, called the Crown Heights Coalition. The report came on the anniversary of the four days of unrest in 1991 that followed the death of 7-year-old Gavin Cato, who was killed by a car driven by a Lubivitcher Jew. The organization was created by Brooklyn Borough President Howard Golden after the disturbance 16 months ago.
The coalition, in a report prepared by 40 educators, civic leaders and clergymen, examined the underlying social and economic causes of the violence. It recommended a host of improvements in city services in Crown Heights, including extra police protection for students walking to local schools and the creation of a major new youth employment program.
Mr. Dinkins's meeting with the coalition, which was scheduled two weeks ago, was described by some of the participants as upbeat. It followed a much more emotional and strained meeting on Wednesday between Mr. Dinkins and rabbis and other representatives of Hasidic and orthodox Jewish groups, who have been the harshest critics of the Mayor's handling of the racial violence in Crown Heights last year and its aftermath.
Mr. Dinkins spoke to reporters in the hallway of Brooklyn Borough Hall early yesterday morning while the four-hour, closed-door meeting was under way. He said that he hoped that his first, tentative meeting with the Hasidic and other orthodox Jewish representatives in Crown Heights on Wednesday would lead to detailed discussions about city services and access to City Hall similar to his meeting yesterday with the Crown Heights Coalition.
The Mayor said he was hopeful that his talks with the Jewish religious leaders would "arrive over time where this meeting is." He said he hoped to be talking soon about police matters, social services and other pragmatic issues with the Lubavitcher rabbis and other Hasidic and orthodox representatives who, until Wednesday, had avoided sitting down face to face with him to discuss their grievances.
But Mr. Dinkins, apparently in response to the rabbis' clear effort to tone down the tenor of their criticism, also said twice yesterday that he would have to respond to their concerns not only by providing specific programs but also by more broad and symbolic gestures.
Mr. Dinkins said he believed that the initiatives city officials presented to the coalition yesterday would help soothe concerns in Crown Heights. "That does not mean," he added, "that I don't have to demonstrate personally to my friends in the Jewish community that I understand the depth of pain and anguish they feel for those three or four days of disruption, rioting in August of '91. I understand that."
Among the Mayor's initiatives for Crown Heights is increasing the number of police officers assigned to the 71st precinct, which covers much of the neighborhood. Norman Steisel, the First Deputy Mayor, said that under a broad expansion of the Police Department approved last year, precincts are to reach maximum staffing levels by 1996. But the city has decided to increase the 71st precinct to its maximum next month, Mr. Steisel said.
When the expansion began, the precinct had 181 officers, said Suzanne Trazoff, a Police Department spokeswoman. It now has 246 officers, Ms. Trazoff said, and, under the Mayor's new plan, it will have 274 officers next month.
The issue of increased police protection came up yesterday at a private meeting of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and about 80 representatives of Jewish groups who met in his office at the World Trade Center. After the meeting, the Governor said that the main message of the Jewish leaders was: "We need to feel safe on the streets." Declaring that "safety is a concern of many people in the New York area, in the larger Jewish community and beyond," Mr. Cuomo said the problem was "difficult but not intractable."
Rabbi Shmuel Butman, a Lubavitcher spokesman, said he was pleased that the number of police officers would increase. "We don't feel that, for example, a basketball game with black and Jewish youth, is the answer," Rabbi Butman said. "The answer is substantial issues in the community. There has to be a feeling in this community that there is accessibility to City Hall and that City Hall cares about every citizen of this community."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
A Notable New Jersey Bond Issue

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
New Jersey sold the second-largest municipal bond issue in history yesterday and included a new type of bond product that appeared highly popular with some portfolio managers. The $1.8 billion of general obligation bonds is second only to the $2 billion issued by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority in 1987, according to the lead underwriter, Lazard Freres & Company.
The new product is a "detachable call." In effect, New Jersey is selling the ability to call, or redeem, a small portion of the bonds before they mature if interest rates decline. 
 This is only the second time this has been done. The first such sale was made with much less visibility last month by the Municipal Electric Authority of Georgia.
A call is the right of the issuer of a bond to buy it back after a set period of time, like 10 years. The issuer wants this right in case interest rates drop. Almost 41 percent of the $233 billion in municipal bonds expected to be issued this year have been sold so existing higher interest rate bonds could be called.
Investors and portfolio managers, however, would prefer that bonds not be callable because if bonds paying high interest are called, they usually have to substitute bonds with lower yields. But if a portfolio manager could buy a call right alone, it could be turned into a form of protection -- or hedge -- in a portfolio.
In yesterday's sale, the calls on the $86 million of bonds due in 2013 were sold separately. That means one investor bought a bond priced to yield 6.15 percent that is callable after 10 years. Then, separately, New Jersey sold the right to make this call to other investors. What these investors paid -- the equivalent of 11 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point -- lowered the overall cost for the state by bringing the effective yield down to 6.04 percent.
New Jersey ends up with a noncallable bond. That would normally be risky. If interest rates declined enough, the state would lose. But because of Treasury regulations, the state cannot use the call in these particular bonds, according to Robert Lurie, director of the office of public finance. But the third parties who bought the calls can use them.
The idea of selling the call separately is a product of several factors. One is that with interest rates very low now, some issuers may feel there is little risk in not having the right to call. And the people in the business of financial innovation argue that selling this right will save more money for the issuer than just issuing a bond without a call in it.
The reason the call can be sold for more is that some money managers would like having such calls in their portfolios, in part because they are much cheaper than buying a bond. They can use them as a hedge, to offset the risk that bonds they do own may be called. If interest rates decline enough for their other bonds to be called, they would be able to buy the New Jersey bonds and collect the 6 percent coupon.
There were two signs yesterday that there was demand for these calls from portfolio managers. First, Lazard Freres was able to raise the cost of the detachable call to 11 basis points from 10 basis points. It also increased the calls available by the raising the total of bonds with a 2013 maturity to $86 million from $68 million.
The rest of the tax-exempt bonds were priced to yield from 4.30 percent in 1996 to 6.15 in 2013. In the top tax bracket this is equivalent to yield from 6.23 percent to 8.91 percent. About $900 million of the bonds is being used to pay existing higher interest rate bonds. The rest will be used to pay interest and principal on other current bonds, something the state has never done. This frees money in the state's general funds for some capital projects.
 
Treasury Market
 Prices and yields in the Treasury market jumped up and down all day yesterday with mixed results. The price of the 30-year bond was up 4/32 , to yield 7.42 percent, down from 7.43 percent on Wednesday. But the price of the five-year Treasury note dropped 2/32 , to yield 6.04, unchanged from the day before.
The market was buffeted by a series of economic reports in light pre-holiday trading. The 22,000 increase in initial jobless claims sent prices higher and the yield on the 30-year bond dipped briefly to 7.40 percent, its lowest level since the first week in October. But then the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported that its December index of regional business conditions jumped to 31.5 from 16.6 in November and a lot of the price gains were lost.

HEADLINE: Sports Betting Is Way Behind In 4th Quarter

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
A bill that would have made New Jersey the second state in the nation to offer sports wagering in casinos suffered a setback today that was probably fatal.
The measure, openly opposed by some of the senior Republican leadership, stalled in the Assembly Appropriations Committee, making it extremely unlikely that it will reach the full Assembly for a vote this session, which ends on Jan. 12. If the measure passes, it would allow New Jersey voters to decide on the November 1993 ballot whether to permit wagering on professional and college sports at Atlantic City's 12 casinos. 
 The president of the Casino Association of New Jersey, Thomas D. Carver, said the death of the bill would cost the state as much as $14 million a year in new tax revenue and would hurt the competitiveness of the Atlantic City's 14-year-old gambling industry.
"With new casinos opening all around us, sports wagering would be the only thing that New Jersey has that is unique," Mr. Carver said.
Opposition to the bill came from many fronts: from fiscally conservative Republicans concerned that its economic impact had been inadequately studied; from professional and collegiate sports organizations worried about possible criminal influence on the outcome of games, and from groups worried that the new form of betting would increase addiction to gambling.
 
Hearing Interrupted
 The Senate approved the sports wagering bill on Monday by a 21-to-16 margin. But the legislation stalled in the Assembly today after its Republican sponsors -- Assemblyman Robert W. Singer and Senator C. Louis Bassano -- interrupted an Appropriations Committee hearing and asked that members postpone a vote on the bill.
Even as his fellow Republicans were conducting today's hearing on the legislation, Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian was meeting with reporters and telling them the bill was headed for defeat.
"It's a matter of each Assemblyman's personally voting their conscience and their district," he said, explaining why the bill was in trouble in the Assembly where the Republicans have a normally solid voting bloc.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Loves New York, And He's Explaining Why

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

 BODY:
When he announced almost exactly a year ago that he would not be a candidate for President, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said his greatest regret was giving up a national forum to rebut the attacks on New York being leveled by Republican politicians.
The campaign may be over, but Mr. Cuomo is still rebutting. At New York University yesterday, he kicked off "The Real New York" lecture series, a six-month program of speeches by state officials aimed at debunking what Mr. Cuomo refers to as "the shibboleths" about the state and, more to the point, about his record in governing it. 
 Mr. Cuomo also is writing a book by the same name and with the same purpose. Two speechwriters for the state's Urban Development Corporation are helping with research and editing of the manuscript. Mr. Cuomo, who is negotiating with Crown Publishers, hopes to see the book in print by the end of the year, said Stephen Villano, a spokesman for the U.D.C.
Mr. Villano said any profits from the book would go to the state's general fund. He justified the use of state workers to help write the book by saying, "It's like an extension of the 'I Love New York' campaign."
 
Loving and Selling the State
 "It's a marketing tool," he added. "It's the rationale to why he loves New York as Governor and how he would like to sell the state to others."
The book and the lecture series also give Mr. Cuomo a chance to help shape a legacy. The Governor acknowledged in his speech yesterday, as he has frequently, that the budget-cutting burdens of the recession have taken a heavy toll on his popularity. He is considering running for a fourth four-year term in 1994.
Mr. Cuomo began his speech by referring obliquely to Vice President Dan Quayle's assertion during the campaign that New York City demonstrated the failure of the welfare state and to President Bush's use of his convention acceptance speech to ridicule the notion of Mr. Cuomo as a Supreme Court justice.
"The Presidential campaign intrigued me because one party spent so much time attacking New York," Mr. Cuomo said. "There was something about the idea of New York that could get you political points if you were a member of this party.
"They even tried by using more or less familiar names from New York in the early part of the campaign as a kind of signal of disdain."
Although he said the tactic backfired, Mr. Cuomo said the state was harmed badly during the Reagan and Bush Administrations by what he argued was a misperception of the state as high-spending, high-taxing and wasteful. That syndrome, he said, has contributed to a severe inequity in Federal spending in which New York sends far more in tax revenues to Washington than it receives in aid.
Mr. Cuomo defended the state by highlighting its appeal to foreign investors, its geographic and cultural diversity and the vibrance of its immigrant community. He cited the small surplus in this year's state budget and asserted that New York ranks 24th among states in per capita taxes -- though that figure does not account for heavy local taxes in many areas that have risen as the state and Federal Governments have cut aid.
 
'We Invented the Midwest'
 Almost self-mockingly, the Governor reviewed the state's past with more hyperbole than history.
"New York was here before America," he said. "We invented banking. We invented the Midwest. We really did. They all came here to New York City, spoke in a Babel. Then they worked their way up the Hudson River, found Albany. Paradise. Oh, Albany's wonderful. You should come. It really is. I think it will be open this weekend.
"They did Albany and they did the Erie Canal and they got to the Great Lakes. Voila, the Midwest. We made Michigan. We created all those places. You should understand that."

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Signed in 3 Capitals

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The leaders of Mexico, Canada and the United States signed a free-trade agreement today that would eliminate import taxes and other barriers to commerce across North America. But the pact faces an uncertain future under the Clinton Administration.
President-elect Bill Clinton said he supported the agreement as a way to create more American jobs and foster economic growth in Mexico and Canada. But he said again, as he did during the election campaign, that he would seek to negotiate three supplemental agreements and make unilateral changes in American law on labor and environmental issues before he would sign legislation putting the agreement's provisions into law. 
 Congress seems likely to pass the implementing legislation eventually, though many members are uneasy about the agreement in its present form. They fear it will encourage American companies to move factories to Mexico to take advantage of low wages and lax enforcement of environmental laws there.
 
 
Most Important View
 "The President's view will be the most important one, and we will listen to that," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is likely to become the chairman of the Finance Committee. The committee will help draft the legislation next year.
But he added that "as a matter of American foreign policy," he had lingering concerns about restrictions on individuals' liberties in Mexico.
Senator Max S. Baucus, the Montana Democrat who heads the Finance Committee's panel on international trade, said that he, too, had reservations and thought that if President Bush had been re-elected, he would have had a hard time putting the legislation through Congress. "I think the President-elect will have a much easier chance, a much better chance," he said.
Mr. Bush, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada each signed copies of the agreement at separate ceremonies in their respective capitals.
In Ottawa, protesters interrupted the brief signing ceremony at the House of Commons, accusing Mr. Mulroney of lying to the Canadian people about trade. Many in Canada blame the 1989 Free Trade Agreement between the United States and Canada for that nation's high unemployment, now running at 11.8 percent.
Mr. Bush signed the pact in the main hall of the Organization of American States here, and was not interrupted.
By signing the agreement today, Mr. Bush guaranteed that Congress would have to consider the implementing legislation under the so-called fast-track rules, which bar any amendments and require a vote within 90 working days after a President has submitted the bill. To become law, both houses must pass the pact by a simple majority. Canada's Parliament and Mexico's Senate are expected to approve the pact very soon because of strong and disciplined ruling-party majorities in both legislative bodies.
The agreement is scheduled to go into effect at the end of next year, but that could be postponed if Mr. Clinton delays submitting the implementing legislation.
 
 
Campaign Pledge
 Mr. Clinton has given no indication of when he will submit the bill to Congress and could in theory wait for many months. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader from Missouri, said last month that he did not expect Mr. Clinton to send the bill to Congress until all of the conditions in his campaign pledge had been met.
In a speech on Oct. 4 in Raleigh, N.C., Mr. Clinton called for supplemental agreements to strengthen labor and environmental protections and to prevent unexpected import surges. The current agreement already has some safeguards, and labor and environmental agreements have been negotiated separately by the Bush Administration, but Clinton aides dismissed these efforts as inadequate during the campaign.
In the same speech, Mr. Clinton also called for the United States to adopt legislation unilaterally that would set up worker retraining programs, clean up the environment, hold imported food to strict health standards, provide greater public participation in bilateral disputes and limit the temporary entry of Mexican workers.
The free-trade agreement's most easily understood feature is the elimination of all tariffs on trade between the three countries. Some would disappear immediately when the agreement comes into force; many would be phased out over 5 or 10 years. A small number would be phased out over 15 years because they protect high-cost industries that are very vulnerable to imports, such as West Virginia glass producers and Mexican corn farmers.
But the pact goes much further, covering everything from Mexican truck drivers who enter the United States to special legal remedies for American businesses that run into trouble in the Mexican bureaucracy and courts.
In a speech at the signing, Mr. Bush portrayed the free-trade pact as a historic step toward free trade that one day would extend from Alaska to Argentina. He invoked the name of Simon Bolivar, who helped lead six Latin American nations to independence from Spain in the early 19th century and sought to create a single nation covering most of Latin America.
"More than 150 years ago, Simon Bolivar, 'The Liberator,' whose statue stands outside this hall, spoke about an America united in heart, subject to one law and guided by the torch of liberty," Mr. Bush said. "My friends, here in this hemisphere, we are on the way to realizing Simon Bolivar's dream."
 
 
Still a Hero
 Bolivar remains a hero in many Latin American countries, although his name was often invoked by military regimes. He believed that presidents should serve for life, and apparently ordered the execution of prisoners and other drastic measures during a civil war in Venezuela that coincided with the American War of 1812.
Mr. Bush said in Detroit earlier today that Eastern European and Asian nations might someday join the North American free-trade area, but made no mention of this prospect after the signing. "It strikes me that there is an inconsistency between what he said there and what he said here," said Fred Bergsten, who heads the Institute for International Economics here and was a guest at today's signing ceremony.
Kathleen Lydon -- the chief spokeswoman for Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative who oversaw the negotiations that produced the free-trade pact -- said that the Bush Administration had planned to expand its regional free-trade area first within the Western Hemisphere. "It's not inconsistent with Detroit," she said.

HEADLINE: Keep Strict Bank Rules, Officials Urge

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Federal banking authorities said today that it cost banks $17.5 billion each year to comply with increasingly stringent and complex regulations, but they cautioned against relaxing the rules as a way of stimulating the flow of credit to encourage economic growth.
The conclusions were made in the annual report to Congress by the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council, a committee of banking regulatory agencies. 
 The discussion came while the Clinton Administration has been considering whether to stimulate the economy by relaxing bank regulations that might limit riskier forms of lending, like lending to small business, while encouraging financial institutions to hold relatively safe Treasury securities instead.
 
Lobbying by Banking Groups
 Major banking organizations like the American Bankers Association have been lobbying for a rollback of some of the regulations. Bankers most recently made their case at the economic meeting this week in Little Rock, Ark., at which President-elect Bill Clinton listened to their pleas with apparent sympathy.
But the bankers association welcomed the report that was issued today, calling it a "first-class job."
Any step back from the regulations of the last few years would have to overcome considerable Congressional opposition, and the bankers' pleas themselves are already inviting a counterattack. Consumers Union, Public Citizen and Acorn, a grass-roots organization, urged the Clinton Administration today not to undo recent regulations on banks.
"The new Administration should immediately indicate that it will not be duped by the banking industry's slogan of 'regulatory burden' and its accompanying public relations campaign into relaxing any of the critical laws related to safety and soundness or consumer protection," the consumer groups said. "This kind of deregulation won't stimulate the economy."
In its report, the council of regulators said that regulatory costs were growing as new regulations took hold in the wake of the crisis afflicting federally insured institutions. The group urged that new regulations be carefully considered to make sure their costs were justified by benefits to the public.
Some of the new rules have won broad approval among bankers and regulators alike -- including one that takes effect this weekend calling on regulators to intervene promptly when a troubled bank's capital dips below set thresholds. But others have been frequently criticized. An example is a rule requiring advance notice when a bank closes a branch, even if it is nothing more than an automated teller machine.
 
Effect on Lending Disputed
 But John P. LaWare, a Federal Reserve governor and chairman of the examination council, said he did not believe assertions by some bankers that the regulations were hampering lending activity.
"There is plenty of capacity in the banking system to lend," he said. "As the economy picks up, the banking industry will stand ready to finance whatever demand arises."
And each of the five members of the council agreed that it would be a mistake to alter the capital standards set by the Basel Accord, an international agreement that increased the amount of capital banks must hold as a defense against failure.
Federal Reserve officials have repeatedly warned against weakening the capital rules, an idea that has been kicked around by some of Mr. Clinton's economic advisers and even mentioned in passing by Mr. Clinton himself as an option to be examined.
On the other hand, some Federal Reserve officials have acknowledged that there may be ways to change regulations to stimulate commercial lending, especially to small companies.
At a conference on banking at the Brookings Institution in Washington on Wednesday, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, David Mullins, said there might be ways to encourage banks to lend to small companies without sacrificing the security provided by some new regulations.
"The banking industry may be systematically retreating from small business lending in favor of mortgage and consumer lending," he said. To some extent, he suggested, that may be because it is much easier to manage the paperwork behind consumer lending than to meet the more rigorous standards for risky commercial and industrial loans.
Even though the banking industry is enjoying a year of record profits, Mr. Mullins said, "the rising tide of regulatory burdens does constitute a threat to the viability of the industry."
And today the new report by the Federal regulators said banking rules were especially burdensome on smaller banks. While the cost of regulations averages out to about 14 percent of the industry's operating expenses, not counting interest costs, the figure for smaller banks can be much higher.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Europe Discord on Trade Talks

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Vehement exchanges between European and American officials, the most vitriolic since a trans-Atlantic trade war was averted by an accord on Nov. 20, suggested today that a world trade agreement might not be achievable in the next few months.
Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France described the November agreement between the European Community and the United States on European oilseed production and agricultural exports as "null and void" -- the most strongly worded French rejection yet of an accord that had been widely seen as opening the way for a successful conclusion of broad six-year trade negotiations intended to reduce barriers to world trade. 
 Those talks, under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, are widely viewed as vital to reviving the stagnant world economy.
In response to Mr. Dumas, a senior United States official, who insisted on anonymity, said the Foreign Minister's remarks "put in question whether the European Community can seriously negotiate on behalf of its members."
The official, who was attending GATT talks in Geneva, added, "It is increasingly difficult to imagine how we can possibly wrap up a conensus on the text of the Uruguay Round agreement in the near future." The trade talks are known as the Uruguay Round because they began in that country in 1986.
One reason a quick agreement is important is that March is the expiration date of American legislation that has allowed Presidents to negotiate trade agreements and submit them for consideration by Congress with no amendments permitted. If this "fast track" legislation is no longer in place, Congressional approval could be a lengthy process and might add amendments that would require renegotiation with the 104 other members of GATT.
Although European Community negotiators in Washington in November were supposed to be representing the agreed position of member countries, France, the largest European agricultural producer and exporter, immediately reacted angrily to the accord, under which subsidized grain exports from the community would be reduced by 21 percent and oilseed production cut back sharply.
The French have argued that the compromise is unfair to Europe's farmers. Farmers in France have enormous political power, and general elections are scheduled for March.
But for all the harsh words, it is possible that the French are posturing, hoping to gain concessions in other areas under negotiation, like financial services and telecommunications.
Tran Van Thinh of France, the European Community's Ambassador to GATT, said today that negotiations must continue in Geneva and that a final decision by the community, including France, would be made only when a complete GATT package was in place. France has threatened to veto an accord at that stage if its farmers do not secure a better deal.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rise, With I.B.M. Recovering a Bit

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks rose yesterday as a recovery in the shares of the International Business Machines Corporation ended the market's five-day losing streak.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 14.05 points to close at 3,269.23. In the broad market, advancing issues led declines, 1,139 to 664, on the New York Stock Exchange, on trading volume of 251.6 million shares. 
 I.B.M. rose 1 1/8, to 53, as eight million shares were traded after two days of large losses. It had slumped to an 11-year low on Wednesday after its announcement of drastic job cuts and a probable dividend cut.
"When a dividend is cut, it is perceived as a negative, but in the long run it's a major plus because there is less of a burden in restructuring," said Peter Cardillo, director of research at Westfalia Investments.
David Bostian, chief economist at Herzog, Heine, Geduld, said the market was likely to resume its traditional year-end rally now that I.B.M. had stabilized.
Analysts said encouraging economic data on weekly jobless claims and the October trade deficit also helped lift to stocks out of their five-session slide.
Initial claims for unemployment benefits rose by 22,000, to a seasonally adjusted 347,000, in the week that ended Dec. 5, but analysts had expected claims to rise even higher.
The merchandise trade deficit narrowed to $7.03 billion in October from $8.58 billion in September, the Government reported.
Meanwhile, the Philadelphia Federal Reserve said its business outlook survey showed the pace of growth in manufacturing was accelerating, nearly doubling to 31.5 percent in December from 16.6 percent in November.
"Today's positive economic statistics are just part of a whole mosaic of improving economic data suggesting the economy is out of recession," Mr. Bostian said.
A first-day stock issue, Student Loan, closed at 18 3/4 after Citibank priced the initial offering of 3.6 million shares at 16 3/4 a share.
Intel climbed 3, to 86 1/2, after Gruntal Investment Research raised its rating to buy from hold and increased its fourth-quarter earnings estimates for the company by 20 cents a share, to $1.50.
Ford Motor shares fell 7/8, to 39 3/4, in reaction to its decision to take a charge of nearly $8 billion in 1992, including a $419 million fourth-quarter charge to restructure European operations.
Procter & Gamble gained 5/8, to 52 3/4, on news that it would raise $1.2 billion through a series of commercial pulp plant and timberland sales. The consumer products giant also plans to sell its Memphis cotton linters pulp plant.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks gained 3.91 points, to 435.43. The American Stock Exchange index rose 1.12 points, to 390.42.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks rose 1.86, to 239.12. The average share gained 27 cents. The Nasdaq index gained 8.83, to 658.46.

HEADLINE: Selig Altschul, an Aviation Expert And Investment Adviser, 78, Dies

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Selig Altschul, long a premier financial expert and counselor to the aviation industry and those investing in it, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78 and until recently also kept a home in Pawling, N.Y.
He died of cancer, his family said.
Mr. Altschul's company, Aviation Advisory Service Inc. in Manhattan, served leading airlines and aircraft companies in this country and abroad. He established his consulting practice in 1947 and headed it as president until he suffered a stroke in 1990. 
 He also wrote for financial newspapers and magazines on the economics of transportation industries. He and his wife, Marylin Bender, were the co-authors of "The Chosen Instrument," a biography of Juan Trippe, the founder of Pan American World Airways (Simon & Schuster, 1982).
 
Began as a Securities Analyst
 A native of Chicago, Mr. Altschul graduated from Northwestern University in 1934, when he started his career as a railroad securities analyst for Chicago brokerage houses. At the same time, he began to write financial articles on the budding airline industry, whose swagger was about to be reined in by the regulators under the 1938 Civil Aeronautics Act.
His writings gained him an invitation to join the new Federal Civil Aeronautics Board as a senior analyst from 1941 to 1943. Then, while serving in the United States Army Air Force, he took part in the Strategic Bombing Survey of Germany. He returned to the C.A.B. as chief analyst in 1946 but left for Wall Street the following year to start his company.
Mr. Altschul advised airlines and investment banks on regulatory matters and on how to finance the growth of the airline industry. He often appeared as an expert witness before government agencies and United States Tax Courts. He took on various government assignments, working as a consultant to the Congressional Aviation Policy Board, the Senate Commerce Committee and, in 1955, as head of a Hoover Commission task force that examined the capabilities and performance of the Military Air Transportation Service.
President John F. Kennedy named him to his Task Force on National Aviation Goals, known as Project Horizon.
In the early 1960's Mr. Altschul also played a pivotal role in the merger of debt-ridden Capital Airlines, then the country's fifth largest, into United Air Lines.
In 1977, the United States Railway Association asked him to to serve as chairman and chief executive of the Delaware & Hudson Railway to save it from bankruptcy. He did so for a year and remained a director until 1983, when the company was acquired by Guilford Transportation Industries.
Over the years, he also held directorships in several corporations, including Western Union Corporation and Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce Trust Company.
In addition to his wife, a former reporter and editor of The New York Times, Mr. Altschul is survived by two sons, Michael F. of Arlington, Va., and James S. of Manhattan; and two brothers, Herman and Sidney, both of Chicago.

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Deficit Narrows to $7 Billion

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
In a surprising tally that conveyed mixed messages about the economy, the Commerce Department reported today that the nation's trade deficit narrowed sharply in October, to $7 billion, as exports jumped to a new record. Imports fell moderately.
The $1.6 billion monthly improvement, to the smallest merchandise trade gap since June, was hailed by the Bush Administration but greeted skeptically by most private analysts. 
 Indeed, there was widespread belief that fresh trade deterioration was almost certain in coming months and that friction would intensify with Japan. At $5 billion in October, up from $4.4 billion in September, the American deficit with Japan was the biggest in nearly four years.
 
 
'Good Reason to Cheer'
 From Beijing, where she is leading a large Government entourage on a mission to get the Chinese to buy American goods, Commerce Secretary Barbara H. Franklin issued a statement citing the latest figures as providing "good reason to cheer this holiday season as U.S. companies continue to benefit from President Bush's efforts to open markets and promote exports."
Private commentators, however, generally regarded the October trade results as an aberration.
"I think this is temporary," Harald B. Malmgren, a Washington trade consultant, said. "Exports can't continue to surge when the rest of the world economy is really sluggish."
Mr. Malmgren also said he expected that the dollar would rise in coming months, reflecting greater relative appeal of American interest rates. That would further erode the trade position by making this country's products more expensive to foreigners while making imports cheaper.
 
 
Double Trouble
 "We've got the double-whammy," he added. A stronger domestic economy "will continue to suck in imports without any place to export." Both Germany and Japan, major trading partners, are generally considered as having now slipped into recession.
Barry Rogstad, president of the American Business Conference, a group of rapidly growing midsized companies, also played down the record October exports, which climbed $1.3 billion, or 3.4 percent, to a total of $39.2 billion.
He noted, as did others, that nearly 75 percent of the increase came from civilian aircraft, a sector in which big-ticket items are delivered at irregular intervals, and from shipments of nonmonetary gold.
The October totals "cannot disguise a world economy that is dead in the water," Mr. Rogstad said.
Nor is expected American legislation likely to help, said John E. Silvia, economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. He said that one-third or more of American factory equipment was imported and that adoption of an investment tax credit proposed by President-elect Bill Clinton to increase business investment in equipment would raise demand for foreign goods and exacerbate the trade imbalance.
 
 
International Agreements
 Advisers to Mr. Clinton have ruminated about denying credit for imports, but this, various specialists said, could probably not be done without violating international agreements.
Imports during October eased to $46.2 billion, or five-tenths of 1 percent below the record September level, today's report showed.
Geographically, the American deficit with developing countries shrank by about $500 million, to $2.6 billion, according to figures that are not seasonally adjusted. The deficit with China eased by $300 million but, at $2 billion, remained at a level that Secretary Franklin said "cannot be sustained."
Besides the $600 million erosion with Japan, the American deficit worsened by about $250 million with Canada and what had been surpluses of $500 million with Mexico and $250 million with Western Europe virtually disappeared.
The main shifts in exports were increases in industrial supplies and materials and in capital goods, the report showed, while imports were dominated by declines for consumer and automotive goods.
The nation's bill for imported oil climbed to $3.8 billion from $3.5 billion in October as volume rose by 17 million barrels at an average price, $18.15, that was 29 cents above that of September.
On a three-month moving average, the deficit edged down to $8.2 billion from $8.3 billion, the department also calculated.
For trade in advanced technology products, in which the United States has traditionally shined, the surplus jumped to $2.7 billion from $2 billion on an unadjusted basis.
Over all, commented Richard S. Peterson, chief economist at Continental Bank, Chicago, the latest figures "still show we're competitive." But he added, "I think the deficit is going to continue to rise on balance" in coming months and total nearly $100 billion in 1993, about 20 percent ahead of this year's level.

HEADLINE: Initial Claims By Jobless Rise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for jobless benefits rose in early December for the first time in four weeks, but the Government said today that the increase was an aberration because of the Thanksgiving Day holiday.
The Labor Department reported that first-time applications for unemployment insurance rose to 347,000 during the week ended Dec. 5 from 325,000 the previous week. 
 But, it added, "The rise was mainly the result of the return to a normal workweek after a shorter reporting period the prior week due to the Thanksgiving Day holiday."
"The basic thing is that we've been in a downtrend in claims since late summer," Robert G. Dederick, an economist with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said.
Analysts noted that the four-week moving average, which smooths out the erratic weekly changes and is considered a more reliable indicator of the labor situation, fell to a low for the last two and a half years.
The average was 352,000 during the period ended Dec. 5, down from 361,750 a week earlier and the lowest since it reached 350,250 on June 9, 1990.
The number of new claims has remained under 400,000 for 11 weeks, which some analysts contend means an improving employment situation.
The number of initial jobless claims excludes claimants using a special emergency unemployment program in early December.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Mixed Despite Positive U.S. Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against major currencies yesterday in light trading even though the Government released positive economic statistics.
Gold prices rose. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $338.40 a troy ounce, up 50 cents from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank said gold added 70 cents an ounce for a late bid price of $338.20. 
 Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer with Bank Leumi, said the dearth of activity in the dollar market stemmed from the approach of the holidays.
 
Dollar Still Seen 'as a Buy'
 Also, while the economic statistics were positive, they were insufficient to cause a rally. Strengthening came with traders realizing that with the European monetary system "still somewhat shaky, the dollar is still regarded as a buy," he said.
In New York, the dollar closed at 122.74 yen, down from 122.95 on Wednesday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 123.12 yen, down 0.75 from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 123.15 yen.
In New York, it cost $1.58 to buy one British pound, more than Wednesday's $1.5745. The British pound was quoted in London at $1.573, down from $1.5775 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: marks, unchanged, at 1.5575; 1.3995 Swiss francs, up from 1.399; 5.3245 French francs, up from 5.3235; 1,404.5 Italian lire, up from 1,399, and 1.273445 Canadian dollars, down from 1.27675.
Gold closed in London late yesterday at $338.30 an ounce, up from $337.35 bid for an ounce late Wednesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $338.25, up from $337.20 late Wednesday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $2.22 to close at a bid $337.55.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Supercomputer Tensions Rise

BYLINE: By John Markoff

 BODY:
THE United States and Japan are nearing a confrontation over supercomputers.
Japanese Government and corporate officials are growing increasingly irritated by the United States' refusal to consider Japanese complaints that the American Government market is closed to Japanese supercomputers. At the same time, their American counterparts say the Japanese have failed to comply with a 1990 bilateral trade accord under which Japan agreed to open its Government market to American makers of the fastest computers. 
 "We're at a watershed," said John A. Rollwagen, the chairman of Cray Research Inc., a leading supercomputer maker. "The supercomputer could become a symbol of renewed trade tensions. If it breaks down into trade barriers, then both the Japanese and the Americans will be losers."
A collision could come as early as March, when the American Government and Cray Research may decide to challenge NEC over its installation of an SX-3 supercomputer at Japan's National Institute for Fusion Sciences. Cray Research lost that contract and a subsequent appeal, but the Americans believe NEC won by bidding a "paper" machine -- one that exists in blueprints but not in reality, and will ultimately fail to meet performance specifications. The two Governments are now skirmishing over whether the Japanese will permit what the Americans consider a fair test of the machine once it is installed next year.
The Japanese are said to be considering a variety of responses to what they see as America's refusal to open the Government market, including withdrawing from the 1990 agreement. Last week, a Japanese Government negotiator met with the deputy United States trade representative, Ira Wolfe, over a variety of trade issues including supercomputers. The meeting "opened up a wide field for disagreement," an American Government official said.
The chill between Japan and the United States deepened shortly before the Presidential election when an interagency team of American negotiators met with the Japanese in Tokyo. At the meeting on Oct. 28-29, the Japanese presented the American team a two-page document listing questions and issues related to concerns of the Japanese about their inability to sell supercomputers to the American Government.
The Japanese argue that United States Government officials have systematically prevented Government laboratories from purchasing Japanese supercomputers. "The United States has had doubts about the openness of our markets," said Mr. Koro Bessho, an economic official at the Japanese Consulate in Washington. "We wanted to see how the United States does these things. We have found some things that were contrary to what we expected."
Cray Research and United States Government officials respond that the American market is, in fact, open, but that Japanese machines introduced recently, like the NEC SX-3, still do not measure up. Cray executives point out that setting aside both Japanese and American markets, their company is the dominant supplier in Europe, which is considered a more neutral market.
That is not entirely convincing, independent industry experts say. "I have trouble buying that argument totally," said Gary Smaby, president of Smaby Group, a supercomputer industry consulting firm. "The Japanese don't have the robust software environment of Cray, but there are a number of applications where the Japanese machines do quite well. If the market was totally open, then my guess is that somebody would have tried to buy the machine."
A crucial issue is the strength of Japanese supercomputing software. American officials are eager to test the NEC SX-3 to determine if it is capable of automatically parallelizing applications -- effectively tying together several separate processors. This is a key area where Cray Research has retained a significant lead, at least until now.
Both countries contend that while the Japanese now have the fastest single processors, American makers like Cray offer faster overall machines because of their parallelizing software.
An American Government official who has participated in supercomputer trade negotiations said that parallelizing software was a significant reason the Americans were anxious to keep Japanese supercomputers out of United States Government laboratories. Directly connecting a Japanese supercomputer to the United States' high-performance computer network would permit the Japanese to make rapid strides in software, he said.
Although supercomputers represent a tiny market in terms of international trade, they are considered pivotal because of their strategic significance and as symbols of national prestige. American negotiators say the outcome of the supercomputer dispute may directly influence other trade battles, including those involving satellites, other types of computers and construction contracts.

HEADLINE: Dining Out In New York On $50 a Day

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:
"LUNCH and dinner in New York City for $50 a day?" sniggered a seasoned veteran of Manhattan restaurants. "Is that sitting down?"
A wisecrack like that would have been justified five or six years ago, before a recession, evolving dining habits and changing demographics opened a trap door in dining rooms through which customers disappeared at alarming rates. 
 But in the last year, restaurateurs have fought back with aggressive discounting, special promotions -- most notably the $19.92 lunch specials that began in the summer -- and a heightened emphasis on customer relations. As a result, New York City restaurants today offer more bargains than Macy's in January.
In addition, the city has seen an explosion of inexpensive quality restaurants where full meals are served for $25 or less.
Considering all of this, yes, it is possible to dine out at lunch and dinner in New York City, even in Manhattan, without spending more than $50 a person for both meals.
To reach this target, you must set out with certain information in your quiver. For one, pay attention to the widespread and ever-changing prix fixe meals offered. Although pre-theater specials were largely confined to the greater Broadway district just a few years ago, they now are advertised all over the city, even if there isn't a theater anywhere nearby. Savings can be 30 percent of a la carte prices or even more. And if you are willing to eat at off-peak hours -- before 6 P.M. and after 9:30 or 10 P.M. -- more remarkable bargains can be found.
Another tip: if you are on a tight budget, lay off the expensive mineral water.
For this roundup on pages C30 and C31, Eric Asimov and I have proposed a theoretical weekend that includes Friday dinner, Saturday lunch, Saturday dinner and Sunday lunch or brunch. Lunch tabs are less than $20, dinner tabs less than $30. The meals are planned around typical weekend activities: art museums and galleries, Broadway theater, cinema, classical and pop music, shopping and dance programs.
Prices include an appetizer, a main course and a dessert, which can be tallied precisely. Beverages are not included because habits vary so widely. A glass or two of wine could push the tab slightly over the $50 threshold. Tax and tip are extra, as is any popcorn at the movies.
