HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
The Way the West Was Won, and Reinvented

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

Gunfighter Nation
The Myth of the Frontier in 20th-Century America
By Richard Slotkin
850 pages. Atheneum. $40
Since 1893, when Frederick Jackson Turner delivered his epoch-making address on the crisis America faced in the closing of its geographic frontier, historians have been busy debating the winning and losing of the West. The latest study to tackle this widely written-about subject is the scholar Richard Slotkin's stirring new book, "Gunfighter Nation: The Myth of the Frontier in 20th-Century America," the concluding volume in an ambitious trilogy tracing the evolution of the myth of the American frontier.
"Gunfighter Nation" builds on ideas laid out in the trilogy's first two volumes, "Regeneration Through Violence" (1973) and "The Fatal Environment" (1985). It often echoes the work of other scholars as well, most notably, Henry Nash Smith's influential "Virgin Land: The American West as Symbol and Myth" (1950) and "The West of the Imagination" (1989) by William H. and William N. Goetzmann. At the same time, the book breaks new ground in its careful explication of the continuing dynamic between politics and myth, myth and popular culture. 
 Writing in clear, sure-footed prose, Mr. Slotkin methodically illustrates the ways in which the myth of the frontier has both informed American foreign policy -- from Presidents Theodore Roosevelt through Ronald Reagan -- and shaped popular thinking through books and movies. If his book's relentless determination to look at American history through this single, narrow lens results in some oversimplifications -- the country's idealism and taste for isolationalism are both consistently underplayed -- it nonetheless succeeds in making the reader re-examine the underpinnings of American political and cultural ideology and reassess a century of remarkable change.
According to the myth of the frontier, says Mr. Slotkin, "the conquest of the wilderness and the subjugation or displacement of the Native Americans who originally inhabited it have been the means to our achievement of a national identity, a democratic polity, an ever-expanding economy and a phenomenally dynamic and 'progressive' civilization." Central to this myth was the belief that "violence is an essential and necessary part of the process through which American society was established and through which its democratic values are defended and enforced."
Whereas the early settlers achieved progress (and, Mr. Slotkin implies, a sense of spiritual regeneration) through the continual annexation of new lands, Americans were forced to look for new sorts of conquests when the Western frontier closed in the 1890's. With the Spanish-American War and American involvement in the Philippines, Theodore Roosevelt extrapolated the frontier myth to the world of foreign affairs. For Americans to renew their virility, Roosevelt suggested, they must take up the challenge of empire and bring civilization "to the red wastes where the barbarian peoples of the world hold sway."
Later administrations, says Mr. Slotkin, would invoke the frontier myth to justify the use of counterinsurgency measures in the cold war and to rationalize America's growing involvement in Vietnam. In each case, Mr. Slotkin argues, the enemy was portrayed in terms similar to those once used to depict Indians, as ruthless, savage adversaries, whom the "side of progress and civilization" must fight "without quarter and even without scruple."
At the same time, adds Mr. Slotkin, American movies were reinforcing -- and in some instances, subverting -- these premises through the vehicle of the western, a genre used by film makers "to allegorize a wide range of difficult or taboo subjects." While westerns like "High Noon" and "Shane" asserted "the entitlement of representatives of the 'better' or 'decent' classes to a privileged form of violence" (much the way, Mr. Slotkin implies, that American Governments justified the abuse of official procedure in the name of national security), other films would begin to question just how far the gunfighter could go "without becoming morally indistinguishable from the enemy."
The film "Vera Cruz" (1954), which tells the story of a group of American gunfighters who go to Mexico to help suppress a radical revolution, suggested a willingness, in Mr. Slotkin's words, "to measure means by their effectiveness rather than by their conformity to 'longstanding concepts of fair play.' " And "The Searchers" (1956), which features John Wayne as an ex-Confederate soldier obsessed with exacting revenge on the Indians who massacred his family, re-examines the whole concept of racialist war and its moral consequences for both the victor and the vanquished.
As America's involvement in Vietnam escalated, Mr. Slotkin says, the western -- particularly the Mexico western focusing on the experiences of Americans south of the border -- became a convenient vehicle for metaphorically dealing with the problems of the war. By the mid-1960's, these films had already grown increasingly violent and cynical; by 1970 -- after Tet and the shocking revelations of the My Lai massacre -- some of these movies had begun to invert the traditional myth of the frontier. In "The Wild Bunch" (1969), for example, the adventures of a group of Americans in Mexico lead not to a heroic last stand, but to a bloody shootout that destroys an entire town.
With the return of the last American combat forces from Vietnam, the popularity of westerns precipitously declined, from a high of 29 in 1971 to only 7 in 1974, a development indicative, Mr. Slotkin contends, of the decline of the frontier as a viable national myth. Vietnam, the failure of the war on poverty, Watergate, the hostage crisis and the sobering realities of a worsening economy and a fragile environment all combined, in Mr. Slotkin's view, to diminish the validity of the frontier myth with its old promises of manifest destiny and infinite progress.
Although President Reagan tried to invoke the old symbolism of the myth -- with promises of economic bonanzas, warnings about the "Evil Empire" and even references to his former movie roles -- Mr. Slotkin argues that "his repair of public myth was partial and incomplete" for he could not erase "either the material consequences of our historical experience or its registration in memory."
Yet a century after Turner pointed to the closing of the geographic frontier, a nostalgia for the myth -- or at least the vocabulary -- of the frontier remains. With United States forces in Somalia, both Government officials and reporters have already begun to invoke some familiar imagery. As Ted Koppel recently said on "Nightline," "We like, as Americans, that sort of western image of the big, swaggering, broad-shouldered American coming into the town that is in trouble and clearing everything up."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Toys or Torture

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
At the end, President Bush had one fine political opportunity left. He could walk into history cleanly, with dignity.
Poor Mr. Bush. No American can take pleasure watching a departing President soil the leave-taking by a last-minute cynical maneuver that can mortgage the successor Administration -- and the lives of those who suffer under tyranny. 
 As he leaves, Mr. Bush allows Secretary of Commerce Barbara Franklin and a large entourage of bureaucrats to pull off one last piece of sleaze. They are on a $450,000 expedition to China to sign a few more deals to placate its Communist rulers.
Given Bushbaker's record of appeasing Beijing, it is difficult to know why the killers of Tiananmen Square, the captors of millions of slave laborers, must be placated further.
Still, appeasement is addictive. Beijing, which knows a kowtow when it sees one, is promoting the trip as a great victory.
Back home, meanwhile, Bushbaker is considering the sale of advanced jet engine components to Communist China. The Defense Department objects: the components could throw cruise-missile payloads much farther than the Chinese can now. Picky old Defense Department.
In case anybody had any doubts that the mission was aimed at pre-empting a Clintonian China policy, Ira Wolf straightened us out in Beijing. Mr. Wolf, an assistant U.S. trade representative, says he would rather have a Secretary of Commerce in Beijing now than have to wait until August 1993. Presumably Mr. Wolf thinks that is when Mr. Clinton might decide to send one -- or call off the placating game altogether.
Running for President, Mr. Clinton made a strong stand against appeasement. He supported legislation that was backed by a Congressional majority but was veto-meat for Bushbaker. Congress consistently tried to make Beijing pay for low-tariff privileges -- by showing some human rights decency or controlling its lust for selling missiles and nuclear technology to other dictatorships.
In Little Rock the other day, Mr. Clinton said he did not "want" to withdraw China's tariff privileges. That made some Congressional human rights supporters nervous. But they say he is simply guarding his words and inviting Beijing to make a decent human rights offer while it has the chance.
Mr. Clinton also said that the value of being tough with Beijing was shown by Bushbaker itself when China said it would no longer ship slave labor goods to the U.S. Somebody is peddling Mr. Clinton a rubber sausage. The "agreement" on shipping slave products to the U.S. has no investigative or enforcement teeth. It will not free one slave for one hour.
In Little Rock a toy manufacturer pleaded with him not to prevent a Communist Santa Claus from delivering all those low-cost goodies.
But Mommy, how do you know this nice teddy bear made in China doesn't come from a slave-labor camp?
Oh, shut up and play, you little brat.
So, as a new American China evolves under Mr. Clinton, let's review some basics.
Basic one is that China is ruled by a bunch of tough old killers. They intend to pass on Communist power to other tough killers, not quite so old.
Basic two: They rule by terror, torture and slave labor. Americans who do not know do not want to know.
Basic three: China is making economic progress, as have dictatorships before. Beijing makes good use of capitalist tariffs and loans.
American buyers of Chinese goods and propaganda tell us that Communist economic progress leads inevitably to political freedom. As where?
I heard that line when I was a correspondent in Poland during the coldest days of Stalinist Communism, and ever since. The people of the evil empire achieved liberty not when it grew richer but when it collapsed under rebellion, corruption -- and Western pressure. So it will be in the last great bastion of the empire.
Americans have a choice -- Mr. Clinton on down. We can use economic pressure to help at least some prisoners and slaves of Chinese Communists. That might cost some American jobs -- but maybe Americans will wind up making those toys.
Or we can go on playing with our cheap teddy bears.
But it is not an economic choice. It is a choice between prisoner and torturer. That is the fourth basic.

HEADLINE: Immigration Stimulates the Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Immigration Reform Holds Key to Economy" (letter, Nov. 27) Prof. Vernon M. Briggs Jr. of Cornell University's New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations uses a Nov. 10 news analysis, "How to Lift the Poor," as a springboard from which to promote his own anti-immigrant agenda.
In the process, he confuses the issues and misleads readers by asserting, without offering any evidence, that our immigration policy fosters poverty and urban blight. 
 The contrary is true. A 1989 Department of Labor study found that "neither United States workers in complementary jobs, nor most minority workers, appear to be adversely affected by immigration."
This finding is supported by many other studies, including those by the Rand Corporation, the University of Maryland, the United States Council of Economic Advisers and the National Research Council, all of which indicate that immigrants in the United States, both legal and undocumented, do not have a negative effect on the earnings and employment opportunities of native-born Americans.
You concluded on this topic two years ago in "So Much for Assumptions About Immigrants and Jobs" (The Week in Review, April 14, 1990) that "the conventional economic wisdom pitting American poor against the immigrant poor is crumbling." In a recent poll of 38 of the country's top economists, 68 percent favored increased immigration, while none favored less.
These studies also show that immigrants pay more than $90 billion in taxes annually, that they are not a drain on the economy and they contribute far more than what they receive. As the studies show, immigrants create jobs for both citizens and other immigrants and, contrary to Mr. Briggs's assertion, are revitalizing many cities by starting businesses and generating jobs in the communities in which they settle.
Indeed, the policies Mr. Briggs advocates will have the effect of worsening urban problems by creating a class of people especially vulnerable to exploitation, by depressing wages and by causing widespread discrimination and intolerance that will affect all. For example, a 1990 study by Congress's General Accounting Office found that the 1986 law penalizing employers who hire undocumented aliens has led to widespread discrimination against citizens and authorized workers.
Urban reform is a difficult and complicated issue that cannot be intelligently addressed by advancing simplistic and xenophobic ideas such as those expounded by Mr. Briggs. A sound policy attacks poverty; it does not groundlessly make scapegoats of immigrants.
 
LUCAS GUTTENTAG
Director, Immigrants' Rights Project
American Civil Liberties Union
New York, Dec. 2, 1992

HEADLINE: Company to Pay $111 Million In Health-Claims Fraud Suit

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18

 BODY:
National Health Laboratories Inc., one of the nation's largest providers of clinical diagnostic testing, pleaded guilty today in Federal court to two criminal charges of submitting false claims to Government health insurance programs. The company agreed to pay $111 million to settle the case, Government officials said.
The settlement, the largest ever reached between the Government and a health-care provider, is a result of a two-year Federal investigation into the company's marketing and billing practices. 
 The inquiry was initiated in response to accusations by a whistle-blower who could be entitled to more than $15 million of the settlement.
 
Unneccessary Tests
 Federal officials contended that National Health Labs, of La Jolla, Calif., manipulated doctors into ordering unnecessary tests for cholesterol and serum ferritin -- iron in the blood -- as part of a basic series of blood tests.
The extraneous tests for cholesterol and ferritin were billed to Medicare, Medicaid and the Civilian Health and Medical Program of the Uniformed Services at prices much higher than the doctors expected. The tests resulted in millions of dollars in excess charges to the insurance carriers, whose costs have risen much faster than the overall economy has grown.
"Marketing schemes like the one exposed today are a primary reason for these escalating costs," said William Braniff, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of California, who handled the case. "This is not a case where National Health billed for tests that were not performed or tests performed in a fraudulent manner. Instead, National Health sought to subvert the medical judgment of doctors who were ordering the tests."
The medical testing concern's president and chief executive, Robert E. Draper, pleaded guilty to two counts of submitting false claims and resigned. Mr. Draper will forfeit $500,000 to the Government and could face up to five years in prison on each count.
Under the terms of the settlement, National Health Labs will pay a $1 million fine for pleading guilty to the charge of presenting false claims to the Civilian Health program. The company will pay $100 million in recoupment costs to Medicare and $10.4 million to state Medicaid programs to settle civil actions.
According to the Justice Department, the company will pay $35 million by the end of this year, another $30 million by March 31 and the rest by the third quarter of 1995.
National Health Laboratories is a former unit of Revlon Inc., the cosmetics company, and its chairman and largest shareholder is Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman of Revlon.
Mr. Braniff said the practices to which National Health had pleaded guilty were not limited to that company.
He said National Health Labs had conducted a marketing campaign that suggested the lab was performing the cholesterol and ferritin tests as part of a basic blood series test, called sequential multiple analysis computer, or SMAC, which is the single most common laboratory test ordered by physicians.
But National Health was actually charging the Government insurers $18 for each of the three tests, Mr. Braniff said. Private insurers were charged only 65 cents for the same tests.
 
Agencies Billed Directly
 The Federal officials said that the Government agencies were billed directly by the labs, while the charges for tests of patients with private insurance were sent to the doctors who ordered the tests. Many doctors would have challenged such high charges for blood tests, prosecutors said.
"The impression they created was that you got all three tests for the one basic price, but that was simply misleading," Mr. Braniff said. "They also took away the doctor's ability to order only one of the tests, because they were not listed separately on the company's order form."
As an example of the huge financial impact that National Health Labs' practices have had on the public health insurance system, Federal officials who directed the criminal investigation said that in 1988, before the company added ferritin to its basic blood tests, the Medicare program paid less than $500,000 a year to National Health for ferritin tests. In 1990, a year after the tests were added, the company received more than $31 million from Medicare for the tests.
The company's rapid growth in such testing caught the attention of C. Jack Dowden, a sales manager for a competing lab company, who ultimately became the whistle-blower in this case. Mr. Dowden's lawyer, John R. Phillips, said his client was puzzled that National Health Labs was gaining so many accounts and determined with the assistance of a doctor that it was billing the Government for tests that it said were included in the basic blood screening.
Under the Federal False Claims Act, a person who alerts prosecutors to fraud against the Federal Government can collect 15 to 25 percent of any money collected by the Government.
Federal officials said that they were continuing to investigate marketing and billing practices of other blood-testing companies and that they thought many of these companies had engaged in practices similar to those of National Health Laboratories.
 
Big Surge in Testing
 Diagnostic testing has grown substantially in the last decade, encouraged by advances in medicine and technology, as well as by economic and legal pressures on the doctors who order the tests. Such testing is estimated to cost about $30 billion a year, or more than 6 percent of the nation's total health-care spending.
Officials of National Health Labs said that the company would take a charge of $85 million against its earnings in the fourth quarter as a result of the settlement.
An assistant Attorney General, Stuart M. Gerson, chief of the Justice Department's civil division, said in a statement today: "The Department of Justice has made health-care fraud a priority investigative area, and this case indicates the department's commitment to investigate and prosecute aggressively abuses of the Federal health-care system."
Federal officials said they did not know of any suits filed against National Health Labs by private insurance companies, probably because the testing lab charged doctors only about 65 cents for the cholesterol and ferritin tests that were performed for private insurance patients. In some instances, the company waived the 65-cent fee if doctors or patients complained, the officials said.
In a statement, National Health Labs said it had included the cholesterol and serum ferritin tests in its standard testing profile because it believed they were necessary for a full diagnostic evaluation, were medically sound and were supported by a growing consensus in the medical and scientific communities.
"At no time did the company believe that its practices were interfering with a physician's discretion," the statement said. "Rather, the company understood that it was following the common industry practice of marketing a combination of tests together as one basic profile."
 
Much Government Business
 James Richmond, a National Health Labs spokesman, said that the company had projected earnings of 31 to 32 cents a share for the fourth quarter but that the settlement was likely to result in a charge against earnings of 87 cents a share.
Mr. Richmond said that the company's fundamental business was still strong and that it would continue to participate in Federal and state health programs, which account for 40 percent of its revenues.
In the first nine months of 1992, National Health Labs reported net income of $92.2 million, or 96 cents a share, compared with $77.1 million, or 78 cents a share, in the period of 1991. Revenues were $541.1 million in the period, up from $449.6 in the corresponding period a year earlier.

President Boris N. Yeltsin abruptly cut short a three-day visit to China to return to Moscow, saying he had to "restore order" because a struggle had begun to replace reformers in his Government. 6
 
RUSSIA SEES QUICK ARMS PACT
While in China, President Yeltsin surprised the White House by announcing that a major nuclear-arms treaty could be signed in January. Unsure whether he meant that he had agreed to the final details, American officials scrambled for a response. 6

HEADLINE: EX-DISSIDENT WINS ELECTION IN KOREA

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Kim Young Sam, who spent years under house arrest for his opposition to South Korea's authoritarian rulers and then joined forces with the ruling party two years ago, was elected President on Friday, the first in three decades to be drawn from outside the ranks of the military.
In a surprisingly strong showing after a hard-fought campaign, Mr. Kim received about 42 percent of the vote in what many here called the most peaceful and fair election in South Korea's tumultuous postwar history. 
 With about 92 percent of the vote counted this morning, the country's most famous dissident, Kim Dae Jung, received about 34 percent, according to tallies this morning by the Korean Broadcasting System. The billionaire founder of the giant Hyundai industrial group, Chung Ju Yung, drew about 16 percent.
 
Takes Office in February
 Kim Young Sam, who turns 65 on Sunday, will take office in February, succeeding Roh Tae Woo. Mr. Roh, a former general who narrowly defeated both Kims in the country's first open election five years ago, is constitutionally prohibited from serving another term.
In a campaign dominated by fears that the country's competitive edge is eroding after years of remarkable growth, the vote for Kim Young Sam seemed driven by a national desire for stability.
While he promised moderate change, Mr. Kim merged his own party with President Roh's in 1990, abandoning a lifetime served in the opposition. Since then he has closely associated himself with the Roh Administration's policies on everything from keeping American troops based here to a growing dialogue with the Communist Government in North Korea.
 
Vote Shows 'Desire for Change'
 Speaking at a news conference this morning to declare victory, Mr. Kim said the vote "shows the people's desire for change and reform amid stability."
Perhaps more importantly, he also won the grudging respect, though not the affection, of South Korea's military elite. In 1987, there were rumors of military intervention if anyone but Mr. Roh was elected. This year there was none of that, and Western diplomats here say they expect the military to stay out of politics in coming years.
"They can live with him," a senior United States official said not long ago.
Mr. Kim will inherit management of what may be the most critical transition Seoul has faced since the Korean War 40 years ago: Negotiating a permanent peace, and later a possible reunification, with the North, at a time that the Communist Government is still believed to be attempting to build nuclear weapons.
Seoul's fear is that the North Korean economy could collapse, costing the nation hundreds of billions of dollars that otherwise would be spent competing with Japan and the United States and moving South Korea to a more advanced phase of its development.
Though he has long been a fixture in South Korean politics Mr. Kim, the only son of a weathly shipping and fishing magnate, remains something of a mystery to many Koreans. At the age of 26, before the Korean War, he was secretary to the then prime minister, and was elected to Parliament nine times. At moments in his career he has taken large risks, once even staging a 23-day hunger strike to demand that the Government permit far greater liberty in South Korea.
 
Reputation for Honesty
 In a country marked by political corruption, Mr. Kim enjoys a strong reputation for honesty. Yet he speaks in vague terms and sometimes seems to have a loose grasp on complex national issues. His critics have described him as an opportunist whose lifetme ambition to become President has compromised his judgment.
In 1990, Mr. Kim calculated that he stood a better chance of getting elected by joining Mr. Roh's party than by staying in the opposition. So he announced a merger with the ruling Democratic Liberal Party in return for what many suspsect was an informal guarantee that he would be the party's candidate for president this year. Though many of his supporters were angry and alienated, Friday's results showed that many more came back to the fold.
In the days leading up to Friday's election, Mr. Kim's candidacy seemed threatened by a scandal in his hometown area of Pusan, where the mayor and a variety of intelligence and police officials were secretly recorded plotting a way to assure his election. But there was no evidence that their activities were santioned by Mr. Kim, and in the end it seemed to have cost him relatively little support.
The surprise in the campaign was the relatively weak performance of Mr. Chung, whose enormous wealth -- he is reportedly worth $4 billion to $6 billion -- and his powerful reputation as a leader of Korea's best-known industrial group made him a daunting candidate. Kim Young Sam's supporters feared he would split the country's conservative vote, handing the election to Kim Dae Jung. But in the end, the 77-year old Mr. Chung's popularity waned.
 
A Final Setback
 The results were perhaps the final setback for the 67-year-old Kim Dae Jung, who was making his third try for the presidency. Known in the West as the man who survived death sentences, imprisonment and exile in the cause of bringing democracy to South Korea, he was unable to persuade the country's voters that he would not quash the nation's economic miracle.
While he performed strongly in his southern stronghold of Cholla, where he had upwards of 90 percent of the vote, he barely won in the critical precincts of Seoul. He needed a big win in the capital, his supporters said, to make up for his unpopularity throughout much of the rest of the country.
Today, Kim Dae Jung conceded that he had feen fairly defeated and announced his retirement from politics.
 
Milestone for Democracy
 For Korea, Friday's election marked a major milestone in the country's democratization. Unlike the 1987 election in which Mr. Roh took office with 36 percent of the vote, today there were no major accusations of disappearing ballots, intimidation at the polls or computer fraud in the counting.
"In 1987 there was a lot of vote buying," said Chung Won Bok, a 45-year-old worker at Korea Telecom, as he stood on the steps of a polling place in a working-class neighborhood on the western fringes of Seoul on Friay. "I even received a little present from a candidate then," he said.
But this year, he added, "I've seen very little of that."
All day long Korean families could be seen lining up, many with young children in tow, outside schools and neighborhood offices, clutching their national identity cards and the small stamps used in many Asian nations to seal important documents. Each was given a numbered paper ballot, stuffed into giant green metal bins at more than 15,000 locations across the country. At times the atmosphere seemed festive, with friends moving from the polling places to coffee houses and department stores after voting.

HEADLINE: '92 Office Party: Bah to Mistletoe and Liquor

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
After several years of recession-prompted Scrooge-ism, businesses are giving holiday office parties again this year. Caterers, florists and rent-a-Santa services across the nation report a resurgence of the traditional fete. They also say there has been a widespread transformation of the custom.
In an attempt to banish the litigious potential of holiday office parties past, where liquor and libidos ran freely, corporate hosts are holding "interactive parties," events where everything from bumper cars to competitive snowflake-cutting keeps guests busy -- and away from the dark corners and the bar. 
 In New York City, companies from Chase Manhattan Bank to MTV are giving parties that are decidedly more Barnum & Bailey than they are Charles Dickens. Their caterers are transforming anything from Dezerland, a complex of catering halls and game rooms on the West Side, to the New York Public Library into amusement parks for a night. And they hire corps of performers to pour on live entertainment as heavily as companies used to pour champagne.
In fact, when Pfizer, the pharmaceutical company, held its holiday party at the New York Public Library last week, magicians, Santa Claus and Wendy Brackman, proprietor of Wendy's Wacky Hats, who fashions party hats out of paper plates for guests, roamed the stately rooms. The sideshows all but supplanted the punch bowl. "Guests were so bombarded with entertainment they couldn't think about anything else," said Ms. Brackman, whose company is based in Brooklyn.
There were even more entertainers at Chase Manhattan's holiday party at Metro Tech in Brooklyn last week. "It was like a total eclipse of party acts," Ms. Brackman said. "Everybody from Gooen's Baloowins to Mr. Face Paint was there."
Linda Kaye, president of Birthdaybakers Partymakers, a Manhattan business that specializes in interactive parties, said: "We used to call these stunts icebreakers. Now the icebreakers fill the evening."
Paul Hencke, an editor of Research Recommendations, a weekly publication of the National Institute of Business Management, said more companies would give more parties this year. But he said businesses increasingly take potential liability into consideration in planning their parties and include "protective devices."
"Employers are very sensitive to anything that has a legal aroma," Mr. Hencke said. "The incidence of sexual harassment claims soars after holiday parties, and there is a growing concern about liability in cases of excess alcohol consumption, as well. Most companies have eliminated an open bar in favor of one that is controlled by a professional bartender, and they provide employees with transportation home."
Dozens of national corporations have sought the advice of his company, an Alexandria, Va., concern that watches business trends, in designing holiday festivities for employees. Among the recommendations he makes are that a weeknight should be chosen for the event and that the invitation should specify when the party will end.
These concerns, compounded by strained budgets, have wrought other changes in the office party. The buffet has replaced the sit-down dinner, there have been scattered reports of cash bars and employers have begun to give luncheons instead of evening get-togethers. Restaurateurs in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles say that rather than huge company-wide parties, employers are giving small lunches or dinners for departments within their organizations.
"Employees appreciated the intimacy," said Sharon Destephano, a spokeswoman for Jacoby & Meyers, the legal firm, which last year held small dinners instead of a large party for all the employees. Last week, the firm held a company-wide party to celebrate its 20th anniversary as well as the holidays, but Ms. Destephano said the firm planned to go back to smaller parties next year. She added that circumventing possible litigation was not the reason for the company's smaller party format.
 
'Urge for a Lavish Party'
 But Andrew Sherwood, president of Goodrich & Sherwood, the Manhattan-based human resource consulting firm, said "these concerns are all pervasive." In the grim economic climate in recent years, he said, there have been fewer situations that provided a social setting for possible sexual harassment or over-imbibing. But now the mood is upbeat, he added, and "businesses are faced with the urge for a lavish party and the potential litigious pitfalls."
"I can't tell you how many harassment complaints we get after office parties," he said. "Careers are destroyed every year."
The spot beneath the mistletoe has become a war zone. Indeed, florists said mistletoe sales had plummeted. "Kissing's got dangerous," said Dagny Duval, president of Plant Specialists, a company that supplies floral services to offices in the New York area. "Maybe they should change the tradition from kissing to hugging."
But even a ho-ho-ho kind of hug is starting to seem like a throwback. "I'm noticing a lot less gals wanting to sit on the lap," said Eugene Karpin, a freelance Santa Claus who lives in Manhattan and has been appearing in his red velvet suit in midtown stores for 24 seasons. "Even Santa isn't safe."
And the bar is still dangerous territory. Last week, a guest on "The Oprah Winfrey Show" said she had ruined her life by drinking too much at an office Christmas party. Caterers said most employers offer only beer, wine and soda. But even beer and wine can stimulate unwanted winks and unsought soliloquies about office policies.
"The key is diversion," Mr. Hencke said. "You have to keep people away from the bar and involved in group activities."
The solution appears to be the interactive party.
The entertainment industry is already producing high-technology interactive parties. For its company party on Thursday, MTV turned a Manhattan club into a series of human-scale computer games in which guests became players.
"The theme was 'virtual reality,' " said the party's planner, Tinker Bow, president of Mood Food caterers in Manhattan. "The idea was to get people out of the corners, out of little cliques and couplings, and get everybody from people in the mail room to the C.E.O. to play. Movement is essential."
To keep employees circulating, some record companies have rented a floor at Dezerland, which has game rooms, batting cages and bumper cars, and have given each guest a bumper car for the evening.
"We're not the Waldorf-Astoria," said Dezerland's manager, Jeffrey Zelin. "But I have bumper cars full of the black-tie crowd, sometimes two or three parties a night. I had to turn parties away this holiday season."
So far, there have been no reports of Pin-the-Beard-on-the-Santa, but the corporate party fashion has taken a turn toward the toddler birthday party. In fact, Ms. Brackman of Wendy's Wacky Hats has noticed "a big increase in office parties for the whole family, with everything from finger painting to fortunetelling."
Mr. Sherwood of Goodrich & Sherwood said, "People tend to be on their best behavior when their spouses and children are around." Both he and Mr. Hencke of the National Institute of Business Management encourage family parties.
So do party professionals. But most say that children are merely a foil for the child inside the workaday professional. "You should see their eyes light up when I make them a great funny hat," Ms. Brackman said of the adults.
Certainly, the interactive office party poses a new set of social challenges. Just how is one supposed to nibble a canape while steering a bumper car in one's best taffeta?

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
National Health Laboratories will pay $111 million to settle complaints that it fraudulently billed Medicaid and Medicare programs for medical tests it performed. The company and its president, Robert Draper, pleaded guilty to the charges in Federal court in Los Angeles, and Mr. Draper resigned. [Page 1.]
Peter Lynch, the famous stock picker, is returning to Fidelity Investments, but only as a coach of the firm's younger analysts and only for two days a week. Mr. Lynch managed the spectacularly successful Magellan fund before retiring two years ago. [37.] 
 Infinity Broadcasting plans to appeal the F.C.C.'s decision to fine it $600,000. The radio company said Howard Stern's broadcasts were "not actionably indecent." [37.]
Sears, Roebuck dismissed John T. Lundegard as chairman and chief executive of its Western Auto Supply division but would not discuss the reasons. [39.]
Robert Farrell is stepping down as the chief stock market analyst at Merrill Lynch although he will remain as a senior investment officer. Richard McCabe, a first vice president, will succeed Mr. Farrell on Jan. 1. [39.]
A California company, 3DO, plans a high-end video game system that is attracting attention because it is backed by Japanese consumer electronics companies and Hollywood. [39.]
Peter R. Kann reportedly angered Dow Jones employees this week by saying it was unnecessary for the company to adopt a written policy banning discrimination against employees based on their sexual orientation. [39.]
Time Warner is planning to shrink its 21-member board by reducing the number of both inside and outside directors, several executives close to the board said. An executive close to the board said the plan was to have 14 or 15 board members. [39.]
 
 Markets
Stocks surged sharply higher, driven by the heaviest trading in three years. Trading was fueled by the "triple witching hour," when options and futures contracts expire. Big Board volume was 389.3 million shares, and the Dow rose 44.04, to 3,313.27. [37.]
Treasury bond prices were unchanged to lower in lackluster pre-holiday trading. The yield of the Treasury's 30-year bond was unchanged at 7.42 percent. [46.]
Crude oil futures rallied again as traders scrambled to close out positions on the spot January contract. [45.]
The dollar moved higher. Gold prices were lower. [45.]
 
 The Economy
New standards for banks take effect today and require tougher and swifter regulatory action against the weakest banks. But fears that there would be an avalanche of bank failures now appear to be unfounded. [37.]
Paul Mozer has reportedly agreed to plead guilty to two felony counts in connection with last year's Government bond scandal involving Salomon. Mr. Mozer is accused of filing false bids in Treasury auctions. [39.]
Businesses are giving more holiday office parties than they have in recent years. But companies that provide services for such parties say the custom had been transformed into "interactive parties," where less liquor is consumed. [1.]
 
 Your Money
Prenuptial agreements have come into vogue as a result of changes in divorce law. But they are increasingly complex financial documents and they are expensive to draw up. [35.]
G.M. did well when it sold 55 million new shares last spring, but the offering has not been a good deal for the investors who bought them at the offering and have held them since. [35.]
Picking an insurance company is an important decision in light of the recent failures of a number of major life insurers. [36.]

HEADLINE: An Unbroken Tradition of Giving to Neediest

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
The year was 1922. Warren G. Harding was in the White House and Rudolph Valentino was the reigning matinee idol. Six-year-old Virginia Goldman was living in an apartment on 181st Street in the Inwood section of Manhattan, near the site where workers would later build the George Washington Bridge.
Almost a decade earlier, Virginia's parents had started contributing to a new charity sponsored by The New York Times. That year, Virginia joined them for the first time. She carefully stuck a dime -- her entire life savings -- to a piece of paper using paste that she made from flour and water. She signed the letter and her mother mailed it. 
 Thus began a tradition that continues to this day.
Last week, Virginia Miles (nee Goldman), a 76-year-old marketing consultant in Englewood, N.J., wrote a check for $100 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, marking 70 straight years that she has given.
Through wars and natural disasters, recessions and expansions, marriages and divorces, moves across town and across the country, some people pride themselves on donating to the Neediest Cases year after year. For them, mailing a check to the fund is a hallowed ritual of the holidays.
"It wouldn't be Christmastime if I didn't do it," Mrs. Miles said. "It's become my own personal tradition to watch for the first article in The Times on the fund and then send the money. I don't want to break the streak."
In 1948, Fred H. Hill had just left the Army and was opening his own real-estate firm in Manhattan. Soon after he bought his first brownstone -- a purchase that he would repeat thousands of times over the years -- he mailed a check for $50 to the fund. Last week, Mr. Hill, now 77, gave $500, his 45th donation in a row.
Since the early years of this century, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has used donations from people like Mr. Hill to help thousands of New Yorkers who lack food, clothing, shelter, health care and other services. The New York Times pays for the fund's overhead, so all gifts are given directly to seven charities. This year's appeal ends on Feb. 28.
Hortense H. Hirsch first donated to the Neediest Cases shortly after her 3-year-old son, John, died of diabetes in 1917. She contributed every year in his memory until she died in 1990 at the age of 103. Since then, her 72-year-old daughter, Carol H. Kridel of Manhattan, has taken up the tradition. She sent $100.
"I am so thrilled that I am in a position that I can do this," Mrs. Kridel said. "I believe in what the fund does and I believe that it is a way to honor my mother and my brother. It brings tears to my eyes when I even talk about it."
Dave Schoenfeld first gave to the Neediest Cases in 1933 to honor the birth of his daughter, Florence. Every year after that, he mailed a check to the fund in the amount of her age. When she became an adult, she inherited the tradition. Last week, Florence Glazer, now a 59-year-old receptionist who lives in Yonkers, sent $59 to the fund.
"This is continuity," she said. "It's keeping up something that he started for me. It's another way of keeping his memory alive."

HEADLINE: Clinton Wants Wife at Cabinet Table

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 18

 BODY:
Hillary Clinton has sat at corporate board tables, campaign strategy tables and lawyers' round tables. Now, President-elect Bill Clinton and his aides say she will be welcome to sit at his Cabinet table as well.
Because of a law enacted after President John F. Kennedy named his brother Robert as Attorney General, Mr. Clinton cannot legally place his wife in the Cabinet. But she has been a political and policy adviser to him in the campaign and the transition, and he has made it clear that she will continue to play that role in his Administration. 
 Mr. Clinton said in an interview in The Wall Street Journal today that he hoped his wife would attend Cabinet meetings. "She knows more about a lot of this stuff than most of us do," he said.
At a news conference called this week to announce Cabinet appointments, the President-elect did not hesitate to tell reporters that Mrs. Clinton had helped him pick his advisers. "She advised me on these decisions, as she has on every other decision I've made in the last 20 years," he said.
 
'Free to Attend' Meetings
 George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director, continued in the same vein at a news briefing today, when he was asked if he expected Mrs. Clinton to participate frequently in decision-making sessions at the White House.
"I don't know how many she'll attend, but certainly she'll be free to attend when she feels she can make an addition, and that's probably a lot," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "She obviously can contribute on a number of issues having to do with children, family, but I wouldn't want to limit it in any way or expand on it in any way right now."
Aides have said that she has helped Mr. Clinton select Cabinet members in much the same way that she helped plot campaign strategy.
"Clearly, as First Lady and as one of his closest advisers, she will have a role in his Administration," said Lisa Caputo, Mrs. Clinton's press secretary. "Beyond that, I think the Governor's statement speaks for itself."
The role of the President's wife has always been a subject for debate, particularly during the years of such close Presidential confidantes as Abigail Adams, Eleanor Roosevelt, Rosalynn Carter and Nancy Reagan. But Mrs. Clinton's much more publicly acknowledged influence has raised new questions.
Many people who are uncomfortable with the notion that she might act as an unelected co-President have been quick to revive the phrase Mrs. Clinton used early in the campaign: "If you vote for him, you get me."
But the evidence of Mrs. Clinton's influence has been encouraging to some women's groups, whose members have expressed frustration with Mr. Clinton's naming only one woman to his Cabinet so far, Donna E. Shalala, the chancellor of the University of Wisconsin who was chosen to be Secretary of Health and Human Services. Other appointments of women have been to sub-Cabinet-level positions.
In a letter sent to Little Rock today, Eleanor Smeal, president of the Fund for the Feminist Majority, asked Mr. Clinton to slow his appointments process so that more women can be considered for top posts.
"If the trend you have established in your Cabinet appointments continues, it is probable that you will appoint fewer women to the Cabinet than Presidents Carter, Reagan or Bush," she wrote.
Perhaps in part in response to some of those complaints Mr. Clinton has apparently expanded his search for Secretary of Energy. Clinton transition aides said tonight that he had interviewed Hazel R. O'Leary, a Minnesota utility executive, for the post, but they would not say whether she had replaced Senator Tim Wirth of Colorado, who is retiring, as the leading contender for the job.
Ms. O'Leary, 55 years old, is executive vice president of the Northern States Power Company. She would be the third black person named to the Clinton Cabinet if she got the appointment.
Ms. Smeal added: "You have the opportunity to shatter the glass ceiling in our generation, and -- at the very least -- improve upon your predecessors' records. It seems incredible that you would consider doing less."
Lynne Cutler, a Clinton transition aide who has helped draw up lists of women for possible Administration appointments, defended Mr. Clinton against the criticism. When all the appointments are completed, she said, women will be represented fairly.
"It's fair to say a lot of people have raised the issue, and it certainly is a concern," Ms. Cutler said. "This isn't a we-they situation. All of us inside feel the same way."
Women have been mentioned for some unfilled Cabinet posts like Secretary of Agriculture and Attorney General, but Mr. Clinton is close to offering senior positions to several more men, including Warren M. Christopher, the transition director, for Secretary of State and Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, chairman of the House Armed Service Committee, for Secretary of Defense.
Mr. Clinton met with Mr. Aspin at the Governor's Mansion here today, but Mr. Stephanopoulos said no Cabinet selections would be made until Monday.

HEADLINE: Make-or-Break Time for Stores

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Across the country, cash registers have been ringing since Thanksgiving, pealing a tune many of the nation's retailers have not heard with such strength in four years. But the countdown to Christmas really begins today.
Traditionally, the Saturday before Christmas is the second-busiest selling day of the season, surpassed only by the day after Thanksgiving. And over the last few years consumers have telescoped more and more of their shopping into the week ending on Christmas Eve. 
 Because the next few days are so important, most retailers refuse to provide specifics about how they have done so far. Fresh statistics should start to trickle out on Monday and Tuesday.
 
8% Rise Is Reported
 But a telephone survey conducted on Tuesday and released yesterday by Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm, showed that retailers nationwide have experienced an 8 percent increase in comparable-store sales since Thanksgiving and expect the season to finish an average 9 percent ahead of last Christmas. The survey covered 40 of the accounting firm's retailing clients.
Department stores like Kmart say toys like voice-activated trucks are moving well. So are Rollerblades and Barbie dolls. F.A.O. Schwarz in San Francisco is selling caravans of Barney, the popular purple dinosaur.
Store owners and analysts were expecting a pickup in Christmas sales, if only because the last three years have been filled with disappointment. Those expectations were buoyed in recent weeks by positive signs on the economy and Bill Clinton's election as President, developments that bolstered consumer confidence.
"People seem to feel better than they did a year ago, and it is starting to have an effect, " Michael Stemen, president of R. H. Macy & Company's flagship store in Manhattan, said yesterday.
He said sales of men's dress shirts and ties were "very big," and that watches and fine and costume jewelry were moving out of the women's accessories department.
But shoppers are not spending much on the more frivolous items.
"Practicality is the name of the game," this year, said Cynthia Cohen Turk, president of Marketplace 2000, a Coral Gables, Fla., marketing and strategy consulting firm whose clients are mostly retailing and consumer products companies. "We are not going back to sterling silver Perrier bottle holders."
But the gains so far are not being enjoyed equally across the country. Retailers in the Northeast are reporting better sales and traffic in their stores, but last weekend's violent storms hit many hard. Business is extremely strong in Florida, especially in hurricane-ravaged South Florida. But Texas is said to be spotty: stores in Houston are doing very well, not as well in Dallas.
And in recession-torn California, Ms. Turk said, retailing success varies from one neighborhood to the next, especially in the Los Angeles area.
Gloria Salvador, owner of a gift and ice cream shop in San Simeon, Calif., south of San Francisco, said sales were great until May, "and then it went on a real down slide."
As Ms. Salvador browsed recently through the accessories department at Macy's in San Francisco, she said she planned to spend about $1,500 on gifts, about the same as last year. But she said she would be spending the same amount to buy more items.
Caution is also the watchword in Detroit, but for different reasons.
At Saks Fifth Avenue's store in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., Diane Merz, 46, said she was worried about President-elect Clinton, who did not get her vote.
In fact, uncertainty about the policies of the incoming Administration spurred Mrs. Merz and her husband to do some heavy spending on themselves recently: they bought a Lexus SE400.
At the Lakeside Mall in Sterling Heights, Mich., recently, Timothy Wranosky, a 24-year-old engineer at G.M., said the troubled company's health insurance changes will leave him with less money to spend after Jan. 1. As a result, the Wranosky family is cutting 10 people from its shopping list.
In Atlanta, retailers seem to agree this year's season has been better than 1991.
"Customers started shopping at Thanksgiving, and they've continued straight through," said Donald Hess, president of Parisian Inc., a Birmingham, Ala., clothing chain that opened two stores in Atlanta just in time for the Christmas shopping season.
There are no single hot areas, he said. "I can't point to any particular area except very specialized items like our videotape on 100 years of Alabama football," he said.
 
Pickup in Florida
 Armed with insurance checks to cover damages suffered during Hurricane Andrew, consumers are turning out in droves in the Miami area. But again, much of the spending seems to be for items that do not carry a big price tag.
"A lot of people in South Florida are replenishing their music libraries," said Ann Liss, president of Spec's Music Stores, a company that has 64 outlets, 62 of them in Florida. "With all of the problems we have had down here, from Eastern Airlines to the banks to the hurricane, it is nice to see people spending some money."

HEADLINE: After a Night of Unity at the Apollo, Optimism Wavers

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
Something happened at the Apollo Theater in Harlem on Thursday night. A documentary film about black G.I.'s liberating Jewish concentration camp prisoners during World War II brought an audience of 1,200 blacks and Jews to tears. They spoke of common ground, embraced and passionately agreed that together, they had experienced a rare, powerful moment -- a catharsis in the increasingly hostile relations between blacks and Jews in New York City.
But in the colder light of day, many wondered whether theirs was a lasting epiphany on race relations or a moment as fleeting as it was strongly felt. And yesterday, unlike the night before, not everyone could agree. Some considered the evening at the Apollo a turning point, while others feared the truce would be about as permanent as those jaunty waves across the trenches between British and German soldiers in the early days of World War I. 
 Some dismissed the event as a public relations stunt. Calling it "just cosmetic," Rabbi Shmuel Butman, a leading figure in the Lubavitcher community in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, declined to attend. But Mayor David N. Dinkins, who faces a re-election campaign that may well turn on racial fears and tensions and who has spent the last few weeks trying to repair his damaged relationship with Orthodox Jews, sought comfort from the evening.
 
'Tremendously Helpful'
 "He is very optimistic about the future after this showing last night," said a spokeswoman, Ruby Ryles. "He thought it was tremendously helpful in bringing attention to what Jews and blacks have in common."
The film, "Liberators: Fighting on Two Fronts in World War II," was also shown Thursday night on WNET, the public television station that broadcast the documentary for the first time ever last month. The Rev. Jesse Jackson, the financier Felix G. Rohatyn, and others who had viewed it on Nov. 9 at a Lincoln Center screening urged the Mayor to press for the documentary to be broadcast more widely to highlight moments of harmony between blacks and Jews. Mr. Jackson called Percy E. Sutton, the owner of the Apollo Theater, and Mr. Dinkins asked Howard J. Rubenstein, a public relations consultant who has helped the Mayor build bridges to the Jewish population in the past, to coordinate the evening -- as well as the kosher/soul food party for 1,500 that followed.
If the stage was occupied by the heroes and the victims of World War II, the audience was filled with some of the most prominent figures in the city, ranging from the Rev. Al Sharpton and Betty Shabazz, the widow of Malcolm X, to Peggy Tishman of the Jewish Community Relations Council, Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem and Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney.
But it was the documentary film that brought people together. It also prompted different reactions in different viewers.
Richard Green, executive director of the Crown Heights Youth Collective, had brought 45 young people, blacks and a few Hasidim, by bus from Brooklyn to see the film. Afterward, his charges stood in line outside the theater to get autographs from the stars of the documentary, the aged black veterans who as young men had liberated German concentration camps, and who at the Apollo were reunited with some of the Jews they had rescued.
 
'A Sense of Heroes'
 "It gave the kids a sense of heroes -- something besides Michael Jordan," Mr. Green said. He added that the sight of needy Jews depending on blacks for salvation was novel for the youngsters. He found it salutary. "Usually, blacks are seen benefiting from Jewish giving and altruism," he said, referring to such cases as Jewish civil rights organizers descending on the segregated South, Jewish philanthropists and Jewish labor organizers helping blacks join unions. "This showed it is also reciprocal."
But Rabbi Avi Weiss of the Hebrew Institute of Riverdale seemed less comfortable with that role reversal. He praised the film, calling it "very, very important," but quickly added that schoolchildren should simultaneously be taught "that Jews were also liberators." He said that "too often, Jews are seen by certain elements of the white and black population as either victims or victimizers."
"It's important that the flip-side also be shown," Rabbi Weiss said.
 
'A Real Spiritual Moment'
 The rabbi, an outspoken critic of Mr. Dinkins's handling of the Crown Heights disturbances, said that while the evening was mostly "symbolism," he noticed that the participants in the Thursday night event "shared a real spiritual moment."
It wore off rather quickly.
Wilbert A. Tatum, the publisher of The Amsterdam News, was one of 20 or so prominent blacks and Jews who were invited after the film to a round table discussion on Channel 13 moderated by Charlie Rose. Mr. Tatum said he almost did not go on after learning that Rabbi Weiss was also invited. "I did not want to make something as serious as this a circus," he said. Coaxed by Mr. Rose and others, he eventually changed his mind. Mr. Tatum, usually a passionate debater, kept his temper in check all evening -- even after Mr. Weiss repeatedly denounced WLIB, a black-owned radio station. During one attack, Mr. Tatum turned on him and, picking up a faintly Yiddish accent, said, "enough already."
Rabbi Weiss was also subdued during the discussions, though later he called the event an "extravaganza" and "a media bite." He returned to his past laments, demanding justice for the killing of Yankel Rosenbaum and complaining that the Mayor "never calls me 'Rabbi' -- he calls me 'Avi Weiss,' or 'Weiss and his ilk.' "
 
Resentment Surfaces
 Resentment over seemingly small slights were felt on both sides, and at times it seemed to poke through the giddy good feeling of the evening. The Rev. Herbert Daughtry, the pastor of the House of the Lord Church in Brooklyn, said he was annoyed that Channel 13 had identified him on the screen only as as a "community activist," saying, "even though they managed to get all of Avi Weiss's titles in." But he said he shrugged it off "because in the midst of euphoria, who wants to be a wet blanket?"
But he noted that for all its emotional power, the Apollo gathering and the discussion that followed failed to address "what separates us." Mr. Daughtry said he believed that everyone's lack of candor had reduced the evening to a temporary "good and lovey-dovey" feeling.
 
'What the People Are Saying'
 Citing differences between blacks and Jews on such issues as the Palestinians, Professor Leonard Jeffries and Louis Farrakhan, Mr. Daughtry said, "This is what the people are saying. It may not all be based on fact, but you need to hear it."
He said the evening reminded him of the momentous night in New Hampshire during the 1984 Presidential campaign, when Jesse Jackson apologized for calling New York City "Hymietown."
"He got a standing ovation in a synagogue. People cried. We thought we had put it all behind us. The next day all we heard was that Jesse was not sincere."'
Even those who were enthusiastic about the evening's power warned that it by itself could not permanently alter racial conflicts in the city. If there was one area of agreement, it was that the Apollo event was only a first step. Voices as disparate as Rabbi Weiss and Mr. Sharpton argued that such meetings should be organized in schools, churches, synagogues and community centers throughout the city. "I think for a moment it did unite the communities," Mr. Tatum said. "But a catharsis only has a lasting effect if it is repeated over and over again."
 
'It Has to Make a Difference'
 Mr. Rohatyn, who as a child fled occupied France to escape the Nazis, called the film "incredibly moving" and said it should be shown in every school in the city. But the financier, who has long predicted economic ruin for New York City, has grown just as gloomy about the state of its race relations. Of the evening at the Apollo, he said bleakly, "I think it has to make a difference -- if this doesn't, I don't know what will."
Dennis deLeon, Commissioner of Human Rights for New York City, took a more optimistic view, suggesting that while prominent city figures may have had an epiphany at the Apollo, the healing was already taking place in the city's neighborhoods -- undetected, at times, by the city's power elite. He said many people had already begun reaching out between communities because "they can't live with this tension."
"Ordinary people are not waiting for the media players to resolve it," he said. "They just do it."

HEADLINE: Bank 'Doomsday' May Not Be So Bad

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
To the pessimists, this weekend was supposed to be the bankers' doomsday. The scenario predicted by the House Banking Committee chairman, Henry B. Gonzalez; Ross Perot, and other influential figures was of a December surprise. They warned about an avalanche of bank failures, concealed by regulators and set off by new rules that take effect on Dec. 19 and require tougher and swifter action against the weakest banks.
But the deluge is turning out to be more of a trickle. 
 "The sky is not falling," said Andrew C. Hove Jr., chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. But while many bankers are celebrating the fact there will be relatively few casualties, regulators and some lawmakers are still keeping their champagne bottles corked. They acknowledge it will be hard to repeat this year's record profits and point to California and the Northeast as signs that significant parts of the industry are still in for rough times.
On the whole, though, 1992 has been a remarkable year for most banks.
Reaping an unanticipated windfall from the lowest interest rates in decades, many of the nation's banks, large and small, have been strengthening their balance sheets. Such steps have been taken not only to avoid the wrath of the regulators, but also to take advantage of special new benefits for being strong, like lower deposit insurance premiums.
At the same time, the regulators have managed to avoid a raft of December and January failures by already taking over some of the sicker and larger institutions, including the Meritor Savings Bank of Philadelphia; the Heritage Bank for Savings in Holyoke, Mass.; the Howard Savings Bank of Newark, and the First City Bancorporation of Texas.
As a result, at latest count by both Washington officials and outside analysts, only about two dozen bank companies holding about $2.5 billion fall below the new guidelines requiring that they have shareholder capital of more than 2 percent of assets. These banks are ripe to be seized in the next few days unless they are somehow able to raise more money or persuade regulators to give them more time.
An additional 136 banks with assets of $36 billion are in the second-worst category and will require closer regulatory attention and possible seizure farther down the road, but not immediately. This is from an industry of more than 11,000 institutions holding assets of more than $3 trillion.
And regulators are revising their estimates of bank failures for 1993 and 1994. The new projections are expected to show marked improvements over earlier forecasts.
Some industry problems still lurk on the horizon, however.
Slumping real estate markets in California have shown few signs of bottoming out. The Northeast continues to suffer from economic problems like high office vacancy rates that are still taking a toll on the banks.
The number of banks, particularly large ones, on the closely watched "problem list" has been declining very slowly and still constitutes about 15 percent of the industry. Completing the savings and loan bailout will still require at least an additional $45 billion to $50 billion in new spending to shut down institutions and provide seed money for the Savings Association Insurance Fund, which protects depositors of failed institutions.
And any jump in interest rates could cause a new round of serious problems for even more profitable banks, many of which have been booking profits by buying Treasury securities whose values would plummet if rates rise.
 
Interest Rate Trap
 The concern is that the banks, by locking themselves into long-term fixed investments, could be devastated if inflation accelerates and forces them to borrow money at higher rates than their investments. That is precisely what happened to the savings and loan industry in the 1980's.
"It's impressive that the banks have the highest capital ratios since 1966, but there are still dichotomies within the industry," said Representative Jim Leach, the Iowa Republican who was recently selected ranking minority member of the House Banking Committee. "Strong banking is in inverse proportion to proximity to the coast, and to some degree, by size of institution."
He and other lawmakers expressed particular concern about any increase in the Federal deficit, which could provoke interest rates to rise and begin to take bank profits, and even some banks, down.
Mr. Hove of the F.D.I.C. said that while the regulators were closely watching the exposure of banks to swings in interest rates, he believed the industry was in no immediate danger. He said that about 1,200 banks, holding 10 percent of the industry's assets, have 20 percent or more of their investments in fixed-rate instruments of five years or longer.
"That shows those banks have a 20 percent exposure, but it also means that they do not have an exposure for the other 80 percent of their investments," he said.
He also said that because the industry would have its best year since records were compiled in the Great Depression, the $5.5 billion deficit of the bank insurance fund, which protects depositors, would doubtless improve by the end of the year.

HEADLINE: New Leader for University of Chicago

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The University of Chicago today named Hugo F. Sonnenschein, an economist and self-professed optimist who is the provost at Princeton University, as its next president.
When he takes over next July, Mr. Sonnenschein, a 52-year-old microeconomics theorist, will lead a university that in the last three years has produced three winners of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science. During that time the university has struggled through the same painful belt-tightening that has forced most major research universities to re-examine what they do. 
 "It's an enormous privilege and an enormous responsibility, and one that we look forward to," Mr. Sonnenschein said at a news conference in Ida Noyes Hall, accompanied by his wife, Elizabeth.
He will replace Hanna H. Gray, who after 15 years as president will retire at the end of June to return to teaching at Chicago. Mrs. Gray is one of the few women to lead a major university.
 
Discussions With Yale
 Last week, Nannerl O. Keohane, president of Wellesley College in Massachusetts, was named the next president of Duke University.
With the appointments of Ms. Keohane last week and Mr. Sonnenschein today, two of the four major university presidencies that were open this academic year have been filled. Columbia University and Yale University have not yet acted.
In the unusually competitive atmosphere created by the four simultaneous vacancies, search committees have felt added pressure, knowing that their top candidates were probably also being wooed by the other universities. Yale is believed to have had substantive discussions with both Mr. Sonnenschein and Ms. Keohane.
Mr. Sonnenschein refused to talk today about any contact he may have had with other universities. Howard G. Krane, chairman of the university's board, said Mr. Sonnenschein's name was the first to have been nominated after Mrs. Gray announced last April that she would resign.
"There was never a short list," Mr. Krane said. "This was our choice."
Mr. Sonnenschein's specialty in economics is equilibrium and game theory, the mathematical study of strategic behavior in social situations. He said he may teach at Chicago, adding that he looked forward to working with the university's Nobel-winning economists: Gary S. Becker, who won the Prize in 1992; Ronald H. Coase, in 1991, and Merton H. Miller, 1990. Mr. Sonnenschein said he may even join the economics department if the department approves.
He said today that despite the financial difficulties facing Chicago and other universities -- Chicago is in the second year of a faculty hiring freeze -- he believed higher education in America was heading into a promising, though difficult, future.
"This is not all bad," said Mr. Sonnenschein, who was born in Brooklyn and graduated from the University of Rochester, then received his master's and doctoral degrees from Purdue University. "The opportunity to help a great university make the choices it has to make is a challenge."
He added: "I'm optimistic for this place. I'm optimistic that institutions as fine and wonderful as the best institutions in this country really will be more appreciated in the future."
Mr. Sonnenschein taught economics at Princeton and various universities until 1988, when he became dean of the School of Arts and Sciences at the University of Pennsylvania. He returned to Princeton in 1991 as provost.
As provost, Mr. Sonnenschein was the second in command at Princeton. He also headed a strategic planning committee responsible for preparing Princeton for the 21st century.
His easygoing manner contrasts with the formal style of his predecessor at Chicago, Mrs. Gray, as much as the gentle country setting of Princeton differs from the tough streets of Chicago.
The University of Chicago is also a much larger institution with about 11,000 students, nearly twice as many as Princeton; six professional schools and a teaching hospital. Only 3,300 of Chicago's students are undergraduates, and the university is often viewed as an academic pressure cooker where extracurricular life ranks a distant second to studies.
Lori King, a fourth-year philosophy major from New York City and the editor of the student newspaper, said she took Mr. Sonnenschein's Princeton background as a hopeful sign that he will be attuned to the needs of undergraduate students.
Mr. Sonnenschein said that he was "obsessively interested in undergraduate education" and that there may be room for improvement in that area at Chicago.
When he was an 18-year-old undergraduate in danger of flunking out of the University of Rochester, he said, he spent a summer at the University of Chicago studying poetry and mathematics. He said the experience helped him get back on track.
Members of the search committee said that after 15 years under one president, they had sought someone from outside the university who might bring a fresh perspective. J. Paul Hunter, a professor of English who was chairman of a faculty advisory committee to the trustees, said Mr. Sonnenschein was "not only a unanimous choice but an enthusiastic choice."
"He explains us very well," Mr. Hunter said. "He has a knack for seeing what people are doing in fields besides his own and making others understand what's good and important about that work."
Mr. Sonnenschein will be the 11th president in the university's 101-year history.

HEADLINE: Peotone Journal;
747's May Drown Out the Sound of Corn Growing

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PEOTONE, Ill., Dec. 18

 BODY:
This neighborly village 44 miles south of Chicago seems an unlikely stage for bitter charges, billion-dollar schemes and political intrigue.
But in the last few days the town has been abuzz with talk of nasty letters mailed instead of Christmas cards, protest signs and late night telephone threats to the village president. People here cannot recall tempers ever being shorter. 
 The trouble started last month when Gov. Jim Edgar, a Republican, said the rich farmland near Peotone would be a great place for the Chicago area's third major airport.
Most of the town opposes the idea. But losing farmland is not the major issue. Losing a way of life is what frightens residents. As one woman put it, Peotone is part of a fading America.
The local newspaper prints bowling scores. A big lunch costs $5, including the tip. Children play safely outside well after dark. Neighbors still help raise barns. At night, people can see the stars. In the morning, they can hear the birds sing. The place has 3,000 people and not one traffic light.
But building a third airport has long been a dream of Illinois politicians, frightened by the sluggish economy and desperate for jobs, patronage and glory. Most recently, Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago pushed, shoved and banged his fist in an unsuccessful campaign to get the third airport built within his city.
Thwarted by Republicans in the State Legislature, Mr. Daley, a Democrat, angrily abandoned the plan. Then the Governor suggested Peotone (pronounced PEE-ah-tone and meaning "a good place to come" in the language of the Pottawatomi Indians), even though it is about an hour drive from downtown Chicago.
Pilots know Peotone as the name and location of a popular radio beacon used in navigation, but most passengers lack that familiarity. A Chicago Tribune writer took a taxi to Peotone and reported that the ride cost $60 one way.
"We love the fact that no one knows where we are located, and we wish it would stay that way," said Carol Henrichs, an opponent of the airport. "We don't want to become a suburb. We want to remain a rural community. Their plans will ruin our culture."
Over the years, Peotone has become a popular place where people from the big city settle to escape the urban frenzy and to enjoy the fresh air, the inexpensive food at "R" Place diner and the sound of silence. "It's so quiet here, you can hear the corn grow," said a farmer with good ears.
But lately anger has been growing faster than anything else.
The tension has got so thick that the village president, Richard Anderson, recently resigned in the middle of a town board meeting. He said he had been receiving threatening telephone calls and letters. Many residents complained that Mr. Anderson had not been aggressive enough in opposing the airport.
What happens next is uncertain. Mr. Daley does not support the Peotone site, largely because it is not in Chicago, and in a few days he may have more than enough influence to stop it: his younger brother, Bill, a Chicago banker, is regarded as a leading contender for the post of Secretary of Transportation in the Clinton Administration. That possibility has brought a smile to many a windswept face here.
But not everyone is against the airport, and many people believe it will eventually be built after the politicians retreat into a back room and play a few rounds of "Let's Make a Deal."
There is room for negotiation. Governor Edgar wants the airport or some other big project to generate jobs and votes. The Governor's spokesman said Mr. Edgar was willing to discuss other sites.
Mr. Daley also wants, as he says, "jobs, jobs, jobs." He is eager to have a $2 billion casino development built in Chicago, which has been struggling with budget problems, crumbling schools and rising crime. So far, the Governor has opposed the casino, but politicians rarely say never, and even less often do they mean never.
"They'll make a deal or something," a Peotone woman said as she sipped coffee at "R" Place. "We're like poker chips. What the people want and need doesn't really matter."
Most people here say that building an airport would destroy this town by pulling it into the noisy, stress-packed 1990's.
"The only thing that bugs you here is the mosquitoes," said Faye Bowers, a nurse who treats gunshot victims and crack-addicted babies in a rough Chicago suburb. "I moved to Peotone to get away from the craziness. This is like your childhood was. And I don't want to grow up."
