HEADLINE: Clinton's Aides Seek Bigger Cut In Deficit Early

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton's economic advisers are recommending that he trim the deficit more than he had proposed in the election campaign so as to fulfill his pledge of halving the deficit within four years.
Seeing that estimates of the deficit for the 1996 fiscal year have soared since last spring, Mr. Clinton's economic advisers said they had called for the deficit to be reduced by about $145 billion for that year as against the $90 billion that he originally proposed. 
 Relying on the latest estimates from the Congressional Budget Office, Mr. Clinton's advisers forecast that the deficit would be about $290 billion in 1996, far higher than the estimate of $190 billion that the budget office made last March. The advisers said today that the estimate had risen for many reasons. One is that spending on health care has increased faster than anticipated.
Mr. Clinton's economic advisers made their proposals as part of a menu of options being presented to the President-elect this weekend in Little Rock, Ark. Four of Mr. Clinton's economic advisers, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the options would include voluminous plans on the budget, trade, telecommunications, banking and manufacturing technology, converting some military factories to civilian use and building roads, bridges and other infrastructure.
 
Seeking Legislative Package
 Several Clinton advisers said his economic team is tentatively scheduled to meet with him next week to begin choosing options for a legislative package.
Noting that they and the President-elect want to signal their seriousness about cutting the deficit over the long term, the economic advisers said one option is to have certain spending cuts take effect either 18 months after Inauguration Day or when the unemployment rate falls to a certain level, perhaps 6.5 percent. Such cuts would occur over time so as not to undermine the fragile economic recovery.
The advisers would not tip their hand on details of the deficit-cutting proposals. But they said that when Mr. Clinton asked them to draft policy options, he did not ask for tax increase proposals beyond those he suggested in the campaign, notably higher income taxes on people earning more than $200,000 a year. Many economists say it will be almost impossible to cut the deficit in half without more tax increases.
Mr. Clinton's advisers are said to be leaning in favor of a small, temporary increase in deficit spending to speed economic growth and create jobs. But Mr. Clinton said after this week's economic conference in Little Rock that he had not made up his mind on such stimulus.
Any such plan would probably include increased public works spending and tax credits for investment in business equipment, his advisers said. They said Mr. Clinton might ask that a plan to spur the economy be prepared in order to have it available in case employment growth faltered.
 
Deficit Spending Considered
 One option being proposed is to carry out the four-year $220 billion Government investment program that Mr. Clinton called for in his campaign but to delay tax increases and spending cuts that had been planned to finance such spending. Economists say the resulting deficit spending would give the economy a boost.
Several Clinton advisers acknowledged that he had been too optimistic in saying he would raise $45 billion over four years by collecting more taxes from foreign corporations, suggesting he might not even be able to collect half that amount. The options present additional deficit cuts to offset that shortfall, they said.
One option presented to Mr. Clinton, aides said, was increasing the minimum wage and the earned income tax credit to make sure that full-time workers do not live below the poverty line. Another option is to adopt a new budgeting system that would use an operating budget and a separate capital or investment budget.

HEADLINE: The Day the Ocean Came And Swept All Before It

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONG BEACH, L.I., Dec. 17

 BODY:
Danny Vooris saved the family cat, his Led Zeppelin record collection and most of his lizards from the water that rushed into his basement apartment here the morning of Dec. 11. But in the week since then, that, like the linoleum floor he has slept on, has been pretty cold comfort.
Almost all his possessions were destroyed. His wife had a nervous breakdown and was hospitalized. His 3-year-old son still follows him around, afraid that his father might be swept away. And, while vacuuming up the water that drained from his walls all week, he wondered again and again how, with Christmas looming, he would keep ahead of his many creditors and whether a Federal disaster declaration would rescue him. 
 "We got killed," said Mr. Vooris, a 29-year-old sanitation worker in Long Beach, as he recalled the driving rain and 90-mile-an-hour gusts that without warning caused the Atlantic Ocean, for the first time in his life, to swallow vast portions of the slender island where he grew up.
The only help from any relief agency the family has received so far, he said, was a box of canned chili beans and some baby food.
On the other side of Long Island, several rungs further up the economic ladder, Richard and Joanna Nabet spent the week drying out the two-story house they built 11 years ago in Bayville. They had had the foundation sealed, but that was no defense against the water that squeezed through the windowsills and filled the basement to a depth of four feet. "That gurgling," recalled Mrs. Nabet with a shudder, "the sound water makes as it comes through the walls."
In the week since the wind, the rain and the moon conspired to put their homes below sea level, families throughout the region have struggled to evict the ocean, salvage what they can and start again. How many people are badly hurting is still unknown. Though the Red Cross estimates that almost 20,000 homes were damaged during the storm, the extent of the ruin for individual families remains unclear.
 
A Painful Process
 But the experiences of the Vooris and Nabet families are no doubt being shared by thousands of others, and they show that for people who were hit hard, cleaning up has been a painstaking and painful process, one that will not end with President Bush's expected announcement of disaster relief for New York. Long after their plight slips out of the public eye, these families will still be wrestling to reorder lives that the nameless storm -- just a nasty December rain to many of their friends and neighbors -- so carelessly swept up and tossed about.
The Nabets got rid of all the water by Monday and began hosing down the walls to remove the muck and the smell of sewage from their backed-up septic system. In their newly remodeled basement, the walls, furniture and appliances in their children's rooms, the laundry room and the den were wrecked, as were the tools Mr. Nabet, a retired policeman, uses in his floor-refinishing business. They had no flood insurance to cover the damage, which they estimate at $75,000 to $100,000. Today, a pile of sodden mattresses, warped cabinets and a sofa sat by the curb.
"I kind of lost it a couple of times," said Mr. Nabet, 47, as he described a week spent mostly without electricity and entirely without gas or neighbors, all of whom fled for shelter elsewhere. "It's a hopeless feeling."
Part of the problem, Mr. Nabet said, was that many people did not seem to realize how much he and his neighbors have suffered since Long Island Sound and Oyster Bay rushed each other down his narrow street.
"You know, they say, 'You had no electricity or gas?' " he said. "We almost had no house."
 
'Like a War Zone'
 Mr. Nabet says the sudden gap between him and other residents of Bayville strikes him forcefully when he drives up a hill in the small, tidy town and sees nothing more unusual than Christmas lights. "Then I come back here and it's like a war zone," he said. The Red Cross set up a service center in town on Thursday, and Mrs. Nabet plans to visit in hopes of getting clothes and certificates for food at a local grocery store. Once a Federal disaster is declared, the Nabets plan to apply for low-interest loans to rebuild their home and business.
The week did have a positive side. There was the restraint displayed by the family dog, J.D., who waited 30 hours before Mr. Nabet could get him into a rowboat and push him to dry ground. "He was so happy to get to that little patch of dry land," Mr. Nabet said.
And there was the determination displayed by Richard Nabet, 21, who walked two and a half miles across flooded land, at times wading through freezing water chest deep, to reach his parents.
"You have to look at what you didn't lose," said Mrs. Nabet, 44. "We didn't lose life. We lost a lot, but we still have a lot."
 
Mention Brings Tears
 The only life the Vooris family lost was Mr. Vooris's favorite lizard. But they do not have much else left. Veronica Vooris, 24, returned from the hospital Wednesday. She still breaks into tears at the mention of the flood. "It's a nightmare," she said, beginning to tremble. "I've got nothing."
"Please, baby," Mr. Vooris pleaded. "You've got to be calm."
For Mrs. Vooris, the worst moment came when Danny Jr., having been carried out of the apartment to safety, raced back down the steps to find his parents, still inside, and fell into the swirling water. "I couldn't get the door open," his mother said. "He almost drowned."
The family's new plastic Christmas tree was destroyed, along with the children's toys, the television set and video-cassette recorder, Mr. Vooris's guitars and everyone's clothes. Because Mr. Vooris heard that children get 85 percent of their education at home, the couple recently bought a set of educational books and tapes for $1,565 through the school their 6-year-old daughter, Vanessa, attends. The tapes are destroyed, the dozens of volumes of the "New Book of Knowledge" still waterlogged. They have paid only one installment and the company recently called to demand the next.
Before the flood, Mr. Vooris borrowed $500 from his credit union to make repairs on his 1975 Cutlass, which, like scores of other cars in Long Beach, was swamped and probably destroyed by the flood. He cannot borrow more for at least six months, he said, and his credit is not good enough to get him a bank loan.
The Voorises said they had heard that if a disaster is declared they might qualify for an emergency grant. But they had no idea how to get such help. "When are they going to announce it?" Mrs. Vooris asked. "Where will I go to apply?"
The family rents their small apartment from Mrs. Vooris's parents, who charge them $700 a month for rent and utilities, and they say they cannot afford to move elsewhere. Mrs. Vooris's parents have given them new socks, sweatclothes and underwear, and other friends have pitched in.
This afternoon, a burly man in a blue sanitation uniform knocked on the door and Mr. Vooris stepped outside to talk. He returned with a big grin and a plastic bag full of toys.
"The guys on the job went out and got them this," he said. "I said, 'Wrap them up for Christmas?' He said, 'No, they need them now.' "
 
Sharing the Slingshot
 Danny Jr. seized the slingshot with a passion that portended much trouble to come, while Vanessa sat on the floor, stacking up the Barbie doll and toy microphone. "We're going to have to share this," she told her brother solemnly.
Christmas weighs heavily on Mr. and Mrs. Vooris. "We won't have that little pretty Christmas setting, with the little tree with the toys under it," Mrs. Vooris said, the tears beginning again. Her husband disagreed.
"My kids are going to have Christmas," he said grimly. "That's the bottom line."
The Nabets are planning to spend Christmas with relatives who have a dry home. Although the evergreen they chopped down in the woods was floating in salt water last weekend, by today it appeared to have recovered.
"We'll have a nice Christmas," Mr. Nabet said. "One we'll never forget, that's for sure."
"I'm putting that tree up," Mrs. Nabet said. "Come hell or high water."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Quiet Session; Gold Shows Some Losses

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar moved higher yesterday in what traders described as a quiet holiday-season session, with many market participants closing their trading accounts for the year.
Gold prices were lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fell $1.50, to $336.90 an ounce. The late bid at the Republic National Bank in New York priced gold at $337.00, off $1.20. 
 There were no new economic reports or significant international developments to inspire a sharp move in the currency markets, several traders said. One dealer described a very quiet session, with some participants leaving the trading desk for midafternoon Christmas shopping.
"There are very few players in the market at year-end," said Curtis Perkins, a currency dealer with Chemical Bank. "Most people are protecting what they made in the turbulent September period, and they do not want to give anything back."
Mr. Perkins referred to the wildly volatile currency dealings in the fall, which occurred as Germany refused to cut interest rates and leading currencies, like the British pound, came under tremendous selling pressure.
Among the currencies that lost strength to the dollar yesterday was the French franc, which had been under speculative pressure in recent days.
Andrew Hodge, vice president of Bank Brussels Lambert, said the franc had been getting support from intervention in the market from German monetary officials.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 5.3435 French francs, up from 5.3245 late Thursday. That was after the franc dropped in Europe, with the dollar quoted at 5.3445 French francs, up from 5.3390 late Thursday.
Elsewhere, the dollar closed at 123.05 yen in Tokyo, down 0.07 yen from Thursday's close. But it rose later in London to 123.25 yen. At the closing in New York, the dollar was quoted at 123.18 yen, up from 122.74 yen late Thursday.
The British pound fell to $1.5650 in London, from $1.5730 late Thursday. In New York, the pound was quoted at $1.5665, down from $1.5780.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5645 German marks, up from 1.5575; 1.4090 Swiss francs, up from 1.3995; 1,406 Italian lire, up from 1,404.50, and 1.27525 Canadian dollars, up from 1.27345.
In Europe, the dollar's closing rates, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.5660 German marks, up from 1.5625; 1.4115 Swiss francs, up from 1.4025; 1.7600 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7565; 1,407.75 Italian lire, up from 1,403.00, and 1.2750 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2739.
Gold traded late in London at $337.05 an ounce, down from $338.30 late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid was $336.80, down from $338.25.

HEADLINE: Leaders Urge Trade Accord

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
President Bush, Prime Minister John Major of Britain and Jacques Delors, the president of the European Community's executive commission, called today for a global free trade agreement by mid-January.
But negotiators in the 108-nation talks remain far apart on a wide range of issues, and some American officials doubted today that a deal could be struck before the inauguration of Bill Clinton on Jan. 20. 
 "Some negotiators are privately gloomy, but you have to keep trying," said an American official who insisted on anonymity.
The comments by the three leaders nonetheless represented an unusually strong declaration of support for negotiations after years of more vague comments by heads of state. "We agreed that a sound Uruguay Round agreement is essential to boost worldwide economic growth, and we all agreed to conclude the GATT agreement in Geneva by mid-January," Mr. Bush said at the White House today after talking to Mr. Major and Mr. Delors.
Mr. Major flew here this morning after meeting with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada in Ottawa on Thursday, and he is scheduled to fly back to Britain on Sunday evening after spending the weekend with President Bush at his retreat at Camp David, Md. Conspicuously absent from his schedule of meetings was President-elect Clinton, although the two men spoke today by telephone.
Mr. Major supported Mr. Bush during the election campaign. But the British official insisted this evening that the two men did not meet on this trip only because Mr. Clinton had not yet finished developing his foreign policy positions.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Good for G.M., but Bad For Buyers of Its Offer

BYLINE: By Susan Antilla

 BODY:
MANAGERS at General Motors may not be rocket scientists when it comes to running a car company, but investors could pick up a few tips from them on the arcane subject of stock market timing.
G.M. was a seller of 55 million new common shares on May 19 -- a marketing coup that brought $2.1 billion in new funds to the company. A master of timing, G.M. pulled in $39 for each of the 55 million new shares. And the stock had traded as low as $26.88 only five months before. 
 By yesterday's close, though, G.M. had declined 15 percent from the offering price, ending the day at $33.125. For investors who bought during the post-offering euphoria and brokerage-firm recommendations that took shares up to $44, yesterday's close represented a 25 percent loss.
Publicly held companies are entirely justified, of course, in orchestrating their stock sales to take place at times when investors are particularly willing to buy. The stock market had been hitting a string of new highs when G.M. said in April that it would float a record $2.15 billion of new shares -- far greater than the previous record $1.46 billion stock offering of Conrail in 1987. It made sense for the troubled auto maker to put more securities into the market at a time when investors' appetites were healthy.
But did it make sense for investors? Not really. "The hype around G.M. was that the economy was coming around, and people weren't looking at the firm very closely and got pulled in," said John Markese, director of research at the American Association of Individual Investors. "And a secondary offering means more shares out there driving prices down eventually."
Yet in the headiness of grand promises of a new improved General Motors investors bought in anyway. As it turns out, history's largest-ever offering of stock makes for some good lessons in avoiding potential dogs.
To understand part of the reason why G.M. shares rallied, then fizzled, after the May offering, it helps to know how Wall Street peddles stock of wobbly companies. And stocks of healthy companies, for that matter.
In G.M.'s case, the auto maker had racked up a record $4.5 billion loss in 1991. The company's recurring promises of a new, improved, lean-and-mean G.M. sounded increasingly hollow. G.M. stock was trading at a fraction of its high of $56.875, reached in 1965.
Yet the nation's brokerage houses managed to peddle more than $2 billion of new G.M. shares last spring. The magic was in part a function of a quid pro quo of stock offerings that institutional investors say was at work in G.M.'s case: The customer agrees to buy into so-so offerings, and the issuer makes sure to include them next time there's a hot deal.
Other quirks of the financial world helped sell the offering, too. Institutional investors and other potential buyers of G.M. stock frequently owe a chit to brokerage firms that are part of the syndicate selling the stock. So institutions sometimes buy into new issues in order to let the brokerage house get the commission built into the offering price, settling a debt in the process.
Investors don't get lots of critical analysis about new issues like G.M.'s because analysts can't pontificate on the merits of a stock when the firm that employs them is part of the selling group of a new offering. The Securities and Exchange Commission tells brokerage houses that analysts are basically gagged from discussing a stock if the firm is going to profit from selling new shares. The idea: to minimize hyping of stocks that might inflate the price. The reality: investors who think analysts have something to contribute to their investment decisions don't get analyst feedback when they need it most.
Not that investors were necessarily deprived of sage advice. With gag orders off after the secondary issue was successfully completed, Dean Witter's auto analyst upgraded G.M. to a "buy" on June 3, when the stock was at $41.75. (The firm had downgraded G.M. on March 20, when the stock was at $39.13). Paine Webber added G.M. to its key "focus List" June 11 when the stock was at $43 -- within one point of its 52-week high. By Sept. 28, when G.M. closed at $32, Dean Witter downgraded G.M. -- a tad late for those who bought on Witter's advice at $41.75.
And Morgan Stanley, the biggest winner of fees on the G.M. deal as "lead" in the syndicate, bit the bullet on Sept. 23 and slashed G.M.'s earnings estimates for 1993 to $3.35 a share from $4.25. Morgan's $4.25 estimate far exceeded the average brokerage firm estimate at the time, which was $2.46 a share, according to Institutional Brokers Estimate System, which tracks earnings estimates.
Morgan is still among six stalwart firms with a "buy" rating on G.M., according to Zachs Investment Research, which also keeps tabs on analyst ratings and earnings estimates. The Wall Street count on G.M. today: Nine firms say to "hold" the stock -- a euphemism for running for the hills. Seven call it a "buy-hold," which is a lukewarm recommendation at best. And six say "buy."
Logic would have dictated that the selling of more than $2 billion of new G.M. shares would have been impossible given the company's black eyes last spring. Yet the impossible happened, and a number of investors are a little poorer as a result.
Instinct kept members of the National Association of Investment Clubs away from G.M. this year, said Tom O'Hara, director of the group. G.M. is only the 63d most popular stock owned by the club members, who "really look at the numbers," and apparently weren't impressed.
But other investors, perhaps caught up in the hopes that a one-time American institution might finally turn around, couldn't resist.
"The old cliche is true," said Laszlo Birinyi of Birinyi Associates, a research firm. "Stocks are sold, not bought."

HEADLINE: Dairy Wars: A Pitch to Local Pride;
Ad Agency Fires a Protectionist Broadside on Behalf of L.I.

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST NORTHPORT, L.I., Dec. 18

 BODY:
In the latest twist in the border wars between New York and New Jersey, a small Long Island dairy has begun an advertising campaign that features a cow grazing contentedly on the asphalt in front of a petrochemical plant.
"Ever wonder why milk from New Jersey doesn't taste as fresh as ours?" the ad asks in bold black type. 
 The tongue-in-cheek campaign, which began this week in a weekly newspaper on the East End, touts the supposed advantages of milk that does not have to travel the extra hours on the bumpy highways from New Jersey to the Island.
But one basic fact is left out: none of the Long Island dairy's milk comes from Long Island cows.
 
No More Cows
 Oak Tree Farm Dairy, a family-run business here, has pasteurized, homogenized and distributed milk around Long Island for 50 years. Cows once grazed on its 37-acre property, but in the 1950's, the Cosman family, the dairy's owner, moved them upstate. Now, it trucks 18,000 gallons of milk daily from farms near Syracuse to the company's Long Island plant, where it is processed.
The absence of Long Island cows, however, has not stopped Oak Tree from firing a protectionist broadside intended to appeal to Long Island milk drinkers' local pride.
"There's a very strong sense of loyalty to 'buying Long Island,' and we want to capitalize on it," said Charlene Cosman, the dairy's chief financial officer. "People like the idea of keeping other Long Islanders working."
Miss Cosman also insisted that her company's milk was fresher and thus tasted better than her competitors' milk. Other dairies disagreed, and dairy experts were skeptical.
The campaign arrives amid heightened tension between New Jersey and New York. A few weeks ago, Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey announced a plan to lure away New York businesses. More recently, New York announced efforts to crack down on shoppers who cross the Hudson River to try to avoid New York's higher sales tax.
Dweck & Campbell, the Manhattan advertising agency that created the campaign, said it began work on it months before the border war began, but that it was pleased with the timing.
The ad is running in Dan's Paper, a free weekly that says it reaches 83,000 readers on the East End and in New York City. The agency plans to expand to other newspapers and is considering radio and television.
It is unclear whether the ad has had any impact or whether Long Islanders care where their milk comes from.
 
'From New Jersey?'
 At a Pathmark supermarket in Commack this afternoon, a few miles from the dairy, six customers picked up store-label milk and cream, under a hand-lettered sign saying they were from Tuscan Farms in Union, N.J. None were aware of the products' origins, but when asked whether they had a preference between New Jersey milk and Long Island milk, it was like asking Marines whether they loved the flag.
"This is from New Jersey?" asked Joe O'Connor, a retired construction worker from Smithtown. "Where can I get Long Island milk? I want to keep my money here."
Joan Ciliotta, a nurse from Fort Salonga, said she thought that Long Island milk might be fresher, but she said that would not affect what she bought. "I buy milk where it's convenient," she said.
Miss Cosman is banking on the idea that Long Islanders, hit hard by the current recession, will feel strongly about standing by one of their own.
Her father established the dairy in 1941, when there was, she said, a "dairy every 250 feet." Today, all three Cosman children work there.
The number of dairies on the Island has dwindled from more than 12 in the 1960's to 2 a few years ago. Oak Tree became the last when the other was bought by a group that wanted to convert the land into a polo field.
Miss Cosman said Oak Tree milk is sold in 500 convenience stores, groceries and delicatessens on Long Island. She declined to provide sales figures or information about profits.
Until five years ago, ads like Oak Tree's would have been unneeded, because New York law barred milk from out of state. Now, most of the milk sold on Long Island is processed elsewhere, much of it by two New Jersey companies: Tuscan Farms and Farmland Dairies in Wallington.
Miss Cosman said the ads simply highlight better quality. From the time the milk is homogenized and pasteurized, Oak Tree gets it into the stores faster, particularly on the East End, she said.
The ad states: "New Jersey milk must travel more miles than our milk to get to you. Plus it has to spend time near the New Jersey Turnpike, an activity that has never improved anything."
Not surprisingly, dairy executives in New Jersey are miffed.
"Since when is the Jersey Turnpike any worse than the Long Island Expressway?" said Colin Kagel, vice president of administration for Tuscan Farms. He added: "I was born in New York and raised in Long Island. I have nothing against Long Island. But we're all getting our milk from the same cows."
Asked to respond to the ad, David Bandler, a food science professor specializing in the dairy industry at Cornell University, said he was "hesitant" to become embroiled in the dispute. "This is not science," he said. "It is merchandising or whatever you want to call it."
"The milk from New Jersey, the milk from Pennsylvania, the milk from New York all meets the same requirements of the Pasteurized Milk Ordinance of the United States Public Health Service," he said.
Michael Dweck, president of Dweck & Campbell, said his agency's strategy was to run eye-catching ads that would provoke an outraged response. Asked if he was concerned about misleading consumers, Mr. Dweck said it was "intentional exaggeration" and was "not meant to be taken seriously."
The controversy is to some degree calculated. This is Oak Tree's first campaign, Mr. Dweck said, and its $500,000 advertising budget is not enough to establish a strong brand identity with straight product advertising.
The agency has scheduled a second ad for Dec. 31 that makes the first one look mild. It shows a cow with three eyes in front of the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant. the ad starts, "What is it about milk from Pennsylvania that gives us a bad feeling?"
Mr. Dweck said that he had been brainstorming for weeks on an ad impugning Connecticut. "The problem," he said with a sigh, "is that it's hard to find something bad to say about Connecticut."
"With New Jersey," he said, "it took about three and a half seconds."

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Times

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The Los Angeles Times published its last San Diego County edition today. The Times announced on Nov. 6 that it would end the edition because of the recession in California and because the newspaper wanted to strengthen its editions closer to Los Angeles. HEADLINE: Wedding Bells, Dotted Lines

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
Marc Wein owned a prospering video production studio, a co-op in Manhattan and a vacation home on Shelter Island by the time he was planning to be remarried. And he was anxious to avoid a bitter fight over the rights to those assets if his second marriage also ended in divorce.
So several months before the wedding he told his bride-to-be about his concerns. That forced her to think about her own situation. "It made me realize I had money of my own I wanted to protect," Melina Wein said. 
 With the help of lawyers they drew up a prenuptial agreement assuring them that if either felt it had all been a mistake they could "back out without any heavy legal bills or hard feelings," as Mr. Wein put it.
 
Pitfalls to Avoid
 But does it really work as smoothly as all that? Not necessarily. Prenuptial agreements, which are normally drawn up and negotiated by lawyers specializing in family law, have been available since around 1980. They came into vogue as a result of changes in divorce law -- termed equitable distribution in some states and community property in others -- that made it far less clear who would end up with what if a couple separated.
At the time, lawyers recall, these contracts were often only five pages long and many cost less than $1,000. In line with feminist concerns rising at the time, the agreements addressed life style issues like the division of household duties as well as finances. And they were considered above challenge.
Not so today. As a result of successful legal challenges, prenuptial agreements are almost exclusively financial documents. They have grown longer and more complex -- some are more than 40 pages in length -- and they now include comprehensive financial statements and stipulations on the disposition of joint assets.
As a result, they are becoming increasingly expensive. "Some are costing as much as $25,000," said Barbara Ellen Handschu, past chairman of the family law section of the New York State Bar Association. However, the average is more likely to be closer to $2,000.
Moreover, because so many have been thrown out or modified by the courts -- after accusations by one of the parties of coercion -- many lawyers are questioning whether they are worth the time and expense.
"We can no longer say with certainty that any one of them will be impervious to attack," said Arthur E. Balbirer, president of the American Academy of Matrimonial Lawyers. Instead, he calls them "smoldering bombs" that become just another contentious issue to be haggled over when a rift occurs, as Donald J. Trump found when his marriage to Ivana Trump was breaking up. "I haven't found that they make breaking up any smoother," Mr. Balbirer said.
Mr. Balbirer argues that an about-to-be-married couple never really allows its lawyers the kind of probing and bargaining needed to draw up a truly "arm's length" agreement -- one that is also based upon full financial disclosure. This is a serious problem, he said, that eventually weakens the validity of many contracts.
For this reason some lawyers may now refuse to draw up a prenuptial agreement and they certainly will refuse if a couple arrive on the doorstep only a few days before the wedding ceremony. "We would tell them it's too late," warned Stephen Gassman, chairman of the family law section of the New York State Bar Association. Under the circumstances, he noted, the document could too easily be tainted with charges of duress.
Yet just as case law is turning these documents into Swiss cheese, pressure to draw them up is on the rise. Anyone in a business partnership, with an interest in a family business or who has children by a previous marriage, may be under great pressure to get one.
Discussions should start before a wedding date is set. If third-party pressure is involved, so much the easier. "If you can say it's because of someone else," said Dr. Donald Bloch, a Manhattan psychiatrist who specializes in the emotional impact of economic issues facing families, "it looks less like you don't trust each other." But, he warned, the agreement should never be forced on the other party because eventually it will embitter the relationship.
 
What They Should Cover
 A good prenuptial agreement should cover estate rights, support rights and the ownership and disposition of existing and future property, said Amy Reiss, a lawyer specializing in marital law with Morrison Cohen Singer & Weinstein in New York City. And the couple must be prepared to bare their financial souls and hire their own lawyers independently.
Since prenuptials are based primarily on hypothetical situations, percentages should be used rather than dollar figures. Mechanisms and time frames for the liquidation of assets are also necessary if the contract is to work, lawyers say.
There is also a growing interest in "sunset" clauses or rights to renegotiation because the way a couple feels about dividing assets may differ after a marriage results in children or has lasted several years.
The Weins, for example, arranged for their contract to cease after three years or the birth of a child. Their son, Everest, is now 4 months old, and they are more confident of each other.
"But I'm still glad we had it at the beginning," Mr. Wein said. "I think we both felt less threatened."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
DIGITAL EQUIPMENT IS CLOSING PLANT IN BOSTON

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that it would close its cable manufacturing plant in the Roxbury section of Boston and put 190 people out of work. The company, which has been trimming manufacturing capacity as part of a plan to eliminate redundancies and divest itself of non-core businesses, said it would phase out the Roxbury operations over three or four months. The plant is expected to be closed by April, the computer company said. In a statement, Edward B. McDonough, Digital's vice president, manufacturing and logistics, said the company had decided to buy cable equipment from outside vendors.

HEADLINE: The World's Poor Need Bill Clinton

 BODY:
Thirty-four nations, including the United States, agreed this week to continue the current pace of multilateral aid to the world's poorest nations through the International Development Association. Their three-year pledge of $18 billion was an encouraging sign of unflagging commitment by the nations that are better off, despite widespread recession and budget deficits.
In real terms, the new pledge is roughly equal to the last one, in 1989, but in effect it works out to a little less. Expanding populations and environmental protection stretch aid funds thinner; also, more governments, including the former Soviet republics, are likely to be seeking I.D.A. aid. 
 The agency's loans are interest-free, and borrowers have 35 to 40 years to repay, with a 10-year grace period to start. To qualify for a loan in recent years a country's per capita income had to be less than $765 a year, or barely $2 a day. Sad to say, more than 60 currently qualify. But it is a mark of progress that two countries that once received aid are now among the 34 donors.
The United States is still the largest donor, but barely; in the new agreement, its share shrinks to 20.85 percent while Japan's rises to 20 percent. Actually, Washington will be putting up a half-billion dollars more than last time -- $3.75 billion over the coming three years -- but that works out to a smaller share because the dollar's value is down. Switzerland, Japan, the Netherlands, Sweden, Korea, Mexico and Ireland helped the most to make up the difference.
The U.S. pledge itself needs affirmation by Congress, which is usually tight with foreign aid funds and may be tighter next year when the focus is on curing domestic ills. Honoring this commitment to the world's desperately poor will be an early test of Mr. Clinton's leadership.

HEADLINE: BILL'S LIST;
Crime Control, City by City

SERIES: Bill's List

BYLINE: By Stephen Goldsmith and Kurt L. Schmoke; Stephen Goldsmith, a Republican, is Mayor of Indianapolis. Kurt L. Schmoke, a Democrat, is Mayor of Baltimore.

 BODY:
When Bill Clinton took his celebrated walk along Washington's violence- and drug-plagued Georgia Avenue, he had his eye on the long term.
What such neighborhoods need, he said, is economic development. Look to his Administration, he promised, to revitalize the Small Business Administration. An unidentified spectator had a more immediate perspective on the impact of his appearance. "It sure got the drug dealers and winos off the corner," he said. 
 There was insight in both comments -- insight that the new President and new Congress should heed. With the flames of Los Angeles still in memory, with a tidal wave of drugs and violence washing over our cities -- with gunshots literally within earshot of the Capitol -- the nation cannot escape seeing how tired, rote and unproductive the Federal debate about crime has become.
As former prosecutors and current mayors, we know crime and its effect on our cities. We know how disturbed we and many fellow mayors were when this year's Federal crime bill fell victim to partisan conflicts over issues like the death penalty, gun control and death-row appeals.
We know how deeply our cities -- all cities -- hope for Federal help in preventing crime. And we believe America needs a new Federal perspective and role if that hope is to be realized. For decades, the debate about controlling crime and improving conditions in crime-ridden cities has been dominated by two apparently incompatible positions. The "law and order" view holds that crime and the fear of it result from too many criminals and insufficient criminal justice. The advocates of the get-tough approach call for more police, stricter punishment and more prisons. By contrast, the "root causes" thesis argues that crime and fear result from systematic disadvantage, prejudice and neglect. This theory's champions urge economic development, training, education and public investment in poor communities.
The first position argues that crime must be controlled before community life can improve; the second, that community life must improve before crime can be controlled. The polarization of these views has brought paralysis to public policy and near-despair to our cities. Neither idea has won the public's heart and mind. And neither holds immediate promise for ruined neighborhoods.
Few people truly believe that either alone offers salvation. We believe that both views are true and that neither can proceed far without the other. As former prosecutors, we know the power of the police, courts and prisons to combat crime, fight fear and support the community. As mayors, we know the power of the schools, public health system, social services, public investment and policy to help create better lives.
We believe that only when both approaches are pursued together will there be hope.
In cities nationwide, largely unheralded local initiatives are providing reason for hope. Baltimore's Sandtown section, one of the city's worst areas, is a promising example. The city government and Sandtown residents sat down and designed a plan to reclaim the neighborhood. Residents' relations with the police improved, and their work together helped suppress the drug trade. New housing, built with Federal support, improved the quality of life: city-brokered agreements with the housing contractors insured that Sandtown residents got construction jobs and on-the-job training. City services such as roadwork and family counseling were adjusted in accordance with the community's sense of its own needs. The struggle continues, but Sandtown's crime rate has leveled off, and where the city has been most active the streets are safer.
Experiences similar to Sandtown's in other cities seem to share four elements.
First, rather than using one-size-fits-all solutions, participants have custom-designed solutions to local problems. In Sandtown, a turning point in addressing street disorder turned out to be shutting down a troublesome liquor store.
Second, the communities themselves, so often left out, were given power over their own fates; residents, not just the police and governments, helped define problems and develop and carry out solutions. In Tampa, Fla., the public made it clear that it was less concerned about drugs than about the disorder caused by blatant street sales of them. The police, working with the residents, largely put an end to the sales.
Third, the efforts were partnerships, with the police, other parts of government and the public pooling expertise and resources. In Houston, residents around Link Valley, a neighborhood blighted by cocaine dealing, developed an arrangement under which the police provided security and the residents organized a huge cleanup; the residents then worked with landlords and officials to make vacant buildings secure and found developers to invest in the newly attractive area.
Fourth, crime control was pursued not only through law enforcement but through various measures aimed at preventing crime and fighting fear. In Los Angeles's gang- and drug-plagued Wilshire neighborhood, the police, residents and the city hauled away abandoned cars, painted out graffiti, fixed street lights and then built effective partnerships to fight gang crime.
There are two very important ways in which the Clinton Administration and Congress, soon to be under one-party control, can help mayors develop local solutions.
Washington administers and finances thousands of programs in law enforcement, housing, health, education, job training, social services, drug prevention and treatment, and youth and family services. Looked at together, this wealth of resources needs to be yoked to a strategic plan.
Thus, Washington should make it easy to organize Federal resources in conjunction with local plans, perhaps by offering waivers from program rules and setting up a liaison office to coordinate the Federal side of such plans. It could also, at a modest cost, provide seed money for Sandtown-like experiments, study the results and furnish advice and technical support to other communities.
Second, the failed crime bill included many noncontroversial items of immediate importance, particularly financing for new prison space, aid to local enforcement and tougher sentences for repeat violent offenders.
Congress and Mr. Clinton should make prompt passage of those portions of the bill a top priority.

HEADLINE: New Work Corps Could Change People's Lives

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Having interviewed veterans of the 1930's Civilian Conservation Corps in the last decade, I believe they would greet Stephen E. Ambrose's proposal in "Revive Roosevelt's C.C.C." (Op-Ed, Nov. 28) with mixed skepticism and enthusiasm. 
 Moralists among them believe that it would shape up and give a new positive toughness to young "druggie" "street people." Others feel that the ready availability of alcohol, drugs and automobiles would make it impossible to maintain the tight discipline necessary. Some think today's projects and workers would require prohibitively expensive chain saws, safety equipment, liability insurance, skidders and other power equipment, where axes, saws and shovels sufficed in the 30's.
Negatives notwithstanding, those who served six decades ago are virtually unanimous in wishing that the C.C.C. could be successfully revived, so that some of this generation of young adults would be able to tell their progeny: "That was the turning point of my life," "It just put a whole new outlook on life," "You learned how to get along with people."
One infantry-trained camp commanding officer would insist the program be run by the military, for "if they give it to a civilian organization, God help us."
 
DAVID D. DRAVES
Durham, N.H., Dec. 3, 1992
 
The writer is author of "Builder of Men: Life in C.C.C. Camps of New Hampshire" (1992).

HEADLINE: Patent System Protects Inventor Better

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Prof. Michael Davis's description of me as a "patent terrorist" in "Why a Single Court for Patents Isn't Enough" (letter, Nov. 28), and his attack on the patent court system, obscures my contributions to technological innovation, while it ignores the real issues in the debate, which include protecting the rights of the inventor and patent owner. 
 In a career spanning more than 30 years, I have received in excess of 500 patents and have licensed many of my patents to large and small corporations throughout the world. In the process of licensing such inventions as the automatic warehousing system and the industrial robot, I have witnessed the lack of respect that most corporation managers have for the independent inventor.
Although many corporations have profited handsomely from the limited monopolies that are granted them by the patent system, they are all too often willing to use patents owned by inventors without paying for them. Many of these same corporations have licensed their patents to whole industries without being called patent terrorists. Certain of these same corporations have refused to honor my patent rights or even to negotiate with me.
The United States patent system was conceived by our Founding Fathers as an incentive for all our citizens to devote their time, energy and money to inventing products and processes. In Jefferson's time, the independent inventor was the source of most technological innovation. In the modern era, however, independent inventors with significant contributions to technological innovation and to our economy have found it increasingly difficult to protect their intellectual property rights.
Before the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit was established by Congress in 1982, the inventor and small-business man found it almost impossible to protect their patent rights. The patent game functioned to the advantage of large corporations with significant financial resources. The independent inventor, by comparison, had at best a one-in-six chance of upholding his patent rights in court.
What Professor Davis perceives as a pro-patent policy by the Circuit Court of Appeals is but the court's interpretation of our patent laws in a uniform, even-handed manner. Donald Banner, former Commissioner of Patents, referred to the previous inconsistent treatment of patents before the establishment of the court as a "cruel hoax" against the inventor.
I believe that going back to the previous system, as Professor Davis suggests, would constitute a policy of bad innovation, reduce the incentive of many Americans to invent and perpetuate a gross injustice against the independent inventor and small-business man.
 
JEROME LEMELSON
Incline Village, Nev., Dec. 5, 1992

HEADLINE: New Work Corps Could Change People's Lives;
Include Human Services

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The infrastructures and environment of our country can be helped by such a corps as Stephen E. Ambrose suggests in "Revive Roosevelt's C.C.C." (Op-Ed, Nov. 28). In addition, the new Administration should not overlook human services as an area for such workers. 
 The City Volunteer Corps in New York City has in eight years revitalized the most precious resource of an urban area, its youth. A recent study of several hundred young people who participated in the program shows gains in self-esteem, continuing education and employment productivity. Participants have had the satisfaction of knowing they do make a difference in the lives of others. Compassion, understanding, tolerance and charity are the human values they learn, far exceeding any lesson that can be taught in a classroom.
A national service program could include after-school tutorial classes, recreational and leisure participation for the young and assisting the elderly.
 
(Rev.) JOHN E. LAZAR
Brooklyn, Dec. 2, 1992
 
The writer is a member of the board of the City Volunteer Corps.

HEADLINE: New Work Corps Could Change People's Lives;
California-Style

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Stephen Ambrose's suggestion to create a 1990's version of the Civilian Conservation Corps (Op-Ed, Nov. 28) certainly caught our attention. The California Conservation Corps, modeled after the Depression-era, program has been going strong for more than 16 years, and there are other corps programs in this state and many other states. 
 Youth corps are not about make-work. Our modern-day C.C.C. has tackled more than 35 million hours of natural resource work in California. But there is something beyond building parks, planting trees and fighting fires. Many of our youth are in crisis, and as Mr. Ambrose points out, missing the rewards that discipline and hard work can provide. In a youth corps, young people boost their skills and their self-esteem. For many, the sense of empowerment they develop changes their entire lives.
We believe the C.C.C. ideals are more than a concept. From our experience, there is no reason such programs could not make a significant impact in other metropolitan areas, as well as rural regions throughout the country.
 
R. A. BERNHEIMER
Interim Director
California Conservation Corps
Sacramento, Calif., Dec. 11, 1992

HEADLINE: Trapped In the Baltics

BYLINE: By Francis Fukuyama; Francis Fukuyama, a consultant at the Rand Corporation, is author of "The End of History and the Last Man."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The plight of the 25 million Russians outside of Russia has become a foreign policy concern of President Boris Yeltsin's Government. In this issue are the seeds of another crisis more dangerous than the breakup of Yugoslavia.
Estonia has passed and Latvia has proposed discriminatory citizenship laws requiring Russians, as well as other ethnic minorities, to go through a difficult naturalization process during which they cannot vote, own property or hold certain jobs. 
These policies may be understandable for historical reasons, given Baltic fears of being overwhelmed by the Russians. Nevertheless, discrimination is discrimination; many Russians have become victims, and the Russian Government is understandably upset.
At the United Nations in September, Andrei Kozyrev, Russia's pro-Western Foreign Minister, criticized Estonia for violating the human rights of Russians. And in October, the Yeltsin Government halted troop withdrawals from the Baltics to put pressure on local governments to respect Russians' rights. In Moldova, Georgia and Tajikistan, Russians have killed and been killed in ethnic violence. Increasingly, they are arming themselves in self-defense.
The instincts that served us well during the cold war may be inappropriate now. It is natural for Americans and Europeans to side with the Baltics and other captive nations that suffered under the yoke of Russian and Soviet imperialism. But the human rights principles underlying U.S. foreign policy do not extend to support for efforts to create ethnically or racially homogeneous nations.
More important, as a purely practical matter, Latvia and Estonia are tiny communities on the border of the world's largest country. It's unrealistic for them to expect protection from the U.S. or the European Community; they will have to find a way to live with Russia in the long run. It is hard to see how Latvia and Estonia can expect to disfranchise half their populations and remain viable, stable and democratic countries.
To be sure, Moscow's motives in championing the rights of Russians abroad are in many cases highly suspect. Some officials, such as Vice President Aleksandr Rutskoi, are not entirely reconciled to the loss of empire and would like to use local Russian populations as a means of winning back the country's hegemony.
But many other Russians are sincere democrats who supported Baltic independence two years ago and feel betrayed by the Baltics' reneging on promises to treat their minorities fairly. It is senseless to hand would-be fascists in Russia an easy issue with which they can attack Mr. Yeltsin and discredit his close relationship with the West.
Under these circumstances, the U.S. must take an unprejudiced and evenhanded position, supporting the rights of all ethnic minorities in the region, including Russians. This might mean applying pressure on Baltic and other post-Soviet governments to liberalize their citizenship and permanent residency laws, even as we continue to press Russia to withdraw its forces from the former Soviet republics.
Aid and trade to these states should be conditioned not just on economic reform but also on human rights. George Kennan's suggestion that aid be used to build housing for Russian servicemen being brought home from the Baltics and elsewhere is a good one for the incoming Clinton Administration.
With the appointment of Viktor Chernomyrdin, a lifelong Soviet bureaucrat, as Prime Minister, the Russian Government is more likely to provoke a crisis with the Baltics over the rights of ethnic Russians. But the big explosion is in the future, if Ukraine moves away from its liberal policies on rights and citizenship toward nationalist conformity.
Unlike the crisis in the former Yugoslavia, the one in the ex-Soviet states will present the Clinton Administration with not just a moral but a major geopolitical problem. Russia could intervene against the Baltics or, worse, confront Ukraine over the rights of Russians in Crimea. Let us hope that our tragic reluctance to become involved in Yugoslavia will not be repeated in the case of the former Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: Enormous Changes on a Small Planet

BYLINE: By John Noble Wilford; John Noble Wilford, who writes about science for The New York Times, is the author of "The Mapmakers."

 BODY:

HAMMOND ATLAS OF THE WORLD
303 pp. Maplewood, N.J.:
Hammond Inc. $65.
 
NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC ATLAS OF THE WORLD
Revised Sixth Edition.
136 pp. Washington:
National Geographic Society.
Softcover, $73.
Hardcover, $89.
 
THE NEW YORK TIMES ATLAS OF THE WORLD
Third Revised
Concise Edition.
244 pp. New York:
Times Books/
Random House. $75.
 
OXFORD ATLAS OF THE WORLD
288 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $65.
 
TODAY'S WORLD
A New World Atlas From the Cartographers of
Rand McNally.
192 pp. Chicago:
Rand McNally. $29.95;
$24.95 before Jan. 1.
 
THE ECONOMIST ATLAS OF THE NEW EUROPE
288 pp. New York:
Henry Holt & Company. $75. 
 THREE times in this century the map of the world has been redrawn both metaphorically and literally. The Treaty of Versailles at the end of World War I created new countries and boundaries out of the ruins of the Austrian, German, Ottoman and Russian empires. In the aftermath of World War II came more changes in Eastern Europe and the Middle East, as well as in the multitude of postcolonial nations reshaping maps of Africa and Asia. Now, with the reunification of Germany, the collapse of the Soviet Union and its system of satellite nations, and the disintegration of Yugoslavia, events have once again sent cartographers back to their drafting tables and publishers back to press.
The results are thoroughly revised editions of the major world atlases. That they are being issued now can be interpreted as a vote of confidence by publishers in the prospects for a period of geographical stability. It may simply be a calculated risk taken in response to marketing imperatives. Who would keep buying maps showing a divided Germany or a city named Leningrad, except perhaps someone banking on their future antiquarian value alongside those curiosities marking the existence of New Amsterdam or the Holy Roman Empire?
In either case, the past few years have been "a map maker's nightmare," in the words of John F. Shupe, chief cartographer of the National Geographic Society. But upon awakening, map makers have succeeded admirably in catching up with events. The publishers have also seized this opportunity to call attention to the considerable improvements being made in the art and science of cartography.
It was a similar convergence of geographical turmoil and advances in cartography that led to world atlases as a publishing innovation some 400 years ago. Europe's map makers, shaken out of their formerly cloistered ways, were struggling to keep up with the deeds of explorers. By the second half of the 16th century, the discoveries had whetted appetites for knowledge of newfound exotic places, and better engraving and printing techniques made it possible to satisfy the demand. This led to an emerging commercial trade in maps, notably in the Low Countries.
The first modern geographical atlas was issued in 1570 by Abraham Ortelius, an editor and publisher of maps in Antwerp. A merchant named Hooftman, a map collector, had found the job of rolling up and unrolling his many large maps an increasing nuisance. So he commissioned Ortelius to gather maps and bind them in a single volume. Ortelius decided to do the same for a general audience, incorporating 70 maps into a volume he called "Theatrum Orbis Terrarum" ("Theater of the World"). It was an immediate success.
Gerardus Mercator, the century's foremost cartographer, then published a three-volume collection of maps in book form, the final one appearing a year after his death in 1594. Mercator's title for the collection represents the first use of the word "atlas" in connection with a geographical work, for reasons that are not entirely clear. The full title reads: "Atlas, or Cosmographical Meditations Upon the Creation of the Universe, and the Universe as Created."
Each of the world atlases under review here is both a handsome work in the tradition of Ortelius and Mercator and a worthy response to the challenge cartographers are always facing: to be comprehensive and up to date while also conveying prodigious amounts of information in crisp graphic form. The heft of several of these books would test the strength of mighty Atlas. So much more is known than ever before of the world, all the lands and even the sea floors having now been charted. But how does one assess the relative merits of these new atlases?
One way to start is by considering prices, which for many atlases are not trivial. Rand McNally says that at $29.95 ($24.95 until Jan. 1), its "Today's World" is the lowest-priced large-format world atlas in bookstores. What's more, the jacket displays a bright yellow sticker with an unusual offer. The sticker can be mailed in for a free updated world wall map should the maps in the atlas become outdated because of political changes before Dec. 31, 1993.
The other atlases each cost more than twice as much, but they offer more -- the world and continents and regions shown at various scales and from many different perspectives, and also comprehensive indexes giving the names of thousands of cities and towns and their locations in the world and on the maps in these volumes. The National Geographic Atlas of the World, for example, has 150,000 such entries, including 20 new countries and 14,000 other name changes since its 1990 edition. In newly independent Ukraine, more than 95 percent of all place names had to be revised because of reversions to pre-Communist nomenclature.
The Hammond Atlas of the World boasts that its revisions go well beyond name changes. The publisher says this is the first atlas to be computer generated from digitized geographic data, facilitating the presentation of countries at different scales and perspectives. Another advantage will be the speeding up of future revisions.
The National Geographic Atlas, the Oxford Atlas of the World and, to a lesser degree, the New York Times Atlas of the World are more than map collections; they are veritable encyclopedias of geographic and demographic information, profusely illustrated with multicolored maps and graphs. Those old staples of geography textbooks -- fossil fuel reserves, steel production, literacy standings -- never looked more inviting of further study. In addition, the National Geographic book has a "Nations of the World" section, with brief profiles of the 193 nations, which it says is the greatest number in world history.
These three atlases also cast a glance beyond the earth, providing graphic summaries of the latest knowledge about the universe and a tour of the solar system. The Times atlas even has a concise history of space flight.
As its title announces, the sixth new atlas, the Economist Atlas of the New Europe, takes in much less territory and is not the place to look for general maps of the continent or individual countries. This is mainly a book of illustrated statistics, with accompanying texts, about Europe's banking, industry, trade, people and culture.
I hope no one will be shocked when I confess that my examination of these atlases fell short of checking out the curve of each coastline, the elevations of all mountain peaks or the spellings of places in Tajikistan. One must trust experts in some matters. For an evaluation of these works, my initial approach was both personal and random, and I suspect others will be inclined to follow suit.
First, I thumbed the pages to find maps of the familiar, ones showing Paris, Tenn., and Paducah, Ky. There they were, just where I left them in childhood. In the Oxford atlas, I noted with satisfaction, the index gave as much space to the Paris in Tennessee as to the French capital.
Next, in checking how the atlases handled some remote places about which I have some knowledge, I discovered a lingering gap in post-Soviet geography. Just where in Kazakhstan is the Russian space launching base? In the days of cold war secrecy, the Russians were misleading by identifying the base with a place named Baikonur, although Western analysis of flight paths put the actual site a couple of hundred miles to the southwest, closer to the Aral Sea. The atlases are silent on this issue, merely listing without further comment a place called variously Baykonur, Baykonyr or Bajkonyr -- except for the National Geographic volume, which elaborates the name to Bayqongyr on the map, leaving it Baykonur in the index. But near the Aral, just north of the city of Leninsk (formerly Tyuratam), a label on the map indicates the location of the Baikonur Cosmodrome. Does this certify the solution to an old cold war mystery?
Czechoslovakia presents a more immediate problem for the atlas makers. Only Hammond is unequivocal in showing two separate nations, the Czech Republic and Slovakia. The other atlases map the split but, at least typographically, remain dominated by the ghost of the old country.
After one rambles through the maps for a time -- ah, the preferred spelling for Timbuktu now seems to be Tombouctou -- some overall impressions began to emerge. Some of the most visually pleasing maps are in the Hammond and Times volumes. But the Oxford and National Geographic atlases are more satisfying, with their greater variety of maps and the inclusion of so much noncartographic information.
Map makers, it also is clear, are having more success presenting information in forms ever more pleasing to the eye. Centuries ago, cartographers created imaginative and colorful works of art to compensate for the paucity of their information. For well over a century, until recent decades, maps had been more utilitarian and prosaic. As these atlases demonstrate, maps can be both practical and appealing.
So many of the maps in these atlases are delightfully new. By more skillful shading, mountain ranges seem to rise from the pages in lofty splendor. The Oxford and Hammond atlases make especially effective use of such techniques. In nearly all the volumes, colors are used with more variety and to better effect than ever before. The icy blues and frosty whites of Antarctica and Greenland send a shiver down the spine, and the sandy hues of the Gobi and the Sahara bring on a gritty thirst. For populated areas, the colors illustrative of elevations are sufficiently subdued so that names and boundaries stand out clearly.
Some improvements are less apparent. Using computers, the cartographers have devised new mathematical schemes to reduce the inevitable distortions associated with the translation of a spherical earth onto the flatness of paper. The problem is to show as accurately as possible the true shape and size of lands, whether they are near the Equator or where the lines of longitude converge toward the poles. The National Geographic has adopted a new system for dealing with the problem; and Mitchell J. Feigenbaum, an authority on chaos theory at Rockefeller University, advised Hammond on developing computer software for reducing such distortions by as much as 60 percent.
A test of how well they did is to look at Greenland and South America. On many older maps, particularly those following Mercator's practices, Greenland looked every bit as big as the whole of South America, even though the latter is nine times as large. These world atlases pass the test, cutting Greenland down closer to actual size and shape.
Let us hope the world settles down for a bit, giving us time to catch up with all that has changed and permitting these new atlases a long shelf life.
Now, where was I? Looking for the mountains in New Mexico where this boy spent a summer long ago imagining he was a cowboy. And off in the pages showing Central Asia, trying to learn the enchanting names of the oasis towns harking back to the legendary Silk Road. As Ortelius might have foreseen, good atlases are like that. Open them for one purpose, say to write a review, and soon the mind is traveling wide latitudes in space and time.
