PUB-DATE: December 20, 1992

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2756 words

HEADLINE: Dear Museumgoer: What Do You Think?

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL

 BODY:
In a Malibu, Calif., conference room, eight people are giving their impressions of the J. Paul Getty Museum, a place they have never visited.
"I've been told there's heavy, very classic type of art, somewhat stuffy and stand-offish," says a middle-aged man in a brown suit. "It's the kind of place you wouldn't want to take your kids and let them run around." 
 An older woman concurs: "I get the impression it's a little stuffy and has old art."
A young man in a blue blazer chimes in: "I was driving up past Malibu and I saw the sign. I'd never heard of it before. I thought it was a place where they were going to show you how to refine oil or something."
This group of people -- a randomly selected, geographic and demographic cross section of Californians -- is surprisingly uninhibited, considering that the participants know they are being videotaped by museum officials through one-way mirrors.
The Getty is not alone in doing such studies. These days, more and more museums are turning to market research -- once the sole province of toothpaste makers and detergent manufacturers -- to overhaul their images and to help make decisions about what hours to be open, how to write a wall label, how much admission to charge and, perhaps one day, even what kind of art to show.
In New York, visitors leaving the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Magritte retrospective, the Guggenheim's Russian Constructivist exhibition and the Museum of Modern Art's Matisse show are being hit with questionaires, part of a coordinated survey conducted by the three institutions. And last year, 11 museums across the country participated in a separate research project financed by the Getty Center for Education in the Arts and the J. Paul Getty Museum. "These days, it takes more than just salesmanship to get people in the door," says Edmund Pillsbury, the director of the Kimbell Museum in Fort Worth, which uses market research to determine how to advertise its special shows.
With government financing down over the last five years and private donations in the doldrums, museums are more eager than ever to get paying customers through the doors. At the same time, they find themselves competing for the public's leisure time. Thus the lure of market research.
While some art-world observers believe that catering to the Joneses is a savvy business move, others fear that public opinion could supplant curatorial wisdom. If the Joneses say they would rather see a Norman Rockwell retrospective than a Vermeer exhibition, what then? Should museums appeal to the masses or are they basically purveyors of high culture? Is it a museum's job to instruct or to entertain -- or can it do both simultaneously? These are questions museums may have to address in the future, and they suggest the depth of the issues raised by combining market research and fine art.
Most museum executives are guarded about discussing the implications of market research, other than to say it's helpful in redesigning traffic flow patterns around the galleries or in rethinking brochures and hours. One exception is Sandra Horrocks, manager of public relations at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Describing the conditions that make market research almost inevitable for museums, she said: "We're all struggling. Our membership and attendance is stagnate. Corporate funding has dried up. We no longer have the blockbusters that bring great numbers of people into the museum; therefore, we have to figure out something else to do. We need information, and that's something surveys and focus groups provide."
But some curators wonder just how accurate these studies are, and what market research portends for the future. "If a museum's main concern is stuffing the largest number of paying bodies into a building, then they've lost their birthright," says William Rubin, director emeritus of the department of paintings and sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art. "Museums aren't just meant to produce shows that have broad popular appeal, they're also supposed to do unpopular shows. It's the balance that's crucial."
 
Research
A Portrait In Numbers
 For many museums, there is safety in numbers -- that is, the large number of major institutions now doing market research and the impressive new statistics museum director can use to back up requests for financing. The Getty's research project last year involved no less than 11 important museums: the Getty itself, the Art Institute of Chicago, the Brooklyn Museum, the Cleveland Museum of Art, the Dallas Museum of Art, the Denver Museum, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, the National Gallery of Art in Washington, the Philadelphia Museum of Art, the Seattle Art Museum and the Toledo Museum of Art in Ohio.
Each museum held focus groups with people who may or may not have visited the institution. In some cases, officials found that their museums were perceived as being intimidating and needed to become more user-friendly. Many of those interviewed changed their minds, however, after actually entering the museums.
Ultimately, such research is aimed at increasing the museums' bottom lines. One important reason for the survey being conducted at the Metropolitan, the Modern and the Guggenheim, for example, is to track the economic impact of these institutions on New York City. High numbers would provide the museums with ammunition to fight government budget cutbacks. By showing just how much money is spent by visitors who come to New York to attend art exhibitions, the museums also hope to entice corporations into sponsoring shows.
"Corporations these days need to see where their money is going and the impact it will have," says Suzette Sherman, manager of visitor services at the Guggenheim. "These studies give them a means of comparison."
The Metropolitan, a pioneer in museum market research, conducted its first visitor survey in 1971. Recently, it has stepped up its efforts. Jeffrey K. Smith, a professor of educational psychology at Rutgers University who works part time at the Metropolitan, estimates that each month his team interviews roughly 700 visitors.
During the three-and-a-half-month Seurat exhibition in 1991, for instance, research indicated that museum visitors brought an estimated $313 million into the city, and that out-of-town visitors spent $9.7 million in the museum shops. Of those attending the show, 26 percent came from New York City, the rest from out of town. After seeing the Seurat exhibition, 61 percent of the out-of-towners dined in a restaurant, 57 percent went shopping, 33 percent caught a Broadway show, 10 percent visited the Statue of Liberty and 1 percent went to the Big Apple Circus.
 
The Results

Turning Numbers Into Actions
 Gathering information is the easy part. The hard part is deciding what to do with it. When a study at the Getty revealed that only 7 percent of its visitors brought children (compared to 15 percent to 20 percent at other museums), the Getty felt a need to make changes. "What we realized is that the Getty wasn't doing anything to encourage families," says Margaret Menninger, who helps the museum organize its market research. In response, the Getty introduced family programs on weekends and provided toys for children to play with while visiting. One, titled "Puzzling Pots," is a compact game about Greek vases and mythology; it's available for children to use in the gallery at no charge.
Other museums have similarly made changes based on market research.
* After surveying 2,500 tour operators, the Guggenheim began offering group tours of the Russian Constructivist show in six languages, packaged with tea or lunch at the Russian Tea Room.
* After some 200 interviews, the Kimbell Art Museum decided to sell advance tickets to "Egypt's Dazzling Sun: Amenhotep III and His World," which opened in October. (On the other hand, the Metropolitan Museum prefers not to sell advance tickets; poll-takers found that its visitors, two to one, prefer standing in line over buying tickets ahead of time.)
* A man-in-the-street survey of 341 people in SoHo convinced the local branch of the Guggenheim to stay open until 10 o'clock three nights a week to attract the young working people in the neighborhood.
* Survey information led the Philadelphia Museum to begin advertising its new late hours on a local rock-and-roll radio station.
* The Philadelphia survey also suggested using television to reach audiences, so the museum participated in a joint promotion with the CBS affiliate WCAU to push a recent Picasso show. The station's call letters were put on exhibition materials, an anchor provided the voice for the audio tour, and the show got, in return, almost $300,000 of free air time.
"My only fear is that the public will see all they want on television and not bother coming to the show," Ms. Horrocks says of such efforts. The Philadelphia Museum does have its limits when it comes to commercial stunts. A car company interested in sponsoring the Picasso show wanted to put one of its vehicles in the museum's great hall. "That was a bit much," Ms. Horrocks says.
Are museums nevertheless sinking to the level of the lowest common denominator? Research has shown that some visitors are naive or ill informed about art, and museums have had to take steps to accommodate that audience. A man who was about to visit the Philaldelphia Museum for the first time told his focus-group colleagues that he had never heard of any important artwork being there. During the same session, a woman said she expected the museum to be filled with "pictures I would not understand. . . . I've seen art where it looks like kids splashed paint."
In response, the museum reinstated an image of van Gogh's "Sunflowers" on the cover of its brochures, along with other easily recognizable works. "For a while we took them off because we wanted a change," Ms. Horrocks says, "but I guess that was a mistake."
The Cleveland Museum found that at least one visitor could not even find the van Goghs. "I guess I expected banners or something," a focus-group member said. "We walked by them three times before we noticed them. After a while, everything looks alike."
In response, the museum redesigned its map, making it easier for visitors to spot its masterpieces. Visitor surveys also helped the Cleveland Museum set limits on verbiage in wall labels: 75 words, maximum. "When curators feel frustrated," says Evan H. Turner, director of the museum, "I tell them the Lord's Prayer is only 52 or 53."
 
The Danger
A Tyranny Of Statistics?
 For all the practical good that has come out of these studies, the use of market research raises important issues. A few officials say that it's about time their institutions listened to what the people have to say, while others are apprehensive about what the surveys could lead to. "Clearly museums are competing for people's time and funds, but at the same time museums shouldn't turn into MTV," says Martin Friedman, former director of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis. "It's important not to lose sight of an institution's artistic mission."
Others question the accuracy of such research. "Surveys are as accurate as the skill of the people developing them," says Stephen Bitgood, a psychology professor at Jacksonville State University in Alabama who has worked with museums for 18 years. "We're living in a time when it's a social trend to have a public reaction to everything. The only problem is that it's all too easy to generalize the results. This whole process is still in its infancy."
According to Mr. Rubin, of the Museum of Modern Art, "One problem with surveys is that the slighest inflection, the way the questions are posed, can change the answer. It's different than using polls to determine the outcome of a Presidential election, this is far less cut and dried, far more complex."
Still, curators and museum directors seem to have embraced market research as another step in the corporatization of the museum world. "We don't like to think of our visitors as customers or our art as assets," says William H. Luers, president of the Metropolitan. "On the other hand, we're so big and the money involved is so large."
Most curators insist that market research does not affect what shows are being mounted. Museum experts are quick to point out that questions of taste -- for instance, the popularity of one artist versus another -- are not included in questionaires or asked in focus groups.
"We were fearful in the beginning," says Keith Christiansen, a curator in the department of European paintings at the Metropolitan. "If the purpose of the survey is to accommodate what the man-on-the-street wants, then it's cause for alarm."
But, the curator says, this is not what the Metropolitan seems to be using them for. Instead, says Philippe de Montebello, the Metropolitan's director, visitor surveys "confirm things we already knew," like the need to stay open later and to cut back on the information in labels.
In at least one case, however, an audience survey and a museum's curators came to the same conclusion. In studies done during the Seurat exhibition, researchers discovered a surprisingly enthusiastic response to the artist's drawings. While the Metropolitan points out that its coming exhibitions were planned well ahead of the results of the Seurat survey, the museum's spring schedule now includes four drawing shows: "Arthur B. Davies and the Metropolitan Museum," "Daumier Drawings," "Abstract Expressionism: Work on Paper, Selections From the Metropolitan Museum" and "Drawings From the J. Paul Getty Museum."
"Any information about one's audience is good," says John Elderfield, the curator of the Modern's Matisse exhibition, "but after that, it's up to the curators to know how to use it. It's not bad knowing what the audience thinks."
In fact, suggests one former museum director, it's highly desirable. "It's time visitors start calling the shots," says Thomas Hoving, director of the Metropolitan from 1967 to 1977. "The more popular you can go the better. I think what's wrong with museums these days is that they have lost touch with the public, and it shows."
What will happen then to the small, obscure show that was never meant to draw crowds but simply to educate? Mr. Rubin says a successful show can help finance a less popular one. And even obscure artists can be made more palatable, advocates of polling say, if museums can find ways to educate the public about the shows and make them more enticing.
And so, apparently, the camel's nose of market research is already inside the museum tent. Ms. Horrocks says that, since exhibitions at the Philadelphia Museum are planned several years ahead, it's too early for such research to affect curatorial decisions . . . yet. "We haven't come to the point where it's an issue," she says. "But we're starting an exhibitions committee and we will be considering audiences."
 
 
 
A VIEW FROM HOI POLLOI
 When museums conduct surveys and lead focus groups, they sometimes get scathing criticism from participants. Here is a sampling of comments about five institutions gathered during a survey of 11 museums last year by the Getty Center for Education in the Arts.
 
National Gallery of Art, Washington
* "If you didn't get the handouts, you didn't know who the
artists were."
* "People did not linger in the 20th-century galleries. They went through fast."
* "When I asked the guards a question, I was referred to the
information desk."
 
Philadelphia Museum of Art
* About the 20th-century galleries: "The art looked like something I could have done myself."
* "There wasn't anything pointing to where you were to go."
* "I walked away with a feeling of frustration. I would have liked more explanation."
* "I'd rather go see the dinosaurs."
 
J. Paul Getty Museum, Malibu, Calif.
* "The signs were all very uniform. They were almost like an eye test they were so small."
* "There's a lack of sitting areas in many of the rooms."
 
Art Institute of Chicago
* "It made me real nervous not to know where I was going. Those maps are really confusing."
* About the brochures: "I don't like them. I found them
confusing."
 
Cleveland Museum of Art
* "I felt like I was in a rat maze. You don't know what you've seen and what you missed."
* "How many times do you want to look at Buddha? Boring."
* "It was so large it turned me off. Toward the end it got
monotonous."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
But Wait, There's Some Life Yet in the 'Cheers' Gang

BYLINE: By ANITA GATES

 BODY:
What a blow, and right before Christmas! NBC announced this month that "Cheers" will call it quits at the end of this season, after 11 years, 26 Emmys and God knows how many beers on the eternally unpaid tab of the unemployed accountant Norm Peterson.
So America will no longer be able to follow the saga of Sam Malone, former baseball star and recovering alcoholic turned bar owner, and the memorable assortment of Bostonians who were his employees, customers and lovers. 
 But at NBC and Paramount, which produces "Cheers," there is already talk of spinning off some of the characters into a new series. It could be great. It could be "AfterM*A*S*H" (CBS, 1983) or, more to the point, "The Tortellis," a show that spun off Carla's first husband (NBC, 1987). Meanwhile, in the spirit of the season and of the current state of prime-time series television, here are some hypothetical possibilities for the stars, offered with the fervent hope that no one takes them too seriously.
 
Ted Danson (who plays Sam Malone)
In "A Votre Sante," Sam, unable to accept either aging or his deep-seated loneliness, marries a 26-year-old fitness instructor and moves to Montreal, where he becomes a sports broadcaster. Hilarity ensues as Sam tries to socialize with his wife's young friends and tries to speak French in a bilingual city. Premiere: Sam thinks he sees Diane (Shelley Long) in a mall.
 
Kirstie Alley (Rebecca Howe)
Rebecca tries to start a new life in Southern California. Each week, in "The Big One," she has a really big opportunity for success or happiness but, at the last minute, loses it. This week: No one believes that Rebecca almost married the billionaire Robin Colcord. Guest star: Marla Maples.
 
Rhea Perlman (Carla Tortelli LeBec)
Carla, devastated by the closing of the Cheers bar and haunted by her unrequited love for Sam, gives up men and decides to devote herself to full-time motherhood in "Eight Is More Than Enough." Tonight: Gino Tortelli has a crush on his teacher and his parole officer.
 
George Wendt (Norm Peterson)
In "America's Favorite Neighborhood Bars," a reality series from the producers of "America's Favorite Videotaped Assaults," Norm makes behind-the-scenes tours of bars across the United States. Tonight: the Whiskey, at the Paramount Hotel in New York.
 
John Ratzenberger as Cliff Clavin
After retiring from the United States Postal Service with a generous pension, Cliff buys and manages an eight-unit bed-and-breakfast on Cape Cod. In "Ma and Me," Cliff's mother lives with him in a rambling Victorian house out back. Or does she? Guest star: Janet Leigh.
 
Woody Harrelson and Jackie Swanson as Woody and Kelly Boyd
Ten years have passed since their wedding, and Woody and Kelly are beautiful, rich, bored and hopelessly estranged, despite the love they share for their two handsome blond sons. In "Unhappily Ever After," the couple decide to stay married but lead separate lives in adjoining wings of their Beacon Hill town house. This week: Who owns the copyright to "The Kelly Song"?
 
Kelsey Grammer (Dr. Frasier Crane)
After his divorce from Lilith, Frasier moves to Chicago and establishes a private psychiatric practice, specializing in group therapy. This week on "Frasier": Fear of Flying. Co-starring Suzanne Pleshette.
 
Bebe Neuwirth (Dr. Lilith Sternin)
After her year in the Ecopod, Lilith Sternin-Crane drops her hyphenation and takes a teaching job at Harvard. In "Cambridge 02138," she finds a circle of brilliant but emotionally troubled friends, all of whom have gray hair, advanced degrees and verbally gifted children. Premiere: Little Frederick takes an I.Q. test.

HEADLINE: TIME WARNER;
What Explains Shock Appeal?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
What we really need to know is not what led Time Warner to produce material that is inflammatory and controversial -- we all know that it was profit -- but rather, why is it that at this moment in our history the most shocking and controversial art forms are the most profitable? 
 Why are significant segments of the American audience receptive to, or actually eager for, such products as Ice-T's "Cop Killer" and Madonna's "Sex"? Why did much of the American public believe Oliver Stone's "J. F. K.," despite the condemnations of the historical experts?
Richard Clurman's analysis cannot answer these questions because, like too much media criticism, his article posits an ex post facto argument of historical explanation: company X produces art form Y, the media determine that it is flawed or controversial, then a critic tries to reconstruct the process by which the company created the controversial form.
The film "New Jack City," for example, is faulted by Mr. Clurman because it "was greeted by fights and shootings outside movie theaters." Does Mr. Clurman really believe that Time Warner deliberately chose to make a movie that would lead to mayhem in American theaters? The story that Mr. Clurman tells of Time Warner's decision-making shows that in most cases the company's management was caught by surprise at the reactions, especially the negative and violent ones.
Moreover, media critics and protest groups play an important role in the process of controversy-making and contribute to the profitability of these ventures. A case in point is the "Body Count" album by Ice-T, which was selling rather modestly until the hue and cry was raised over the song "Cop Killer." Then thousands more bought the album. The story of how controversial art forms get produced and labeled "controversial" is more complex than that which Mr. Clurman tells us.
But why is today's American audience embracing such oppositional cultural forms? To understand why such forms are so popular, we must recognize that generally they are not consumed by one single, undifferentiated audience: those who buy a copy of "Sex" are not necessarily the same people who go to see "Malcolm X." We are witnessing in American popular culture the emergence of a highly differentiated set of audiences, whose wants and perspectives Time Warner has tapped into.
Mr. Clurman lumps all of the forms produced by Time Warner into a category labeled "controversial" without stopping to consider the social forces that make these messages acceptable to an audience. Can one really understand the popularity of "Cop Killer" without addressing the issue of brutal police treatment of young black men who see in the Rodney King beating a call to arms? Can one understand Madonna without addressing her appeal to gay men and heterosexual young women as someone who is in control of her own life and image?
Can the appeal of "Malcolm X" be understood apart from the need by black and white Americans for a story of personal redemption in the face of the family breakdown, moral degradation and group hatred that emerge from American ghettos? I think not.
The tension between the rights of capitalism and the social community has been around since John Winthrop delivered his speech "A Modell of Christian Charity" on the deck of the Arbella. But that social community is now more diverse and economically powerful than ever before. And that diversified public will continue to use its purchasing power to select its preferred entertainment, despite what elitist moral custodians think.
 
JEFFREY C. STEWART
Washington
 
The writer is a fellow at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars.

HEADLINE: Architects Sheltering In Government Projects

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN

 BODY:
FACED with a sharply reduced market for private construction brought about by the downturn in the New York metropolitan region's economy, more and more architectural firms, including some of the biggest and most prestigious, are turning increasingly to government for work.
Firms that in the mid-80's would have been busy planning 50-story office buildings, gigantic shopping malls or high-rise city-center hotels are instead trying to underbid one another for courthouses and public schools or engaging in expensive, winner-take-all competitions for ferry terminals and Federal office buildings. A decade ago many of these firms would have counted on government contracts for as little as 10 percent of their business; now, they say, the figure often reaches 50 percent or more. 
 "The public sector is where it's at right now," said Peter Samton of Gruzen Samton Steinglass, a major New York City firm that has long done government work. "There's slim pickings for all architects in the private sector in the New York area. Anytime there's the possibility of a project in the public sector you'll find most architects going after it."
Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the giant firm whose Lever House at Park Avenue and 53d Street is a landmark of private construction and whose Sears Tower and John Hancock Center in Chicago are also known worldwide, has designed a Federal Courthouse in White Plains. Venturi, Scott Brown & Associates, the unorthodox Philadelphia concern, has designed its first New York building, the controversial new terminal for the Staten Island Ferry.
Kohn Pedersen Fox, which spent the 80's putting up office buildings all over the world, is responsible for a new Federal Court House in Foley Square and Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum has designed a 974,000-square-foot office building as part of that project. James Stewart Polshek and Partners is designing a new public library in Queens and Rafael Vinoly Architects was chosen for the new Housing Court in the Bronx.
Many of these firms of course have always been involved in government work; Skidmore, for instance, has a long tradition of work in the public sector, and Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum has frequently designed public projects. What has greatly increased is the percentage of time all these firms spend as government consultants.
"WHAT is happening is that more of the quality architectural firms that were basically doing private work are now coming into public architecture," said Rudolph J. Rinaldi, Commissioner of Buildings and director of the Office of Construction for New York City. "You're getting a lot more of the artsier firms, the better architects."
The influx of architects has created a far more competitive market, a competition that, officials say, has driven prices down, led to better design -- and caused concern among architects that government is getting the better of them.
"The city has been the beneficiary," said Kenneth J. Knuckles, Commissioner of New York City's Department of General Services, the municipal landlord and purchasing agent. "We're getting a better price and a better product."
Andrew Gerardi, director of design and construction for the Northeast region of the Federal General Services Administration, agreed.
"We've been getting a lot more architects applying for the work," Mr. Gerardi said. "It's unfortunate the economy is that way, but it's also fortuitous, because we can explore with better firms better public architecture. The public, the government and the nation at large benefit. It's more work for us, but in a sense it's pleasant work: It's like choosing between chocolate, vanilla and strawberry."
Statistics from the New York City Department of General Services show that the number of names on its lists of qualified consultants -- which include not only architects but also engineering and construction management firms -- has tripled since 1986, from 250 to 800. Most of the increase occurred in the last three years, and many of the new names belong to concerns that had never before been interested in public work.
In 1986, officials said, the department began an outreach program and sent information about city work to 60 of the highest-profile firms; half responded. Requests to be included on the qualified lists have almost doubled, from 137 in 1987 to 269 in 1991. The department uses the lists to select, generally at random, 8 to 12 candidates for a job; those chosen submit proposals, from which the consultant is eventually named.
When the department announced plans for a new Flushing branch of the library system in Queens, Commissioner Knuckles said, 11 firms responded to a request for a proposal; 7 were interviewed, and the project went to James Stewart Polshek and Partners.
At times, though, projects are awarded by competition, and when the department announced a competition for the design of a $230 million, 475,000-square-foot Police Academy in the Bronx, 30 design teams made formal submissions. The winner, announced in November, was Ellerbe Becket with Michael Fieldman and Partners, which was chosen from seven high-profile finalists.
AMONG the department's many other projects are a $23 million, 92,000-square-foot Housing Court in the Bronx designed by Rafael Vinoly Architects; a $35 million annex for the Criminal Court Building in Kew Gardens, Queens, for which Ehrenkrantz and Eckstut is the architect, and a million-square-foot courthouse complex in the Bronx on which consultant selection for the first phase -- $122 million and 293,000 square feet -- will begin early next year. They are all part of a $2.8 billion master plan for the city's courts that is to involve 32 projects, either new buildings or major renovations.
The interest in public work even extends to the subways. John Tarantino, assistant vice president for station design at the Transit Authority, said that many new firms and some that had not done subway work for at least 15 years "had come knocking on the door again" inquiring about the authority's station rehabiliation program. Mr. Tarantino said the firms include Skidmore and Kohn Pedersen Fox, which have been added to the lists of qualified consultants.
James A. Schmidt, executive vice president for planning, design and construction at New York City's Economic Development Corporation, said that because "some of the most exciting commissions have always been public commissions" many of the biggest firms, eager for the public and media recognition that such projects bring, have frequently been involved in public work.
"The real point," Mr. Schmidt said, "is that since things are so quiet in the private development community, the public sector becomes more important, it represents a larger percentage of the work."
The development corporation recently held a competition for perhaps the most exciting commission in recent years, the Whitehall Street terminal for the Staten Island Ferry. "We got an excellent response," Mr. Schmidt said.
For architects, the $112 million terminal and especially the big clock, 120 feet in diameter, that is its design centerpiece, have become symbols of the changing times. Six of the most important architectural firms in the country were finalists in the design competition; the winner, Venturi, Scott Brown & Associates (with Anderson/Schwartz Architects), is a world-renowned firm that has rarely been involved in public work.
Most of Venturi, Scott Brown's designs have been institutional, for universities and museums. Recent ones include the Sainsbury Wing of the National Gallery in London and the new Seattle Art Museum. But Mr. Venturi said that "about 40 percent of our architectural work is now public, while in the mid-80's it would have been about 10 percent." Among the other public projects Venturi, Scott Brown is working on these days is a resort for the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications in Japan. It also made a losing bid for the Police Academy.
Mr. Samton of Gruzen Samton Steinglass said his firm now did 90 percent of its work in the public sector. Among the projects are the recently opened new Stuyvesant High School on the Hudson River north of the World Financial Center in Manhattan, on which it was co-architect with Cooper, Robertson & Partners, and six prototype public schools, including the new P.S. 5 by the Harlem River in Washington Heights, for the New York City School Construction Authority.
"IN the best of times," he said, "it would have been 50 to 60 percent private and 40 to 50 percent public." Much of the private work that now exists, he said, is institutional and nonprofit.
Marilyn Taylor, a partner in Skidmore's New York office, said that although her office had long done public-sector work, in the 1980's it amounted to about 10 percent, "while these days it's closer to 40 percent."
"We're doing the bridge that crosses West Street at Chambers Street to the new Stuyvesant High School," Ms. Taylor said. "We took a shot at the Staten Island Ferry and didn't make it. We have been involved in the courthouse in Charleston, W. Va., which is in the design stages now. We're also doing a field office for the F.B.I. in downtown Washington."
The firm's Transitional Housing for the Homeless project in New York City, seven units for families and four for singles, has won three awards, most recently the Bard Award of the City Club of New York.
There's also the $33 million, seven-story, 155,000-square-foot Federal Courthouse in White Plains, on which construction is scheduled to begin in January; the Northeast Corridor improvement project, involving 13 train stations from Washington to Boston. And, Ms. Taylor said, "one of the biggest projects we've had in the last eight years in this office, the expansion of Dulles Airport in Washington; it's for an airport authority, not government, but I consider it the public sector."
Shelley Fox of Kohn Pedersen Fox said that in the 1980's his firm did about 95 percent of its work in the private sector; today, because of the downturn, it's 20 percent public sector and 50 percent foreign.
The firm has designed Lincoln Square, the large private commercial and residential building at Broadway and 67th Street near Lincoln Center, one of the biggest private projects now being put up in Manhattan. But it is also the architect (with Simmons Architects) of the $241 million, 27-story Federal Court House in Foley Square -- at 921,000 square feet the largest in the country -- and a courthouse in Portland, Ore.
"We're also going after work at the Buffalo airport," Mr. Fox said. "We're talking with the Battery Park City Authority about the renovation of a building and we're going after a number of projects in Washington, including the Internal Revenue Service headquarters."
Jerry A. Davis, managing principal of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, said that his firm had always done public work but that its public and institutional work had increased from 40 percent in the mid-80's to 90 percent now, including the $276 million, 34-story Federal office building at Foley Square. Its tenants are to include the Internal Revenue Service and the United States Attorney's office.
Other government work, he said, includes an ambulatory care teaching facility at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, a medical-research facility at SUNY Buffalo and a replacement hospital for Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn for the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation.
While the architects are eager to talk about how much more they are serving the public interest, many also do not hesitate to bring up the downside: excessive competition, lower fees, needless bureaucracy and the necessity to spend up front what are often large amounts of money to get a project, money that is lost if they do not succeed.
MS. TAYLOR of Skidmore said it was not unusual for firms "to spend $40,000 or $50,000 in advance to go after the larger projects, some of them in the hundreds of millions of dollars."
"Firms show up with site analyses and models," she said, "for all of which in the past we'd say, 'You'll have to pay us to do these things.' Frankly, architects are so desperate now they're willing to do this. And with government fees not so high, it's a fairly significant up-front risk. If they get the projects, it pays off. But if it doesn't they've lost the money."
Being an architect today, said Mr. Samton of Gruzen Samton Steinglass, "is like being a runner making a living trying to win a marathon. Each request for proposals often gets 60 to 100 responses. So if you think about it, 60 to 100 people are in the race and only one gets the job."
Fees are also a concern. Mr. Samton said that sometimes firms "quote such low prices that should the economy recover they will find themselves with a burden."
"Two or three years from now," he said, "if things get better, they will find themselves still working on projects that no longer seem attractive compared to whatever is new that will be out there."
While prices have generally gone down, Mr. Samton said, the percentage of time that each firm spends on marketing and seeking new business has significantly increased.
"It used to be between 10 and 25 percent," he said. "But it's probably more than half now. Architects have become more and more like salesmen going out there looking for where the business is, putting the proposals together and going to interviews. They're out there trying to get a job instead of doing it. Some people may not acknowledge this because they're embarrassed by it, but that's the case."
One way that architects are coping with the competition, Ms. Taylor said, is by teaming up. "If you can get someone on your team who might have been a competitor," she said, "it increases your chances. Also, the government carefully reviews the number of people you have who are capable of doing the job, and the more you have the better your chances."
Working for the government, said Mr. Davis of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, can often be "more difficult and time consuming" than working in the private sector.
"When you work with a commercial developer, there is usually one decisionmaker," he said. "In government, you can often have hundreds, with many conflicting desires. It requires a different sort of mind set. People who are very good and quick and agile working with private developers tend to get very frustrated working with government."
Architects are working with New York City to cut the bureaucratic red tape -- particularly to simplify the procurement process, so that getting and doing work has fewer hassles. That process, many of them say, has become increasingly complicated in recent years because of changes brought about by the new City Charter and the establishment of a Policy Procurement Board. The changes were initiated partly in reaction to the corruption that has tainted city construction in recent decades.
But the new rules have created "a whole raft of problems with the city," said Lenore M. Lucey, executive director of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects, "everything from demeaning pay scales to length of time to get anything approved and processed to lack of control of construction process."
"ONE of the largest problems," she said, "is the way city agencies go about selecting an architect or an engineer or a landscape architect. The procedure has a tendency to be abused and create a situation where in the best scenario, consultants are kept on the hook waiting for eight, nine or 10 months, and in the worst scenario, the consultants have to prespend a large chunk of their fee preparing the materials required by the procurement process."
Recently, she said, for a small project in Queens, a city agency requested proposals from 29 firms on its list of qualified candidates, "and required an inch-and-a-quarter-thick document from each firm in color and in triplicate; that's no mean amount of money."
And then, too often, she said, the selection of the winning firm is based more on price than on quality.
A meeting was held in November with Mr. Rinaldi of the Office of Construction, she said, and a committee has been formed to recommend changes, which Mr. Rinaldi agreed are necessary.
"We need to streamline the process to make it quicker and less costly," he said. "We need to make it a little less onerous in terms of the kinds of resources that go into making a proposal. For the most part, we try to select the best consultant, not necessarily the least expensive, and we want to continue to do so. We should pay a reasonable fee, not necessarily the cheapest."
Commissioner Knuckles of the Department of General Services added that he was for "any simplification of the rules that does not bring about any compromise in the integrity of the process."
Architects and public officials agreed that it was important to keep the best architects interested in continuing to work in the public sector, even if the private sector heats up and that interest is no longer fueled by necessity.
"It represents a wonderful opportunity for New York," said Kent Barwick, president of the Municipal Art Society. "New York is the capital of world architecture. We have more world-class architects than anyplace else, and more young people who are hoping to become world-class architects. What the City of New York needs to do is to put these architects to work planning the city that we need."

SECTION: Section 10; Page 3; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Industrial Occupancy;
A Blue-Collar Home Feels Recession's Grip

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
TIMES are turbulent in industrial real estate again, says Mathew R. Sassano, who is well placed to judge such matters. He is the general manager of Atlas Terminals, a 25-acre industrial center in Glenwood, Queens, where 52 tenants operate in 38 buildings with a total of one million square feet of space.
Occupancy had reached 100 percent in the 80's after the dispiriting 70's, he said, but the vacancy rate climbed back to 25 percent over the last two and a half years. About half the net loss was a result of bankruptcies of smaller mom-and-pop businesses, many of them newly formed in the 80's; the rest came when businesses left New York City for areas of lower operating costs. 
 But Atlas Terminals has kept reinvesting in the property and there have been some new arrivals and expansions. One of the arrivals is an office user paying about double the rent of an industrial tenant.
All in all, the property provides a snapshot illustration of the problems in industrial property that recession has compounded. Historically successful under the long-term ownership of the Hemmerdinger family, Atlas Terminals shows the effects of the city's shrinking blue-collar-jobs base, the continuing pressure of high taxes and labor costs on small business and the effort of a property owner to adapt industrial space to the market. As the recession continues, it provides another clue to what the city can expect in the way of declining property tax revenue.
Citywide, assessments on commercial property have dropped 15 percent in the last two years -- from $51.1 billion to $43.3 billion. Factory and industrial buildings, a subcategory of commercial properties, fell 20 percent, to $785 million from $987 million. Commercial property as a whole provides about half the $7.9 billion in property taxes billed by New York City.
The trend foreshadows a shrinkage of the tax base, which will be magnified over time by laws that make it difficult in New York City to convert industrial buildings to more productive commercial uses.
But so far, property taxes have risen rather than fallen. The reason is the steady increase in the tax rate and the fact that assessment changes are phased in over five years, causing a lag between actual assessments and billable assessments. At Atlas Terminals, taxes have risen 30 percent in the last two years, to the point that they now amount to about 25 percent of total rents.
Atco Properties & Management, a subsidiary of the Hemmerdinger Corporation, operates Atlas Terminals. The family-run company has broader real-estate interests, but it continues to make capital improvements at the industrial center, which was started by the late Henry H. Hemmerdinger in 1922. The company's president now is H. Dale Hemmerdinger, the founder's grandson.
Last year Atco put over $1 million into upgrading a building with two floors of 30,000 square feet each on a long stretch of Cooper Avenue, the property's main street frontage, at 80th Street.
"We are long-term players so we put money back into the property," said Mr. Hemmerdinger, "although there is usually not enough in rent to justify the investment because the industrial base is shrinking. We took a chance that by investing that amount of money we would get a better quality tenant that would help the whole terminal."
The tenant was forthcoming. Community School District 24, the board with which Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez is embroiled in a dispute over his "rainbow" curriculum requirements, took the second floor on a 10-year lease in September. The board and its staff of 75 work there.
AS an office tenant, the school district is paying about $10 a square foot a year, double the rent of $5 to $5.25 a square foot a year that industrial tenants pay. The opportunity to turn part of the occupancy to office use, especially in the renovated and attractively refaced buildings along Cooper Avenue, was created by the neighborhood -- pleasant, residential and close to city bus service.
On the ground floor of the upgraded building is a Manhattan-based manufacturing tenant, N.C.C. Sportswear Corporation, a maker of women's sportswear and knit tops.
The company took 30,000 square feet for its cutting and shipping operations; the knitting is done by small jobbers at various Queens locations. N.C.C. Sportswear started out three years ago in 15,000 square feet in the Ozone Park section.
"New York is coming back a little bit because of the South American help we're getting," said Oliviero Capacchione, the production manager, although clothing manufacturing that requires heavily automated equipment has long since left for lower-cost locales. "As long as there are people who work on sewing machines, you have an industry."
There are only 25 employees in the space, part of a work force of 1,000 at Atlas Terminals. But only a quarter of them work in manufacturing now, said Mr. Sassano, the general manager. Most of the rest are in warehousing and distribution. Fifteen years ago there were 1,500 jobs at Atlas Terminals and three-quarters of them were manufacturing.
The activities are diverse. There is a sign maker, a fine-furniture maker, a mattress distributor, a medicine manufacturer, a food importer, a book distributor, a trucker, a maker of scented clothing hangers.
In one business, Glendale Products, Enzo Alcamo is carrying on a custom furnituremaking trade established in 1944. He joined the company in 1959 as a cabinetmaker from Italy and is now the owner with 30 employees in 18,000 square feet.
"Most companies like ours in New York have gone out of business," said Mr. Alcamo, whose products include high-quality furniture for executive suites.The major problems have been high taxes and union wage rates, he said. But it also has been necessary to "teach new employees at our own expense."
Nevertheless, he expects to renew his lease when it expires next year.
"This location is ideal -- very residential, and you can find restaurants and banks," he said. "If we were to go out of town we'd never find the skilled labor we need."
NEARBY, Leonard Horowitz, general manager of Mason Medical Products, a division of M.R.C. Industries, says New York City's occupancy tax is the main reason much business has left. The commercial tenant pays the city a tax of 4.2 percent of its gross rent outside central Manhattan and 6 percent in Manhattan south of 96th Street.
Mason Medical produces cushions and bed products for hospitals and nursing homes. It has about 120 employees and has renegotiated its lease on 100,000 square feet to the year 2000.
"The cost of doing business is sky high here," he said, "but it would not be advantageous to move and lose our labor force."
In 1993 Atlas Terminals plans to upgrade another building, an 18,000-square-foot warehouse and distribution structure that will get thermal windows and waterproofing and be "made to look good for the future," said Mr. Sassano. A construction man who has run Atlas Terminals for 25 years, he said that in the last three weeks two tenants had agreed to renew their leases and expand. Mason Medical took an additional 18,000 square feet and National Van Equipment Company added 16,000 square feet to its 30,000 square feet.
"These are the first deals we've made in a year," he said. "We hope this is a sign of a turnaround, but it's really too soon to say that."

HEADLINE: In Hartford, the Latest Desert Boot Comes in Pairs of Four

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN

 BODY:
FOR nearly 200 years, the Smith-Worthington Saddlery Company of Hartford has filled some unusual orders. When explorer Richard E. Byrd went to Antarctica, his sled dogs were equipped with harnesses made by Smith-Worthington. When the bobbies of England, who traditionally did not carry firearms, were issued revolvers during World War II, the Hartford company made the holsters. In more recent years, it did some leather work on the prototype of a space suit and even produced a harness to hold a pacemaker on a pig for an experiment at Yale-New Haven Hospital.
And now, perhaps, it's racing shoes for camels. 
 A year ago, the American embassy in Abu Dhabi, the largest state of the United Arab Emirates on the Persian Gulf, inquired in a memo to certain Government agencies: Did anyone know of an American company that could supply custom-made leather shoes for racing camels?
In the Middle East, camel races are major events. In Abu Dhabi, the memo explained, there are about 10,000 racing camels; one can sell for as much as $1.5 million in United States dollars. But the expensive camels get sore feet so much while training that they are often unable to enter the races. Although it is forbidden to wear shoes during a race, training shoes would at least protect their feet so they could get to the starting line.
John Cabitor of the Hartford office of the United States Department of Commerce read the memo and immediately thought of Smith-Worthington, third oldest company in Connecticut, oldest saddlery company in the nation and the fulfiller of many strange requests over the years. He called Curtis C. Hanks, Smith-Worthington's president.
In the last few months, Mr. Hanks has been communicating with officials in Abu Dhabi, with some success and a lot of frustration. Initially, he had sent a letter to the American embassy in Abu Dhabi expressing interest in making shoes for camels but mentioning that he would have to see a sample shoe. "Frankly," he wrote, "we do not have many camels in Hartford and we would be hard put to properly design-manufacture one without a sample."
 
Doing Research on Goshen Farm
 In return, he has received letters from two companies in Abu Dhabi expressing interest in establishing a connection with Smith-Worthington, but no sample shoe has arrived as yet. So Mr. Hanks is planning on doing some preliminary research at a farm in Goshen where there are a few camels.
He knows that getting close to a camel is an experience not coveted by most businessmen. Camels are renowned for their foul dispositions and are apt to kick and spit when displeased, which is often. Camels do not even like other camels.
Still, Mr. Hanks is willing to chance a camel's fretting in the effort to find a new market for Smith-Worthington, which has survived for nearly two centuries by adjusting to the times and finding niches in the market.
Through the 19th century and into the 20th it supplied saddles, bridles and whips for the cavalry and harnesses for draft horses on the farms and for those that pulled the wagons of the Barnum & Bailey circus from city to city.
When the horse was king, Smith-Worthington was a giant. During World War I, its five-story plant on the Park River employed about 1,000 persons working on a variety of contracts, including making pack saddles to carry big guns and ammunition for the Russian army.
 
Then Came the Automobile
 The automobile spelled the end of Smith-Worthington as a big company and eventually its plant was razed to make way for the portion of Interstate 84 that cuts through Hartford. It became a small company at a new location on Homestead Avenue but with a big reputation for making custom English saddles, bridles and other equestrian supplies for a worldwide market.
It makes about 1,000 saddles annually but only about 100 are produced in Hartford, by two saddle makers seated at leather-working machines that date to the turn of the century. The rest of the saddles are designed in Hartford but made in England. The reason is one of simple economics, Mr. Hanks explained: "I can get an experienced saddle maker there for the salary of a person putting them in boxes here."
Many of Smith-Worthington's customers, Mr. Hanks said, are professional trainers and others who do a lot of riding. Many disabled people often need special saddles. "A few weeks ago, we made one for a lady who is only in her 30's but she has a progressive disabling disease and knows she will be in a wheelchair in five years but wants to enjoy riding until then," he said. Very large people can require very large saddles. "One man had a thigh like this," said Mr. Hanks, stretching out one arm as far as it would go. "Two people could fit in the saddle we made for him."
And then, said Mr. Hanks, there are the people -- he calls them the "Rolls-Royce crowd" -- who want custom saddles because they are that, custom made. One day in 1958, a man who identified himself as the Shah of Iran showed up with some retainers to buy saddles for his royal horses. The people at Smith-Worthington called the Iranian embassy in Washington to make sure it was the Shah. It was.
 
Passed Through Three Families
 Curtis Smith paused by a saddle under construction. "If Mr. Smith were to return today," he said, "he'd say we were doing it the right way." The "tree" of the saddle, he said, is of metal and wood. The webbing is of linen. The leather has been stretched three times to make sure it will retain its form. No plastic or artificial materials go into Smith-Worthington saddles.
The Mr. Smith he referred to was Normand Smith, who founded the company in 1794. The business was situated north of the Old State House, which still graces Hartford's Main Street, at "the sign of the Mounted Dragoon."
Perhaps the most impressive statistic about Smith-Worthington is that only three families have owned it during its 198 years: the Smith family, the Roberts family and the Hanks family. The Worthington name was added for George Worthington, a Smith family in-law, when he joined the company.
The Smith family held on until this century when the company was purchased by an employee, John Allen Roberts. Then, after World War II, it was purchased from Mr. Roberts by another employee, Clinton C. Hanks, who had gone to work there in 1936 as an office boy and bookkeeper. The elder Hanks, now 77, is chairman of Smith-Worthington but comes in to work three days a week. His son, as president, carries on day-to-day operations.
And business, said the younger Hanks, is just fine today, despite the recession. "We did more business by the end of August this year than we did in all of 1991," he said.
He admits, though, that he would like the camel shoe business. It does have an exotic flavor to it.

HEADLINE: Overcoming the Holocaust With Success

BYLINE: By RICHARD F. SHEPARD

 BODY:
THE other night William B. Helmreich finished a talk in Great Neck, fielded a few questions from the audience and then listened with pleasure as one man stood up and said, "I just want to express my deep appreciation for what you did. You gave us respect and dignity."
The man was not speaking for a special-interest group or a class of people who need to wrap themselves in images. He was a survivor, a word in certain circles that takes on a particular and somber uniqueness: a survivor who lived through the specific and dreadful ministrations visited upon unfortunates in the grasp of the Nazi regime. 
 The man was expressing gratitude for Mr. Helmreich's latest book, "Against All Odds: Holocaust Survivors and the Successful Lives They Made in America" (Simon & Schuster, $23). The author, a 47-year-old professor of sociology and Judaic studies at City College and the City University Graduate Center, was gratified by the stranger's comment, because, well, he was a stranger, and the thanks derived purely from the book itself.
 
Interviewed 300 People
 "He was not one of the 380 people I interviewed for the book," Mr. Helmreich said, adding that he had not even met him in Great Neck, where the author lives.
There have been many books about the survivors of the concentration camps, but this one, the author said, struck off into a new direction.
"No book talks about the survivors in regard to anything but their pathologies," Mr. Helmreich said. "There are no social histories. Until now, most sources drew from limited samples. Yet only 18 percent of the survivors ever saw a psychologist. The survivors had lives before and after the war.
"Why did I write this book? I felt it would be a travesty if survivors were only remembered as the skeletons they looked like when they emerged from the camps. Hitler made them look that way. Why give Hitler a victory by leaving this impression?"
There were 140,000 Jewish Holocaust survivors who made it to the United States, and those were the people that seized Mr. Helmreich's interest. His parents had escaped from Belgium to France and Switzerland, where the author was born 10 months before the family emigrated to New York in 1946. His Polish-born father and his mother had lost family members to the Holocaust.
For all his personal interest in the subject, Mr. Helmreich saw in this study of adjustment a universal meaning applicable to many people. "Everyone goes through a personal crisis at some time," he said. "How did these people learn to live, to love, to trust, to bring children into the world? Generally, they coped well."
The project took six years to finish, which Mr. Helmreich did last year in Israel, as Iraqi scud missiles were flying in the gulf war. He was a visiting professor at Hebrew University and remembers that as a New Yorker, he was not especially daunted by a refractory scud-menaced atmosphere and that he had told himself, "No third-rate dictator is going to chase me out of a place."
Perhaps it was an attitude absorbed from the survivors Mr. Helmreich had interviewed, as varied slices of life as one could expect to find in any group of people indiscriminately plucked from their homes and their lives and subjected to horrors that defy explanation or excuse.
"I traveled to Tuscaloosa, to Atlanta, to Racine, to Kenosha, the length and breadth of the land," Mr. Helmreich said, explaining that survivors had clustered in New York, but spread to every corner of the country.
"While they are united by the unique experiences they went through, I found tremendous individuality. In some places I found two people who lived within a block of each other but wouldn't speak, not because of hostility, but because they had altogether different interests. I chose people who were representative of a range of varieties, from Hasidim to farmers."
The diversity of survivors who speak about their arrivals in America, the effects of their Holocaust years and their adjustments is astonishing. Art dealers, business people, wage earners, a survivor who became an American general, another who became a California Congressman and another who headed the Anti-Defamation League all addressed the issue put to them by the author, and their reactions were as unpredictably varied as the people are as a group.
The publication of the book gives little promise that Mr. Helmreich will have time to loll about Great Neck with his wife, Helaine, a speech pathologist who has just finished a first novel; his three sons, 9 to 19 years old, and his 6-year-old daughter.
"Against All Odds" is Mr. Helmreich's eighth book, and he shows no signs of calling it quits with his word processor. In addition he is active in more than the classroom at City College.
As a matter of fact, it is difficult to pin down the interests of the youthful-looking blue-eyed savant, who as a student at Washington University in Missouri in the 1960's, found himself as the lone white person in a group affiliated with the Black Panthers and a protester against police harassment.
Put that together with Mr. Helmreich's service as a volunteer in Israel in the 1967 war and his work with Bowery derelicts, and an impressive, if confused, portrait emerges. He is also an enthusiastic New Yorker. Upon returning from Israel this year he walked every block on Broadway, apparently mostly to energize himself.
The books that Mr. Helmreich has written also do not wrap him up easily. "The World of the Yeshiva" was a fascinating volume about education in the traditional Jewish world in which he grew up. "The Things They Say Behind Your Back" examines the stereotypes that various ethnic groups are saddled with, including chapters on Jews, Italians, Blacks, Japanese, Chinese, Irish, Poles, Hispanics and WASP's.
"Growing Up Jewish in New York" was a Book-of-the-Month Club alternate. Then there was a study of the relationship of black people to Africa, a textbook of sociology and "How to Interview for a Job."
"I'm in my 20th year at City College, and I feel my students need me," Mr. Helmreich said. "They are just like the students who went to City in the 1930's and 1940's. They have the same needs and aspirations. This is their Harvard."
 
An Undiminished Interest
 Years back Mr. Helmreich immersed himself in black studies at Yale, an interest that has not diminished, as evidenced by his leadership in campus projects like the Center of Urban Legal Studies at City College and the City College Center for Conflict Resolution.
"I've just finished doing interviews on black anti-Semitism," he said. "The results are interesting. Younger blacks are not rigid and don't know a lot about Jews. They feel optimistic. They don't see this in racial and religious terms, but in economic terms."
Perhaps Mr. Helmreich's optimism has rubbed off on the students. That is because he is an optimist, if only because he says it is the only way that one can work toward any future that is not written in despair.
For a man whose laundry list of human problems seems inexhaustible, Mr. Helmreich presents a profile that is anything but harried. Enthusiastic, yes, but worried, no. "I find it's best not to take life seriously, at least in my own affairs," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William B. Helmreich, professor of sociology and Judaic studies and author of "Against All Odds: Holocaust Survivors and the Successful Lives They Made in America." (Betty Rosenzweig)

LENGTH: 1561 words

HEADLINE: On a Cold Night, Room for the Homeless

BYLINE: By ALBERT J. PARISI

DATELINE: RIVER EDGE

 BODY:
A COLD, bitter December wind lashed at their clothing as the five men and two women stepped from a van and entered the First Congregational Church here. Somewhere in the building, radiators clanged and whistled a shrill song.
It was 7:30 P.M., and they had nowhere else to sleep. There had been no room for them at the county center for the homeless in Hackensack, and a county van had brought them to the church. 
Inside the auditorium-gymnasium, where Christmas ornaments hung delicately from the ceiling, volunteers waited to show the seven their cots for the night, the men and women separated by a wooden divider. With blankets and bedsheets supplied them by the county, they made up cots upon which they placed their few belongings.
Anna Rodriguez, 37, a thin, fragile-looking woman from Jersey City, sat on her cot, clothing neatly folded beside her, her back to the other visitors. Confusion and joy chased each other across her face.
On this night, the church here, which is affiliated with the United Church of Christ, was one of two in Bergen County that were taking the overflow from a county-run shelter for the homeless in Hackensack. It is part of a program in which 42 churches and synagogues are participating through the Inter-Religious Fellowship for the Homeless of Bergen County, a nonprofit agency.
In this county, ranked for years as one of the nation's top 10 wealthiest areas, the homeless population rose from 2,530 in 1989 to 4,302 in 1991, and it is still rising, according to a county report issued in August. And those figures reflect only the people who seek assistance. Advocates for the homeless say there are at least seven times as many in need who do not seek help and remain uncounted.
To receive help through the nonprofit group's program, applicants must be actively seeking employment and come from the county's 72 communities, but even those who do not meet the requirements are sometimes accepted.
"When the temperature outside is below freezing," said Kathleen J. Stanton, the program's executive director, "it's kind of tough to say no to anyone."
In the hour before the visitors arrived, volunteers in the kitchen were unwrapping dishes of food they had brought from home. "It's very hard to get good gravy out of meat loaf," said Bertha Myhren, 64, of Oradell as Sally Zick, 65, of River Edge nodded agreement. They placed the heaping aluminum trays in an oven and turned their attention to bowls of mashed potatoes and sunset bright carrots.
Soon the food was ready, and the "guests," as the volunteers called them, began filling their plates. At nearby tables they sat and ate as the volunteers joined their ranks.
Miss Rodriguez sat to one side, and the Rev. John H. Danner, the congregation's pastor and his wife, Linda, joined her and exchanged smiles. Nearby, a black and white television set came to life with "Wheel of Fortune," but the volume was low and it received little attention.
For Laura Silver, 32, formerly of New Milford, and Gordon DeFreese, 36, formerly of Mahwah, this was their first night in a shelter after losing a makeshift apartment in an illegal rooming house in Hackensack.
 
A Landlord's Complaint
 "We've been staying with friends, but they could only take us in for so long before the landlord started complaining," Miss Silver said. Both are receiving limited government assistance and are looking for work, she said, but their prospects are few.
"I was working in a cemetery, was there about 11 months, and the shop supervisor took a dislike to me," Mr. DeFreese said. "I got fired." Being late for work "a couple of days in a row sure didn't help," he added.
Miss Silver, a baker's helper by profession, said that more and more local bakeries were laying off staff members rather than hiring.
They look upon the shelter program as a safety net of sorts. Mr. DeFreese, who has been jailed three times for failure to pay support for his four children, said that most of what he has earned recently has gone to pay that support. "There just wasn't that much left for me after that," he said.
 
Three Children Taken Away
 Miss Silver said her three children had been taken away from her and placed in permanent foster homes. "It's tough, especially with Christmas coming on, what with us not having enough to give to the kids," Mr. DeFreese said.
"If I could do it," he added, "if we both could do it, we'd like nothing more than to have a place of our own and all the kids together under one roof. But I'd be dreaming, and that wouldn't make this here nightmare go away."
By 8:30, the mealtime dishes had been cleared and another pot of coffee was brewing. When the guests were asked about their lives, some talked eagerly; others spoke hardly at all.
Larry Rogers said that his family was in Poland and that he hoped to join the family members someday. He said he is terminally ill and unable to work.
Robert Jones, a Vietnam War veteran, told volunteers that he was a machinist for 18 years until he recently lost his job. He has entered a county retraining program.
Miss Rodriguez, a native of Puerto Rico, does not remember the last time she worked or what job she held, she said. Her deep brown eyes are both suspicious and warm, as quick to change as the images on the nearby television screen.
 
First Night in Bergen Program
 This was her first night in the Bergen County program. She recalled a stay in a Newark shelter as a fearful experience. For a while, she said, she had stayed with a male friend until his demands for sex led her to leave.
"People out there, they try to hurt you, and I've seen too many friends die in the streets," she said. "Maybe here it is different, people are different. I don't want to be raped again."
Tyrone C., who insisted that his full name not be used, is 26 and eager for work. He passed around color photographs of his wife and 3-year-old daughter, who live with family members in Middletown, N.Y.
"I never truly understood what it meant to be homeless until I became one myself," he said.
"I was working two jobs, had my own place and was saving enough to bring my family here when it happened," he said. Within the course of a week, the part-time job he had at a Hackensack diner ended when it was closed for renovations; he arrived one day at his other job, in an auto body shop, and "found the place padlocked."
Tyrone C. said that he could have been staying with his brother nearby, but that "he has enough to worry about with his own family." He added: "With God's help, I'll come through this O.K., and living here like this, well, it's kind of a means to an end."
 
Guests Getting Ready for Bed
 By 9:45 the conversation had subsided. Overhead lights were dimmed, and some guests began to drift toward their beds. Miss Rodriguez lay on her cot wrapped in a gray blanket as though she were in a cocoon.
By 10:30, the lights in the auditorium were turned off. An illuminated exit sign cast an orange glow over the cots and the guests in their blankets, some of them already asleep. The overnight volunteers moved off to the separate kitchen area.
Art Caughlan, 45, of River Edge, a volunteer at the shelter, owns a local insurance agency. He feels he has been lucky in life, he said, and "I believe in giving back to the community in whatever way I can." In the past, he has helped raise funds for the overflow shelter program -- but now, he said, "funds are hard to come by, especially from corporations."
To be an overnight volunteer at the shelter, he added, was "kind of like having guests overnight in your house; with your heart, you watch over them."
The other overnight volunteer, Wayne Placek, 45, of Oradell, the church's shelter coordinator and a sales manager for a glass replacement company, remembered an unemployed construction worker who had stayed overnight at the church shelter last summer. "He asked us to pray for him," Mr. Placek said, "that he had a job interview and was confident about it."
 
A Job Is Found
 The following week, the construction worker returned, Mr. Placek said, "shook hands all around -- he'd gotten the job -- and thanked us for our prayers and support."
By 1:30 A.M., the wind was so strong that it was shaking the windowpanes. A mandatory bed check showed that all the guests were accounted for. "All is quiet," Mr. Caughlan noted in a log sheet that would be given to officials at the county center.
During the night, Mr. Placek and Mr. Caughlan took turns catching naps on a couch upstairs in the church. Shortly after 5 o'clock, they set about brewing a fresh pot of coffee and preparing a breakfast of doughnuts, cold cereal and orange juice for their guests.
Soon the guests themselves were up and stirring, folding their sheets and blankets and putting personal belongings back into their bags. There was a general move to the breakfast table, though Miss Rodriguez joined in only after Mr. Placek invited her.
Tyrone C. knelt quietly against a far wall in silent prayer.
By 6:30, carrying bagged lunches prepared by Mrs. Danner, the guests were ready to take the van back to Hackensack, where county aides would help in their job search.
"Maybe today we'll be lucky," Miss Silver said as Mr. DeFreese nodded somewhat groggily in agreement. "I've just got this feeling, a special feeling," she said.
