HEADLINE: Japan's Nuclear Fiasco

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TSURUGA, Japan

 BODY:
IT STARTED as the ultimate Japanese dream: a technology that promised a virtually inexhaustible supply of electricity to power Japan's factories and houses, and a quick, neat way for Japan to convert its growing piles of nuclear waste into an energy source that could keep the country running through wars in the Persian Gulf, natural disasters or political upheavals. Japan's bureaucrats, awash with success in autos and electronics, expected it to become another triumph for Japanese industrial policy.
Now, week by week, Japan's most ambitious nuclear project is falling apart, variously described as an environmental disaster waiting to happen, an invitation to terrorists looking for fuel for nuclear weapons, and a financial fiasco for the Japanese taxpayers and utility shareholders. For the many admirers of Japanese industrial planning -- some of whom met in Little Rock, Ark., with President-elect Bill Clinton last week -- the experience is a cautionary tale. Even the masters of merging the talents of Government and industry can blow it, especially if they ignore fundamental changes in a market or a changing political atmosphere. 
 Nearly three decades ago, Japan decided it would develop a new generation of breeder reactors that would produce new fuel as quickly as they burned the old. There was one hitch: Rather than utilize uranium, the ordinary fuel, these reactors would be powered by plutonium. While both are radioactive and must be treated with great care, plutonium is much more toxic than uranium -- a mere speck can cause cancer. It can also be converted much more easily for use in atomic bombs -- the diversion of a few pounds could put an enormous weapon in the hands of terrorists or countries that are aspiring nuclear powers.
But to the Japanese, the risk seemed worth it. Perhaps no nation feels as perpetually insecure about its dependence on foreign countries as Japan, which imports 80 percent of its energy. True, the breeder reactor project would require Japan to find a safe way to harness one of the deadliest substances on earth -- and persuade the rest of the world that it was safe. But Japan's industrial planners convinced the country's electric utilities that together they could do in nuclear technology what they have done in other industries.
 
A $5 Billion Breeder
 With initial encouragement from Washington, they formed companies, made technological alliances overseas and carefully crafted a public relations campaign that skimmed over some of the unpleasant details. Meanwhile, hundreds of engineers and Government officials descended on this remote fishing village on the Sea of Japan 250 miles west of Tokyo. Since 1986, Japan has spent $5 billion here on a prototype breeder reactor named Monju, for the Buddhist divinity of wisdom.
Japanese officials still defend their plans vociferously. They say the United States -- which dropped its own breeder reactor program 15 years ago largely to stop the proliferation of bomb-grade materials -- will come to regret not taking a longer-range vision for nuclear energy.
But now, with the first of 30 planned shipments of plutonium scheduled to arrive here by sea in a few weeks, criticism is mounting not only of the way the plutonium is being transported but of the environmental, economic and political prudence of the entire project.
And behind the scenes, a Government that prides itself on lifting its industrial policy above the plane of political debate has suddenly found itself divided and bickering, and looking for a way out.
"It is almost inconceivable that such a good idea could have turned this bad," said a senior Japanese official who asked not to be identified. "We spent the last 20 years building this project, and we'll probably spend the next 20 killing it."
So while America has a lot to learn from the way Japan manages the business of high technology, the plutonium uproar holds some important lessons for those who would import Japanese industrial planning techniques wholesale. Among them is that economic realities cannot be ignored once the policy is set.
When the breeder project began amid the energy crises of the 1970's, experts said uranium in the 1990's would be scarce and expensive. That made the far more expensive process of recovering plutonium from the spent fuel of ordinary uranium-burning reactors and burning it for electricity seem less daunting.
Instead, uranium prices have plunged, and, depending on whom you ask, electricity derived from plutonium will be 5 to 15 times more expensive. In a country that already has the most expensive electricity in the world, that statistic has all but doomed the Government's chances of getting utility companies to go along with its plans -- a point underscored recently when the Power Reactor and Nuclear Fuel Development Corporation, which is building Monju, said the $5 billion breeder reactor may operate for only seven years.
 
A Blind Spot?
 Japan's experience also points up the dangers of building such a huge business around a policy that reversing course would cost jobs and political embarrassment. And some of those involved say the plutonium effort demonstrates anew the recurrent blind spot in Japanese industrial policy: Too little regard, until it is too late, for the international ramifications. That was also the lesson of the 1980's, when the Government, discovering that its growing trade surpluses were provoking anger worldwide, scrambled to repair the damage from flooding overseas markets with its cars and computer chips.
A confluence of unanticipated events has made life miserable at the powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry and the lesser-known Science and Technology Agency. The end of the cold war created an unexpected glut of plutonium, much of it from disassembled nuclear weapons. That has heightened fears that there is a vast world oversupply of plutonium -- ripe for diversion to countries like Iraq, Iran, Pakistan and North Korea -- just as Japan sets about producing far more.
In fact, rising international concern about nuclear proliferation has made plutonium breeders a far bigger political problem than anyone anticipated. The Japanese themselves, for example, are in the embarrassing position of insisting that North Korea abandon its plants to recover plutonium from nuclear waste -- the core of a suspected weapons project -- while Japanese engineers are breaking ground for the same kind of facility 700 miles across the Sea of Japan.
Meanwhile, Japanese diplomats have been fanning across Asia trying to quiet countries howling about the potential dangers of the plutonium shipment now under way -- a shipboard fire that could breach the containers holding a ton of plutonium, a terrorist attack, an accident that would force the ship to stop in a crowded port city. South Africa, Brazil, Argentina, the Philippines and a host of small South Pacific nations have told Japan to keep its lightly armed convoy -- bearing the largest sealift of the material ever attempted -- out of their territorial waters.
More horrifying for the Japanese, neighbors with memories of Japan as a colonizing power are questioning the country's true motives. "No one in Korea really believes Japan plans to use this plutonium for peaceful purposes," said Lee Chul, a leading South Korean politician. There is no evidence that Japan is violating its own ban on possessing or building nuclear weapons, but a few weeks ago the Government felt compelled to say that for 30 years "Japan has earned the trust of the international community for its peaceful uses of nuclear energy. There is absolutely no reason to question Japan on this matter."
 
A Start in the 50's
 Japan's nuclear-energy policy originated in the 1950's. Fresh from the end of the American occupation and still preoccupied with rebuilding the country, the Government saw nuclear power as the most reliable way to realize its industrial ambitions. In 1966, it formally declared that it would start a huge effort in self-sufficient breeder reactors.
The next year, it laid the first bricks of the infrastructure, forming the Power Reactor and Nuclear Fuel Development Corporation to coordinate the use of plutonium as a fuel and forging an alliance among private utility companies, MITI and other Government agencies, as well as Japan's research laboratories and universities. It was, in short, classic industrial policy, Japan-style -- this time with the encouragement of the United States.
"You have to remember that the U.S. started with these ideas first, and Japan just followed their plans," said Kenji Yamaji, a research fellow at the Central Research Institute of Electric Power Industries.
From the start, Japan's giant utility companies were reluctant: The expense was huge and plutonium is extremely hard to handle. But none dared question official policy, which was to convert all spent fuel from ordinary nuclear reactors into plutonium for the new breeder reactors.
Starting in the early 1980's, Government researchers realized it would be impossible to recycle all the nation's spent nuclear fuel, but Mr. Yamaji and others say they did not want to sound the alarm "until after the Government agreed to modify its policies." Similar self-censorship, the experts say, is one reason Japan was slow to see the pitfalls in its policy. It had already entered into still-secret agreements with Britain and France to help them build reprocessing plants -- Japan's contribution is said to be more than $3 billion -- and to ship nuclear waste there for conversion to plutonium. So for a decade, Japan has exported its spent fuels, and with them its storage problems.
"Japan had to bow deep to get them to build the plants," said one official involved in the deal. "That is one reason no one can back out of these contracts now." (Japan's own $7 billion reprocessing center, delayed for years, will not open until at least the end of the decade.)
In the mid-1980's, just as Japan began to break ground for the Monju plant, parts of the grand plan began to unravel. Chernobyl happened, and in a nation with an intense nuclear allergy, reinforced by regular images of the victims at Hiroshima and Nagasaki, public opinion began to turn against all nuclear plants.
Though 11 plants are now under construction, no new site has been approved in years; a series of malfunctions of existing plants, leading to some sudden shutdowns, has worsened the public image here. As a result, Japan's early hopes of doubling the number of its nuclear power plants in the next 20 years -- there are 42 operating now -- have been all but officially abandoned.
For the breeder program, the problems were even worse. The Europeans, following the United States' lead, began to rethink the wisdom of the program. France's Superphenix breeder reactor, a model for Monju's design, was forced to shut down in 1988 because of technical problems. It may never restart. The Germans abandoned their prototype, and Britain says it will close its breeder reactor in 1994. The Japanese are the last breeder-reactor customers for the European reprocessing centers.
Officially, the Japanese say they are unfazed. "Were Japan to be the only nation working in this area," the Foreign Ministry said last month, the country would "view its responsibility as even greater and redouble its efforts to contribute to the international community through technological development."
 
A Possible Switch
 Behind the scenes, many in the Government and industry have their doubts. As evidence has mounted that the world -- and Japan -- will be awash in plutonium, the Science and Technology Agency has rushed to come up with ways to burn it rather than produce more. Its idea involves mixing plutonium with uranium to fuel ordinary nuclear power plants, which run on uranium alone.
In other words, the Government has told the utilities to replace a relatively inexpensive fuel with a far more expensive one. The giant utility companies were horrified; the implications for their shareholders, rate-payers and profits were obvious. "In public we will tell you that this is taking the long-term perspective," a senior official of Tokyo Electric Power said recently. "But what everyone knows, and won't say in public, is that this will cost consumers a fortune."
Meanwhile, here at the Monju plant, engineers like Ken Yamamoto have raced to make sure that Japan's breeder reactor is not plagued by the problems that killed France's. The technology is difficult: Breeder reactors must use sodium, rather than water, to carry away intense heat -- a more complex system. Moreover, the piping is much thinner, so as to transfer heat more quickly. That can make the system more prone to cracking. It was the piping that tripped up the French.
"Japanese are very good at checking and quality control, and we think we have overcome the problems," Mr. Yamamoto said the other day at the plant, soon to "go critical" with its first bit of plutonium fuel. "We believe it is safer because it is a Japanese design."
Then there are the political problems -- particularly how Japan would get its European-processed plutonium back to its own shores.
In fact, most experts agree that the risk of shipping the plutonium by sea is fairly low, but still, Japan kept the details of the voyage highly secret. (The convoy swept south from France, around South Africa, and is now believed heading north in the Pacific near Indonesia.)
The shipment is expected to arrive in Japan shortly after the new year. But that will not end the controversy. The fuel will be in reprocessing and storage for at least three years, Japanese officials conceded recently, before Monju is ready to start burning it. To some, that seems to contradict Japan's pledge never to stockpile plutonium, making it a potential target for terrorists. (The Japanese refer to the plutonium as a "running stock" -- to assure steady supply.)
In theory, at least, there will be 30 to 40 more shipments over the next 18 years. In recent weeks, some Japanese officials have started saying the plan is being reviewed, but others argue the country should go full steam ahead, because energy sources and prices are unpredictable -- and Japan cannot afford to be caught without. They reject suggestions that Japan should build a strategic reserve of uranium at the current low market prices. "At this stage there is no reason to change our policy," said Noboru Hatakeyama, Vice Minister for International Trade and Industry.
In the end, Japan will probably scale back the plans drastically. But if experience is any guide, it will not let breeder reactor technology -- or any other strategically vital industry -- die completely. It will just wait for another change of economic fortunes or political realities. Until then, the question is how high a price Japan is willing to pay -- financially and politically -- for an idea that has never quite gone as planned.
 
 
THE HARSH MEMORIES OF MINAMATA
 AILEEN MIOKO SMITH got her start confronting the Japanese Government in one of the country's saddest cities -- Minamata, the site of mercury poisoning that became a symbol of what happens when government and industry turn a blind eye to industrial pollution.
With her late husband, the photographer W. Eugene Smith, she put together a book of painful images of the deformities and illnesses afflicting victims of the poisonings, who had eaten fish contaminated by polluted effluents. The book helped force Tokyo to recognize and compensate the victims.
Two decades later, Ms. Smith is back -- organizing a grass-roots campaign against imports of plutonium to fuel breeder reactors. From her home in Kyoto, she has spent years in the antinuclear movement, a movement that until recently was small enough that the Government and utility companies largely ignored it.
No longer. The daughter of a Japanese mother and an American father, Ms. Smith started an organization called Stop the Monju, a reference to the prototype breeder reactor, that persuaded Japanese homemakers to write to foreign governments, asking them to bar Japan's plutonium convoy from their waters. (Applying foreign pressure on the Japanese Government is usually the fastest way to effect change in Japan.)
"People say that there are no real grass-roots movements in Japan," Ms. Smith said recently. "But in fact a lot is happening."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Europe's Loss Is America's Gain

BYLINE: By Roger Cohen

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
WITH the American recovery more conspicuous than any glimmer of European growth and most analysts expecting a substantial appreciation of the dollar against European currencies in the coming year, investing in Europe in 1993 does not look particularly attractive at present.
One estimate, from S. G. Warburg, is that the dollar will be at 1.85 marks by the end of 1993, up 19 percent from 1.56 marks today. While some analysts are less bullish, there is a general feeling that stronger growth in the United States, the arrival in the White House of Bill Clinton and continuing instability in European currency markets will bolster the dollar. Clearly, this tendency must be factored into any European investment. 
 "The European economy is going to be weak, at least through the first half of 1993," said Didier Philippe, an analyst at the Bernard Barnier brokerage in Paris. "So we favor companies with a strong presence in the United States."
This reasoning leads many analysts to favor Swiss, Dutch and British equities, which are generally most sensitive to the United States economy, and the dollar. Richard Davidson, the European equity strategist at Morgan Stanley in London, likes Royal Dutch/Shell and the Dutch publishing group Elsevier, both of which are expected to show solid earnings growth next year.
Swiss companies are among the most international in Europe and best represented in the United States. The giant food group Nestle, with a price-earnings ratio of 13.5 to 1, still looks cheap to many analysts. Among the big pharmaceuticals groups, Roche and Sandoz are widely favored.
Moreover, the Swiss banking sector could benefit both from an appreciation of the dollar -- the currency in which the banks pay commissions -- and from an expected fall in European interest rates, which would afford the banks wider margins. Melissa Carrington, an analyst at Hoare Gavett in London, likes CS Holdings and the Union Bank of Switzerland.
In Britain, where Andrew Garthwaite of S. G. Warburg estimated that 25 percent of earnings for major companies on the stock market come from the United States, analysts believe lower interest rates could benefit larger retail groups, including Dixons and Marks & Spencer. Other companies that are favored because of their strong international profile include the pharmaceuticals firm Wellcome and the media group Reuters.
However, all European equities are considered vulnerable to the deep uncertainties afflicting the Continent. A business upturn had been expected by the middle of this year, but never materialized. High German interest rates, instability in the European Monetary System and a lack of consumer confidence are all undermining the economy. The auto sector, for example, is deeply depressed and is expected to remain so through 1993.
In a report issued this month, the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development predicted 1993 European growth of just 1.2 percent, half that of the United States. Many believe this forecast, slashed from an earlier 1993 European forecast of 2.7 percent, is still optimistic.
The crucial factor remains German interest rates, which have remained high because of the Bundesbank's determination to stem inflationary pressure resulting from the cost of reunification. Europe's long-expected economic upturn has been held back because Germany's high rates have forced other European countries to follow suit, to sustain their currencies against the mark.
The consensus is that German rates will finally fall in 1993. But when? The latest estimate is that they could start easing in April, when a wage pact should be in place that would help keep inflation down.
With lower rates, financial groups throughout the Continent should eventually benefit. Among stocks that could do well are Banco Santander in Spain, Societe Generale in France and the Dresdner Bank in Germany.
But it remains unclear whether other countries, particularly France, will be able to wait for German rates to ease. Britain and Italy have already left the monetary system.
The French economy is healthier than the German, and, if not for the European monetary system, French authorities would probably lower interest rates, by as much as three percentage points, to stimulate growth.
Mr. Davidson of Morgan Stanley argues that it is inevitable that the franc will be allowed to float until Germany gets its house in order, despite strong statements from French authorities that the franc-mark parity will not budge. On this basis, he is bullish on French stocks, which would benefit heavily from sharply lower interest rates. Among the stronger French companies are the tire group Michelin, the telecommunications group Alcatel Alsthom and the financial group Credit National.
A franc float, however, is far from certain, as are all predictions in an abruptly unstable Europe. In this environment, many analysts favor bonds over equities, particularly longer-term bonds, given the expected fall in short-term interest rates. "My European portfolio for 1993 would be 60 percent bonds, 30 percent equities and 10 percent cash," Mr. Garthwaite of S. G. Warburg said.
Risk-takers might try Eurotunnel. Conflicts with the contractors building the tunnel under the channel between Britain and France continue to plague the company. But if they are resolved, the stock looks cheap to many analysts, and the projected opening of the tunnel late in 1993 should be one bright spot in Europe's somber outlook.

HEADLINE: Castle Rock Raises the Stakes

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD

 BODY:
The sleek offices of Castle Rock Entertainment were humming on Monday morning. "We have our '92 Cadillac," said Alan F. Horn, managing partner of the five-year-old film and production company, as he examined the big weekend box-office receipts of Castle Rock's newest film, "A Few Good Men."
Of course, it is up to moviegoers to determine whether the slick, expensive courtroom drama turns out to be a Cadillac or something more modest. But Mr. Horn and his four partners, including Rob Reiner, the film's director, seem assured that their $40 million gamble, starring Tom Cruise, Jack Nicholson and Demi Moore, will hardly be an Edsel. 
 In fact, although Castle Rock has produced only 10 films, it has already gained a reputation in Hollywood as one of the more innovative and successful independent companies in town. In a business where independents like Carolco, Vestron, Orion, the De Laurentiis Entertainment Group and Cannon have fallen prey to economic turmoil in recent years, Castle Rock has been notably stable.
Whether Castle Rock will succeed in the long term -- in contrast to most other independents -- is another matter. The company, with just 60 employees, faces considerable risks as it makes more expensive movies.
For now, "the outlook for Castle Rock can only be characterized as rosy," said Christopher P. Dixon, an entertainment industry analyst at Paine Webber. He cited Castle Rock's deal with Columbia Pictures, which distributes the company's movies but keeps its hands off production.
"Castle Rock now has the best of all possible worlds," Mr. Dixon said. "It has a strong distribution arrangement with a major studio, yet it is able to maintain creative control. And now with its track record, as Castle Rock attracts talent like Nicholson and Cruise, projects will continue to gravitate to them."
(Actually, the projects have been gravitating to Mr. Reiner, who makes his films there, but Castle Rock executives insist that the company is building its own name.)
"A Few Good Men," which may cost as much as $55 million after advertising and promotion, grossed $15.5 million at the box office in its first weekend. As Castle Rock's most expensive film so far, "A Few Good Men" is expected to perform strongly in the United States and abroad. But its hefty cost will certainly diminish profits.
In the past, the company shied away from big-budget star vehicles and focused largely on films costing $15 million to $25 million (excluding promotion and marketing). But it is plainly moving in new directions now. Its 1993 films include "In the Line of Fire," a $38 million adventure about the Secret Service starring Clint Eastwood. And in April, Mr. Reiner starts directing "North," a $35 million film about a young boy who wants to find new parents.
In a relatively short time, Castle Rock has produced some critical and financial successes, including "City Slickers," starring Billy Crystal, which grossed $123 million in the United States alone; "When Harry Met Sally," grossing $93 million, and "Misery," grossing $68 million.
On the television side -- which started out as Castle Rock's major business but is now secondary to movies -- the company's successes have included "Seinfeld" on NBC. It has also produced "Sessions," the critically acclaimed series created by Mr. Crystal, for Home Box Office.
Of course, Castle Rock has had its share of failures, including "Year of the Comet," which grossed less than $5 million, and "Late for Dinner," which grossed only $10 million.
BUT by far the most painful flop was the Crystal film "Mr. Saturday Night," which cost $43 million including advertising and marketing and grossed only about $16 million. (In typical Hollywood fashion, the company's partners blame everything from the film's marketing to the refusal of audiences to see Mr. Crystal in a somber role as an unpleasant borscht-belt comedian. Critics, however, noted that the film was seriously flawed.)
Castle Rock also produced "Sibling Rivalry," which grossed $20 million, and "Lord of the Flies," which grossed $15 million. And its "Honeymoon in Vegas," which cost $35 million and grossed roughly that amount in the United States, is expected to eke out some profits from videocassette and cable-television sales and foreign distribution.
But what makes Castle Rock unusual in Hollywood is not so much its box score but its management style. In a town of sharks, Castle Rock's partners swim in calm waters. Not that the five partners aren't tough. But the company is run like a 40-something boys club.
Mr. Horn, 49 years old, graduated from the Harvard Business School in 1971 and worked as a branch manager for Procter & Gamble's Ivory Soap before he was hired in the late 1970's to run business and marketing for Norman Lear's Tandem Productions, later Embassy Communications. Mr. Horn eventually became chief executive of Embassy, where he met most of the future Castle Rock partners.
The other partners are Glenn Padnick, 45, who had served as president of Embassy Television and is Castle Rock's chief television executive; Andrew Scheinman, 44, who is executive producer of "Seinfeld" and works closely on all of Mr. Reiner's projects; Martin Shafer, 38, who oversees movie projects, and Mr. Reiner, 45, who played the "Meat head" in Mr. Lear's television show "All in the Family."
Mr. Scheinman, who first met Mr. Reiner on a Hollywood tennis court, said: "We're in and out of each other's offices 50 times a day. There's no knocking on doors. We all know what's going on. We all seem to have a similar sensibility."
Mr. Horn agreed, noting: "We have a voting arrangement in terms of scripts, but I don't think we've ever voted. It's all highly informal."
And Mr. Padnick said: "We have lunch four or five times a week. We play poker every couple of weeks. Nothing goes on that each of us aren't personally aware of. We actually have a good time." He laughed. "That makes us the envy of a lot of people."
IF Castle Rock's easy style is the envy of many in Hollywood, so is the company's financial set-up. The company is privately held, so it does not disclose precise figures about its finances and salaries. Mr. Horn did acknowledge that the five partners received "comfortable" six-figure salaries. In addition, Mr. Reiner receives a director's fee for each of his films, which probably hovers at $3 million to $5 million.
Mr. Horn helped create Castle Rock after quarrels with Barry Diller, chairman of Fox Inc., led him to step down as president of the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation in 1986.
Castle Rock did not follow the path of some other independent film companies that sold stock to the public. Instead, the Castle Rock partners chose to bring in Columbia Pictures as both an equity partner and as distributor. Columbia made an initial investment of $30 million.
Columbia's parent, the Sony Corporation, now owns about 44 percent of Castle Rock, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation owns 14 percent and the partners own the remainder.
UNDER its arrangement with Columbia, Castle Rock is in charge of every level of production. "We are a dependent independent," Mr. Horn said. "We are in the business of making motion picture and television product and retaining all creative controls ourselves."
What this freedom means is that if Mr. Reiner wants to cast an unknown actor or actress, like Kathy Bates in the starring role in "Misery," he can do so. And if he wants to give Jack Nicholson $500,000 a day for two weeks work in "A Few Good Men," that's fine, too.
The downside for the company is that it does not finance films on its own and carefully hedges its investment. It may not lose a great deal of money on flops, but the company is unable to make large sums of money on hits like "City Slickers."
"If our movies had all been marginal," Mr. Horn said, "that formula would have been adjudged brilliant. But it turns out our movies did better than we thought. So these deals did not allow us to participate on the upside as much as we would like."
Because of their cost, "A Few Good Men" and the new Clint Eastwood film are being financed entirely by Columbia Pictures. Under an old agreement, New Line Cinema has financed as much as 75 percent of Castle Rock's film production costs for several other movies in exchange for foreign and video rights. That deal is ending after four more pictures.
For now, Sony's executives seem quite pleased with Columbia's involvement in Castle Rock.
"Castle Rock's growth and well-being is our well-being," said Peter Guber, chairman of Sony Entertainment. "It's a win-win philosophy. We own a bit of the company. They own creative control. We're sitting in their boat."
 
 
 
STAR-STRUCK HIGH FINANCE
 Is Jack Nicholson really worth $500,000 a day?
Well, of course, Castle Rock Entertainment's executives insist.
The high salaries of the stars of Castle Rock's latest and most expensive film, "A Few Good Men," point up how the movie industry's pronouncements about cutting costs do not quite match its deal-making. Take the case of "A Few Good Men." Including marketing and promotion, the movie probably cost a minimum of $55 million. As a result, it will have to gross at least $100 million at the box office in the United Statesto break even.
Why so expensive? Mr. Nicholson was paid $500,000 a day for two weeks work, or a total of about $5 million. The other big star, Tom Cruise, received $12.5 million, plus a percentage of the profits. Demi Moore earned $2.5 million. Rob Reiner, the director, received $3 million to $5 million. And lesser players like Kevin Bacon and Kiefer Sutherland were paid six-figure salaries.
Castle Rock executives insist that to succeed, the film needed top stars who could lure the crowds. But do stars deliver?
Mr. Cruise's last film, "Far and Away," was a financial disappointment. And Mr. Nicholson's recent movie, "Man Trouble," was a disaster. On the other hand, Kevin Costner's current film, "Bodyguard," has strong box-office appeal even though it was critically panned. The apparent reason: Audiences are promised a sexy love story between Mr. Costner and co-star Whitney Houston.
Still, some producers insist that stars are not the main selling point of a film. Richard Zanuck, one of the producers of "Driving Miss Daisy," which had no big stars, is fond of quoting his father, Darryl F. Zanuck, the longtime ruler of 20th Century Fox. The elder Zanuck said three things make a film successful: "story, story, story."

HEADLINE: Technology;
Improving Safety When Removing Lead-Based Paint

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
OFFICIALS charged with maintaining aging steel structures, like bridges and overpasses, are facing difficult choices. At some point, the layers of deteriorating, lead-based paint become so thick that workers cannot just slap on another coat of paint to retard corrosion. Instead, they must strip off the old paint and apply modern, multilayer protective coatings.
That presents the problem of how to get rid of the lead, for its buildup in the urban environment -- by no means all of it from paint -- is a major national health concern. 
 Young children, particularly, are susceptible to mental and nervous disorders from relatively low levels of lead contamination. Sand blasting operations on the Williamsburg Bridge in New York were halted earlier this year because of fears that particles of lead-based paint were blowing onto windowsills, sidewalks and playgrounds.
And even when the blasting operation is properly contained, the process produces tons of lead-contaminated sand, which has to be disposed of as toxic waste. Executives at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's Science and Technology Center report that blast cleaning a single medium-sized highway bridge can produce 800 tons of contaminated grit and that disposing of it in a landfill will cost $400,000.
As an alternative to that disposal, the company, which has been moving into environmental businesses as it gets out of its disastrous involvement with financial services, has developed a process to remove almost all the lead from sand after it has been used in blasting.
The mobile system, which is mounted on a 24-foot-long flatbed trailer, can decontaminate two to four tons of sand an hour, company executives say. The treatment reduces the lead content, which is typically at 12,000 parts per million, to less than 200 p.p.m.
The cleaned sand cannot be reused in blasting because the blasting process rounds off the sharp edges needed for paint removal, Edward J. Lahoda, a Westinghouse engineer, said. But it can be used in other applications, like making concrete.
The contaminated sand is fed by a conveyor onto a screen that filters out stones, twigs and large particles of paint. Anything passing through the screen is fed into a scrubber where it is treated by a water-based chemical that leaches the lead from the sand.
The lead paint particles and very fine sand go into suspension in the fluid, and the now-scrubbed larger sand particles are separated out and dumped onto a clean sand pile. Westinghouse executives report sand recovery rates of 80 to 90 percent in early tests.
The liquid goes into a mixing tank where a coagulant is added and then to another tank, where a flocculant further thickens it. This produces a material that Mr. Lahoda said resembles cottage cheese and contains the lead and fine sand particles. Most of the liquid is separated out and prepared for recycling. The lead-rich material can either be disposed of in a landfill or sent to a smelter for recovery of the metal.
Westinghouse executives say they can treat the contaminated sand for about one-third the cost of burying it -- $500 a ton -- or smelting without pretreatment. And they say the system can also be used for other problems, such as treatment of used foundry sand, which is usually contaminated with the residues of the chemicals used to bind the sand particles together in molds.
"It's basically the same process," Mr. Lahoda said. "You just change the leachate."
An alternative approach, developed by Pentek Inc., of the Pittsburgh suburb of Coraopolis, Pa., eliminates most sand blasting. Instead, it uses a pneumatically powered needle gun, in conjunction with a powerful vacuum system, to beat old paint from a metal surface and swiftly pull it into a sealed collection system.
THE gun uses 64 tungsten carbide needles, each 2 millimeters in diameter, to peen the steel, dislodging the paint. The needles are enclosed by a plastic shroud, which is attached to the exhaust vacuum system. Pentek executives say that because the shroud is in direct contact with the surface of the painted steel, no dust or paint chips escape into the atmosphere, a matter of particular concern in populated areas. In one instance in Pittsburgh, the Allegheny County Department of Health curtailed blasting operations and condemned residents' homes near the blast site.
With the Pentek gun, unlike blasting, no containment system has to be built. And because the paint chips are deposited directly into drums by the vacuum system, only minimal material is collected for disposal.
One problem, however, is that lead-based paint is heavy. A standard 55-gallon drum filled with paint chips weighs more than 500 pounds. So some contractors use 21-gallon drums, which weigh about 200 pounds when filled and, thus, can be handled by a work crew.
 ONE of the drawbacks of the needle gun system is that it requires considerably more direct labor than blasting. Each gun, which the company calls a Corner Cutter, can clear about 20 square feet of surface an hour. But a blaster can clear 120 square feet in the same time. Thus it would take a six-person crew on needle guns to match one blaster. In addition, many paint specifications require a sand-blasting step to prepare the metal surface after mechanical paint removal.
But company executives say that in addition to direct labor, costs must be considered for the labor involved in setting up containment systems and in collecting, shipping and disposing of contaminated sand. The costs of shipping and disposing of 55-gallon drums of contaminated sand exceed $100 each, they say, and thus their system becomes more economical when total costs are compared.
And they say relying on sand blasting to remove lead-based paint has resulted in outdated requirements, given the resultant pollution.
"Perhaps it is time to re-evaluate the use of surface-tolerant coating to reduce the degree of surface cleanliness and profile the industry demands prior to re-coating," Pentek's president, Sheldon Lefkowitz, argued in a paper delivered at a conference entitled Lead Tech '92 in Bethesda, Md., in October.
The problem of dealing with lead-based paints on older structures has become a major headache in recent years, said Bernard Appleman, executive director of the Steel Structures Painting Council, an industry group, for lead was widely used as a corrosion blocker on structural steel for decades.
"Over the last four or five years we have put more effort on lead paint removal than anything else," he said. "Unfortunately, it has increased the cost two- to three-fold."

HEADLINE: Business Diary/December 13-18

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY

 
The End of I.B.M.'s Overshadowing Role 

Last week John F. Akers, chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, said that I.B.M. would take a $6 billion charge and eliminate 25,000 more jobs in 1993. What the Justice Department tried and failed to do for 13 years, Big Blue managed to do on its own. Next year its work force will shrink to 275,000 from 407,000 in 1986. And while I.B.M. stock was worth $175.875 a share in 1987, it collapsed to $51 1/2 at the close last week. While today's computer industry is dominated by smallish companies that spread the risk and the research producing components for each other, I.B.M. is still a massively centralized bureaucracy. But I.B.M.'s problems are due to its failure to realize that its core business, mainframe computers, had been supplanted by cheap, networked PC's and faster networked workstations. "I.B.M. as the I.B.M. that defined computing is over; it's gone," said Nathan Myrthvold, Microsoft's vice president for advanced technology.

Live From Little Rock
 
It didn't exactly bump "Roseanne" out of its ratings lead on Tuesday night, but last week's economic marathon in Little Rock had America's policy wonks glued to C-Span. Though some said the meeting broke no new ground, most participants were pleased. "It opened up Washington to America," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company. "You could see the lights going on," said Charles W. McMillion, another participant, who is president of MBG-Washington, an economic consulting firm. Particularly impressive to the economists were presentations about tapping into new sources of investment capital. John S. Reed, chairman of Citicorp, showed how nearly "$100 billion in investment capital could be freed up by changes in regulations," Mr. McMillion said. But equally impressive was the President-elect, "who was able to concentrate for incredible periods of time," said Mr. McMillion. "He was brilliant."

Hammers Are Ringing Again
 
For months, the only sounds at the construction site were those of birds singing. But according to the Commerce Department, hammers could be heard once more in November as housing starts grew by 1.5 percent to their highest levels in eight months. "The report says the economic slowdown has stopped," said Maria Fiorini Ramirez, head of a New York economic consulting firm that bears her name.But birds could still be heard on a few building lots since the gains were concentrated mostly in the South and West with declines in the Northeast and Midwest.
 
November's Upbeat Production
 
While the wonks debated policy, the Federal Reserve's number crunchers were busy tallying up the figures on industrial production. November was an upbeat month, they said, with production growing 0.4 percent following a revised 0.5 percent rise in October. The rise in October "has more than offset the declines of late summer," the Fed said.

Too Much of a Good Thing
 
The rule of thumb among economists is that when the nation's factories produce at more than 80 percent of capacity, bottlenecks ensue. Capitalism's satanic mills just can't keep up with deman and that brings on inflation. For now, with overall capacity utilization at 77.9 percent for November, up from 77.7 percent in October, according to the Federal Reserve, prices should hold firm. But there is one red light flashing: capacity utilization at the nation's mines rose to 86.7 percent in November, up from 86.2 percent a month earlier.

The F.C.C. Tunes Out Indecency
 
Howard Stern, radio's bad boy, has filled up the nation's airwaves with a mixture of toilet talk, self-deprecation and racial and ethnic slurs. The country loves it. Mr. Stern, whose morning program is syndicated, has more listeners in more cities than anyone else. But while America tunes in to Mr. Stern, the Federal Communications Commission would like to switch him off. Last week the F.C.C. decided to impose a $600,000 fine on Mr. Stern's employer, the Infinity Broadcasting Company of New York, for indecency. But it declined to block Infinity from acquiring three more radio stations for $100 million. ) Seven weeks ago, the F.C.C. fined the Los Angeles station carrying Mr. Stern's show $105,000. Why does the F.C.C. want to zipper Mr. Stern's foul mouth? "The F.C.C. wants timid broadcasters, and that's bad," said Andrew Jay Schwartzmann, executive director of the Media Access Project.
 
The Bell Atlantic Company filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., charging that its free speech rights were violated by the F.C.C.'s ruling that phone companies could carry video signals but not produce shows.

 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
For Now, a Tame Trade Deficit
 
At first glance it looked like more good news on the trade front. According to the Commerce Department, the nation's trade deficit shrank to $7 billion in October, a $1.6 billion improvement from the month before, largely the result of increased exports. Half of those export gains were accounted for by a surge in sales of civilian aircraft and telecommunications. But economists warn the trade gap may soon begin to swell. "We've got the double-whammy," said Harold B. Malmgreen, a Washington trade consultant. With Europe and Japan stuck in semi-somnolent economic states while the United States begins to grow, America "will continue to suck in imports without any place to export."

Japan's Revolving Insults
 
Japan is a nation that prides itself on the gracefulness of its manners. Tell that to its politicians. They seem to delight in lecturing overworked America on its poor work habits and other supposed limitations. Last week Masakuni Murakami, Japan's Labor Minister, told a group of reporters in Tokyo that "foreigners do not work. That is why they are economically being left far behind Japan and Germany." Those words followed statements by Kiichi Miyazawa, Japan's Prime Minister -- America lacked a work ethic, he said -- and by former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone who said blacks and other minorities lowered America's level of intelligence. Upon realizing that his words created quite a stir, Mr. Murakami told reporters that "I wanted to say that economic development by resource-poor Japan was due to diligence."

Slight Growth for the World
 
If you liked slow-growth 1992, you'll love 1993. According to the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Development, the world's economic engine will run at far less-than-full throttle. Growth in the United States will be a mere 2.3 percent, , while Europe will trudge through 1993 growing at about 1 percent. Japan will eke out a 2.6 percent rate of growth the blue-helmeted economists say. At the same time, the U.N.'s forecast sees the Latin American economies losing ground.

 
 
COMPANIES

 
Ford's Bitter Medicine
 
Getting corporate America to swallow the future costs of its retiree benefits hasn't been easy. It adds lots of red ink to a company's bottom line. But last week the Ford Motor Company unpursed its lips and took a swig with a one-time non-cash charge of $7.5 billion. That bitter medicine is likely to give the No. 2 auto maker a loss of $6 billion to $7 billion this year, analysts say, when added to charges resulting from eliminating 10,000 jobs in Europe. That would be the largest loss in corporate history. Ford is taking the hit to comply with a Federal Accounting Standards Board rule that went into effect last year. The rule allows companies to space out retiree health costs and other benefits over 20 years or take them in a single charge before the first quarter of 1993. Why suffer the pain now? "By taking the hit all at once we avoid a $375 million drag on profit for 20 years," said Terry Bresnihan, a Ford spokesman.

Moving In on Cable Territory
 
When it first muscled its way into the nation's living rooms, cable television's only competition was broadcast TV. Now, phone companies are trying to push their way in. Last week the Bell Atlantic Corporation said it would team up with the Future Vision of America Corporation to provide 38,000 homes in Dover Township, N.J., with 60 channels of customized TV from a menu of 124 channels. The Federal Communications Commission adopted rules earlier this year allowing phone companies to carry "video dial tones," but not to produce shows. Bell Atlantic will install fiber optics and coaxial cables to carry phone and video services into the homes. "We're trying to put much more control into the household," said Bob Schema, president of Future Video. "We think people ought to be given the opportunity to watch what they want."
 
Boeing's Engineers Stand Firm
 
Talks between the Boeing Company and the Seattle Professional Engineering Employees Association, which represents 28,000 technicians and engineers, broke down last week when 70 percent of the union -- Boeing's second largest -- rejected the company's offer and authorized a strike. Boeing's proposal contained no wage increases for engineers but did provide for merit raises for technical personnel. That wasn't good enough for the union, which wants a lump-sum payment of 12 percent of wages plus 3.5 percent in wage increases in each of the next two years. With the prospects for jobs in the industry slim and the union without a strike fund, Boeing said it would stand firm. "This is the hardest hardball I've ever seen the Boeing Company play," said Dan Mahoney, a spokesman for the union.
 
Boeing's engineers may be disgruntled, but not its sales people. Last week they reeled in a $4.1 billion order for 82 passenger jets from the International Lease Finance Corporation.

Mr. Perelman's Cigar
 
With the fragrant aroma of cigars about to fill the White House -- President-elect Bill Clinton smokes them a la Jack Kennedy -- Ronald O. Perelman, the billionaire investor, has chosen a good time to bet that the cigar habit will spread. Mr. Perelman, a cigar smoker himself, agreed to buy the Consolidated Cigar Corporation from Vestar Capital Partners Inc. for $180 million. Consolidated, whose brands run from the mass-market Dutch Masters to up-market H. Upmann, also manufactures Mr. Perelman's favorite smoke -- the Perelman special, rolled for him in the Dominican Republic.

Litton's Vessel of War or Rescue
 
The cold war may be over, but the Navy still needs to replace its old ships. That's good for Litton Industries, the big military contractor based in Beverly Hills, Calif. It received a $760 million order last week to build its sixth Wasp ship, the latest in amphibious assault vessels. Wasp class ships carry 2,000 troops, weigh 40,500 tons and are 844 feet long. They can be outfitted for war or as floating hospitals and rescue vessels for disaster relief. According to analysts, shipbuilding accounted for about 28 percent of Litton's profits.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Here's a Switch -- Keep the Job

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
HERE'S a dog-bites-man workplace story: Employers usually hold the trump hand in dealings with employees. Here's the man-bites-dog, holiday-appropriate version: Employer cedes right to fire employees Scrooge-style and gives them a contract that guarantees they will only be dismissed for a good business reason, or "just cause." Meet Tom Zito, the man who bites dogs.
Yes, Mr. Zito, head of Digital Pictures Inc., a year-and-a-half-old Silicon Valley software company, is often asked if he has gone mental, giving away what most people wouldn't think to ask for. And yes, he knows he is breaking ranks with generations of American employers who have long had the power to juggle their employees' destinies "at will," as the employment-law term of art goes. 
 "It flies in the face of how I ought to do business," he said matter-of-factly. Almost any employer, even the benevolent ones, would agree. The principle of at-will employment, in which employees serve at the pleasure of their bosses, is the heart and soul of American employment law. Most states, including California, have laws to protect workers from ruling-class capriciousness, but only one, according to employment law specialists, can reasonably be called a "just cause" state. That state is Montana, the laws of which affect roughly as many people as Digital Pictures has employees (17).
Mr. Zito, 44, has many reasons for violating common business sense. He is a product of the 1960's, with a generation-rampant approach-avoidance attitude toward capitalism. He has memories of less-than-benevolent employers.
But ultimately he grants job security because, like any employer, he wants to attract and keep talent. "People can assume that when they come here, unless they really screw up, they have a place as long as they work here," he said.
Mr. Zito also engages in such odd, unemployer-like behavior as paying people more than they ask for and including current employees on hiring decisions.
He does not, as most software makers do, require new hires to sign noncompete contracts. Such practices inspire loyalty and solidarity. And they keep out clutter. Being willing not to cash in on an applicant's low salary bid, for example, maintains similar wages among similarly situated workers and forestalls resentments.
IT is not clear if Mr. Zito, who was once the rock critic for The Washington Post, founded Digital to develop interactive video programming or to create a workers' paradise at the company's Menlo Park headquarters. He is certainly no stranger to transcendant experience. He once went to an unannounced Rolling Stones concert in Washington, just him and 599 others, sitting at the prancing feet of Mick Jagger. Mr. Zito would not be the first big-chill boomer who tried to translate the ineffable, in-the-now geist of rock and roll into a guide for living.
But he would also not be the first boomer to squeeze value from virtue, and his policies obviously have a practical point. Digital's interactive videos marry movies to software. The enterprise requires software engineers and filmmakers to work shoulder to shoulder. It is not an obvious symbiosis. Software people tend to fly solo; films are made collaboratively. "Getting the two worlds to come together is kind of a collision course with Armageddon," Mr. Zito said. Digital's work environment is designed to help break down cultural barriers between groups. Besides, he says, taking on employees who can't be jettisoned easily "makes you much smarter about the people you hire."
A cynic would be correct in pointing out that most of the unusual arrangements at Digital essentially cost nothing. Mr. Zito believes, for example, that noncompete contracts are unenforceable, so why bother? The just-cause clause needs no budget appropriation -- but reaps good will.
Which is precisely the point. One lesson other companies might take away from Digital is a human resources principle for the 90's: Don't sweat the small stuff.
Can Digital continue on its utopian course as it grows? Mr. Zito says the company has done several million dollars in sales since it began shipping interactive games for Sega's CD-ROM systems earlier this fall. He intends to have discussions with the staff, once life settles down after the busy Christmas season, about what the pace of growth should be. In the interest of preserving its spirit, Digital might decide to rein itself in.
 
 
 
IN NEW YORK, A LITTLE LEGAL HELP
 IF you work for an employer more typical than Tom Zito, you're living in the turbulent world of downsizing and layoffs. The New York branch of the National Employment Lawyers Association has started a referral service, called Nelars, to match worried employees with lawyers who might help them. "The playing field between employers and employees is far from level," said Lisa Lipman, Nelars's executive director.
The service is devoted exclusively to job problems and draws on the expertise of attorneys who specialize in employment law cases. Since the service began in early September, Ms. Lipman has fielded hundreds of phone calls. Two of the top areas: "The whole range of discrimination cases and exit or severance packages," she said.
Callers are referred to one of the lawyers, who charges $25 for a half-hour consultation. For consultations likely to go longer, lawyer and caller agree on a fee ahead of time. Expertise is available on a range of subjects, from sex discrimination to pensions to contract claims to the concerns of public-sector employees.
Ms. Lipman suggests not waiting until disaster strikes before calling a lawyer. There is a perception that engaging a lawyer can escalate a nonconflict into a crisis -- a perception that works against employees who, say, get laid off. "Usually the employee is caught off guard," she said, while the company has counsel. "It helps employees to have the benefit of advice." For severance packages and the like, most employment lawyers take an advisory role and let the employee do the negotiating.
Callers to the service number, 212-603-6491, are asked to leave a message on a voice mail system. Someone will return the call within one or two business days. Referrals for outside the New York area are available from the NELA national office, 415-397-6335.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Greenspan's Gift To the Nation: No Bank Crisis

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
The first job of the Federal Reserve System is to preserve the banking system. And as a new administration takes over in Washington, applause is in order for Alan Greenspan and his colleagues.
This coming week was billed earlier in the year as the time for the "December surprise," when new Federal rules that took effect yesterday would lead to the shutdown of dozens of banks. The bank crisis in 1992, people kept muttering, was just like the savings and loan crisis in 1988 -- almost ignored during the campaign but sure to be a dominant problem for whoever won the election. 
 It now looks as if it won't happen. The number of banks teetering on the edge appears to be quite small. Overall, bank profits are now at their highest level ever, and bank stock prices have leaped.
All this has occurred at a time when there are, by most measures, too many banks in the country. Any business school student will tell you that excess competition brings low profit margins and ruinous competition. Yet bank profit margins are high, even as the industry shrinks.
The reason is that short-term interest rates plunged, while long-term rates did not. That enabled banks to make hefty profits with minimal risk, simply by buying two-year to five-year government securities. "This improvement in bank profitability came at a fairly critical juncture," Mr. Greenspan said last month, in an understatement. In the fall of 1990, bank stocks were so low that it appeared the stock market was worried whether the financial system would survive. Then the interest rates fell, and banks found a way to make nice money without making loans.
There is room to debate whether the Fed under Mr. Greenspan pushed short interest rates down, or whether it simply followed the market. The belief here is that the Fed had a greater role than some admit. In any case, it certainly did not resist the trend.
It is possible that the economy might have begun to grow a bit sooner, in fact, if short-term rates had not fallen so far. In that case, the banks might have been forced to take more risks by making more loans while buying fewer safe government securities. But the profits from those securities have also allowed most banks to recover from the losses incurred through the excessive lending of the last decade.
In last week's economic summit in Little Rock, bankers rightly pushed for changing some paperwork rules that may discourage lending. But another idea, of easing capital rules, should be touched only with caution. As David Mullins, the Fed's vice chairman, noted, "We've been down that road before," and it has a lot of potholes.
Mr. Greenspan has had his blind spots, notably in opposing efforts by Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to force banks to disclose the real values of their assets. That, like the tough capital rules, would help to prevent a repeat of the 1980's excesses. But he has helped to get the industry back to a healthy state, and for that he deserves praise.

HEADLINE: Profile/Carol Nelson and Mary Ann Tighe;
Two Movers in a Tough Market

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
CAROL NELSON and Mary Ann Tighe can't indulge in even the mildest self-deprecation when the other one's around. Let Carol say she's squeamish around vermin, and Mary Ann will launch into a tale about how Carol chased down a mouse while the men in the room cried "Eeeek!" Let Mary Ann describe herself as more pragmatic than creative, and Carol will recite chapter and verse of the creative things Mary Ann brings to deals.
It's a mutual admiration society of the first order. It had better be. In the male-dominated and loner-driven world of New York commercial real estate, Ms. Nelson and Ms. Tighe have been virtually joined at the hip for more than four years. 
 Clearly, the partnership works: The two women, both senior managers at Edward S. Gordon & Company, have become one of the -- if not the -- most successful brokerage teams in the country. They helped Sony U.S.A. negotiate its lease for A.T.&T.'s headquarters building at 550 Madison Avenue, the country's largest real estate transaction in 1991. They took the Internal Revenue Service to 1133 Avenue of the Americas. They got The New Yorker to leave the building it had occupied since 1929.
"I've negotiated against them and they've negotiated for me, and believe me, I'd rather have them on my side," said Douglas Durst, vice president of the Durst Organization, which owns many New York buildings.
With the recession drowning most landlords and brokers in red ink, negotiating skills are at a premium these days. Corporations are giving occupancy costs the same high-level scrutiny as labor costs. They are arguing for huge subsidies for customizing space, for flexible leases that let them sublet, expand or contract almost at will, for long free-rent periods at move-in time.
Landlords, meanwhile, have little room to maneuver. Their main priority is to get lengthy leases with freedom to keep jacking up the rent from creditworthy tenants, in order to insure a continuous income stream that will pay debt. But lenders often will not let them give the very concessions tenants clamor for -- the right to keep the space if the lender takes over the building, say, or the right to assign the lease to another tenant.
"Today's brokers not only have to have entrepreneurial drive," said Gerald D. Schein, publisher of Real Estate Forum, a trade magazine. "They have to know how to crunch numbers and analyze leases, too."
Against that backdrop, the track record of these two women, neither of whom has a business degree, is formidable. In 1990, they were responsible for 12 percent of the 11.5 million square feet of office space leased in Midtown Manhattan -- more than any other brokerage team, Crain's New York Business reported that year. Last year, they helped lease 1.4 million Midtown feet, 15 percent of the total. By the middle of this month, they had done 31 deals for a total of 1.1 million feet, for a 9 percent share. "And remember, the year's not over yet," said Ms. Nelson, who hints at yet another deal pending.
It has been a lucrative few years. Brokers' commissions are usually a percentage of rent. Midtown rents hover around $30 a foot. Thus, although they won't talk income numbers, the sheer volume of deals has undoubtedly made them millionaires.
Not bad for two brokers who entered the field at ages when most people are at the peak of their careers. Ms. Tighe, a former curator at the Smithsonian and arts adviser to Vice President Walter Mondale, was 36 when she went into real estate eight years ago. Ms. Nelson, a former full-time homemaker, won't divulge her age, but she was probably well into her 30's when she joined the business in 1975.
Ms. Nelson was "always fascinated by the buildings, by the way deals were structured," she said. Ms. Tighe took more convincing. Sick of a commuter marriage from Washington (her husband is a doctor at Bellevue), she moved to New York to become a programming director for ABC -- only to find that she traveled so much she saw her husband as little as before. On one flight, she sat next to a retired real estate broker. He put her in touch with some real estate honchos, and they led her to Edward S. Gordon.
For several years, the two women inhabited different stratospheres. Ms. Nelson had risen to managing director at Gordon, a level that still is unusual for a woman. And she had garnered a reputation for creative deals.
She was instrumental in getting I.B.M. to become an equity partner in some buildings where it leased space. She had engineered the deal by which 430 Park Avenue, once the Colt Industries building, became Bank of Montreal headquarters. She persuaded Burson Marsteller to move into a converted loft on Park Avenue South -- a move that many industry mavens say sparked the growth of lower Park Avenue as an office center.
 MS. TIGHE, meanwhile, was doing scut work on dead-end projects. One day, the two got to chatting in front of the ladies' room mirror (they both still giggle at living a cliche), and Ms. Nelson invited Ms. Tighe to work for her. Within a couple of years, they went from mentor/mentee to equal partners. "Carol mowed the way, and I got to walk down the path," Ms. Tighe said.
They are a contrast in appearance and style.
Yes, both are on their second marriages, both live in Manhattan, both have children (Ms. Tighe has one, Ms. Nelson has four, including her husband's from a previous marriage).
But Mary Ann Tighe is dark, exotic looking, vivacious. Her words don't so much emerge as tumble out. Carol Nelson is tall and blond and speaks in far more measured terms. Ms. Tighe thrives on details, on processes, on seeing things through. Ms. Nelson loves the sales pitch, the strategizing, the creation of a deal. "Carol's strength is getting that first meeting; Mary Ann's is implementing the transaction," said Dean J. Shapiro, a senior consultant at Gordon who often works with the team.
BY rights, being women should have hurt them. Like most businesses that revolve around negotiations and deals, an awful lot of real estate contacts are made in male-bastion territories like clubs and golf courses. According to Mr. Schein, the publisher, there are only about 400 women commercial brokers in the country, and only about 100 in New York, with its a total of 5,000 or so commercial brokers.
But colleagues insist that, if anything, their femaleness is a help. "They have a soft and polite way about them," said Robert A. B. Baraf, a Gordon managing director. "They are not Leona Helmsley-mean. Their toughness is on the inside."
Mr. Shapiro is more succinct: "They are dealmakers, not bullies."
Ms. Tighe and Ms. Nelson also shrug off any problems their femaleness may cause. "Sixteen brokers named Bob may call a C.E.O., but there's only one Mary Ann," Ms. Tighe said. "We're remembered."
The big thing, clients say, is that they do their homework, often persuading tenants and landlords alike to look beyond the rent numbers in their deals.
"They helped us put a dollar value on location as well as space," said Salvatore Vitale, senior vice president of operations at the Conference Board, which recently renegotiated its leases at 845 Third Avenue.
In another case, they helped the Bank of Nova Scotia create a complex "phantom equity deal" for 300,000 square feet of space at Olympia & York's One Liberty Plaza. If the building becomes profitable, the bank gets a rent reduction. "They really understood how to look at a transaction in a strategic sense," said Richard E. Waugh, a senior executive vice president of the bank, who has since used Ms. Nelson and Ms. Tighe to negotiate with tenants for space in buildings on which the bank has foreclosed.
But perhaps most important in a moribund real estate market, the two seem to have a knack for spotting potential deals hidden in business reports, and for dreaming up unlikely tenant/building matches. "We call it Zen brokerage," Ms. Tighe said.
For example, when Sony bought CBS Records Inc. in 1988, Ms. Nelson immediately called Walter Yetnikoff, then the division's head, to discuss space needs. At her suggestion, Edward S. Gordon called Michael P. Schulhof, Sony USA's vice chairman. A year later, the conversations had ballooned into talk of a whole new headquarters for Sony, talks that culminated in Sony's leasing of A.T.&T.'s headquarters last year.
In 1990, when the I.R.S. was looking for a large chunk of Midtown space, Ms. Nelson's instincts pointed her to 1133 Avenue of the Americas, a Durst building that was fully occupied and didn't seem to fit the I.R.S.'s needs. Still, she persuaded first Mr. Durst, then the I.R.S., to talk things out.
THE deal has gone through against impossible odds. Ms. Nelson pointed out how many leases in the building would expire by 1994, the I.R.S.'s target for moving in. The I.R.S. said there was still not enough space; Ms. Nelson persuaded Durst to cut through to another building it owned behind 1133. The zoning board said the combined building violated rules governing the ratio of office space to land; the team worked out a compromise in which an entire floor at 1133 will remain unused for 20 years. Upshot: The I.R.S. signed a 20-year lease for 240,000 square feet, at $35 a foot.
The commission was $7 million, split among Ms. Tighe, Ms. Nelson and two other Gordon brokers.
Some of this year's best deals seemed, at first blush, similarly unpromising. Leslie Fay, the fashion company, didn't really want to leave 1400 Broadway, where it had been for 35 years. But it needed to expand beyond its 70,000 feet, and the landlord, banking on the reluctance to move, was holding out for a high rent. The Nelson/Tighe team persuaded Leslie Fay to look around. It did -- and wound up taking better space at 1412 Broadway, across the street.
The brokers pulled a mirror image deal for Griffin Bacal Inc., an advertising agency with 60,000 square feet spread over six floors and several years left on its lease at 130 Fifth Avenue. Ms. Nelson and Ms. Tighe guessed that the agency was overpaying, but the landlord wouldn't budge. So Ms. Nelson found the agency nearby space. Then, the team drew a scenario for the landlord if Griffin Bacall moved, showing what it would cost him to find new tenants, and why his lenders would like to have the space locked in for a long term. Result: Griffin Bacall is staying put until 2002, at a much lower rent.
"Carol found the stalking horse that brought the landlord to his knees, and Mary Ann scripted the deal, told everyone what part they had to play," recalled Mr. Baraf, who also worked on the deal. "I would have hated to be on the other side of the table."

GRAPHIC: Carol Nelson, left, sets it up; Mary Ann Tighe pins it down. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BRIDGE;
Financial Lion Plans A Parlay in China

BYLINE: By Alan Truscott

 BODY:
IT is not easy to combine the roles of bridge champion and Napoleon of finance, but Jim Cayne of Manhattan manages it neatly. Most of his hours are devoted to Bear Stearns, the brokerage house, of which he is president, but he spends much of his free time at card tables.
Three weeks ago in Orlando, Fla., he led his team to victory in the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams championship. To fit in morning golf lessons, he said he was managing on four and a half hours of sleep nightly. 
 Cayne is friendly with Kathie Wei, who has won three world titles and has long been the standardbearer of the Precision system. A month or so ago, they made a triple plan: they would each win a major title in Orlando, which they proceeded to do, and they would later go to China. At the end of January they will play bridge in Shanghai, where Cayne will establish a Bear Stearns office.
This will follow a visit to Beijing to take part in a true V.I.P. tournament. The competition is expected to include these members of the hierarchy: Wan Li, Chairman of the National People's Congress; Ding Guangen, a member of the Politburo who is Deng Xiaoping's regular bridge partner; Deng Pufang, Mr. Deng's eldest son, who is head of an association for the handicapped; Li Lanqing, Economic Trade Minister; Wu Shaozu, Minister for Physical Culture and Sports; Liu Huaqing, deputy chairman of the Central Military Commission; Qi Huaiyuan, former deputy foreign minister; He Guangyuan, Minister of Heavy Industry; Chen Min zheng, Minister of Health; Rong Gaotang, president of the Chinese Bridge Association; Wang Hanbin, Deputy Chairman of the People's Congress; Wu Wenying, Minister of Textile Industry, and Han Xu, a former Ambassador to the United States.
No other country can boast so many bridge players at the top levels of government. Deng's love for the game has surely much to do with it, but whether they became bridge players because they were politicians or vice versa is unclear.
None of the Chinese players is as experienced as Cayne, who also won the Reisinger in 1988. In Orlando, he showed his skill on the diagramed deal, enlisting the opponents' help in bringing home two spades.
East-West might have gone to three hearts, and would have made at least nine tricks thanks to the favorable lie. But they sold out to two spades and West led the heart ten. South ruffed the third round of hearts and sought to remove West's clubs.
Cayne needed to know how the clubs were divided, so he asked the opposition. He led the club queen, expecting both opponents to give a count signal. West played the four, his lowest card, to signal an odd number of cards in clubs. East played the five, the highest card he could spare, to show an even number of clubs.
Cayne studied the trick carefully and worked out that he could afford to take two more club winners. He cashed the ace, led to the king and thought again. West, he decided, surely held both the diamond ace and the spade ace to justify his opening bid.
Leading to either of his kings was clearly due to fail, so Cayne led a spade and ducked. When this lost to the jack his contract was unbeatable. West could cash his spade ace, but then had no exit card. He had to choose between conceding a trick to South's diamond king or giving an equally fatal ruff-and-sluff.

HEADLINE: What the State Is Giving Olympus

 BODY:
"State Bypasses Town in Zoning Approval" [Dec. 6] contains an important misstatement of fact and has failed to reveal several other important issues. I am a partner in the firm that leases Olympus its current facility in Lake Success. While it is true that their lease expires in 1994, we have offered them numerous opportunities to renew or renegotiate their lease at their present facility. Our proposals were for a long-term lease and included extensive renovations to the premises. As recently as this fall we had offered them a two-year extension. 
 The state has offered Olympus a package of incentives which makes staying in our facility or leasing any of the other numerous vacant buildings uneconomical. Projects built by the state need not worry about sales tax -- typically about 3 to 4 percent of a new project's cost -- mortgage recording taxes, 1 percent of a new project's cost; transfer taxes and my personal favorite, the "Cuomo tax," which is the New York State gains tax.
The state will collect payments in lieu of real-estate taxes, but I can assure you that they will be a fraction of the $4 to $5 per square foot Olympus is paying at their current locations in Nassau County. The state's action will accelerate the flight of users from the high real-estate taxes in Nassau County and exacerbate the problems facing Nassau County and the local governments and school districts. My firm is the fourth largest payer of property tax in Nassau County.
Finally there is the issue of the transfer of large state assets such as 53.7 acres of land without competitive bidding. The state does not purchase a box of paper clips without competitive bidding, but in this case is granting the use of a $5 million-to-$10 million parcel without bidding or even the public disclosure of the lease terms.
The granting of leases on public land in this manner last occurred at Mitchell Field in Nassau County, which was subsequently the focus of numerous investigations. Obviously the ability of any politician to grant an individual developer or corporation a major economic benefit without public scrutiny opens the potential for corruption, or at the very least the appearance of impropriety.
I think that the citizens of New York State should be outraged that the state, while quick to regulate its citizens and businesses into oblivion, is also just as quick to circumvent environmental, zoning, building codes and any other laws that are not convenient at the moment.
 
BENNETT RECHLER
Partner, We're Associates
Jericho

HEADLINE: Here's a Plan to Let You Afford a $250,000 College Education

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In a speech before the National Press Club, Neil L. Rudenstine, president of Harvard University, recognizes the growing crisis in the affordability of college because family incomes are growing at a slower rate than college costs (news article, Dec. 1). Keeping colleges and universities open and affordable to students of all economic backgrounds raises serious issues, and it is clear that the costs of higher education are forcing schools to make difficult decisions about resource allocation and, in some cases, forcing substantial cutbacks in programs and services. 
 At Kenyon College in Gambier, Ohio, the alumni council has formed a funding education committee to propose long-range solutions to the af
fordability problem. With the assistance of Kenyon's administrators, the committee is focusing on the affordability of a four-year private college education for a child born this year who will start college in the year 2010.
We have estimated that assuming annual real growth of 2 percent and annual inflation of 4 percent, based on 1992-93 tuition, room, board and fees, a four-year education beginning in 2010 will cost in excess of $250,000. That figure is so substantial that most people just shrug their shoulders and say they cannot do anything about it. We disagree.
The Kenyon suggestion is that Congress and the President collaborate in creating a tax-deferred savings program for postsecondary school education at a trade school or two- or four-year college or university.
Similar in concept to an individual retirement account, the program would be limited to use for education purposes. All taxpayers would be able to deposit funds into the program annually, up to an agreed annual maximum per child. Deposits would be deductible from current income and would accumulate tax free. Withdrawals would be used for education expenses. Withdrawals for other purposes would be subject to a penalty.
The preliminary details of the proposal are described in an article in the current issue of the Kenyon College Alumni Bulletin titled "Funding Education."
 
NEAL M. MAYER
Chmn., Funding Educ. Committee
Kenyon College Alumni Council
Washington, Dec. 3, 1992
