HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Environmental Fix With a Legion of Doubters

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

 BODY:
FROM the high bluffs along the Ohio River, the nation's newest hazardous waste incinerator looks like a gleaming castle -- a beacon, its Swiss owners say, for the high technology, high wage environmental industries that President-elect Bill Clinton enthusiastically supports.
But to perhaps a third of the residents of East Liverpool, Ohio, an aging river town 30 miles downstream from Pittsburgh, the plant looks much more menacing -- a hulking industrial fortress constructed on a flood plain in a valley infamous for its stagnant air and much too close to hundreds of homes and an elementary school. 
 Whatever one's view, the fight over the $160 million Waste Technologies Industries incinerator, which is scheduled to begin full commercial operation next year, has quickly turned into much more than a job-hungry community's struggle over economic development, pollution and public health. It has also become an early test for Mr. Clinton and Vice President-elect Al Gore as they seek to square environmental goals with economic ones.
Two weeks ago, fulfilling a promise he made while campaigning in the Ohio Valley, Mr. Gore announced that the first environmental action the new Administration will take will be to investigate the plant's safety and the legality of its construction and Federal operating permits. Mr. Gore said he intends to block the plant's opening until the investigation. Executives at the plant said that they intend to move ahead with their plans to conduct tests in January that could lead to full commercial operation.
Last week, several groups of supporters in East Liverpool and the incinerator's owner, Von Roll, Inc., fired back in an open letter to Mr. Clinton that was published in newspaper advertisements in New York, Washington and Little Rock, Ark. They told the President-elect that the incinerator, which will employ 125 people and provide $1.7 million in local taxes, had passed every regulatory test and legal hurdle put in its path. "It is cleaner than any steel mill, auto factory, computer chip manufacturer, chemical plant, large farm or any other major facility in the nation," the full-page ads said. "Close it and you are setting a standard that will ship millions of jobs overseas -- a bad way to start your defense of America's economic security."
At the core of this highly visible scientific and political debate is whether incineration is a safe way to dispose of the nation's chemical wastes and household garbage. Critics of the technology say that incineration turns the atmosphere into an uncontrolled waste dump for toxic pollutants like lead, mercury and dioxin.
But during the administrations of Ronald Reagan and George Bush, the Environmental Protection Agency studied incineration, said it was vital to the nation's waste disposal problems and pronounced it environmentally safe. In 1984, Congress prohibited most chemical wastes -- which already could not be dumped in the ocean or stored forever -- from being buried in landfills. Incineration technology inevitably thrived.
More than 60 commercial incinerators now burn roughly 3 million tons of chemical wastes a year, which is about 1 percent of the 300 million tons of hazardous wastes generated annually in the United States. Scores of companies are seeking new permits to gain a share of a market that is now worth $2.5 billion annually and expected to grow, according to E.I. Digest, an industry newsletter.
In addition, 133 incinerators have been built since 1980 to burn household garbage; almost all of them convert the heat generated to electricity. Of all the states, New York and Florida are the most dependent on the technology for municipal waste disposal.
Mr. Gore, though, is suspicious of incinerators because of the hazardous pollutants they are known to release into the atmosphere. In his book "Earth in Balance," he said: "Major health and environmental concerns have never been adequately answered." Mr. Gore, his aides said, also thinks that incineration discourages environmentally safer disposal programs, like recycling or reducing the volume of industrial chemicals. The reason: every incinerator requires a steady supply of wastes to remain profitable.
 
Corporate Persistence
 As if to emphasize an opposition to incineration, Mr. Clinton has named Carol M. Browner, the Secretary of Environmental Regulation in Florida, to head the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. Ms. Browner is not only a former aide to Mr. Gore, but unsuccessfully lobbied for legislation that would have blocked any new incinerators in Florida.
In East Liverpool, Von Roll executives nervously await the conclusion of the Congressional investigation. If the company is allowed to operate its plant, said industry analysts, it would be viewed as a triumph of corporate persistence that could help calm public resistance.
If, however, the East Liverpool incinerator fails to open, it would be the latest in a string of hazardous waste incinerators closed in North Carolina, Kentucky, Illinois and Arizona since 1990. The first was shut because of toxic emissions that harmed workers, two more suffered explosions, and public opposition compelled Arizona Governor Fyfe Symington, a Republican, to buy an incinerator near Phoenix in 1991 before it opened. Should the Ohio incinerator join the list, said industry analysts, it would be viewed by investors as a clear signal that the new Administration was rejecting the technology.

HEADLINE: Clinton, Taking Over the Books, Asks the Shareholders' Patience

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

 BODY:
BILL CLINTON'S extraordinary 19-hour nationally televised teach-in on economics was more than just a novel attempt by the President-elect to play professor to the nation. It was in some ways the opening chapter in an effort by Mr. Clinton to rewrite the rules for how the public should judge a Presidency. Some might call it Bill Clinton's quest for an eight-year honeymoon.
Good luck. 
 As a student of American politics, Mr. Clinton understands that the way Presidential authority is built and sustained in this country is usually through relatively short-term events and short-term success. Like the Pharaohs, Presidents store up political capital in fat years and spend it in the lean years, and if they are lucky the fat years coincide with the election cycle.
But Mr. Clinton also understands that the economic problems he has inherited, and the out-of-control deficit, are long-run and structural in nature. He really does not have the luxury of short-term options.
His dilemma is how a President elected for four years -- on a promise to make things better -- can take actions that may not provide instant gratification, yet will not be politically fatal for him. That requires educating voters in very different ways about their economic predicament and their expectations for their Accountant-in-Chief.
That is what the economic conference was all about. What Mr. Clinton has tried to do both during the later stages of his campaign and through this conference is to shift public attention from economic fluctuations, which usually determine the political fortunes of incumbents, to longer time lines.
He is trying to stretch the boundaries of political accountability in asking the public to define his success not in terms like three straight quarters of improved unemployment figures or housing starts, but by whether he puts an economy in the grip of a long-term structural decline onto a new long-term trend line -- the payoffs of which may come well after his term. No wonder that in his five-minute speech opening the economic conference he used the terms "long-term" and "long-run" six times.
"It is very important to get away from the 100 days trap," said the historian Arthur Schlesinger Jr. "Roosevelt's 100 days was a unique episode which grew out of a unique crisis. Clinton's crisis has a long-term diagnosis. Of course, every new President pleads for more time, but this device he is using is new, and to use the interregnum before his inauguration this effectively is also quite new.
"What struck me was that Clinton clearly understands that politics is ultimately a process of education and persuasion, not preachment, as Jimmy Carter thought," Mr. Schlesinger added.
Mr. Clinton's tactic was to bring together economists, business leaders and labor representatives and let them bear witness on nationwide television to the complexity, toughness and uncertainty of his options, spicing the discussion with his own homilies, such as: "When somebody tells you it is not a money problem, they're talking about somebody else's money."
Maybe the best way to understand what Mr. Clinton was up to is to contrast him with Ronald Reagan.
 
Selling the Impossible
 "Reagan was the grand master of the politically effective gesture," argued Yaron Ezrahi, author of a major study on the culture of American democracy and a visiting scholar at Princeton. "He exploited the American public's wish to believe that all things will turn out well by offering them various forms of instant gratification. Clinton, by contrast, is trying to make honestly coping with a virtually impossible economic situation a politically successful strategy."
It is the difference, added Mr. Ezrahi, between a doctor who is presiding over an accident victim's very slow and painful return to walking, which requires a longer period of trust and cooperation from the patient and his family, and a faith healer who gets the patient up one time and says: "You can walk. You can walk." Everyone applauds and then the man collapses off stage.
Mr. Clinton has several problems, though, in trying to pull this off.
One is that he himself raised expectations during the campaign by his claims that he had a plan to heal the economy, and it is a little bit late for him to dampen them. Another is that his performance as a schoolmaster was so good, and the way he handled the diverse material so deft, that it further raises expectations for his Presidency. We expect a lot from the class valedictorian.
"The student who impresses people most also gets in trouble quickest if he gets a B instead of an A," said Republican political consultant Kevin Phillips.
And even as Mr. Clinton was dazzling business leaders with his smarts, I.B.M. announced that it was laying off 25,000 people in 1993 and closing plants after its worst year ever, underscoring the larger forces at work in the economy that are out of his control.
The I.B.M. story was almost a parable of what happens to large institutions, be they companies or countries, that do not adapt structurally to the rapidly changing tempo of the times. Incidentally, I.B.M., General Motors and Chrysler were not among the select 329 invitees at the Clinton conference.
"I think the challenge for Clinton is to adjust the rhythms of government to the new tempo in the world economy," said Sheryl Handler, president of Thinking Machines Corp., a manufacturer of supercomputers, who attended the conference.
"Let me give you an example," she said. "The Government procurement process for computers takes up to two years. But in the computer industry today a new generation of computers comes out every 18 months. So the Government is always behind the curve."
 
The Attentive Government
 The underlying structure of the American economy, argued Ms. Handler, is quite robust in many sectors, but it needs a government, and governmental policies, that will be attuned to the different rhythms of each sector, with policies that will get the most out of companies, whether by setting the right standards for them or introducing the right tax legislation.
"If Clinton can do through his policies what he did at the conference, which was demonstrate a real feel for the nuances of the economy, I think he can be quite successful," she added. "It is a different sort of leadership."
Indeed, since the advent of the cold war we have grown used to Presidents building their authority more by moving troops around the globe than numbers across a budget ledger. Mr. Clinton no doubt will get his chance to move troops, probably very soon. But for the moment, it seems he will try to derive his authority as much from demonstrating a grasp of economic policy, and a willingness and ability to educate the public on that subject.
You can almost hear the Clinton inaugural now: "Let everyone know, whether they wish us well or ill, that we shall pay any price, bear any burden, meet any hardship, support any friend or oppose any foe to assure the survival and success of . . . our budget."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
A Lame-Duck Diplomat Wrestles With a World in Flux

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: BRUSSELS

 BODY:
LAWRENCE S. EAGLEBURGER doesn't look much like the Red Adair of foreign policy, flaunting his lame-duck status with a crippled bird pin stuck in his lapel. Yet to be Secretary of State in the unwieldy new world of late 1992 means spending a lot of time putting out raging diplomatic fires rather than crafting Talleyrand-like strategies for the future. In these final days of the Bush foreign policy, it is not a comfortable role.
The Secretary of State went to Stockholm, Geneva and Brussels last week, hoping to focus on three issues: cooperative security measures, a far-reaching nuclear arms agreement with the Russians and the war in the Balkans. Along the way, he repeatedly got waylaid by the unpredictable. 
 There was, most dramatically, the diplomatic equivalent of Orson Welles's "War of the Worlds" broadcast -- the startling speech in Stockholm by Andrei V. Kozyrev, Russia's fresh-faced Foreign Minister, which left many in the hall believing for an hour that Russia was prepared to use military force and economic weapons to recreate the old Soviet Union. It was, in fact, just an attention-grabbing ploy to dramatize the fragility of Russia's reform.
As with Mr. Welles's 1938 radio broadcast, which left many Americans believing a Martian invasion was under way, the Russian's message was less revealing than the credulous reaction of his audience. At least some listeners ended the day a bit closer to realizing something fundamental about the new world order: They are going to have to expect the unexpected.
For one thing, the Kozyrev incident exposed how little the rest of the world knew of the Russian Foreign Minister or what to expect of his boss, President Boris N. Yeltsin. Mr. Yeltsin himself underscored the point at the end of the week when he stunned the White House with an announcement that Russia was ready to sign a nuclear-arms treaty that the Administration believes is still under negotiation.
After the Stockholm meeting, Mr. Eagleburger went to Geneva for a conference on the Balkan war and to Brussels for a NATO meeting. But in the course of the week, he also found himself contending with Ukrainian stalling on arms control, a dispute between Armenians and Azeris over Nagorno-Karabakh, the problems of Georgia, Israel's deportation of 400 Palestinians and a refugee exodus from Tajikistan to Afghanistan.
"In the non-cold war world you get a lot of surprises," said Mr. Eagleburger in an interview over breakfast at the end of the week. "It's constant."
In his own down-to-earth idiom, he described a small part of his first day in Stockholm, at a meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe: "We think we got a process working on Nagorno-Karabakh. But the Armenians the day before attack a city. The Azeris threaten to wreck the process and here we are at a meeting with what we thought was a process working and it begins to come unraveled and you kind of run around trying to talk to the Azeris and the Armenians and say, 'Now you guys got to get back together to talk.'
 
'Pasted-Together Diplomacy'
 "You go talk to the Georgian Foreign Minister and you spend half your time talking about whether Georgia is going to hold together or not. Those sorts of things occur all the time now."
In the intellectual competition over what to call the new chaos, Mr. Eagleburger's phrase is as good as any: "Pasted-together diplomacy." And how does he like his job? "I hate this job. I hate this job," he said, with only a hint that he might not fully mean it.
If navigating in the cold war world was like sailing the high seas -- there were dangers, but there was a map and compass, and identifiable friends and foes were on the shore -- then navigating in the new world is more like a Star Trek mission into unexplored galaxies. In the old days, two superpowers kept most of the smaller players under control. Now the absence of a new rule book has given the other actors a chance to try to set the rules.
In Yugoslavia, for example, the European and North American democracies misjudged Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian President, whose campaign of ethnic cleansing in Bosnia is a principal issue -- and could be ratified -- in a Serbian presidential election today.
As far back as March 1991 the reclusive ex-Communist clearly detailed his expansionist goal of creating a Greater Serbia, by any means necessary. But the world thought it impossible that he could carry out such a program. Then the unexpected happened: His xenophobic message caught fire and Serbs began to commit atrocities unseen in Europe for decades.
"There was the belief for too long that Yugoslavia was something that could be saved," Prime Minister Carl Bildt of Sweden said last week. "I think we collectively underestimated Mr. Milosevic and his ruthlessness." Now Mr. Bildt deems the Serbian leader worse than President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. "I don't want to say anything remotely positive about Saddam Hussein but what he did was a fairly conventional invasion of another country," says Mr. Bildt, while the atrocities carried out by Serbs "haven't been seen since the Nazi crimes in Europe."
Mr. Eagleburger, who was convinced months ago that the West needed to take firmer action, named Mr. Milosevic, other Serbians and Croats as possible war criminals who should be brought to justice.
 
Concern About Clinton
 All this turmoil and hand wringing means Europe is still looking to America for answers. While foreign ministers attended their meetings, their aides were pumping American officials for information on Bill Clinton's foreign policy and his choice for Secretary of State. A quick sampling of delegations indicates that many of the Europeans want more American engagement, not less, and that they watched Mr. Clinton's economic summit on CNN with some alarm that attention to the American economy could come at the expense of foreign affairs.
The Russians told the American delegation they favor a continuation of President Bush's diplomacy, with the sort of continuity a Colin Powell would symbolize as Secretary of State. In other European delegations, there was little enthusiasm for Warren Christopher, who served in Jimmy Carter's State Department and is regarded as an able negotiator but not the strategist-fireman that the new world needs. Douglas Hurd, the British Foreign Secretary, told reporters that none of the contacts between Her Majesty's Government and the Clinton team had given him "any great cause for alarm or despondency." In diplomatese, that was one way to say that Mr. Clinton hadn't done much to prompt celebration, either.
What is Mr. Eagleburger's advice for whoever succeeds him?
First: "Do your best to recognize that you'll always be limited in providing yourself time to think about the big issues." Second: "Recognize and use the fact that, while a large part of the world thinks it is now to be heard more forcefully, there is only one power that thinks globally -- and therefore it is absolutely essential that you do your best to develop a world strategy and fit the pieces into it and not the reverse."
And third (half-kidding): "Not to take the job."

(Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: U.S. PENSION AGENCY IS IN DEEP TROUBLE, ECONOMISTS WARN

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
A growing chorus of economists and Government officials is warning that the Federal program that insures corporate pension plans is in deep financial trouble and might eventually require a costly bailout.
Coverage of private plans is just one part of the Government's large pension problem. Because of past inattention, the pension plans for Federal employees -- paid out of separate accounts -- are now underfinanced by more than $1 trillion. 
 Some officials, including President-elect Bill Clinton, have compared the potential problem to the savings and loan disaster. Two Democratic Congressmen with jurisdiction over the issue -- Representatives Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois and J. J. Pickle of Texas -- have told Mr. Clinton that they are concerned about the potential liability to the Government.
 
Insures 40 Million Americans
 The 18-year-old Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation assures that when employers who pay premiums to it go bankrupt, the Government will meet the companies' obligations to their retirees. The pensions of 40 million Americans are now insured by the corporation.
Most companies set aside enough money to cover the pension benefits they have promised their employees. But hundreds of others are neglecting to finance their pensions fully, and those liabilities have grown 70 percent in the last two years alone, to $51 billion at the end of 1991, from $30 billion at the end of 1989. Many underfinanced plans come from the troubled auto, steel, tire and airline industries.
In negotiating new labor contracts with workers, some of these companies have offered to bolster pensions in lieu of raising salaries -- promising, in effect, money they do not have now but hope to have in the future.
 
 
Risks Keep Rising
 The pension agency's annual list of the 50 companies with the largest underfinanced pension plans showed a 13 percent increase in 1991 in guaranteed benefits not backed by money in retirement funds. Among the companies on the list are the LTV Corporation, the Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Company, the Chrysler Corporation, Bethelem Steel and General Motors.
While the Federal pension corporation has enough cash to meet its obligations for the next several years, it shows a deficit of about $3 billion if anticipated future losses are factored in. That shortfall is projected to grow to as much as $30 billion as the baby boom generation begins to retire in 15 to 20 years.
This raises the likelihood that premiums, the main source of revenue, will have to be augmented, with taxpayer money making up the difference, corporation officials say. The Government has raised the premiums before, but that prompted many companies to drop out of the program to avoid the increased costs. As it stands now, costs have climbed to about $19 an employee yearly for a company in the plan, from $1 an employee 18 years ago. Rates are even higher for underfinanced plans.
Some critics of the pension agency contend that the problem is overstated and that the numbers show no immediate cause for alarm. But others maintain that the situation will worsen considerably if not dealt with now.
"Corporations in tight straits are making promises," said Representative Pickle, the chairman of a Congressional oversight committee that has been examining the pension insurance program. "We've got to put a stop to it. If three or four major companies go under, so could the P.B.G.C."
To address the problem of its own pension commitments, the Government has begun setting money aside, but making up the deficit will take larger and larger bites of the Federal budget over the next few decades. Already, pension obligations for military and civil service retirees cost the Federal Government tens of billions of dollars a year.
 
How Big a Burden?
 No one has calculated what the Government's overall pension liabilities might be decades from now if the public and private programs remain unchanged. But military retirees, who can retire after 20 years of service and earn 50 percent of their pay for the rest of their lives, account for about half the Government's pension debts. And the Pentagon has projected that it will have to devote an ever-larger percentage of its budget to financing the pensions. The cost of these commitments is expected to grow to $296 billion in the year 2041, from $11.2 billion this year.
By comparison, during the Bush Administration's four years the Government paid $130 billion to bail out the savings and loan industry. The Pentagon's estimate does not take into account any future changes in the military or in the retirement system.
In the Presidential campaign debate in Richmond on Oct. 15, Mr. Clinton said, "We are going to have to change and strengthen the pension requirements on private retirement plans."
A week ago , officials of the Clinton transition team had not met with executives of the pension benefit corporation, said James Lockhart, the program's executive director. And the issue was barely addressed this week during the two-day economic conference that Mr. Clinton convened in Little Rock, Ark.
 
Options for Clinton
 On Wednesday, however, Gene Sperling, deputy director of Mr. Clinton's economic transition team, said his staff would soon present the President-elect various options to deal with the pension problem. Mr. Sperling added that Mr. Rostenkowski had warned Mr. Clinton about the pension corporation in an August letter.
Several Government officials said they thought Mr. Clinton should deal with the problem quickly, before the deficit grows far larger. Generally, they say, the Government should make it harder for financially troubled companies to expand pension benefits while possibly forcing them to pay higher premiums.
Representative Pickle called the looming pension deficit "a tremendously serious problem" and said Mr. Clinton had agreed with his concerns in a recent meeting.
Mr. Pickle said he intended to introduce legislation on the first day of the new Congress that would limit the ability of financially troubled companies in the Federal program to raise employee benefits.
 
'Raising a Red Flag'
 "I am not speaking from a position of panic," Mr. Pickle said. "I am raising a red flag. We've got to lay down some guidelines of what can be permitted from now on, or else it will be worse than the savings and loan scandal." The Treasury is expected to wind up spending as much as $200 billion to sort out the troubled industry and shut insolvent savings institutions.
In the next two decades the baby boom generation will pass through its peak earning years, and Government tax revenues are likely to remain higher than average. But as the members of this huge generational bubble begin to reach retirement age, higher payments will be required from Federal and private pension funds. At the same time, the nation's wage base will be shrinking.
Other Government benefit programs, including Social Security and Medicare, which are financed by payroll taxes, will also feel the strain. By both Government and private accountings, some companies' current contributions to the pension fund are not large enough to finance all the benefits that will come due when these people begin retiring.
And Mr. Lockhart of the pension corporation, as well as Robert D. Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, say the pension insurance program includes the same embedded liabilities and accounting gimmicks that characterized the savings and loan insurance program before it reached a crisis.
The problems with Federal pension programs for Government employees stem from the Government's failure to set aside enough money years ago. Now the Government has worked out a long-term program to pay the debt, with great consequence to the Federal budget in the later years. The Government already spends more than $500 billion a year in retirement costs and health-care payments for retired people covered by Medicare. That represents more than a third of the Federal budget, compared to 22 percent in 1970.
 
Time Is the Enemy
 "This is the time we should be getting our fiscal house into extraordinary good shape," said Neil Howe, the senior economist with the National Taxpayers Union Foundation, based in Washington, and co-author of a 1988 book, "On Borrowed Time" (ICS/Kampmann), that warned about the future burden of Government entitlements.
"If we wait too long to put in reforms" for the pension plan, Mr. Lockhart said, "the companies will have to declare bankruptcy" because the Government will have to impose far higher premiums and make other changes in the system that many companies will not be able to afford. Mr. Lockhart said his corporation projects a deficit of $18 billion in 10 years and $30 billion in 30 years.
Adding to the Government's problem, some companies with well-financed plans are choosing to leave the Federal system, while poorly financed plans are expanding the benefits they offer.
"We need to make sure that Federal liabilities are not increased with abandon by companies having hard times," Mr. Reischauer said.
The officials who think the pension corporation's problems are not so severe point out that the agency reports a surplus in the Federal budget. But the Federal budget shows only an agency's yearly cash flow; it does not take into account future liabilities. On that basis, the pension corporation reported a surplus of almost $800 million last year.
By contrast, the corporation's annual report reported a $500 million loss, using what is known as an accrual accounting method, which is commonplace at private insurance companies. Under that method, money is set aside now for losses expected later.

HEADLINE: New York City Feels Pressure to Protect Precious Watershed

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER

 BODY:
After half a century in which it has possessed the purest and most bountiful supply of drinking water in America, New York City is facing intense new pressure to protect its reservoirs from pollution and development or spend billions of dollars on a mammoth plant to filter the water.
The Environmental Protection Agency plans to release a complex series of water quality standards this week that the city must meet in the next year. To satisfy the Federal agency, New York will have to enforce a rigorous new plan to control development in the region that supplies its water, including buying ecologically sensitive land in the Catskills. If it does not succeed, the city will almost certainly be ordered to begin constructing the plant. 
 Such a costly enterprise, which Federal officials could impose on the city as early as next year, would quickly become one of the largest public works projects New York has ever tried. Most major American cities already filter their water, as required under Federal law. In the past, however, New York has successfully argued that because most of its water comes from the pristine reservoirs of the Catskills more than 100 miles from the city, it needs only the mildest dose of chlorine to keep it safe.
But tighter Federal regulations, combined with increased pollution and slow but persistent growth in the 2,000-square-mile-area from which New York draws its water, have forced state and Federal health officials to take a new look at the issue.
They say that they are not eager to saddle the city with the huge costs of building a filtration plant, but that unless New York acts fast and effectively to buffer the land that holds its water, there will be no other choice.
"To me this issue is clear," said Dr. William N. Stasiuk, director of the center for environmental health at the State Health Department, which will ultimately enforce any Federal laws concerning the city's drinking water. "The New York City watershed is one of the greatest physical resources any city has on this planet," he said. "It will need protection, not just for 10 or 20 years, but for as long as New York intends to survive. No matter what else it does, the city will have to develop an acceptable plan to protect that area. Then we can talk about putting off filtration."
The Dinkins administration has been presented with what seems like a simple choice: spend a few hundred million dollars now on the region that supplies New York with the bulk of the 1.5 billion gallons of water it consumes each day -- by preventing further development, buying potentially valuable land, stopping soil erosion, and repairing the sewage plants and bridges it controls -- or pay up to $6 billion to build the filtration plant and $300 million a year to operate it.
Easy choice, right?
Not necessarily, because nobody can promise the city that protecting the watershed will be enough to prevent filtration. Some day, public health officials say, the Federal Government may still require New York to filter its water. President-elect Bill Clinton has not yet expressed specific positions on water quality. But many public health officials expect his administration to enforce clean-water regulations more vigorously than did the Bush Administration.
That has made New York politicians, horrified at the prospect of spending so much money in a recession, reluctant to buy land in Delaware County or the Catskills, where most of the city's giant watershed is situated.
"The hardest thing for government to do is to spend money now to save money in the future," said Albert F. Appleton, Commissioner of the city's Department of Environmental Protection, who has made protecting the water supply his chief goal. "Unfortunately, inertia and politics almost always work against good planning."
Uncertainty hurts too, and that uncertainty has turned many environmentalists, who usually argue that filtration is the only certain way to protect the public from new dangers in the water, into ardent opponents of the idea. Like Mr. Appleton, they fear that if the plant is built, New York will lose any incentive or financial ability to protect the reservoir region.

 
 
Land Use: Power and Politics
 New York City has power to control land use in the watershed, along with unilateral rights to stop development. But the political complexities of New York State politics make such authority hard to wield. Upstate legislators have long made it clear that unless the city consults and compromises on watershed growth, other issues crucial to the city, like money for transportation and welfare, will be held up in retaliation.
The water issue has incensed residents of Delaware County, where two of the city's largest reservoirs are located. People there know what growth restrictions would mean: fewer business opportunities and less money in a place where nearly a third of the population receives public assistance and where per-capita income is lower than in Brooklyn or the Bronx.
"It's hard to sit up here and see the city as anything other than vicious and cold," said Kenneth R. Markert, a Delaware County planner who is executive director of the Coalition of Watershed Towns, which represents more than 35 of the small hamlets and villages in the region that oppose the city's plans to control development in the watershed. Mr. Markert's group contends that the city, desperate to avoid the costs of filtration, would gladly force its will upon the politically weak residents of his part of the state.
"For decades they have ignored their obligations to us and to themselves," Mr. Markert said. "They pay less for our water than we do. They neglect the property they control here. And now they are trying to keep us from even trying to make a living. Many people here think New York won't be happy until every one of us is gone and forgotten. Then they can rope off the region and run it the way they like."
On the surface, the battle lines seem clear enough: 100,000 people living a rural life spread among thousands of acres versus the insatiable needs of the nation's biggest and thirstiest city. That is the way it has been for years: balancing the concerns of a small group of upstate landholders against 10 million residents of New York City and its closest suburbs who depend on them for water. Few on either side would argue that New York City, which under state law is responsible for overseeing and protecting the watershed, has been anything but a neglectful behemoth since 1905, when it began to raze villages and burn homesteads in its search for pure water.
Yet, for the first time since regulations for growth in the watershed were last enacted 40 years ago, New York has a rare chance to guarantee the quality of its last untainted natural resource, environmentalists and public health officials say. The city's air remains among the dirtiest in the nation. Its noise levels are unparalleled in America and its garbage problems are worthy of their legend.

 
 
Looming Threat: Filtration Plant
 It was only through a miracle of planning and foresight that the city decided 150 years ago to draw its water from far away. Most major cities went to the nearest river, and today New York is the only American city with a population over 1,000,000 that does not need to filter its water. Everyone agrees that all it would take to preserve that cheap supply of quality drinking water is to shut off development in Delaware and Catskill counties. Faced with the threat of a filtration plant that would cost more than every dam built in the state over the last 100 years, the city finally has the incentive to do it.
"Politics deals with reality," said Eric A. Goldstein, a senior lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a group that is leading the fight to control development in the Catskills. "And reality says if the city feels it has to filter, it simply isn't going to spend the money it should to keep our water safe in the first place. Once we lose that land to development we're never going to get it back. You can't even put a price on that kind of loss."
Such a loss has been demonstrated vividly throughout the Croton watershed in Westchester and Dutchess counties, which now supplies 10 percent of the city's water, and where population has risen by nearly 50 percent in the last 20 years. Once as bucolic and seemingly remote as the Catskills, the Croton system has become so polluted that the city has agreed to spend $600 million to filter its water.
The plant, which is under construction, will make the region's water safe to drink, but nobody thinks Croton water will ever be as good as it was even 20 years ago. And when many planners think about the Catskill and Delaware reservoirs, they mostly worry that what has happened in Westchester could happen again.
That is why the city has proposed stringent new regulations on development, which would prevent new septic systems and the growth they represent from coming to the area. The rules would control farming along the streams that feed its reservoirs, regulate industrial discharges into the rivers and limit the construction of vacation homes.

 
 
Rules Ignite Ire Among Farmers
 Applauded by many conservationists when they were first proposed two years ago, the regulations have ignited nothing but bitterness along the banks of the Delaware River. The original proposals were viewed as particularly onerous by farmers. After much debate the city agreed this spring to spend several million dollars to help farmers there reduce their use of agricultural contaminants that pollute the water. A new system of voluntary pollution restrictions would be tailored to individual farms and be phased in over the next decade.
"I want low-density growth here," said State Assemblyman Richard I. Coombe, a farmer, defeated for re-election last month, who has been a leading opponent of strict regulation in the watershed. "We want the water clean for farming and agriculture and tourism. But the question here is, where do you draw the line? And the city wants to draw it over us."
Mr. Appleton says that is not true. The first city environmental commissioner to seek compromise with upstate residents, he has argued there must be a solution that all can accept.
"This is not a simple issue," Mr. Appleton said. "We pull a major resource out of that region and we ought to recognize it and compensate the people who live there. That has not always been done in the past. But this is not just about growth in Delaware County, where many planners wonder whether growth even makes sense."
"Protecting the environment is about the wise use of resources," he said. "This water is an enormous economic and social asset. I don't think its an exaggeration to say it holds the key to the future of the city, the region and the state."
The residents of Delaware County have heard it all before. New York City is not much loved in those parts. Not since the turn of the century, when the sprawling metropolis started wiping dozens of farm towns off the earth, flooding them to create the lakes and reservoirs that now hold 90 percent of New York's water. Dams and bridges, which the city is required to maintain as a condition of using the region's water, have been allowed nearly to disintegrate.
One bridge, the Dun Raven, used to provide a nice ride across the Pepacton Reservoir, the largest in the Delaware County system. But it began to deteriorate, and fearing disaster, county leaders closed it. Another bridge, in Ulster County, is in such bad shape that school officials no longer permit their buses to drive across it.
The city has started to spend more money on the region lately. Yet, many feel it isn't enough to placate residents there or, barring huge new investment, to keep the region from going the way of the Poconos, where motels dot the land and empty spaces are increasingly hard to find.
The consequences of development for pure water are not debatable. The more construction, the more sewage, the more roads, the worse the water becomes. Today trout run in the waters most New Yorkers drink, clear evidence of its cleanliness.
During the next 10 years, however, the Catskill region is expected to grow by up to 15 percent, and the Delaware by slightly less than that. Most towns in that region have few or no regulations or zoning rules to govern development. Without the mandate from the city, they are unlikely to impose new rules soon.
"You know people used to eat oysters out of the East River and swim in the Hudson," said Robert J. Pirani, director of environmental programs at the Regional Plan Association. "It's sad to think in a few years they are going to look at the water in New York City and say, 'Hey, you used to be able to drink this stuff right out of the tap.' "

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Clinton Social Policy Camps: Bill's vs. Hillary's

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
The social policy of the Clinton Administration is being shaped by separate and in some ways conflicting camps, represented both literally and metaphorically by the occupants of two red brick buildings on Capitol Hill.
One houses the Children's Defense Fund, the child-advocacy group that has become a model of effective liberal lobbying. The other is home to the Democratic Leadership Council, which was founded to criticize and change that same liberal tradition. 
 Hillary Clinton recently led the former; Bill Clinton recently led the latter. The contrast between the groups, and the larger philosophies they embody, is in part between old-style Democrats and self-proclaimed new ones, between those who have spent the last decade denouncing conservative rule and those who have emphasized the need to learn from it.
 
Clash Behind the Scenes
 The two groups do share many important assumptions, not the least of which is that 12 years of Republican Government have left domestic policy a mess. And they both support many of the same proposals, including universal health care and more money for Head Start and child immunizations.
But they have already had a revealing behind-the-scenes clash over welfare reform, one of Mr. Clinton's key domestic proposals. And their differences, in policy and in tone, could shape many other Clinton initiatives, from national service to child care.
"They have had differences in the past," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, who like most others involved with social policy was treating the matter as a topic of some sensitivity this week.
With members of both camps gaining powerful posts, no one is eager to offend. "You're onto something, of course, but I'm not going to get into it," said Mr. Moynihan, who is identified with neither group.
The Democratic Leadership Council's research arm, the Progessive Policy Institute, is a major supporter of Mr. Clinton's pledge to make welfare recipients work after two years, or face a reduction in their benefits. The defense fund, now publicly noncommittal about the idea, has long called work requirements punitive.
One Clinton transition official said the conflict between the two perspectives had dominated welfare planning. "I've run into it from the get-go, God, have I ever," the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "It's dominated all the discussions. The two sides are very different."
Part of the difference can be seen in the catch-phrase preferred by each. The policy institute talks of "reinventing Government." The defense fund says "we know what to do," implying a need not to reinvent Government but to finance it. The fund offers Head Start as a favorite example, arguing that while few people question the program's merit, it still reaches only 30 percent of its possible universe.
The Children's Defense Fund bears the mark of its founder and president, Marian Wright Edelman, who came of age in the civil rights movement in Mississippi during the 1960's.
In a preface to the group's annual report on American children, released this week, Mrs. Edelman evoked the struggles of the past by recalling that she always used to start her car with the door open. That way, if racial antagonists had planted a bomb, "there was a chance of being thrown out and escaping death."
Since its founding in 1973, the defense fund has been a leader in securing new rights for children and more money for the programs that serve them. For instance, the group played an important role in a series of Medicaid expansions in the 1980's that gave free health insurance to millions of needy children.
Mrs. Edelman's approach is one of relentless, often accusational, advocacy, that has sometimes alienated even her liberal allies. This week's report was characteristic, calling child poverty rates "shameful," "a human and moral travesty," and referring to "small, helpless welfare babies."
Leaders of the fund say they are interested in improving Government programs, but their emphasis has been on financing them. This week's report, for instance, criticizes the decade-old Job Training Partnership Act for reaching "only a fraction" of those who need training. But it fails to acknowledge that a recent evaluation showed that the program actually lowered the earnings of the young men who joined it.
 
Legacy of Mondale's Defeat
 By contrast, the Democratic Leadership Council is quicker to criticize the structure of social programs. It was founded a year after Walter F. Mondale's 1984 defeat, by a group of disaffected Democrats that included both Mr. Clinton and Senator Albert Gore, the Vice President-elect.
"The goal was to find new ways to fulfill the old commitments," said Will Marshall, president of the policy institute.
While traditional liberalism has emphasized the rights of the disadvantaged, the policy institute talks about "balancing rights and responsibilities." It advocates time limits on welfare, for instance, and wants to require students to perform community service in exchange for Government loans.
The institute, which Mr. Clinton headed in 1990 and 1991, has also been a sharp critic of centralized Government bureaucracies, calling for "market- driven" or "entrepreneurial" policies. Rather than increase spending on traditional education programs, for instance, the institute advocates a plan that would let parents or teachers get a state charter to start their own, publicly financed school to compete with those run by school boards.
 
'Substantial Convergence'
 Those involved argue that the differences between the groups are minor.
"You ain't gonna get me into a fight with Marian Wright Edelman, because she's very powerful, and she's been right on a lot of stuff," said Elaine C. Kamarck, a senior fellow at the policy institute.
James D. Weill, the defense fund's general counsel, echoed the sentiment, arguing that there was "substantial convergence" between the two groups.
And indeed there is.
Both are pushing for the Government to tighten the collection of child- support awards and to make the payment itself if absent parents don't. Both support a large expansion in the tax credits that the Government gives to low-income workers. Both groups want to expand the job training offered to welfare recipients. Both favor family leave policies and more "family preservation" programs, to try to keep children from foster care.
While the policy institute places more emphasis on the behavior of the disadvantaged, the defense fund is not silent on the issue. It has conducted a public education campaign, for instance, with stark ads that urge teen-agers not to become pregnant.
 
Signal of Fund's Influence
 The defense fund may have won a highly placed advocate when its chairwoman, Donna E. Shalala, was nominated to become Secretary of Health and Human Services. She succeeded Mrs. Clinton as chairwoman of the fund early this year. When Ms. Shalala listed her five top priorities, welfare reform was absent. That, she said, would take more time.
The Clintons have already blessed both camps with personal appearances at post-election fund raisers. Mrs. Edelman enjoys a friendship of nearly two decades with Mrs. Clinton, who worked at the fund during and after law school. As a signal of the fund's new influence, Mrs. Edelman has been besieged with radio and television requests in the past month. She has repeatedly said she will not go into the Government.
But stalwarts of the "new Democrat" camp are also plentiful. They include Al From, the director of the Democratic Leadership Council, who is heading the transition's domestic policy group. His deputy, Bruce Reed, worked at the council before serving as the Clinton campaign's issues adviser.
Other policy institute staff members involved in the transition include Will Marshall, the institute's president, Robert J. Shapiro, a vice president, and David Osborne, who has written two books whose titles have provided Mr. Clinton with catchy phrases: "Laboratories of Democracy," and "Reinventing Government."
 
Areas of Disagreement
 Future clashes between the two camps may be hinted at by past ones. The Children's Defense Fund has made expansions of the minimum wage a priority. The policy institute's first paper called it "an anachronism -- or worse yet." It argued that tax credits were a better vehicle for channeling money to the poor.
The two groups have also shared different views of child care programs. The policy institute calls for converting the $4 billion in Federal child care money to vouchers, which let parents choose where they send their children.
The defense fund has argued that converting all the money to vouchers could hurt parents in poor neighborhoods, since centers might not open there. In those cases, it argues, traditional direct funding is needed.
That issue was part of a larger child care fight that erupted into unusual view in 1990. Mrs. Edelman accused Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Long Island, one of her usual allies, of being "willing to rob millions of children" by making legislative compromises.
Mr. Downey, who lost his recent re-election bid, responded at the time by calling Mrs. Edelman one of "the liberals of the 60's" who had failed to adjust to the times. Mr. Downey, now a Clinton transition aide in the area of social policy, is expected to join the Administration in an influential role.
Isabel V. Sawhill, an economist at the Urban Institute, acknowledged the differing views in the same spirit as everyone else: with carefully chosen words. "This is a very interesting time in trying to sort out, or should I say, integrate the two views," she said.

HEADLINE: Official Says an Increase In Empire Rates Is Likely

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

 BODY:
New York State's Insurance Superintendent said last night that he was likely to grant Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield the entire rate increase it had requested for Jan. 1, which would substantially raise the cost of health insurance for 1.4 million customers.
"At this point I can't see any more money that's available," the Superintendent, Salvatore R. Curiale, said in an interview. "I really can't say what I'm going to do at this point, but we're getting close to the point where I'm going to have to grant the entire rate increase." 
 Mr. Curiale's remarks came after a day when talks between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and state legislative leaders over how to resolve the growing financial crisis at Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield appeared to have broken down. The insurer says that unless it receives more than $420 million soon, its reserves will dwindle to nothing within a few months.
Each side took pains to try to cast blame for any eventual rate increase on the other, and Mr. Curiale's warning could well have been intended to alarm the Senate Republicans into acting on an aid package for Empire. But with relations between the Governor and the Senate particularly bitter as the year draws to a close, it is unlikely that the Senate will relent and grant the company any immediate relief.
Unless it receives at least $85 million from the state in the next two weeks, the insurer's executives say, Empire will have to raise rates for 1.4 million of its small-group and individual customers by an average of 25.7 percent. Mr. Curiale, who is to rule on the rate increase by Jan. 1, had hoped that the Governor and the Legislature would reach some agreement to provide enough money, which would have reduced the amount of any increase.
Governor Cuomo has proposed granting Empire, the state's largest insurer, a one-shot infusion of $85 million from a state fund that provides malpractice insurance to doctors. But that move has been opposed by the Republicans who control the State Senate, who said today that they did not feel they needed to return to Albany to negotiate an aid package and suggested that Mr. Curiale put off his rate decision until the end of January.
Mr. Curiale, a Cuomo appointee who has sole rate-making authority over Empire, said the company's situation was so desperate that he had to make his decision by the end of the year. "Here is a vehicle by which you can pump $85 million into Empire at no cost to the taxpayers," he said. "It seems that the Senate Republicans are adamantly against this."
The issue caused the simmering antagonism between Governor Cuomo, a Democrat, and the Senate leadership to bubble over yesterday in an exchange of words that was nasty even by Albany's rough-and-tumble standards. For more than a month, Mr. Cuomo has tried to get the Legislature to return to the capital to take up several issues, but yesterday the Senate majority Leader, Ralph J. Marino, made it clear that he saw no reason for his members to do so.
The regular legislative session does not start until January, but legislators often return to the Capitol in the off-season to act on one crucial issue or another.
 
Testy Phone Call
 The Senate's reluctance to participate in a special legislative session enraged the Governor, who made his feelings known in a testy telephone call to Mr. Marino yesterday morning. "When I asked him: 'What is the impediment to coming back? Is there a problem? Are you too busy? Is it too cold in Albany?' he wouldn't give me a reason," Mr. Cuomo said in a telephone interview. "They'll come back for Christmas parties; they'll come back for committee meetings, but they won't come back to work."
Whatever happens, the dwindling prospect of a special session further compounds the problems for Empire, which insures nine million people in the New York City, mid-Hudson and Albany areas.
The company says that it needs the money either through a rate increase or a cash infusion from the state, or some combination of both. Last week, a United States Senate subcommittee announced that it had begun a far-reaching investigation of Empire's finances and management, lending fuel to calls for tighter state control over the company in Albany.
Mr. Cuomo has proposed giving Empire $85 million from a state fund set up to provide malpractice insurance to doctors. Empire, which has contributed several hundred million dollars to the fund in the last seven years, has sued the state to get its money back, and the $85 million would come from settling the lawsuit.
The Governor says that although he can settle the lawsuit on his own, he needs the full Legislature to appropriate the money to Empire. For its part, the Senate has suggested that it might appropriate the money anyway -- but sometime in its regular session. And yesterday John E. McArdle, a spokesman for Mr. Marino, said the Insurance Department should wait until the end of January before ruling on the rate increase.
But Mr. Curiale said he had no time. This fall Empire filed suit against him after he denied the company's request for a 14 percent rate increase, claiming that his denial had allowed their cash reserves to dip to a dangerously low point. The company won in the lower courts.
 
Other Pressures
 The state appealed the decision, but Mr. Curiale said it would be irresponsible to deny Empire the money it needs.
Along with the Empire rate increase, Mr. Cuomo has been pushing the Legislature to return to Albany to try to fill the Metropolitan Transportation Association's $265 million deficit without raising bus and subway fares, and to act on a proposal to shift nearly $95 million left from the 1988 Transportation Bond Act from Long Island and New York City to communities in upstate New York.
But yesterday, the Governor's efforts to coax, embarrass and threaten the Senate into returning appeared to have been in vain.
The Senate Republicans said the Governor was, in effect, fabricating crises in order to make the Senate look bad. "It is utter nonsense," said Mr. McArdle. "On each of the issues the Governor has yet to make a convincing case as to why we need to come back, and in fact it would probably be more intelligent to address these issues in January."

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Clinton Plans to Spread the Wealth In Increased Public Works Spending

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
The transportation industry is gearing up a major lobbying campaign to grab a big share of the increased public works spending promised by the incoming Clinton Administration.
But the Clinton team, which has never spelled out how it would divide the $20 billion in additional money that Mr. Clinton promised to spend each year, appears to be planning a much broader array of programs, spreading the wealth beyond traditional road and bridge projects. 
 Mr. Clinton has made clear that he views "infrastructure," the term usually used to encompass all sorts of public works spending, as a very broad area for investment.
"There's no question that if we increase our investment in infrastructure for tomorrow, that we'll do better," the President-elect said at the recent economic conference in Little Rock, Ark. "We need to do it in not just roads and bridges and water and sewer systems, but in new rail systems, new air transport systems, all kinds of things that are out there for us to do. An information highway, broadly defined, is infrastructure."
 
'Information Superhighways'
 And Vice President-elect Al Gore, long a proponent of increased spending on information technologies, chimed in, "Shouldn't we be giving a lot more emphasis to the kind of national infrastructure we need to share information and create and share knowledge?" He spoke of "information superhighways" that would include "digital libraries, the software and the programs that make it possible for children to come home after school and plug into the Library of Congress."
If its membership surveys are to be believed, the transportation sector alone would have no problem devouring the bulk of an annual increase of $20 billion in spending.
The American Road and Transportation Builders Association has already begun soliciting financial support from its members for a campaign of advertising, publicity and lobbying like the million-dollar blitz that preceded passage of the Surface Transportation Act of 1991, which provided $150 billion in Federal aid over six years.
The new campaign began on Dec. 10, when the all-news radio station in Little Rock began to broadcast pro-transportation commercials that ran 14 times a day until the end of the economic meeting there. A full-page advertisement, also calling for increased transportation spending, was in The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette on Monday, the day the conference opened.
But advisers to the Clinton campaign say no further enormous increase in transportation spending is likely to be enacted right away, both because the money is not readily available and because even transportation enthusiasts in Congress doubt that all the projects on the interest groups' wish list can be justified.
Rather, one adviser said, the most that can be expected is something on the order of $5 billion more each year, at least half of which would simply go to financing the 1991 act, whose targets have not been met so far.
Although Mr. Clinton has said he would cut military spending to pay for civil projects, new pressures to cut the deficit could change that plan. The most likely source of additional revenue for transportation spending would be a big increase in gasoline taxes, but Mr. Clinton has appeared reluctant to back away from campaign pledges against raising the gasoline tax.
Another possible source of money is to tap pension funds and other private capital, by marketing new varieties of infrastructure bonds that might be guaranteed by the Federal Government.
Mr. Clinton has not yet named his Transportation Secretary or focused much attention on his public works program, said people involved in the transition.
But many of the people involved in the transition said they believed that if the grand total of public works spending increases is ever to reach $20 billion, it is likely to be through a combination of measures, including research as well as construction, using the broadest possible definition of "infrastructure" in order to flesh out the spending program.
But for the moment, transportation groups are in the best position to list the projects they would spend money on the instant it was made available.
The American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials, after surveying officials in all the states, said it could spend an extra $8.5 billion in Federal highway money in 1993 beyond what has already been provided by Congress.
The legislation enacted in 1991 might have allowed more than $20 billion to be spent on surface transportation projects in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, but in an attempt to keep the deficit down Congress approved only $18 billion for the year in its annual spending bill. State officials said they could spend as much as $26.5 billion this year, concentrating the additional money in easy-to-start repair projects.
The amount that might be spent on surface transportation could be increased even more rapidly if mass transit agencies were given all they are seeking. This year local transit agencies anticipate spending $4.6 billion in Federal money, and they say they have an extra $7 billion in projects ready to go if the money were made available.
The easiest way to spend the money, said officials of the American Public Transit Association, would be to buy new vehicles like buses, vans and subway cars. The association's survey found that agencies could spend $1.25 billion on buses and vans and $1.64 billion on other vehicles.
There are not quite as many billions of dollars waiting to be spent on aviation, but here too there are lists of projects ready to pursue.
The Federal Aviation Administration's airport improvement spending program this year amounts to $1.8 billion, while the long-term needs for airport projects run about $40 billion over 10 years, aviation officials said.
 
High-Speed Railroads
 The question is how many of these programs could make use of a rapid infusion of money. Joseph Del Balzo, the aviation agency's top engineering official, said that airports had 109 runway projects in mind and that the layout plans had been completed for 77 of them. Of these, 26 are far enough along that environmental impact statements have been issued, a sign that construction is ready to begin.
In the passenger railroad sector, a short-term infusion of money would make little sense unless the investment program continued for years to come. One of Mr. Clinton's favorite programs is the development of high-speed intercity trains like those used in Europe and Japan, but these are years from becoming widespread in the United States.
W. Graham Claytor, president of Amtrak, told the economic meeting in Little Rock that the railroad was ready to start "instantly" to spend more money, adding, "Long-term solutions don't come about unless there's short-term action."
Mr. Claytor said it would "take about a billion dollars to get our national railroad passenger system in first-class shape." He was apparently referring to the railroad's annual spending needs. According to Amtrak's long-term capital investment plan, which was prepared for Congress last year, Amtrak needs to increase investments by $1.2 billion a year on new tracks, trains and other equipment from now until the year 2007. Under the Bush Administration, the capital budget was never fully financed.
To accomplish that, Mr. Claytor is seeking the use of 1 cent of the Federal gasoline tax. He has promised that the money "would produce an Amtrak hardly recognizable by today's standards." Most important, he has said, the railroad would no longer have to turn to the Federal Government for operating subsidies to keep its fares competitive.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
A Populist Inauguration: Jackson, With Decorum

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:
When President-elect Bill Clinton's big rock candy mountain moves from Little Rock to Washington, the contrast with previous inaugurations will be palpable, deliberate and historically aware. While there will be entertainment, fireworks and a multicultural festival on the Mall, it is clearly designed to contrast with the plutocratic touches of the Reagan and Bush inaugurations.
Because a partially open house at the White House is on the schedule the day after the inauguration, there is talk of recapturing the spirit of Andrew Jackson's first inauguration, on March 4, 1829. If so, the Clintons had better roll up the carpets and count the silver first. Contemporary accounts of General Jackson's inauguration serve to caution the Democratic residents of the White House about the wisdom of letting the People join in the fun too democratically. 
 President-elect Jackson avoided a parade, vetoed elaborate balls and celebrations and, accompanied by his friends, walked along the sidewalk to his inauguration. (One reason for the simplicity, of course, is that his wife, Rachel, had died on Dec. 22, 1828; a few weeks later, Jackson left his Tennessee home for Washington.)
Some onlookers thought the lack of ceremony an insult to the office of the Presidency. But Francis Scott Key, author of "The Star-Spangled Banner," said of the 10,000 visitors who crowded Washington to witness the oath of office, "It is beautiful; it is sublime!"
As Jackson and his friends approached the Capitol's East Portico on foot, crowds rushed to catch a glimpse of the new President. All but one man in the procession wore a hat; spotting the tall bare-headed figure, onlookers shouted: "There he is, he with the white head! There is the old veteran! There is Jackson!"
 
Crowds, Then a Mob
 People had come from as much as 500 miles away to see the battle- and duel-scarred new President. A witness wrote that Pennsylvania Avenue "was crowded with carriages of every description, from the splendid Baronet and coach, down to wagons and carts, filled with women and children, some in finery and some in rags, for it was the people's President."
After the oath was administered on a springlike day, the White House was thrown open to the public. President Jackson shook hands with a number of people, then escaped by a side entrance to his lodgings at Gadsby's Hotel.
One guest, James Hamilton Jr., recalled the scene in the White House beginning that afternoon: "The mob broke in, in thousands. Spirits black, yellow, and gray poured in in one uninterrupted stream of mud and filth, among the throngs many subjects for the penitentiary."
Referring to a well-known abolitionist, he continued, "It would have done Mr. Wilberforce's heart good to have seen a stout black wench eating in this free country a jelly with a gold spoon at the President's House."
Twenty thousand people passed through the Executive Mansion, attacking the refreshments, breaking china and glassware, standing in muddy boots on damask-covered chairs, ripping down drapery, trampling on rugs and breaking costly handmade French furniture. The doors could not accommodate the crowds entering and leaving; windows had to be used as exits. The food quickly ran out, but tubs of punch, laced with whiskey, kept flowing. When the tubs were finally moved to the lawn, the mob followed and reeled off into the night.
 
In Jefferson's Path
 The Clinton inauguration will begin Jan. 17, with a visit to Monticello, followed by a bus caravan to Washington, a journey to the White House that pays tribute to the path, and presumably the ideals, of the third President, in 1801.
Thomas Jefferson, the first President to take the oath in Washington, walked to the Capitol from his boarding house, a block away, accompanied by a group of riflemen, artillerymen and civilians. His predecessor, John Adams, drove out of the city at dawn because he did not want to attend the inauguration of a man whom he believed would be responsible for the dissolution of the Republic.
 
Elaborate and Expensive
 Beginning with John F. Kennedy's in 1961, inaugurations have become more extravagant. The cost of the Clinton ceremonies, paid for mainly by Democratic Party contributors and corporate sponsors, is expected to be close to $20 million.
Statistics vary on the costs of the last two inaugurations depending on adjustments for inflation and public and private underwriting, but they were reported to be in the neighborhood of $25 million each.
Even as a populist event, the Clinton inauguration will surely contrast with the first inauguration, at Federal Hall in Manhattan.
Although George Washington was rich for his time, he was land-poor and had to borrow 600 pounds to finance his trip from Virginia to that inauguration. His swearing-in was followed by the firing of 13 cannons and 13 skyrockets.
Two months later, a modest ball was held in rooms on Broadway. Martha Washington did not arrive in time to attend.

GRAPHIC: Drawing: President-elect Bill Clinton's inauguration will deliberately contrast those of Presidents Reagan and Bush with a publicly oriented approach reminiscent of Andrew Jackson's ceremonies in 1829. (Century Magazine)

HEADLINE: Yugoslavia Votes, Divided and Fearful

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Voters in what is left of Yugoslavia go to the polls Sunday, bitterly divided about their country's future yet agreeing on one thing: the weeks ahead are full of new and terrible dangers.
The two remaining republics that now make up federal Yugoslavia -- Serbia and Montenegro -- are rife with rumors of coups, military uprisings and even impending war among the rival factions who are contesting the election within Serbia. No matter who wins the voting, most citizens believe that neither side will accept the results peacefully. 
 "I am so scared I can't sleep at night," one Belgrade worker said. "I want to go into my basement and stay there until the whole thing is over."
Most attention is focused on the crucial contest for Serbia's presidency, although voters will be choosing three new Parliaments, a federal one for Yugoslavia and one for each of its constituent republics, Serbia and Montenegro. The Serbian presidential contest pits two radically different candidates against each other.
 
A Distinct Choice
 The incumbent, Slobodan Milosevic, 51 years old , is a nationalist militant who views himself as the bearer of Serbia's centuries-old tradition. His supporters see him as a heroic figure who embodies the mystic Serbian consciousness. But his critics, among them most world leaders, consider him a brutal criminal responsible for the cruel war still ranging in neighboring Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Mr. Milosevic's main opponent, Milan Panic, 63, the federal Yugoslav Prime Minister, says he is determined to lead his country into the modern world.
Born in Belgrade, Mr. Panic emigrated to the United States as a young man, made a fortune in the pharmaceutical business, and returned to his homeland less than six months ago to take the job of Prime Minister. He pledges to end the fighting in Bosnia, make Yugoslavia into a democracy, and shake Serbs out of the nationalist fervor that has led them to the status of international outcasts.
Public opinion polls here are notoriously unreliable, so there is no clear indication whether Mr. Milosevic or Mr. Panic is ahead. Most people say they believe that the race is close, and that the five minor candidates will win enough votes to deny anyone an absolute majority.
If that happens, the two leading candidates will have a runoff election in two weeks.
 
Incumbent Advantage
 During the campaign, Mr. Milosevic has used every advantage available to incumbents in authoritarian countries. State-run television has been heavily biased in his favor, and Government funds have poured into his campaign.
But Mr. Panic has run a surprisingly strong race. To many voters, especially the young, he represents the first hope for a genuine change that this country has had since World War II.
Because Mr. Milosevic is a lifelong Communist who has shown himself willing to use all means necessary to win political victories, many Yugoslavs fear that he will not abide by the results if he loses.
"I can't imagine Milosevic out of power altogether," said Stojan Cerovic, who covers the campaign for the Belgrade news magazine Vreme. "For him, it's almost crazy to think that someone should leave office just because of voting. He is surely thinking of using force if that is necessary to keep his job.
"The opposition is not ready to accept defeat either," Mr. Cerovic added. "If Milosevic wins, opposition parties will say that his victory is illegitimate because the campaign was so unfair. People could pour out on to the streets, and you could have a Beijing-style massacre."
 
A Dangerous Time
 "This is quite a dangerous period, and no one can count on a peaceful solution," he said. "I'm pretty pessimistic. There are too many weapons around, mostly on Milosevic's side. He's a gambler."
Much speculation has centered on the role of the army, the police and the various paramilitary forces that have sprouted here during the last year.
The army is under the official control of Yugoslavia's federal President, Dobrica Cosic, a novelist who has wide public support. In recent weeks, Mr. Cosic has held a series of meetings with senior military officers, seeking to guarantee their obedience.
"The police force has been greatly expanded," said Predrag Simic, director of the nonpartisan Institute of International Politics and Economics. "It has more than 40,000 people in uniform, and about 16,000 of them are political police, trained in special tactics and intensely loyal to Milosevic. Many of them are not from Serbia. They are refugees from Croatia and Bosnia who see Milosevic as their only hope to go back home and continue their wars. If you combine them with these ruthless Mafia-style gangs, you see the possibility for a very deep confrontation here.
"Milosevic realizes that the end of his political career could be the end of his biological career," Mr. Simic said. "Something like half of the Serbian population holds him responsible for the greatest catastrophe that has faced them in modern times. The world wants to try him as a war criminal, and except for Cuba or North Korea or maybe China, he has nowhere to hide. Do you know of any examples of a totalitarian ruler going into peaceful retirement?"
 
Threat of Foreign Intervention
 Many Yugoslavs also worry about foreign intervention. World leaders have threatened an increase in pressure on Yugoslavia if Mr. Milosevic wins. Diplomats said responses could include closure of foreign embassies here, blockades of international borders, and cutting of telephone and other services to Serbia.
If Mr. Milosevic wins, diplomats say, Western governments will seriously consider attacking Serbian military positions in an effort to end the Bosnia fighting. These attacks could be aimed at artillery batteries being used to shell Bosnian towns, or at targets inside Serbia itself.
"Outside pressures intended to support Panic and the opposition have been counterproductive, and future pressures will have the same effect," warned Bora Kuzmanovic, a professor of social psychology at the University of Belgrade. "They provoke nationalist feelings. If someone from abroad tries to help the opposition by intervention, even limited intervention, they will cause a pro-Milosevic uprising that will destabilize the whole situation."
Many Yugoslavs say that if Mr. Milosevic cannot win an outright victory on Sunday, his air of invincibility will be lost, and prospects for his electoral defeat will dramatically increase. They fear that if he senses he is losing, he may provoke a violent confrontation, either in the Serbian heartland or in Kosovo or Montenegro, and use it as a pretext to declare martial law or cancel the runoff election.
"This period is very dangerous because Milosevic is a maniac for power," Vojin Dimitrisevic, a law professor, said. "He cannot tolerate the idea that he would be simply an ordinary citizen, and he cannot be bought off with a villa in France like some African dictator. Like Hitler, he would like to induce the whole nation to commit suicide before he commits suicide himself. I am optimistic that there will be no Milosevic by springtime, but I don't know at what cost."
