HEADLINE: U.S. Moves to Replace Japanese Head of W.H.O.

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

 BODY:
The United States and its European allies are mounting a spirited campaign to prevent the re-election of the head of the World Health Organization, the agency that leads the worldwide battle against AIDS and other threats to public health.
The official, Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima, a Japanese citizen who has headed the agency for five years, is being strongly defended by the Japanese Government. The election is scheduled for Jan. 20. 
 The United States opposes Dr. Nakajima's re-election with the argument that he is an incompetent administrator and a poor leader and communicator, whose frequent travels leave W.H.O. headquarters in Geneva in disarray.
 
Japan Accuses U.S.
 In response, the Japanese Foreign Ministry asserts that Dr. Nakajima has not been in office long enough for his efforts to bear fruit, and accuses Washington of spreading dis information. Dr. Nakajima said in an interview that he had not heard any public or private criticism of his record from United States officials.
But Tokyo, Washington and some European capitals are raising wider issues. Japanese officials say Dr. Nakajima is a symbol of Japan's attempt to play a greater role in world affairs, as Washington has urged.
A senior United States official, on the other hand, cited an internal State Department briefing paper that listed what he described as Japan's intimidating tactics in a diplomatic campaign that for both sides has largely taken place out of public view. He said the issue could damage Japan's prospects for a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council because it raises questions about Japan's conduct in the area of world affairs.
 
State Dept. Paper
 The paper said Japan's "actions -- some reported and others verified -- amount to a pattern of aggressive tactics, including the pursuit of votes in exchange for favors." It listed these actions, among others:
*An official of the Maldives, which has a vote in the W.H.O. election, told American and European officials that Japan had threatened to cut off fish imports from that country if Dr. Nakajima was not re-elected.
*Similar threats were made to cut off coffee imports from Jamaica and purchases from other unspecified countries, and to block a pending $250 million loan to Algeria by the Export-Import Bank.
*A Japanese official offered a job to an official of the Agency for International Development on the condition that he work to change the Government's position on Dr. Nakajima.
Officials of Japan's Foreign Ministry denied the charges. "We have never threatened but we have been threatened," said Masao Kawai, a senior official at the ministry. The Japanese officials accused the United States and other Western countries of undertaking a campaign of disinformation.
State Department officials said in interviews that Japan was also trying to buy votes in the election by offering delegates from key countries first-class tickets to Japan, $14,000 in traveler's checks and $50,000 contributions to their personal research projects.
United States and European officials also say they have received reports from United States embassies that Dr. Nakajima offered the single deputy's job to four people from four countries influential in the election.
A message from the Uruguayan Government to Japanese officials in Geneva said that Uruguay would support Dr. Nakajima's re-election with the understanding that he will appoint a Bolivian as deputy director general.
Dr. Nakajima denied making such pledges. He said it was not he, but Dr. Mohammed Abdelmoumene, the organization's current deputy director and the main opposition candidate to Dr. Nakajima's re-election, who has promised the deputy's position to others. Dr. Abdelmoumene, who denied the assertion, served as deputy director until August, when Dr. Nakajima dismissed him because he had become a rival for his job. Dr. Abdelmoumene, an Algerian, has the support of Washington and the European Community to succeed Dr. Nakajima.

 
 
U.S. Takes Risk Embarrassing Ally
 The United States is investing considerable effort in trying to unseat Dr. Nakajima, despite the certainty of embarrassing a close ally with whom there are many more weighty issues at stake. The stimulus is the high priority United States officials place on the World Health Organization.
W.H.O. led the successful campaign to eradicate smallpox from the world. With an $850 million annual budget, the largest of any United Nations subagency, W.H.O. runs or helps to sustain critical public health programs in many countries, and United States officials say they fear that the re-election of Dr. Nakajima would put these efforts at risk.
"It appears that W.H.O. is losing its reputation as the world's leader in health matters at a time when serious global health problems present daunting challenges to us all," the Health and Human Services Secretary, Louis W. Sullivan, wrote in a recent cable urging other countries to join the United States in choosing a new head.
"Because W.H.O. is dealing with some of the most critical issues facing mankind, we believe it is essential that the organization have the strongest possible leadership," he added.
An American diplomat who is one of Dr. Nakajima's strongest critics and spoke on condition of anonymity said his re-election would establish a precedent that a rich country could buy a new term for what he called an incompetent incumbent.

 
 
A.M.A. Supports Japanese Incumbent
 United States officials have been embarrassed, however, by the support that Dr. Nakajima has received from the American Medical Association, the largest group of doctors in this country. James S. Todd, the A.M.A.'s executive vice president, wrote Dr. Sullivan in July, praising Dr. Nakajima's leadership in providing "a forum for organized medicine from diversified health systems to share ideas with W.H.O. on a host of health policy issues, including private/public sector collaboration, continuing medical education, quality assurance and access to care."
The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, which represents United States drug manufacturers, said it had intended to support Dr. Nakajima but had withheld its endorsement in deference to Washington's opposition to him.
Dr. Nakajima is the first Japanese elected to head an international agency (others have been appointed), and Japanese officials say they do not want to lose face in withdrawing his candidacy.
"He has been given special attention by the Japanese people as well as the Japanese politicians," said Mr. Kawai of the Japanese Foreign Ministry.
Dr. Nakajima is believed to have strong political backing from Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, and Japanese officials say it is too late to find another Japanese candidate.
Japanese officials say they have been surprised by the opposition to Dr. Nakajima, adding that his adversaries had not even hinted at their objections in official statements at W.H.O. meetings and had offered only vague criticism in private discussions.
"This is all disinformation from your side," Mr. Kawai said in an interview.

 
 
Western Criticism Is in General Terms
 Western officials have couched their criticism in general terms. They accuse Dr. Nakajima of a lack of managerial acumen, leadership and vision, and an inability to communicate effectively. They say his autocratic style has alienated his staff and major donor countries at a time of crucial health challenges.
Japanese officials respond by saying one term is too short a time to judge Dr. Nakajima's performance and point out that two former directors of the organization, Dr. Marcolino Candau of Brazil and Dr. Halfdan Mahler of Denmark, served for 20 and 15 years respectively.
Dr. Nakajima, 63, is the 10th generation in his family to become a doctor. He studied psychiatry and pharmacology in Paris and did research there. Although his first wife, who died, was French and his second wife is American, critics say he is not fluent in either French or English and that his thoughts are difficult to follow.
As director general, Dr. Nakajima has traveled often; records show that he was away from Geneva 181 days in 1991 and 176 up to mid-November of this year.
To be an effective head of W.H.O., Dr. Nakajima said, he has to go to the countries to see what their problems are. The heads of other agencies travel even more than he does, he said.
United States officials said Dr. Nakajima has traveled to countries without notifying the appropriate regional directors. One official, Rose Belmont of the Health and Human Services Department's office of international affairs, for example, said Dr. Nakajima did not notify the regional director in Washington when he went to Peru after cholera broke out there.
Dr. Nakajima responded that regional directors often are absent because they are traveling on their own business, but Ms. Belmont called that "a pretty lame excuse" because a deputy regional director was usually present.

 
 
A Small Tempest Over Russian Icons
 One official trip in 1991, to the Soviet Union, created a public relations disaster for Dr. Nakajima over the way he handled later charges in the Soviet press that he had been detained when he tried to take six icons out of the country.
Dr. Nakajima, an art collector, said in one of two interviews that he had bought the icons at a flea market for about $150, in the presence of an official Russian guide who did not explain the need to fill out documents before he put them in his checked luggage in Moscow. The suitcase arrived a day later in Geneva without the icons.
Although Dr. Nakajima said he knew that the Russian newspaper articles were circulating at W.H.O. headquarters and reporters were inquiring about the incident, he did not offer an explanation through his public affairs office. Before reporting the incident in August, The New York Times made repeated calls to Dr. Nakajima, which were not returned.
Then, following a wave of adverse publicity, the agency issued a statement saying Russian custom officials had told the agency that Dr. Nakajima had not been detained at the airport and that they did not regard his action as an infringement of customs regulations.
A senior United States diplomat called the explanation muddy and said he believed the Russians, owing to their desperate need for international aid, were trying to avoid further embarrassment to Dr. Nakajima.
But Japanese officials say the charges of smuggling were groundless.
When asked about Japanese officials' attempts to have him re-elected, Dr. Nakajima dismissed any charges of bribery and said he knew little or nothing about the campaign.

 
 
Deputy Director Is Chief Opponent
 There are three other candidates, all from African nations, but Dr. Nakajima and Dr. Abelmoumene are considered the leading ones. United States officials became impressed with Dr. Abdelmoumene's administrative skills when he filled in for Dr. Nakajima during the Japanese director's absences, said John Bolton, an Assistant Secretary of State.
Dr. Abdelmoumene, 55, who once did research at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., said that if elected, he would work to improve harmony between headquarters and regional offices in seeking to fulfill the agency's goal of health for all. He said he would stay in Geneva more to help restore confidence in the organization's administrative ability.
United States officials have said made few public complaints about the way W.H.O. is run.
At a meeting of the organization earlier this year, James O. Mason, Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, asked whether it was "conceptually and organizationally prepared to provide the health leadership needed by the present changed world, or would it leave the task to other United Nations agencies that were initiating activities in the health field."
Ms. Belmont, of Health and Human Services, said Dr. Mason's comments were spurred by his lack of confidence in Dr. Nakajima's leadership. But Dr. Mason, who will cast the United States vote in the election, did not respond to repeated requests for an interview.
Mr. Bolton of the State Department said he, Dr. Mason and Dr. Sullivan had met with Dr. Nakajima to discuss their criticisms. But in an interview at the United Nations, Dr. Nakajima denied receiving criticism from any United States official.
The representatives of 31 member nations are scheduled to vote by secret ballot on Jan. 20. The outcome is too close to call; but whatever the result, the dispute may damage W.H.O.
Japan, which is the second largest contributor to the agency after the United States, has hinted to American diplomats that it will reduce its contributions to both the agency and its health projects if Dr. Nakajima is not re-elected. After Dr. Nakajima's election, Japan increased its financial support, and its total contributions to this year through November were $57 million, up from $41 million in all of 1988. For comparable periods, the United States contribution rose to $125 million, from $94 million.

HEADLINE: Holiday Travel Has Industry Smiling

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Buoyed by the slowly improving economy, back-to-back long weekends and the growing popularity of winter vacations, more Americans are hitting the road this holiday season than any time since 1989. And they are not only taking to the highways in large numbers, but also to the skies, rails and oceans.
In the two weeks through Jan. 4, an estimated 33.7 million Americans will have driven at least 100 miles from home, 23 million will have flown on scheduled airlines and millions more will have taken buses and trains. 
 While those projections are 3 percent to 5 percent above last year's figures, the actual increases may exceed expectations and bring the travel industry back to where it had been when the bottom fell out in 1990 because of the recession and skyrocketing costs of aviation fuel.
"We forecast a 3 t0 4 percent increase in passengers this Thanksgiving over last," said Dave Swierenga, the chief economist of the Air Transport Association of America. "But the actual increase was on the order of 5 to 6 percent."
 
Favorable Barometers
 Many tourist destinations already report a surprising surge. In New York since the beginning of December, visits to the Empire State Building, a usually good barometer of tourist activity, have been running 12 percent higher than last year. Radio City Music Hall added two performances of its Christmas show this year, for a total of 179, and has sold out almost every show.
At Ford's Theater in Washington, a city enjoying a healthy resurgence of holiday visitors, most of the 58 scheduled performances of "A Christmas Carol" are sold out.
Travel experts say this holiday season has also benefited by the changing pattern of American travel. "The Christmas-New Year's season has become the heaviest travel period of the year," said Paul R. Verkuil, president of the American Automobile Association. "Prior to 1989, the Fourth of July holiday traditionally was the busiest."
While many travel officials caution that it is too early to break out the champagne, after two terrible years and after several false signs that recovery was imminent, some are nevertheless popping their buttons if not their corks.
"Every indication we have is that resorts, ski slopes and traditional resorts are filled," said Earlene Causey, the president of the American Society of Travel Agents. "And it's almost already too late to book the most desirable cabins on cruise ships for this time next year."
 
Full Planes and Hotels
 Some airlines also report near-capacity bookings to popular vacation spots. "All seven of our daily flights from the mainland to Hawaii are filled, and we're flying wide-body planes," said Jim Faulkner of Northwest Airlines. "And if you don't already have a reservation, you can't get in or out of Florida on most days because planes are just packed."
In Little Rock, Ark., to which tourists and politicians have been flocking since Bill Clinton's election as President, hotel occupancy is way up; the Hilton Inn reports that bookings are up 63 percent this month over the same period last year
Many theme parks and resort hotels also expect to do a brisk business for at least part of the holiday season. And while this time of year a visitor could hit the jackpot in Las Vegas and be virtually alone, "after Christmas Day the town is riotous, with so many people flocking here to celebrate New Year's Eve," said Myram Borders of the Las Vegas news bureau.
In a nation that offers something for every taste, it is hardly surprising that some people plan to spend the holidays volunteering in soup kitchens, others climbing mountains and still others running marathons or in religious contemplation. At least 20 Americans will be among the 100 revelers who have paid $9,000 each to celebrate New Year's Eve twice -- once in Shannon, Ireland, then again in Bermuda, after a flight across the Atlantic in the Concorde.
 
Time for Family and Friends
 But for Americans of all faiths, the holiday season remains a time of reunion with family and friends, even on ski slopes and cruises. On Tuesday, when the Crown Odyssey sets sail from San Francisco for a 12-day tour and another Royal Cruise Line ship, the Odyssey, sails from Los Angeles on a similar journey, many of the total 1,750 passengers will include not just the usual parents and children but extended families with grandparents, aunts, uncles and cousins.
As usual, millions of the season's travelers will be college students heading home. "Most of those I talk to want to go home to reconnect with family and friends," said the Rev. David O'Malley, the campus minister of Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland. "It's part of the spiritual nature of being human."
Another traveler who wanted to spend the holidays with her family was Gladys Finnestad, an 81-year-old widow from Streator, Ill. Waiting patiently at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport for her flight to Savannah, Ga., on Friday, Mrs. Finnestad said she had saved all year for the visit with her grandson's family.
"Last year I couldn't afford it," she said. "This year I put away some of my Social Security money. What better way to spend it?"
At Kennedy International Airport in New York that day, Steve Meller of Oak Ridge, N.J., and his wife, Leora, and their almost-2-year-old son, Zachary, were traveling to Aruba with Mrs. Meller's mother, Molly Kalomeer. This will be the family's second Christmas in Aruba, where Mrs. Kalomeer bought a time-share in an apartment.
"I bought the time-share so we could spend the holiday together with the whole family," Mrs. Kalomeer said. "It's a special time."
Midnight Mass at the San Xavier del Bac mission church in southern Arizona is reserved for the Papago Indians, who have worshipped there for 200 years. "But visitors are welcome at the other Masses," said Father Justin, a Franciscan priest at the church on the Papago reservation, "and they usually come in droves."
 
Disrupted by Uncle Sam
 Inevitably, in a country where one in every two marriages ends in divorce, reconnecting with family increasingly means not just with parents, brothers and sisters, but with step-parents, step-brothers and step-sisters -- often in different cities, sometimes at opposite ends of the country.
Ginger Croche, who works for the American Bus Association in Washington, is going back to her native Mississippi this holiday to visit step-children and step-grandchildren in Meridian, then on to see her parents and relatives in Jackson. "On Christmas Day we always have about 25 people at my aunt's house in Jackson," she said.
For the second time in two years, many families' holidays are being disrupted by major American military deployments overseas.
Angie Steele of Oceanside, Calif., had expected to spend Christmas and New Year's with her three young children and her husband, David. But on Dec. 9, two days before the Steeles' 10th wedding anniversary, Second Lieut. David Steele of the Marine Corps shipped out for Somalia.
"When we found out he was going, we put up a tree real quick and held our Christmas celebration then," Mrs. Steele said.
 
Ties to the Old Country
 Some Americans are returning to the old country for the holidays. For the first time in 22 years, Donal McSullivan, the head of a marketing company in New York, will spend Christmas in his native Dublin, taking his wife and young son with him.
But holiday travel is not without its dark side. Baggage theft, pickpocketing and other crimes increase at airports, bus stations and railroad depots. And highway accidents increase, often because of excess speed combined with alcohol from holiday festivities.
But drunken driving is declining nationwide, and in some places dramatically. In Ohio, for example, alcohol-related traffic deaths have fallen each of the last five years, to 36 percent of total highway deaths last year from 44.9 percent in 1989.
"It's never any fun writing a traffic ticket during the holidays," said Trooper Mark Warner, who will be monitoring Interstate 70 west of Columbus, Ohio, on Christmas Day for the State Highway Patrol. "But you think of your own kids and family, and you want those drivers to get where they're going safely."

HEADLINE: Isuzu to Stop Manufacturing Passenger Cars

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 19

 BODY:
In a development that only a few years ago might have seemed unimaginable, one of Japan's automobile companies said today that it would give up production of passenger cars.
The announcement by Isuzu Motors Ltd., which once achieved popularity in the United States with commercials featuring a lying salesman, reflects the hard times that have befallen Japan's automobile industry. 
The move is also part of a new discipline being imposed on companies in many industries as a result of Japan's severe economic slump. With money tight and profits slim, companies that once tried to match competitors in all areas are having to jettison unprofitable products.
"Clearly, we want to focus the organization on our core products," said Donald T. Sullivan, an executive vice president of Isuzu, which is suffering heavy losses. He was sent to help Isuzu by General Motors Corporation, which owns about 37 percent of the company.
For Isuzu, that means focusing on trucks, recreational vehicles and diesel engines.
Isuzu's decision, which had long been rumored, reduces the number of Japanese car manufacturers to eight.
Isuzu makes only one model of car, a compact called the Gemini in Japan. Variations are sold in the United States as the Isuzu Stylus and Impulse and also by General Motors as the Geo Storm. Sales and production have been dropping for several years, and this year the company is estimated to have produced only 90,000 cars, most of which went to General Motors.
"You can't be in the car business with one platform and one product," Mr. Sullivan said.
Despite the economic wisdom of quitting car production, he said "it was a very difficult decision."
Isuzu said it would continue to sell some cars in Japan. But it plans to buy a compact car known as the Domani from Honda Motor Company and resell it under the Isuzu name.
American dealers, however, will not be supplied with cars and will concentrate on selling sport utility vehicles like the Rodeo and Trooper. General Motors told the Reuters news service that it would find a replacement for the Geo Storm from another supplier for the 1996 model year but that it would not offer a Storm model in 1994 and 1995.
In return for getting cars from Honda, Isuzu has tentatively agreed to supply Honda with its Rodeo, which is made at a factory in Lafayette, Ind., owned partly by Isuzu. Honda will resell the Rodeo under its own name in the United States starting in January 1994 and will also consider importing the cars to Japan.
"By exchanging products, both sides will benefit," said Yoshihide Munekuni, executive vice president of Honda.
Such ties between manufacturers are also becoming commonplace. "You have to try to cover as much ground with as few resources as possible," said Peter Boardman, an auto industry analyst with UBS Phillips & Drew in Tokyo.
After years of rapid growth and growing competitiveness that made Japan's automobile industry the envy of the world, car sales in Japan have fallen for two years in a row, and political factors prevent companies from exporting as much as they once did. All the companies have seen their profits slashed dramatically and some, including Nissan, the second largest automaker, are suffering losses.
With slower growth and a depressed stock market that makes it hard to raise money, Japanese manufacturers are focusing their efforts more. Toshiba, the electronics maker, is dropping out of audio products, and some of the consumer electronics companies, like Sanyo and Matsushita, are pulling out of the expensive race to develop computer memory chips.
"The one thing about Japanese companies is that if one company does something and does it well, all the companies follow," said Hiroyuki Mizuno, executive vice president of Matsushita. "We're not going to do stupid things like that."
Analysts have long wondered how Japan could support nine car manufacturers. But as long as the market was growing, the companies could hang on.

HEADLINE: Blacks and Jews on the Relationship: What's Special, What's Myth?

 BODY:
Sixteen months after racial unrest in Crown Heights, black and Jewish New Yorkers are discussing what brings them together and what pulls them apart.
Recently, a group of 14 people -- seven black and seven Jewish -- sat down at The New York Times and asked themselves some hard questions. Is there a natural alliance between blacks and Jews and is that relationship in jeopardy? Is there anti-Semitism among blacks and racism among Jews, and what can be done to heal it? 
 The dialogue was set in motion by an ugly chain of events that began in Crown Heights in August 1991, when a car driven a Hasidic Jew accidently struck and killed a black child, Gavin Cato. Hours later, in apparent retaliation, a group of black youths surrounded and stabbed a Hasidic scholar, Yankel Rosenbaum, who later died.
The late October acquittal of Lemrick Nelson Jr., a 17-year-old black youth accused of being Mr. Rosenbaum's killer, set off seven weeks of bitter criticism of the Mayor by some Jewish New Yorkers, who felt the Mayor should have denounced the verdict.
Many blacks in Crown Heights, meanwhile, accused the city government of pandering to the Hasidim.
On Thursday, 1,200 black and Jewish leaders gathered at the Apollo Theater in Harlem to watch a documentary on the black soldiers who liberated Jews from Nazi concentration camps. At the end, the leaders held hands, wept and vowed to put their differences behind them.
Whether that can happen was at the heart of The Times's round-table discussion. The following was taken from the transcript of the conversations with two reporters, Michael T. Kaufman and Felicia R. Lee.
ALICE FIXX In the beginning is the notion of whether there is a specific problem between blacks and Jews. I mean, I am well aware from the paper about the problems in Crown Heights, but my life is isolated from that. My work and my life are in Manhattan. . . . I couldn't honestly say that I felt that there was specific friction between blacks and whites other than in neighborhoods where there were large pockets of either group, especially the Crown Heights section.
It seems to me, in my environment, that any conflict, sub rosa or on the surface, is between whites and blacks, and not Jews and blacks.
RICHARD BREGMAN For me, the question is almost presumptuous. It assumes, it presupposes that there are certain, I don't know, diplomatic relations between Jews and blacks.
Q. Like two nations almost.
MR. BREGMAN: That's right. And envoys and diplomatic things. . . I never thought that there were special relations between Jews and anyone, blacks and anyone. I understand the sort of perception that's around from a Jewish standpoint that, you know, Jews are persecuted people historically, and blacks also in this country and elsewhere are oppressed, persecuted. And there's a -- a what? -- an identification, an empathy there. But I never understood there to be anything special between blacks and Jews that had gone awry particularly.
RABBI DAVID LAZERSON: Several months ago, another colleague of mine who is involved with the project here, Richard Green, from the Youth Collective, we were invited out to Stony Brook. It was one of the first times in the history of the school that they had an evening sponsored together by the Black Student Union and the Jewish Student Union. And they wanted us to speak about some of our efforts in Crown Heights, and where we saw the problems, and where we saw our successes. . . .
On the same panel was Amiri Baraka And I sat next to him . . . And, to my surprise, we found ourselves nodding our heads to each other's statements pretty much throughout the whole evening.
And he said a statement which perhaps crystallized a feeling that I have had, but was always maybe afraid to verbalize it. Was that, sure, we have our different cultures and we have our own unique sense of heritage and where we've come from, but there's -- and something you alluded to -- there's a lot more that unites us than divides us.
And what he said was it's almost as if the real powers that be in the media and in the country, it's almost as if they have a divide and conquer mentality. Like, "Let's keep these two very powerful minority groups apart. Because, you know, if they get their act together and sort of unify in ways that we have in certainly earlier times . . . " -- So, if we got our act together in that sense, we could perhaps make some serious changes that some people don't want us to make."
HENRY RICE I grew up in Crown Heights . . . Things are blown up now. But before, what people don't realize that you had a group of black kids that would run down to Kingston Avenue on Halloween and throw eggs at the Jewish kids. And then the Jewish kids would run into the black community and do the same thing back. And this rivalry, it was like, "I don't know anything about you, you don't know anything about me. We're different, we don't speak to each other. So, therefore, you're my enemy." . . ."
What I'm saying is that there have been numerous incidences of bias-related attacks happening in Crown Heights. They just never got the media like this one has. And there have been people in the community trying to express this for years and years, it's like a pot, and it just finally boiled over.
MOE FONER There are problems that go back a long time between whites and Jews and between blacks and Jews. And when I was a kid growing up in Williamsburg, I remember that Italian kids would come in on Halloween and beat the hell out of us. And we would not be seen -- we were told to stay off the street. . . .
I believe that fundamental to all of this is economics. That what exists here and in the city, and that it affects black people, but particularly is the economics of injustice. It's what Jonathan Kozol calls "the savage inequality." And I think that that's what got black people angry and bitter. And it's taken out in various ways.
I think that Crown Heights is a particular, peculiar kind of situation because of the -- first of all, it's a very small community, it's a very tight space. You have the Hasidim, a fundamentalist group who stay together very tight. And there are many problems that stem from that kind of relation. . . .
I believe that this situation that has developed from the Crown Heights situation is made to order for Rudolph Giuliani and for Andy Stein. . . . And they will continue to work on it for all it's worth. Because it is the only way that they can get through, is by dividing the constituency that has been supportive of Dinkins.
RABBI MICHAEL PALEY: I think there are a lot of Jews struggling with their identity. I think there are a lot of blacks struggling with their identity. I think the Afrocentric movement among black students is a movement of pointing fingers to people that oppressed them. Fair enough. Fair enough.
 
. . .
 But the Lubavitch Hasidim, who have been murdered and cowed and finally gassed, in this century, to an extraordinary, obscene number, all of a sudden they say, "This is America, and we're strong. And we have big shoulders and we're going to push back." And that, in some ways, you know, that moment has provided a liberating moment for Hasidim. Because they say, "We can stand up and we can yell at the Mayor of New York City and make him pay attention to us."
 
. . .
PAULA CARLOTTI: Is it blacks and Jews? Or is it blacks and whites? I think that certainly Jews have the advantage of being able to cash in on being white whenever they're in a situation of power or when they're being challenged.
RABBI PALEY: But 50 years after Hitler, I'm damned if I'm going to be called white.
MS. CARLOTTI: Well, then you're -- I think that's an individual opinion.
RABBI PALEY: I mean, I don't care if you call me white. Why not? I am not the problem.
MS. CARLOTTI: It doesn't really matter whether you are calling yourself white or whether you can cash in on being white.
RABBI PALEY: Why not? I like those chances.
MS. CARLOTTI: Most black people don't often have the opportunity to cash in . . . What I would say is that black people are the most discriminated-against group . . . I think they are by so far and away more clearly discriminated against than any group, and certainly more so than any group that can cash in on being white. That whenever they find themselves in conflict or in competition with any group, be they Italian, German, Jewish, that they will have less access to the things that you said are the most important, housing, cleanliness, safety, protection.
And this Crown Heights situation, the group happened to have been Jews. I grew up on the Lower East Side and went to the public schools there when the conflict then was control of the Community School Board, therefore, control of jobs in that community. And, more importantly, control of the programs that were to educate the children and secure their futures.
 
. . .
 So I, being a person who grew up in a family who was very involved in the Civil Rights movement and would never allow us to speak of Jews, or allow us to feel hatred towards any group of people, and particularly not towards Jews, the people with whom we were in conflict were Jewish people. I really believe they were white people who happened to have been Jewish people in that neighborhood . . . My experience is that I don't believe that blacks hate Jews. I believe they have conflict with the whites.
MILDRED SCOTT: What we are talking about is power, raw power. We are talking about the services. And since they think . . . -- the Hasidim -- that they are going to get less of the loaf, this is what the whole thing is about. . . .
KEVIN SMYLEY: My point is, the frustration is not necessarily at the Hasidim . . . but it's what they have been able to get and we can't. What's it like living under that frustration? . . .
VERNA HOBSON: I wanted to take it away a little bit from the Lubavitchers and Crown Heights . . . Back even to historically . . . when it was fine to have attitudes, to mistreat, to abuse, to enslave blacks. Until a time when laws were passed, which hasn't been too long ago, where it was no longer acceptable or allowed to do that. With that, people started to change not necessarily their feelings, but what they found acceptable to show . . . And, so, it became unpopular to be racist. . . .
But . . . in the last 10, 15 years or so . . . things started to shift back. People's feelings started to emerge, and they started to become acceptable to have racist feelings. . . .
Bonds that we thought that we had with groups, we began to see maybe we're not really quite there as we struggled for our identities as blacks. There became competitions; there became struggles. . . . Somewhere in the last 10 or 12 years, I began to sense that something was going wrong. . . .
Maybe there was some confusion going on within Jews and their struggles for their identities . . . And some of it was, I think, that some of them were beginning to feel that they were now perhaps becoming white enough not to be thought of as Jews, as far as being segregated against or put into a negative basket as Jews. And with that, they started feeling that it then allowed them the freedom to have attitudes against blacks that they never wanted to admit that they had before.
MS. BACK: What goes on in Crown Heights is deeply disturbing to me, but I personally do not bond with those Jews in Crown Heights. I don't bond with many Jews in mainstream organizations. I've had to form and participate in the formation of other sorts of Jewish organizations that would represent my personal political concerns, as well as my world view, my social vision. . . .
I understand that we're talking about multiple communities. That it has never been a monolithic Jewish community, it has never been a monolithic African-American community. And those communities have been diverse because of class within those communities, because of ethnicity and color in those communities, because of religion in those communities, and because of a whole other assortment of reasons.
Q. What's the bottom line?
MS. BACK: What I mean is that race and racism is the bottom line in this country that separates and divides people.
RODNEY CRUMP: The challenges against black people are coming a great deal from Jewish people.
Q. Why do you think that is?
MR. CRUMP: The issue of anti-Semitism, and defining anti-Semitism, some of our greatest scholars, Dr. Skip Gates and Cornel West, have had to speak on this issue. And they've spoke about black anti-Semitism. But no one ever talks about Jewish racism. No one ever talks about white racism and the historical implications of that. . . .
 
. . .
 We have competing agendas here, and you expect me to separate from my leaders or people who have done wonderful things for my community and say, "No, to hell with them." Just because Jesse Jackson says Hymietown, he's no longer acceptable. Just because Louis Farrakhan does this, he's no longer acceptable. And that's a problem.
FRAN HANDMAN: I think it's fascinating now that Jews have become the enemy for blacks. I mean, Malcolm X was not killed by a Jew. . . . The Panthers were not killed by Jews. The FBI, the CIA went after Malcolm X. Martin Luther King was not killed by Jews. And the Jew -- if you decide that the Jew is your enemy, you're being sucked in just the way the people in South Africa --
MR. CRUMP: No, I'm not saying that the Jews are my enemy. . . .
MS. FIXX: Would you not agree that there's been a very strong anti Israeli feeling amongst Afro- Americans coming out?
MR. CRUMP: Why is there anti-Israeli feeling? Israel has a historic relationship in supporting South Africa. And supporting South Africa, that is a big problem.
Q. What suggestions do we have to make things better?
ROSCOE BROWN JR.: I think we've already had one in terms of the Jewish community at large indicating to the Hasidic community that some of the privilege may have to be resolved in some fairer way than they are now being resolved. As overall context -- I think all of us need to stop romanticizing the fact that there's been such a close relationship between blacks and Jews over the past thirty years and recognize like all people that we have worked together and do work together on occasion . . . But that it isn't just an automatic relationship between blacks and Jews.
Secondly, I think that Jews should desist as much as possible from labeling every black who disagrees with them as anti-Semitic . . . Thirdly, I think we have to recognize that the present crisis is very much fueled by the political fire . . . Some people in the political field will use any type of conflict to suggest that the Mayor who ran on a platform of bringing people together is not effective. And I think we are not to fall into that trap of accusing either the Jewish community, the black community of being anti-this or anti-that and then going to politicians who will then get up and say, "And, see, I can tell you that this man is that way." And, finally, I think that we need to continue dialogue.
MS. HOBSON: I would like to hope that we can ask of our leaders that when we see our group committing wrongs against other groups, we can have the daring and the reasonableness and the fairness to speak out and not only when we feel our group is being wronged against.
MS. BACK: This has been a discussion about difference and we shouldn't be afraid of that and we shouldn't be afraid of separatism, because there are times when we need separatism and concurrently we also need coalition and cooperation and co-sponsored whatevers.
But we shouldn't be afraid of that in the same way that we shouldn't be afraid of the kind of frank conversation we had tonight, where we threw out words like power and like race and like the privilege of whiteness . . . I'm not so sure we all agreed in this room about even using those terms. I'm not so sure there wasn't in fact a lot of resistance to some of those terms. But those are the terms that have to be used again and again and again in every setting. You know, in the Mayor's office and in the classroom. At your police precinct meetings and, you know, obviously at your student union meetings . . .
Let us not romanticize the past. That has been I think one of our biggest downfalls, is that we've romanticized in the past of the relations between blacks and Jews. At the same time let's look for inspiration from the past. Because we certainly have inspiring moments to look towards. We certainly have inspiring leaders and we need those. We saw that when we brought in 6,000 school kids, public school kids to this exhibition at the Jewish Museum. We saw how they so much wanted to find some models, some inspiration.
RABBI PALEY: It seems to me right now the people that are suffering the most are the black communities and that to work against oppression is an important thing and the critical thing and that both communities should unite on that.
MS. CARLOTTI: I have always found Jews to just be more compassionate human beings than other whites. In other words, they have been less white than other whites. No, I mean that seriously because I think that's the only thing that white really means. I mean, it doesn't mean Italian or Irish; it means your ability to oppress other people. And I don't think this conversation would have been possible with a community from Bensonhurst. I think because in that instance the history is a history of hate. And maybe because those people don't have the same degree or the same experience of oppression as Jewish people have, dialogue often involves them hiding their expression of hate. And I don't find that to be the problem when there's dialogue with Jewish people.
MR. CRUMP: The issue of race in this country especially has not developed its own vocabulary that we can all use. However, I think that it's important that we all express ourselves honestly and understand that interpretations oftentimes lie within our own preconceived notions and intuitions about what people are saying . . . We have to listen to everyone, including the dull and the ignorant. You just have to do that. You have to go see Mordecai Levy, yes; you have to go see Al Sharpton, yes; you have to go see all of these different people and all the different perspectives . . . In difference there is some type of solidarity. We can agree to disagree and do so respectfully . . . It's just a matter of being a human being who cares about other human beings, period.
MS. HANDMAN: I was out with a friend of mine, a black friend the other day and she was saying she doesn't know what her name is because she didn't know where her name came from. I know what my name is. I know what my grandfather's name and great grandfather because I can go back. She can't go back and it's a great loss to her. And there are sensitive areas that are specific and particular to certain people. And when you listen, when you make a relationship you have to listen very carefully and you have to respond to what's happening with somebody else and not impose who you are and your value system on what they want. . . .
What I'm talking is about the sensitivities that things that touch nerves, real honest nerves in people of different backgrounds and so on and that when you want to make that bridge from one person to the next or one group to the next, you have to know what that nerve is. It isn't superficial things necessarily that seem very apparent, but they are things that are so close to the hearts of the people that you're talking to and they're not your values necessary, you have to listen and you have to respond. And that's I think how it's going to happen.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 37; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1954 words

HEADLINE: Life in Brooklyn's Forgotten Section;
In Red Hook, 3-Year-Olds Hear Gunfire and Duck for Cover

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Carmen Cruz stood silently alongside the worn and windswept patch of dirt and grass that cut through the mall in the center of the Red Hook Houses, just steps from where Patrick Daly lay mortally wounded the day before. Her friend Elizabeth Gonzalez crouched by a small wooden fence post, pounding a nail into an index card that would become part of the flower-strewn memorial to the grade school principal they and their children had known, loved and ultimately grieved for in the quarter-century he walked among them.
"You was an angel," the card read. "Now get your wings." 
 Ms. Cruz wondered if the time had come for her to fly away, too. She has lived in the same apartment in the Red Hook Houses for half her 41 years, raising four children in the shadow of violence and far from the eye of the rest of the city. She tried to start anew in Texas this summer but returned discouraged after three months in which she alternated between low wages and no wages.
"I came back here because it is the only place I have," said Ms. Cruz, who hopes to get a job in social services after completing a job training program. "Now my kids want to leave again after this tragedy. They're scared to come out. They're even scared to be in the house because of the shots."
Fear, drugs and guns have been part of the Red Hook landscape as much as the towering rows of red-brick apartment towers that line the housing project mall where on Thursday morning Mr. Daly walked into what the police say was the crossfire between rival drug dealers.
Such gunplay is common in the project. But residents remember when it wasn't so, and they remember Mr. Daly as someone who reminded them that the future held promise even for children whose early education includes lessons in ducking for cover.
Now, with Mr. Daly's death, some residents wonder if their community will ever be free of the armed urban terrorists whose numbers are small but whose violence has drastically altered the daily rhythms of the hard-working families and single mothers trying to raise their children. Others, retired from work or finished with raising their families are now talking about leaving.
"I'm going to go so far from here there ain't no coming back," said R. M. Jones, who prides herself on singlehandedly seeing her two daughters through school and helping keep crime out of her building through her work in a tenant patrol. Now, she does not call the police when she spots an intruder or hears a burst of gunfire because she fears retaliation from drug dealers. As soon as her 17-year-old daughter finishes high school, she plans to move from the city, which she feels has ignored the community that sits, cut off from the rest of Brooklyn by the Gowanus Canal, on a spit of land that juts into New York Harbor.
"I'm putting my mother on my back and taking her with me," she said. "This place is sinful. There's a lot of good people here. Tax-dollar-paying people. We deserve better."
The Red Hook Houses, among the largest public housing complexes in the nation, dominates much of the area, which once bustled with rough and tumble activity along its ports and piers. Vestiges of that world can still be found along the waterfront, where cobblestoned streets run past blocks of uneven slate sidewalks and clumps of dry, brown weeds. Other corners of the community, past the projects, are dotted with brick row houses, and three-story apartment buildings are home to old-time Italian and Irish residents.
 
Steady Decline
 The community is ethnically mixed and free of the racial strife that has riven other parts of the borough. It is the kind of place where those who have lived there a decade are still "new people" to other residents.
It is hard to escape the looming cluster of the buildings in the housing project, many of which are six stories tall, where first-floor windows are secured with child guards on the outside and iron gates inside. Some 10,000 people -- at least 40 percent of them in poverty -- live in the housing projects, nearly 40 percent of them under 18 years of age. There are almost equal numbers of black and Hispanic residents, who account for about 90 percent of the housing project's population.
Longtime residents lament the steady decline of their neighborhood, which while always gritty, became deadly with the advent of crack and its enforcers about a decade ago. The place was so orderly that parents would be warned by management if their children rode their bikes down the wide walkways and square plazas.
"The halls used to be spick and span," said a 58-year-old woman who has lived there since 1962 with her husband, a Transit Authority employee, and their three children. "If anybody got in trouble, they'd throw you out. Maintenance would come in 15 minutes. Now it takes five or six days to get anything fixed."
 
Dealers on Patrol
 The woman, who would not give her full name, recalled how years ago her youngest son, who is now in college, romped outside, while she could leave her apartment door wide open.
"Before you didn't have no crime," she said. "Now, I got three locks on my door and gates on my windows."
Eduardo Colon, 14, who lives a few blocks away from the projects, said some youths didn't take seriously the impact of the violence. "People laugh when somebody gets killed," he said. "It's a big joke."
He worried that the drug dealers were killing off the good people, like Mr. Daly.
A dog barked in the distance.
"Even the dogs hate people here."
Where children once played, drug dealers now stand, controlling the wide public spaces whose sidewalks and plazas between buildings are up for grabs. Inside, too.
"They sell in buildings and they don't care if you got kids around," said Eric Smith, a 32-year-old man who has lived in the projects much of his life. He walked down one of the many paths that snake through the projects, cradling his infant daughter. "They got control around here."
The powerless stay inside.
A woman who said she worked in the guidance department at Public School 15, said she rues the day six years ago she moved into the Red Hook Houses, after a fire drove her and her son from their apartment in the High Bridge section of the Bronx. The woman, who would not give her full name, said she had been assaulted once by a woman who clubbed her with a hunk of free cheese when she thought she had jumped a food distribution line. Her son, who was taunted by a local girl, has few friends in the neighborhood. Besides, she said, they venture to other parts of Brooklyn when they want to divert themselves with a movie or other entertainment.
"I'm not used to living like this," she said as she walked her dog, a small, scruffy mutt she got for protection. "If you're not on drugs, you're not one of them, so you have to isolate yourself. I like to be friendly, but you get hurt by people. It's not a healthy way of life."
Young people know they have been denied the chance to do a lot of things that others their age take for granted.
 
Children in Hiding
 "I don't go outside; it's ridiculous," said an 18-year-old who declined to give her name. "There's nothing for us to do." She worried most about those still growing up, diving for cover when they hear gunshots outside.
"How can you raise a child that way?" she said. "A 3-year-old hears a shot and hides behind a couch -- and they live on the third floor?"
Yet children are raised, and some succeed despite the obstacles. "A lot of people are fighting, are going to school," said William Green, the administrator of the South Brooklyn Health Center. "Our pediatric population is the best-taken-care-of population we see. They're well nourished, well dressed and cared for by their parents."
The Rev. John Waldron, the sole priest and pastor of the Visitation of the Blessed Virgin Mary Roman Catholic Church, said that in some parts of the projects, tenants had organized effective associations that have kept thier buildings from tumbling into chaos. And while the face of crime is getting discouragingly younger, he knows of youths who are going on to college and good jobs.
Needs remain, and he would like to transform his parish's old grammar school building, which was closed in 1975, into a community center, adding to a small core of centers that cater to the youths in the area.
The important thing, he said, is to fight the apathy that can sink in when living in a community that is physically -- if not psychically -- severed from the rest of the borough. "There's a feeling of being overlooked and neglected," he said. "You start to accept whatever comes your way."
But there have been encouraging signs, he said. Residents successfully blocked the construction of a sewage disposal plant this year, and there is new economic life along the waterfront, holding out the promise of jobs in an area where those who work often have to spend their first hour's wages on fares to get to work in Manhattan.
"I'm a person of hope," he said. "I still see enough hope to think it has to get better."
The Housing Authority police said that violent crime in the Red Hook Houses has been decreasing in recent years, and that there have been only two murders this year, compared with six the previous year. Residents and those who work in the area say crime may be down, but guns and drugs are not.
"I don't think they're counting the amount of gunfire," Mr. Green said. People don't report hearing a gun being fired."
 
Lives in Danger
 He added that since Mr. Daly's death on Thursday, residents have begun circulating a petition asking state lawmakers to stiffen the penalties for possessing and and firing guns. "There has got to be some concept that not only will you get arrested for having one," Mr. Green said, "but you are endangering the lives of thousands of people in the projects."
A few blocks away on Van Brunt Street, few shops remain along blocks that once brimmed with bakeries, barbershops and other stores. But not all trace its initial downfall to the advent of crack.
Andy Massaro was born in Red Hook 63 years ago, once worked on the piers as a longshoreman for the Barber Line and now owns a cluttered toy shop known to all as Skinny's, for the name that most people use for him.
"What happened here is during the war everybody went into defense and they made big bucks," he said. "When they made big bucks, they left to Staten Island and left us with all the garbage."
Despite his tough words, he dotes on an 8-year-old girl who wants to buy one of the many toys he purchases in damaged condition and repairs for sale at a discount. Children aren't born bad, he said, but something happens along the way -- he's seen it happen to his son, who he said nearly wiped him out with a crack habit.
The street outside his store was dark and nearly deserted when Cathy, a red-haired bundle of nerves, swept into his store and asked for a dollar. She used to work for the post office, but resigned after 20 years, she said. She used to have a house down the block, she said, but she lost it after years of using it as a shooting gallery where she and her friends used heroin. She lives on the streets now, walking countless times each day by her old house, which stands boarded up and empty.
"She tried to commit suicide four or five times," said Mr. Massaro after he gave her a dollar. "But God don't want her."
He said that although he didn't venture outside at night, he didn't feel like a prisoner. "The people in the projects, they're trapped," he said.
Another man ducked his head into his store, seeking a handout. Mr. Massaro waved him off.
"Satan himself is walking the earth," he said. "These kids' souls are taken."

HEADLINE: Cutting Fiscal Corners in Trenton

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
For the last 11 months New Jersey's administration and lawmakers have been using a new and largely subterranean system of deficit financing to keep the government running, tapping into billions of dollars worth of bonding authority and pension funds -- all the while avoiding the dreaded word "taxes."
In the process, they have sidestepped both the requirement for a public vote for capital bond issues and prohibitions against unbalanced budgets and the use of bond money for general operations. 
 For the most part, despite some grumbling about "one-shot gimmicks" and "quick fixes," the fiscal maneuvering has the tacit support of both both the Democratic administration and the Republican Legislature.
Just this week, for example, Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat, signed a new bond issue bill that was approved by a joint committee of both houses of the Legislature, which are controlled by Republicans.
 
Lonely but Outspoken Critic
 The Senate minority leader, John A. Lynch, is a lonely but outspoken critic of not only the bond bill but the new drift of state finances in general.
"A single gimmick here and there may not be bad in the scheme of things," Mr. Lynch said in an interview. "But three and a half billion dollars in 11 months is disastrous."
Mr. Lynch was referring to a series of fiscal maneuvers since January, when the Republicans took control of both houses of the Legislature, including these measures:
 
'Inadvisable,' U.S. Says
 *The method of valuing the state's public employee pension funds was changed to allow the state to cut its contribution to those funds. Public employee unions angrily protested the shift. The United States Department of Labor called it "inadvisable" -- and hinted that it might be illegal -- but the change put nearly $1.2 billion into the badly imbalanced budget coffers.
*Last month, legislative leaders and Florio administration officials agreed on a health care plan for the uninsured that will siphon $1.6 billion out of the state's unemployment insurance fund into the new health care fund over the next three years. When the administration of Gov. Thomas H. Kean tried to do the same thing three years ago, with considerably less money, $100 million, the Federal Government declared the whole thing illegal and forced the state government to pay back the money, plus $35 million interest. This time, the shift was done by a more circuitous route to create at least the appearance of propriety. The Federal Government has not publicly commented.
*This week, the Legislature unveiled yet another plan that would divert $357 million over the next two years from the state's Transportation Trust Fund to pay for other state operations. The diversion, accomplished by "de-appropriating" -- removing from the budget -- the state's contribution to the fund will mean the fund will have to issue yet more bonds to complete its capital program.
*Then there was the new borrowing approved this week, described as "refinancing" to take advantage of current lower interest rates. In fact it is mostly new debt, coupled with a modest chunk of genuine refinancing to make it possible to call the whole thing refinancing. That was done to allow the whole package, including the new borrowing, to be done under the cloak of the Refunding Bond Act of 1985, which gave the state broad authority to refinance bonds to take advantage of favorable changes in interest rates.
 
Like a 2d Mortgage
 The principle is roughly equivalent to refinancing a home mortgage to get the lower interest rate. But in this case, the state also took out what amounted to a huge second mortgage, and plans to use part of that to pay old debts and interest.
What the state is in fact doing is refinancing $700 million of old debt at newer, more attractive rates, then borrowing an additional $912 million in new money.
The new money will finance new building projects like bridges and hospitals, but part of it, $335 million, will be set aside to pay existing bond debts. That means that the state is borrowing money to pay the interest and principal on its existing debt. And it is issuing new bonds without a popular vote of approval in a general election as would be normally required by law for such a bond issue.
In addition, the use of the newly borrowed money to make the existing bond payments makes it possible to transfer the $335 million that would normally be used to pay off the bond debt into the general fund and to a so-called "rainy day fund" for fiscal emergencies. Labeled as "surplus," it will be used however the Governor and Legislature ultimately choose.
 
Selling Highway to Itself
 The fiscal shuffling actually began two years ago, when the state sold part of Interstate 95 to itself. The transfer back to its own turnpike authority cost the authority $400 million. The exchange was made because the turnpike had $400 million in bonding authority the state's general fund didn't have.
In signing the legislation enabling the $1.6 billion bond revision and new issue, the Governor applauded the Legislature for its "willingness to put politics aside for the benefit of New Jersey."
Senator Lynch describes the fiscal maneuvering "nothing more than gimmicks and raids that doesn't include the more than $30 million in fee increases to plug gaps" in the budget.
The Legislature has been working to close the budget gap by raising various fees and imposing new ones. The state's hospital admission fee, for example, was raised to get $1 million more in revenue; the co-payment that the elderly, the indigent and Medicaid recipients make for prescription drugs was raised to $5 from $2, which raised about $16 million, and a similar increase in the prescription drug fee for state employees raised another $3 million.
All told, the various fee increases written into the new budget produced about $24 million in new revenues to replace those eliminated by the cut in the state sales tax to 6 percent from 7 percent.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Hardball Isn't New To Top Negotiator

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH

 BODY:
Sonny Hall, the president of New York City's 37,000-member Transport Workers Union, does not profess to know about the inner workings of major league baseball's labor-management relations. But Hall is not at all surprised that as new negotiations approach, some very new twists are about to be introduced to some age-old baseball arguments.
Revenue sharing. Revenue participation. Salary cap. 
 "That doesn't surprise me at all," Hall said of the landmark goals. "That sounds like Dick," he added, and laughed.
 
Peace Is Priority
 Dick, to those unfamiliar, is Richard Ravitch, former head of New York City's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, architect of the revitalization of the Urban Development Corporation and the Bowery Savings Bank, former mayoral candidate and now the point man on labor for baseball's 28 owners.
Two weeks ago, Ravitch, president of the Player Relations Committee, the owners' bargaining arm, announced that the owners had decided to reopen the basic labor agreement with the players union, albeit by a slim 15-13 vote. The task at hand now, for both Ravitch and the union representatives, is to find a way to win the peace before another war breaks out in the form of a strike or a lockout. Ominously, it is something neither side has been able to avoid in seven consecutive sets of negotiations.
To try to reverse history, Ravitch will try to alter the staid approach to business that many in management, including Ravitch, insist has brought small-market teams to the precipice. And, as Hall pointed out, it is not the first time Ravitch has tried to buck overwhelming odds.
As chairman of the M.T.A., Ravitch once came up with what Hall described as "a radical concept that scared us and others" -- the capital rebuilding of the subway and bus systems using a bonding system that would offer fare boxes as collateral.
 
Right in Most Cases
 "It was a dramatic change for anybody to look at and it made a lot of people nervous because of the very fact that it was a radical change," Hall said. "It was not the way business was done. Putting that weight on the fare boxes scared everybody."
Ravitch, allied with wary state officials, carried the day, and Hall says now that if he had not, "the rebuilding of the subway system of New York just never would have happened."
"So we've been fortunate," Hall said. "He has been proven in most cases to be right when he did radical moves with us."
No one can predict whether that will happen again, especially in a unique industry where players and their employers both boast multitudes of millionaires, where the union basically demands that the status quo be preserved, and where the owners' local interests are often at odds with the game's national interests.
But Hall does point to one certainty he is sure to come baseball's way.
"Dick makes people face the issue," Hall said. "If you're opposed, he's going to make people explain why they're opposed. You can't use the argument with Dick Ravitch that, well, we've never done business this way."
To some, the comparison between Ravitch's past predicaments and his present situation are too delicious to pass up.
 
'A Lot of Parallels'
 "I imagine trying to handle the subway situation there in New York has got a lot of parallels with trying to figure out how to try to make baseball come together," said George W. Bush, a general partner with the Texas Rangers and a supporter of the course Ravitch is plotting.
Ravitch chose to explain his presence in baseball more bluntly.
"Some would say I have a neurotic addiction to difficult problems," he said in an interview last Wednesday. "Look, I love sports and it was presented to me as a challenge of limited duration but one fraught with significance to the future of baseball."
Ravitch decided to join the sport about a year ago for all of the above reasons plus one more.
"Baseball is a very important part of my culture, and I thought it would be an interesting thing to do," he said.
Ravitch came to the game as well-schooled as possible in the history of those who have gone before him and knows it is neither pretty nor for the faint of heart. But he believes things could change, for both the game and himself.
"I think that the times are different and that the definition of my role is different from that of my predecessors," he said. "And my mandate, my privately stated mandate, was to deal with the total economic situation in baseball, not just with the union contract."
 
A Broader Look
 That Ravitch was instructed to take a broader look by the owners perhaps best explains both why and how he was presumed to be a major player in baseball's major conflagration this past summer. That firestorm consumed baseball's last commissioner, Fay Vincent, after Vincent resisted the effort by Ravitch and some owners to cede the commissioner's "best interest of baseball" powers in the area of labor.
Ravitch has steadfastly declined to discuss his role in that battle publicly other than to insist he was neither empire-building nor trying to succeed Vincent. "I have no other agendas," he said.
Vincent also declined to discuss events that led up to his forced resignation. Nor will the former commissioner comment on Ravitch other than to say, "I think he's in a very tough spot, a no-win situation, because he's walked into a mess and he didn't know what he was getting into."
Perhaps, but as Bush points out, Ravitch did survive the summer's blood letting, did extract the vote he desired on the re-opener and is still standing.
"And I think one reason why he's survived without getting his foot blown off is that he's been through politics," Bush said. "He understands that in politics there's a time to enter the fray and there's a time to stay out. He's been very judicious in that choice.
"I also think it's important for people to recognize that he knows who he works for. He's an employee. So I think he's had a nice touch of leading and getting out of the way."
 
A Continuing Challege
 Building a consensus among owners is not only a continuing challenge, but it is also one-half the chore. Ravitch must also deal with the powerful Major League Baseball Players Association which, as Ravitch is well aware, remains unbeaten and untied on its particular field of play.
Ravitch generally has nothing but praise for his counterpart, Donald Fehr, who declined to talk about Ravitch. And he accepts as part of the job some of the gibes that have come his way from what is, for the most part, a tightlipped union team. For instance, he said he took it as a compliment when Mark Belanger of the Players Association labeled him a dangerous man.
"It's flattering, if it means they believe I do my homework and come to the table prepared," Ravitch said.
And both Hall and former Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York both take exception to a charge that riles Ravitch as well: that he is a union buster brought in specifically to dismantle the players' association.
"Union buster? No," Koch said with a laugh Friday. "The fact is, during the 1980 strike, I was the tough guy." Koch was referring to an 11-day transit strike in which Ravitch negotiated for the M.T.A. and the city. "I said that the city won the battle in the streets, but I was unhappy with the settlement that was obtained at the table. But on the other hand, he would say, so was the union, and therefore he did his job. So it is foolish to call him a union buster."
Koch's comments are indicative of those who have crossed swords with Ravitch only to come back in calmer days with undeniably flattering statements.
"I think he's very much in the mold of former Mayor Wagner, with infinite patience, and that's what you need when you're engaging in negotiations," Koch said. "That's what he has. He's very intelligent, very well-versed in city affairs and the private sector as well. He's a Renaissance man."

HEADLINE: Don't Wax Nostalgic for Airline Regulation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is quite apparent that Mr. Pevsner either did not take economics in college or has forgotten all that he was taught. Return to those days when everyone was charged the same air fare, resulting in vacation travelers subsidizing business travelers? Mr. Pevsner seems intent on depriving millions of Americans of the advantages of low fares when they book ahead. 
 If Mr. Pevsner, a lawyer, is such a fan of regulation, he should first propose regulation of his own industry, an industry in which lawyers are not loath to charge $300 an hour for a simple document that could be prepared by a paralegal for a tenth of the cost.
 
VINAY KAPOOR
Ithaca, N.Y., Dec. 6

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Clinton's Security Trio

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB; Anna Quindlen is on vacation.

 BODY:
What do we know about President-elect Clinton's national security team? What do these choices tell us about Clinton policies and how they will be made?
The short answer is that the expected appointees -- Warren Christopher for Secretary of State, Les Aspin for Defense Secretary and Anthony Lake for National Security Adviser -- are highly experienced problem solvers. Like almost all their predecessors when they took office, these three are untested at the highest levels. 
 They like President Bush's new-world-order rhetoric about standing for American values, paying more attention to international economics and using force for humanitarian as well as strategic reasons. But unlike Mr. Bush, they take those words seriously and will try energetically to turn rhetoric into reality. None of the trio seeks the limelight, and all will fit comfortably with Mr. Clinton's plan to make policy in the White House.
Contrary to comment, the trio bring to their posts as much high-level government experience as most of their predecessors. Mr. Christopher has held the number two jobs in the Justice and State Departments. Mr. Aspin, a Pentagon alumnus, has served in Congress for two decades and for eight years as chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. Mr. Lake started as a career foreign service officer, worked for Henry Kissinger and directed the State Department's policy planning under President Carter. They know where the land mines are.
All three have their roots in the liberal wing of the Democratic Party but have evolved into pragmatists of different sorts. Mr. Christopher is a cautious liberal, Mr. Aspin a conservative activist and Mr. Lake an eclectic pushing toward the new world order he helped sketch in Mr. Clinton's campaign speeches.
If they have a weakness as a group, it is their lack of pre-cooked clout. None brings commanding stature to his job or possesses a movie-star personality. Each will have to fight to prove he's tough and worthy.
Also they have little expertise in foreign economic policy, the area Mr. Clinton rightly made so much of during the campaign. Mr. Lake will turn to the much-respected Samuel Berger, expected to be his deputy. The others will turn to their deputies.
Mr. Christopher was one of my bosses in Carter's State Department. He is no less stiff and formal privately than publicly. His jacket is always buttoned. He listens impassively, nodding "uh-huh, uh-huh," and says little. Ever the world-class lawyer, he is exceedingly careful, tidy, disciplined, precise -- no mistakes.
When troubles came, Mr. Carter and Secretary of State Vance usually turned to him. "Chris," as he is called, is a brilliant political tactician and negotiator. He helped to gain Senate approval of the Panama Canal treaties and negotiated the release of the American hostages from Iran.
Mr. Christopher is not a policy maker and has no known policy agenda, though he himself wrote that the Secretary of State "must be the architect" of U.S. policy. He thinks case by case. But he can take any policy paper and find its flaws and make it viable.
Mr. Aspin and I first worked together in the Pentagon in the Johnson Administration. He is disheveled, folksy, informal. At the same time,he is often detached and abstract in the manner of a policy wonk or intellectual.
Mr. Aspin is a defense intellectual. That is his life. No one has thought harder or better about the military power the U.S. will need in the decade ahead and when to use it. He would make do with somewhat fewer forces than the Bush team, yet be more willing to use force in places like Bosnia -- and would have used it sooner in Somalia. He strongly backed the Persian Gulf war. (Mr. Lake supported the basic war policy also. There is no record of Mr. Christopher's position.)
Mr. Lake's office adjoined mine in the Vance State Department, and before and after that we co-wrote articles and books. "Tony" is puckish and deeply committed to traditional liberal values, yet power oriented and a careful bureaucrat. Sometimes hawkish, sometimes dovish, he is as tough and aggressive as his smile is cherubic.
Mr. Clinton will almost certainly turn to him and Mr. Berger to shape an overall strategy for a world that seems to defy one. But Mr. Clinton, by far the strongest personality of the lot, will shape the trio more than they shape him.

HEADLINE: DEC. 13-19: Master vs. Bigger Strategy;
Fischer Indicted for Defying The Yugoslav Embargo

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

 BODY:
Ever since he was stripped of his title as world chess champion 17 years ago for refusing to defend it, Bobby Fischer had lived in virtual obscurity. That changed this fall when he agreed to an exhibition rematch in Yugoslavia against Boris Spassky, a reprise of their celebrated 1972 contest. He defeated Mr. Spassky, again, and won the $3.3 million purse, but the price for the tournament may now be permanent exile from the United States. 
 Last week a Federal grand jury indicted the temperamental chess genius for violating the American economic sanctions order against Yugoslavia. The indictment was hardly a surprise. At a news conference in September, Mr. Fischer had spit on a letter from the Treasury Department warning him against playing. He faces the choice of staying abroad, where extradition would be difficult, or returning for trial and a possible 10-year sentence.
