HEADLINE: What Has the World Done for Bosnia?;
A Diary of Disgrace

 BODY:
February 1992 -- Serbian forces opened a campaign of aggression against the former region of Yugoslavia called Bosnia and Herzegovina. In short order they launched a relentless bombardment of Sarajevo, the historic city that gave living proof that many faiths can coexist. This assault was only the most visible part of the Serbs' barbaric campaign of ethnic cleansing against the Muslim Slavs -- 44 percent of Bosnia's 4.4 million people. What did the world do?
April 7 -- The U.S. recognized Bosnia. Five days later the United Nations disclosed plans to send 100 observers to Bosnia, and the Security Council discussed dispatching 10,000 peacekeeping troops. None of the troops were sent. 
 April 14 -- After a major Yugoslav Army offensive, Bosnia reported "mass massacres" by Serb irregulars. No reliable casualty counts were available but estimates reached the thousands. Hundreds of thousands of refugees fled in terror. What did the world do?
April 14 -- Secretary of State Baker condemned the use of force and urged the European Community to issue a joint protest, threatening economic and political isolation of Serbia. Nothing was done to tighten the economic sanctions against Serbia.
Mid-spring -- The U.S. Government received the first unconfirmed reports from Bosnia that Serbs were setting up concentration camps in which Muslims were being tortured and killed. By U.N. estimates, some 30,000 Bosnians were becoming refugees every day. What did the world do?
Washington did not press for immediate investigation of the camps. Instead, it tried to keep the reports from becoming public. If other countries received similar reports, they gave no public sign.
May 4 -- With Serbs in control of half the country, the Bosnian Government appealed to the world, with poignant logic, to lift the arms embargo on Bosnia and give it the means to defend itself. What did the world do?
The arms embargo remains, to this day.
May 7 -- Serb and Croat nationalists in Bosnia agreed to carve up the republic, a process the European Community blandly called cantonment. Five days later the U.N. reported a concerted effort by the Serbs to create "ethnically pure" regions in Bosnia "in the context of" the E.C. negotiations on cantonment. What did the world do?
May 14 -- The State Department expressed concern about "allegations of ethnic cleansing." A day later the Security Council backed sending humanitarian aid to Bosnia, but not the armed force needed to deliver it. And the following day the U.N. evacuated its staff of 200 from Sarajevo.
Late May -- The siege of Sarajevo tightened. Serb gunners took deliberate aim at civilians, blasting away at bread lines. The Serb commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic, was overheard ordering his gunners to "drive them crazy" and "burn it all." What did the world do?
May 30 -- The U.N. finally imposed an economic embargo on Serbia but stopped short of enforcing it. Secretary of State Baker said that "Before we consider force, we ought to exhaust all the political, diplomatic and economic remedies that might be at hand." An unnamed U.S. official said, "We are really talking about the need -- maybe -- to do something next time. Everyone in the loop concedes that Yugoslavia is a past case already."
Early June -- Outside Sarajevo, the carnage of ethnic cleansing continued. Serbs had by now overrun two-thirds of the country, displacing 700,000 people. What did the world do?
June 6 -- President Bush said, "We're concerned about the situation in Yugoslavia, but there's no commitment on that." Ten days later the U.S. agreed to help airlift food and medicine to Sarajevo, but only after a U.N. force of 1,100 took control of the airport. The U.N. said it could not send in such a force until a cease-fire took hold.
Throughout June -- Relentless Serb shelling continued to reduce beautiful old Sarajevo to rubble. What did the world do?
June 26 -- The Security Council gave the Serbs an ultimatum: Stop shelling Sarajevo and put all heavy guns under U.N. control or face military action. A senior American official said, meanwhile, "No action is imminent."
July 3 -- The Serbs temporarily withdrew from the airport but without relinquishing their heavy guns. The airlift began, but only fitfully under intermittent Serb shelling. Three weeks later Roy Gutman of Newsweek visited Serb-run camps and heard eyewitness accounts of murders and atrocities. Other reporters uncovered rape camps where Muslim women were violated by the thousands. What did the world do?
The U.S. expressed concern and insisted that the Red Cross be allowed into the camps. It said nothing about freeing those imprisoned or punishing the perpetrators.
Summer and fall -- Serbs conducted hundreds of bombing and strafing raids on Bosnian towns. What did the world do?
 Oct. 9 -- The U.N. Security Council banned military flights over Bosnian territory. But it ducked a vote to enforce this ban.
Late autumn -- The Serbian air raids slowed, but reconnaissance and troop flights continued. The shelling continued. So did ethnic cleansing. And many camps still operated, unvisited. By now more than 100,000 Bosnians, mostly Muslim Slavs, were dead or missing. And what has the world done?
Washington, finally, is prodding the U.N. to enforce a no-fly zone over Bosnia -- four months too late. The U.S. is prepared to lift the arms embargo that effectively keeps Bosnia from defending itself -- six months too late. Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger now denounces Serbian war crimes, doubtless hoping that will help defeat the strongman Slobodan Milosevic in today's Serbian election.
But even now Washington, and London, and the European Community, and NATO and the U.N. shrink from forceful actions to counter the Serbs' aggression and slaughter in Bosnia:
Attack their big guns and supply lines;
Send in enough U.N. troops to secure safe havens in areas now menaced by Serb-sponsored ethnic cleansing;
Threaten to attack military installations in Serbia unless it stops its brutal aggression in Bosnia and the rest of Yugoslavia.
After a year of savage slaughter, mass rapes, ethnic cleansing and undoubted genocide, the world has responded with all the right words. But the question remains, What will the world do?

CORRECTION-DATE: December 22, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Roy Gutman, the reporter who first uncovered Serb-run concentration camps in Bosnia, was incorrectly described in an editorial Sunday. He writes for Newsday.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Growing Market For Gay Travel

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
IN the last 10 years suppliers and opportunities for travel by gay men and women have increased enormously. Some travel experts describe the market as virtually recession-proof, pointing to the usual pattern among gay couples of two jobs and no children. Luxurious ocean cruises are increasingly popular, providing what has been described as a private city for people who do not always find a welcoming environment for leisure. This column touches on a few new offerings in a rapidly growing field.
A landmark event was scheduled for yesterday, when Seaspirit, a 207-foot cruise ship launched in 1983 by Clipper Lines of St. Louis for the luxury trade, was to make her first sailing as a gay-owned, gay-operated vessel, under United States registry and the ownership of RSVP Travel Productions, a tour operator in Minneapolis. Seaspirit was due to sail from St. Thomas for a week's cruise in the Virgin Islands, including Jost Van Dyke, Salt Island, Tortola, Norman Island and St. John. Saturday sailings are scheduled until April 10 next year. The per-person prices for a week, with two to a cabin, range from $995 to $1,795. 
 According to Andy Schmiedel, director of advertising and sales for RSVP, the clientele on the cruises is mostly gay men, but a few women do join. A women-only week is scheduled for Jan. 30 to Feb. 6, and single men's weeks are Jan. 9 to 16, Feb. 6 to 13 and March 6 to 13. After spring trips to the mainland and up the East Coast to reposition, the vessel will sail a New York-New England itinerary.
Since it was founded in 1986 by its owner, Kevin Mossier, RSVP has chartered ships for gay cruises and when the 100-passenger Newport Clipper came up for sale, RSVP bought the vessel for $2.5 million, refurbished it and put it into service as the Seaspirit. Information: RSVP, 2800 University Avenue S.E., Minneapolis, Minn. 55414; (800) 533-1482.
 
Renting a Club Med
 The big cruise company for lesbians is Olivia, which began as an offshoot of 20-year-old Olivia Records and has chartered nine cruises for women, attracting 4,500 passengers in three years. Judy Dlugacz, the president, said that when she started out in travel, she chartered a ship for a year later, and then learned she needed to put up considerable money. To her surprise she found that 600 women would pay the full amount right away.
From Feb. 13 to 20, Olivia will charter the Commodore Line's 730-passenger Enchanted Isle for a cruise from San Diego to Puerto Vallarta, Mexico. Per-person prices in double occupancy range from $795 to $1,595. The company's first land-based venture will involve rental of Club Med at Playa Blanca, Mexico, from May 1 to 8. Six hundred guests will pay $895 each, double occupancy.
Ms. Dlugacz is already planning a cruise to leave from New York after the Gay Games there in the summer of 1994. She will charter Commodore's Crown Monarch for 530 passengers to travel to Provincetown, Mass., Bar Harbor, Me., and up the St. Lawrence to Quebec and Montreal. Information: Olivia Cruises, 4400 Market Street, Oakland, Calif. 94608; (800) 631-6277.
Steve Jackson, operations director of Pride Tours, a wholesale travel company in Queens, went into Manhattan for two days this month to book 10,000 hotel rooms and as many dormitory rooms as possible for the summer of 1994. Mr. Jackson was preparing for Gay Games IV to be held around New York from June 25 to July 4, 1994.
Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York announced in April that the city would play host to the games and 15,000 participants from 40 countries, only one indication of the strength the movement has built. Like the Olympics on which they are modeled, the Gay Games are designating the agencies and operators to sell official packages, in this case, members of the International Gay Travel Association, whose officers and membership include both men and women. This association, in its ninth year, has 580 members, principally retail travel agents, tour operators, cruise lines, hotels, resorts and guesthouses.
While the organization does not have the staff to provide a referral service, it runs ads in the gay magazine Advocate that list a selection of member companies.
 
A Newsletter's Ratings
 A travel newsletter for gay readers, Out and About, began this fall, and its owners say that with 700 subscribers it is halfway to breaking even. The owners, David Alport and Billy Kolber, decided that gay guidebooks tended to be out of date and thought there was space for a newsletter. "Magazines and newspapers provide good information," Mr. Kolber, the editor, said, "but it's not particular to gay travel."
They wanted to evaluate the offerings in destinations popular with gay travelers, like Key West, as well as report how welcoming mainstream places were. For instance, Mr. Kolber said, in the Caribbean few places cater exclusively to gay guests, but there are three or four that are "better choices" among the others. "We are travel people first," he said, "then people who appraise places according to the specific needs and sensitivities of our readers."
The newsletter also discusses attractions, like a walking tour of the Castro district in San Francisco, that are naturals for gay travelers. The most recent issue contains the first of two articles on travel health by Dr. Frederick L. Altice of the Yale School of Medicine.
The newsletter accepts no advertising and the owners and their researchers have not accepted free rooms or meals. The owners both formerly worked for American Express -- Mr. Alport at headquarters in New York in marketing and sales, Mr. Kolber as manager of the New Haven, Conn., office -- and their research bookings are made at the travel agent rate.
Out and About is published 10 times a year and will have 16 pages starting with the January-February issue. Subscriptions cost $49 a year. Back issues are $5. Information: Out and About, 542 Chapel Street, New Haven, Conn. 06511; (203) 789-8518.
Our World, a magazine directed at the same market, began in 1989 and broke even after five issues. It carries advertising. The magazine now has 18,000 subscribers, according to Wayne Whiston, the editor. The December issue covers cruises, including yacht charters. A subscription for 12 issues -- there are 10 a year -- costs $44. Sample copies are $5. Information: Our World, 1104 North Nova Road, Suite 251, Daytona Beach, Fla. 32117; (904) 441-5367.
The gay community faces a dilemma in Colorado. Aspen Gay Ski Week, scheduled this winter for Jan. 23-30, has been going for 15 years and last year attracted 3,000 visitors. Yet on Election Day, Colorado adopted an amendment that prevents the enactment of laws to protect homosexuals from discrimination. The board of the International Gay Travel Association does not want to support travel to such a state, Mr. Jackson said, but it held a phone poll immediately after the election Nov. 3 and while the board voted a Colorado boycott, it exempted those who already had tickets for Gay Ski Week because they would lose deposits and it would hurt travel agents who backed the event as well as the "very supportive" town of Aspen. A peaceful march has been planned for Jan. 23, according to Tom Mooney of the Aspen Gay and Lesbian Community.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 3, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The Practical Traveler column on Dec. 20, about accommodations for gay vacationers, included an outdated schedule for the Gay Games of 1994, in New York. The dates -- now June 18 to 25 -- have been moved ahead a week, so the games will precede Stonewall 25, the observance of the 25th anniversary of the Stonewall Inn clashes on June 27, 1969.

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 10; Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1152 words

HEADLINE: Bigger Presence for Green Point Savings

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: TARRYTOWN

 BODY:
SWIMMING against the tide of bank closings, the Green Point Savings Bank, with headquarters in Flushing, Queens, recently opened four branch offices in Westchester and Rockland Counties. The offices -- in Ossining and White Plains in Westchester and Pomona and Chestnut Hill in Rockland -- were acquired from the Crossland Federal Savings Bank and bring the number of Green Point's branches to 25.
"This is the largest expansion in our history," said Michael J. Gagliardi, chairman and chief executive officer, in a recent interview at the Tarrytown Hilton here. "We usually build new branch offices from scratch, but the Crossland offices were in locations that suited our marketing plan." Negotiations for the acquisitions were begun last June. 
 Green Point first tested the Westchester waters in 1987 when the bank opened a branch in Eastchester.
"During that first year of operation in Eastchester we had deposits of $40 million," he said. "This year Eastchester has $174 million in deposits, which encouraged us to open other branches in the area," he said. "We feel there is enormous potential for growth for our type of bank in Westchester and Rockland Counties."
 
Assets of More Than $6 Billion
 Green Point, he said, is the largest state-chartered mutual savings bank in the country and one of the strongest financially.
Green Point's assets exceed $6 billion, making it the 20th-largest thrift institution in the nation, Mr. Gagliardi said. The bank's assets and net worth have grown steadily throughout the recession, he added, saying: "We have been heavily committed to the residential mortgage market since the bank was founded in 1869. High volumes of home mortgages make up 83 percent of our assets. We have the money to lend. Our primary role is residential mortgages, but our specialty is no-income-verification loans. We fund all our lending in investment programs entirely by deposits generated through our branches."
In order to attract depositors, Mr. Gagliardi said, Green Point has consistently paid some of the highest desposit rates available. Former Crossland depositors, he said, will receive higher yields from Green Point.
"In our new branches the yields will be 3.56, up from 3.3," he said. "We are the largest mortgage lender in Brooklyn and in Nassau County and one of the largest in the entire metropolitan area."
 
Maintaining High Equity Value
 In return for not requiring income verification, Mr. Gagliardi said, the bank charges borrowers a point more on a fixed mortgage and half a point more on an adjustable mortgage.
"No-income-verification loans carry a higher element of risk," he said. "Not many banks make them. In order to successfully make these loans, we have to have first-hand knowledge of local property values. Unlike most banks, we don't depend upon outside appraisers. Instead, we have an expert staff of two dozen in-house appraisers who know property values in each of our marketing areas."
And to cut the margin of error even further, he said, the appraisers are subject to review by a senior appraiser who, in turn, is reviewed by the bank's executive loan committee.
"Our tight control over the appraisal process is what assures us of high equity value on our loans," he said. "In 124 years, our loss level has been very small."
The new branches in Westchester and Rockland add $245 million to Green Point's deposits, which were $5.2 billion as of Sept. 30 -- an increase of $236 million over Dec. 31, 1991, Mr. Gagliardi said. He added that the new offices were part of a five-year expansion plan within a 35-mile radius of Green Point's headquarters in Flushing.
"Controlled growth, not overexpansion, has always been our policy in seeking major branch locations," he said. "Our average branch deposit size is $258 million. We feel our new branches have the potential. For instance, our six-month goal for the White Plains office is $125 million; for Ossining it is $90 million." As for former Crossland employees, none of them will lose their jobs, Mr. Gagliardi said.
 
A Former C.P.A.
 "We also transferred their tenure," he added. "Having an experienced staff in place is an asset for us. The staff knows their customers, and we hold training sessions to familiarize them with our methods, but we feel it will take about a month for customers to absorb the conversion, which is why we're planning our kickoff celebration for January."
Mr. Gagliardi is 52 years old and a former certified public accountant. Part of the work he did for his accounting clients was to examine records at their banks.
"Banks were easy," he said. "Their inventory was cash. I became an expert at examining financial institutions, which was an important reason why I was recruited in 1975 for my first banking job for a small bank in New Jersey as vice president and controller."
Mr. Gagliardi was eventually recruited by a larger bank that needed to raise capital, and after he managed that bank's conversion to private ownership, he received an offer to join the Green Point Savings Bank.
"They asked me to become executive vice president," he said. "I knew the chief executive was ready to retire, and I felt that here I had an opportunity to become president of a strong bank." Last Jan. 1 Mr. Gagliardi was named chairman, president and chief executive officer of Green Point.
"This year has been a good one for us," he said. "We're projecting a record-earnings year, the highest in our history. When I'm asked why we have been successful while other banks have not done as well, I say one reason is our low overhead costs, thanks to the large level of deposits of each branch and the $240 million growth of our mortgage portfolio."
And when a bank has been in business for 124 years, Mr. Gagliardi added, it earns customer loyalty.
"We received one of the nicest letters I've ever read, in response to a mailing we made to Crossland depositors," he said. "It came from a customer in Ossining who wrote that she grew up in Green Point, Brooklyn, and that the Christmas she was 7 years old she got a $5 bill, the first one she had ever received for a Christmas present."
"The letter said in part: 'I remember how my father walked me to the Green Point Savings Bank on Manhattan Avenue and opened my first bank account. I can remember walking into that bank and seeing the high domed ceiling, hearing the clicking of the cash registers and experiencing the hushed tones and dignified atmosphere in which the business of the bank was carried on.' The letter writer added that she kept the account until she got married and moved to Pennsylvania. "Now years later I am back living in Westchester County," she said. "I feel I have come full circle: to have an account in the Green Point Savings Bank again, back where all my financial transactions started."
"Isn't that a great letter?" Mr. Gagliardi said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael J. Gagliardi, right, chairman and chief executive officer of the Green Point Savings Bank, with customer at the bank's new branch office in Ossining. Bank recently opened four branch offices in Westchester and Rockland counties. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 6; Page 26; Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1999 words

HEADLINE: CHRISTMAS OBSERVED;
A Quarrelsome Peace

BYLINE: By Jane Smiley; Jane Smiley's most recent novel is "A Thousand Acres," for which she won the 1992 Pulitzer Prize.

 BODY:
The editors of the New York Times Magazine decided it would be a fine seasonal gift to ask some of America's most accomplished writers of fiction and essays to compose short stories of reminiscences about Christmas. The initiative was an unconventional one for this magazine, which traditionally has published nonfiction. The startlingly contemporary reference points the writers choose - malls, a precinct station house, broken homes - also seemed unconventional at first. But reflecting on these settings appear to sustain old tradition. Christmas is a holiday that encourages us to celebrate out shared experience. 
 The reason Mary Ann makes her first mistake is that Bonnie's anguished cry, as she throws herself down in front of the Christmas tree, happens to rouse her from one of those comalike sleeps she can achieve only in the afternoon. Of course Mary Ann jerks upward in a panic. Of course she doesn't know where she is, only that Bonnie needs something. Of course, when Bonnie screeches, "We haven't bought a present for Mr. Jones," Mary Ann tries to employ her calmest, most conciliatory manner. She barely realizes what she is saying -- this is the mistake: "We can go to the mall now, if you like."
Bonnie rises from the carpet immediately and goes to the closet for her coat. It takes Mary Ann considerably longer to rise from the couch, because she is nine months' pregnant (due after New Year's), and despite the conversation she is still mostly comatose.
She moves in a heavy daze toward her coat and her purse. She says: What? Where are we going?"
Bonnie says, "We're going to the mall to buy Mr. Jones's Christmas present."
Mr. Jones is the cat.
Mary Ann is having second thoughts. She begins, "Honey. . . ."
"You said you would! He has to have a present. He always has a present. Except this year! This year, no present."
This year! New husband, new stepbrothers, new house, new baby! Bonnie's tone distills the betrayals of the year into the bitters of this representative one. That is why Mary Ann puts on her coat after all and picks up her purse in order to drive through Christmas traffic to the mall, where she will buy a present for a cat who comes up from the basement every morning solely to pull garbage out of the garbage disposal, who lives on permanent feline unemployment because he doesn't know how to groom himself and has nothing else to do, and whom even Bonnie doesn't like to pet much because he insists on crawling up your chest and putting his head in your mouth when you show him any attention whatsoever. A cat that Mary Ann has been glad not to touch since discovering she was pregnant.
On the way to the mall, 8-year-old Bonnie is much like her old self -- alert and talkative, drawing Mary Ann's attention to light displays and Christmas trees in picture windows. She cheerfully solicits an old story, "Did you really have a pink Christmas tree, Mom?"
"No," says Mary Ann, "it was made of aluminum. It looked pink because we shined a pink light on it. And all the glass balls were pink, too. Grandma had it because her new family room was decorated in pink, black and white. We all hated it, but she would say, 'It looks very Christmassy to me.' " Bonnie joins her on the punch line, imitating her grandmother perfectly, and they laugh.
But when they park far from the entrance and Mary Ann has to support her protruding belly with one hand and pull herself out of the car with the other, Bonnie's look darkens, and Mary Ann has a sense that she has often had lately of a new Bonnie snapping closed over the old one, hiding her completely. The new Bonnie is unrelentingly critical and dissatisfied, especially with the fact that the baby, according to the amniocentesis, is a girl.
Mary Ann had assumed that everyone in the family assimilated the baby's female identity months before -- they have been calling her Liza since August -- but lately Bonnie speaks of the baby only as a grotesquely exaggerated SHE, as in "SHE doesn't need presents. SHE won't even be here for Christmas," a remark Bonnie made at the table to Isaiah and Jake, her younger stepbrothers, who then burst out crying inconsolably because they and Mark, Mary Ann's husband of eight months, had just spent the afternoon buying baby toys and equipment. A look of recognition had crossed Mark's face -- Mary Ann saw it -- recognition that Bonnie was truly unpleasant and obnoxious. This is a recognition that Mary Ann has had herself, though she hasn't voiced it.
Now, as they enter the mall, Mary Ann can feel the pressure building up, the pressure to do just the right thing and do it quickly, before Bonnie loses her temper and makes a scene. As if in response, the baby, who was quiet during the car ride, jams her feet against Mary Ann's diaphragm and her head against Mary Ann's bladder. To distract herself, Mary Ann says, "What do you want to get Mr. Jones?"
"Catnip. A new scratching post." She pauses, then snaps, "Something really good."
Something, Mary Ann thinks, that will transform him from a dusty, needy scavenger who has been known to extract a potato from water boiling on the stove and flee with it to the basement to another cat entirely -- sleek, elegant, independent.
Bonnie exclaims: "We took the wrong turn! The pet store is in the other wing."
The thought of trudging to the other wing is almost more than Mary Ann can bear. They are near Walgreens, however. Mary Ann uses her most ingratiating voice, a voice that Mark maintains she uses too often with Bonnie. "That's awfully far, honey, but Walgreens is right here. They have a pet section there."
"But there's nothing special there."
"O.K." Mary Ann calls reserves of energy she is probably supposed to be saving for labor and delivery. Of all her mistakes with Bonnie, this is the one she makes most -- thinking that pleasing the child will help her into an easier state of mind. But, as with all her mistakes, Mary Ann realizes it is a mistake only after she is committed.
It may be that she and Bonnie do not present the spectacle of gray exhaustion and bleak rage that Mary Ann thinks they do as they make their way through the crowds to the pet store, but most of their fellow shoppers are smiling, and some are humming along with the piped-in Christmas carols. The bags and packages they are carrying look promising and richly heavy. The groups of teen-age girls who always roam the mall today look almost innocent, as if Christmas has succeeded in returning them partway to childhood. Everyone, everyone, looks as if he or she is anticipating returning home in the bustling dusk to a delicious, festive meal. Mark and Mary Ann have agreed to avoid the cooking by going to friends of his who Mary Ann doesn't know well, but now Mary Ann almost regrets that -- their own kitchen will be cold and clean, their own house dark on the most domestic night of the year, a night when they might have found, after eight slippery and difficult months, their footing as a family. It may be that she and Bonnie do not present such a spectacle, but when they pass some mirrors, Mary Ann notices that they do look unhappy and disheveled, and she thinks that she would feel sorry for them if she were anyone else in this mall.
Bonnie gives out a penetrating wail compounded equally of disappointment and anger, and Mary Ann's immediate response is a physical one -- her hand twitches with the desire to cover Bonnie's mouth and muffle that sound. The sign on the door of the darkened pet store reads, "On Christmas Eve, we will close at noon. Happy Holidays."
"Well," says Bonnie, "I guess we'll have to go back to Walgreens."
"I can't," says Mary Ann. "It's too far."
"We have to. We have to!" She whirls on Mary Ann, and her face is ugly and insistent, the face of every spoiled child and every failed maternal effort that Mary Ann has ever seen and deplored. It is not happy families that are alike, but unhappy children -- noisy, selfish, dissatisfied, reduced by unhappiness to a mechanical condition of repeating demands and high-pitched whining.
Bonnie yells: "Why are you having this baby! I know it was a mistake. You and Mark weren't even married."
No cat presents in this wing -- only the Gap, the Limited, County Seat and the faces of all the happy shoppers turning curiously in their direction. In a low and serious voice, Mary Ann says something she doesn't mean and will always regret. She says, "You were the mistake, Bonnie."
For a moment she is pleased, because her remark has the desired effect -- Bonnie is so shocked that she falls silent. Her face loses, for once, that aggressive and determined look that has been its principal feature for months. In fact, the child's face loses all expression. It freezes into an unreadable mask, so remote and inhuman that Mary Ann's pleasure evaporates into fear, then into regret -- fear that this mask is the only other face Bonnie has to offer these days, regret that she has summoned it. And at Christmas, too. She says, "I didn't mean that, Bonnie." The stony mask does not soften. "It's just that I'm really tired and what you said hurt my feelings and, um, embarrassed me. . . ."
Still, Bonnie's face remains impassive, and Mary Ann realizes that she has been harboring a wish for many months. It is of Bonnie not exactly coming over to her side, but relinquishing her intransigence. The most salient component of this hope is the feeling Mary Ann remembers of Bonnie's body nestling into hers, seeking warmth and comfort. She has been missing that contact half-consciously for months, and no other contact with Isaiah or Jake or Mark, none of the intimate flutters or rollings of Liza within, and certainly nothing in Bonnie's stiff hugs and formal kisses have made up for it. Now Bonnie stands resolutely apart from her, the distance of six cool hard tiles in the floor of the mall, and Mary Ann knows that they have cast their lots on opposing sides of a quarrel that will never end.
And at Christmas, too. Mary Ann is resentfully, but nevertheless fully, subject to that sentimental irony.
She looks at Bonnie, who is looking at her, and two things happen. The first is, she gives it all up -- her wish that Bonnie would melt toward her, her shame at the person Bonnie has become, her sense that Bonnie has somehow betrayed her, even her desire that Bonnie and Mark and Isaiah and Jake like each other. As if to underscore that she has no choice but to give up all these feelings, the baby stretches gently against her left side and one of her feet presses firmly against her right. The second is, Mary Ann all at once sees their new situation from Bonnie's point of view -- little gained but new rules and inconveniences, much that is familiar and private and relied upon lost forever. The fact is, she has resisted seeing things from Bonnie's point of view, probably out of fear. Mary Ann starts to cry.
Bonnie pushes her toward a nearby bench.
They sit down.
Bonnie says, "Why are you crying, Mom?"
Mary Ann blubbers, "I'm sorry it's Christmas."
"Me, too," says Bonnie. She sighs. She puts her hand, which is surprisingly small for someone who looms so large, on Mary Ann's leg.
They sit through "God Rest Ye Merry, Gentlemen," "It Came Upon a Midnight Clear," "What Child Is This?" and most of "Jingle Bells." Finally, Mary Ann blots her eyes on the hem of her skirt. She looks around. The mall is emptying out. Bonnie's face is no longer masklike, or even defiant. It is calm, as if she, too, has come to some conclusion, but Mary Ann resists prying. She says, "I guess we'd better get home."
"Do we have any hamburger?" Bonnie says.
"Yes."
"Can we give Mr. Jones some of that?"
"Yes, I guess."
"Well, he'll just have to settle for that this year. That's all there is to it."
When they are almost to the exit, and can see the full darkness outside, Mary Ann says, "Do you think he'll mind?"
Bonnie says, in a mild voice, "Probably." And Mary Ann accepts that.

PUB-DATE: December 20, 1992

SECTION: Section 7; Page 9; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 781 words

HEADLINE: A Majority of One

BYLINE: By John B. Judis; John B. Judis is the author of "Grand Illusion: Critics and Champions of the American Century."

 BODY:

IZZY
A Biography of I. F. Stone.
By Robert C. Cottrell.
Illustrated. 388 pp. New Brunswick, N.J.:
Rutgers University Press. $25.95. 
 BY the end of World War II, I. F. Stone, who died in 1989 at the age of 81, was already at the top of his profession. He worked as a columnist for a string of New York dailies and was the regular left-winger on "Meet the Press" 's panel of journalists. But his sharp opposition to American cold war policies led to his exile from the radio and television program. By November 1952, when The New York Daily Compass, for which Stone wrote a column, went out of business, he had become, in his biographer Robert C. Cottrell's words, "an unemployed, middle-aged journalist and Old Leftist who appeared to be yet another victim of the temper of the times."
But Mr. Cottrell tells us in "Izzy" that what might have been the end of Stone's professional life was really the beginning. He decided to start his own newsletter, which he called I. F. Stone's Weekly, and in which he pioneered a new kind of investigative journalism, based upon the close reading of government documents. In the 1950's, he gained renown for exposing the hazards of nuclear testing. Then, as the United States became embroiled in Vietnam, he became one of the war's most persistent and effective critics and a hero to a new generation on the left.
Mr. Cottrell, an associate professor of history at California State University, Chico, has written the first book-length biography of Stone. Without concealing Stone's more foolish or ignoble opinions, particularly on the Soviet Union, Mr. Cottrell portrays him as an ink-stained saint -- an "American original." Stone's fans should welcome this book, but it is not a very good biography. Mr. Cottrell's narrative is clumsy and repetitious. And despite his air of familiarity with Stone, whom he repeatedly calls Izzy, he fails to make his subject come alive. At a minimum, this biography would have been more interesting if Mr. Cottrell had simply quoted more extensively from Stone, who was a witty and acerbic writer, rather than constantly paraphrasing his opinions.
Most important, Mr. Cottrell does not adequately account for the changes in Stone's underlying political philosophy -- from uncritical admirer of Soviet and American Communism to anti-anti-Communist to self-described "liberal" opponent of the war in Vietnam. Mr. Cottrell relies entirely on Stone's own reminiscences five decades later to explain his support in the early 1930's for a "Soviet America." As for Stone's liberalism, the author fails to quote enough of Stone for the reader to be able to judge what he believed. This is all the more important because, in an unrelated context, Mr. Cottrell quotes Stone in 1983 praising the Soviet Union as a "distortion of socialism" but "still socialism."
Mr. Cottrell is justifiably effusive about Stone's journalism in the 1950's and 60's. Stone was a remarkable reporter who did not flinch from facts that contradicted his hopes. After a 1961 visit to Fidel Castro's Cuba, he warned of a "revolutionary euphoria" and "demagogy" that seemed "dangerously unrealistic." Stone also sensed very early that the 60's New Left was destroying itself by mimicking the sectarianism of the Old. Mr. Cottrell is on shaky ground, however, in applauding Stone's work before 1952.
Stone was, unfortunately, another brilliant intellectual whose brain was addled by the Russian Revolution. He was still defending the Soviet Union in 1939, when many prominent intellectuals and journalists, including Edmund Wilson and Dwight Macdonald, already understood that the Revolution had fatally miscarried. Mr. Cottrell terms Stone's cold war criticisms "remarkably astute," but after World War II Stone tended to grant the Soviet Union the benefit of the doubt while believing the worst of American intentions. Unlike Walter Lippmann (who was also a cold war critic), Stone failed to understand that the pro-Soviet regimes in Eastern Europe were sustained by Soviet tanks, not by the wonders of Marxism-Leninism. And like Henry Wallace, whom he supported for President in 1948, he mistakenly read into the politics of the late 40's the onset of an American fascism.
Mr. Cottrell says in his introduction that Stone's life "serves as a microcosm through which to view the state of the American left, political journalism and the intellectual experience over the course of the better part of the 20th century." That is true enough (even today, when some on the right are accusing Stone of having been a paid Soviet agent), but Mr. Cottrell fails to make good on the potential that this interesting microcosm holds.

GRAPHIC: Photo: I. F. Stone in his home in Washington in 1987. (George Tames)

HEADLINE: A Majority of One

SECTION: Section 7; Page 11; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1220 words

HEADLINE: All the King's Women

BYLINE: By Angeline Goreau; Angeline Goreau is the author of "Reconstructing Aphra: A Social Biography of Aphra Behn."

 BODY:

THE WIVES OF HENRY VIII
By Antonia Fraser.
Illustrated. 479 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $25. 
 "WHO does not tremble when he considers how to deal with a wife?" asked Henry VIII in 1521.
That the King was writing on behalf of marriage, emphasizing the precious and sacred charge involved in such a union, must surely be one of the odder ironies of history. Odder still, given subsequent events, was that his motive in writing "The Defence of the Seven Sacraments" was to refute Martin Luther's heretical challenge to Pope and church. For Henry's efforts, the Pope granted to him and his successors the title Defender of the Faith.
Just six years later, Henry initiated the divorce that ultimately propelled England into the maw of schism. The divorce (never, of course, recognized by the Holy See) took another six years to orchestrate, but, once accomplished, ushered in a period of marital chaos whose extremes have rarely been equaled -- even in our own era of rampant family dysfunction. Renaissance Europe watched aghast as the King of England ordered his second wife, Anne Boleyn, beheaded on trumped-up charges of treason after only three and a half years of marriage, then registered with disbelief the coronation of four more Queens of England in the space of little more than a decade. When apprised of the news that Henry had repudiated his fourth wife, whom he had married just six months before, to place on the throne an adolescent named Katherine Howard, the King of France shook his head in wonderment and asked: "The Queen that now is?"
To keep track of the dizzying list of royal mates, Lady Antonia Fraser tells us in the introduction to her latest work of popular history, people took to counting them off in a little refrain: "Divorced, beheaded, died; divorced, beheaded, survived." The six women in question, Lady Antonia observes, have come to be "defined in a popular sense not so much by their lives as by the way these lives ended." She proposes, in "The Wives of Henry VIII," to rescue them from this historical injustice.
One might object in passing that to be remembered for the manner of one's demise, provided it was spectacular enough, is not an uncommon fate. But a much stronger objection to Lady Antonia's point is that divorce, as modern experience has proved, need not be the end of one's life. Indeed, the popular refrain that Lady Antonia cites reveals a more important point, for it fixes the moment -- and means -- at which these women ceased to be regarded by the King as his wife (with the exception, naturally, of his widow, Catherine Parr). One of the most interesting aspects of Lady Antonia's book, in fact, is its exploration of the manner in which the two divorced wives, Catherine of Aragon and Anne of Cleves, dealt with the limbo in which they were cast by divorce.
There have been many fine individual biographies of Henry VIII's queens, but until the publication earlier this year of Alison Weir's lively study "The Six Wives of Henry VIII," there were few responsible collective treatments, probably because the very idea of uniting these six biographies in one volume requires that their subjects be defined, first and foremost, as wives. Putting these life stories together, however, turns out to have an unexpected advantage: it throws into relief the ways in which six women of very different character and background learned -- or failed to learn -- to cope with a prodigiously difficult man. Conversely, looking at the story as a whole allows us to see how grappling with Catherine of Aragon and Anne Boleyn, two very powerful and (each in her own way) defiant women, fundamentally influenced not only Henry's next choice of a wife, the relatively docile Jane Seymour, but also determined the way he would behave toward wives who followed. After Henry's experience with the fiery, intelligent, plotting Mistress Anne, Lady Antonia notes, "the King would specifically order his future wives to avoid argument." If they failed to keep this caveat in mind, he would darkly remind them of their predecessor's fate.
Not surprisingly, the King's favorite wife was his third, Jane Seymour, who took as her motto "Bound to obey and serve." Of all his wives, she alone produced a male heir, and she did him the favor of dying before he could tire of her. For it was Henry's own peculiar destiny to be attracted to women of spirit and discover afterward that spirit in a wife was an irritation he could not suffer gladly.
Another strength of "The Wives of Henry VIII" is its author's determination to retell the story as though she did not know what its end might be. "Although we know Henry VIII will marry six times," Lady Antonia writes in her introduction, "we must always remember that he did not." Unfolding the story from its relatively innocent beginning, she takes us step by step through the process of moral compromise through which the Renaissance's splendid, golden boy king was transmogrified into a repulsive old tyrant whose monstrous proportions perfectly mirrored his ego. Like that of Oscar Wilde's Dorian Gray, Henry VIII's character coarsened by degree with each violation.
Yet, despite her obvious disgust with Henry, Lady Antonia is determined to be fair. She puts events carefully in context, supplying the political and social underpinnings of what looks to 20th-century eyes suspiciously like one long royal nervous breakdown. She reminds us, for example, that by 16th-century standards Henry was a fairly good husband to his first wife for nearly 20 years until, deeply distraught over Catherine's repeated miscarriages and the realization that no more children would come from the marriage, he finally turned to divorce as a means of freeing himself to produce a male heir. Lady Antonia points out, furthermore, that Henry's desperation over the succession had its roots in the fact that his father had won his crown at the battle of Bosworth Field. Henry VII, the usurper, passed on to his son what might be called an intense throne anxiety. Without an indisputable -- that is to say, male -- heir, Henry feared that England might well fall once again into civil war.
Lady Antonia also disentangles the highly complicated strategies by which the King justified his actions, always managing to preserve "the tender conscience on which he prided himself." The same man who did not shrink from letting his ministers invent the charges on which Anne Boleyn was tried was nevertheless reluctant to tell an outright lie himself. "Taxed many years later with having had an affair with three Boleyns, two daughters and a mother," Lady Antonia writes, "the best he could do was to reply shamefacedly: 'Never with the mother.' "
"The Wives of Henry VIII" does, as it promises, admirably succeed in bringing to life, with economy of detail, the six women who married England's ruler. But, despite Lady Antonia's assertion that "this is not his story," the biography's focus keeps wandering inevitably back to "the gigantic Maypole . . . round which these women had to dance." This may be, however, an unavoidable consequence of the fact that what these six women had in common was coming to terms with Henry. Finally, the book's greatest interest lies in its deeply engaging portrait of a marriage -- in serial.

GRAPHIC: Drawings: Catherine of Aragon, divorced (1533). Anne Boleyn, beheaded (1536). Jane Seymour, died after childbirth (1537). Anne of Cleves, divorced (1540). Katherine Howard, beheaded (1542). Catherine Parr survived Henry's death in 1547. (Nick Higgins)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1104 words

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Clinton's High-Stakes Shuffle To Get the Right Cabinet Mix

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 20

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton's effort to fill his Cabinet has become a high-stakes game of mix and match as he struggles to create an inner circle that is diverse in race, sex and point of view.
Even some of his closest aides are unfamiliar with his thinking as he has continuously shuffled the personnel deck. "Hiring" a Cabinet, to use Mr. Clinton's word for the process, has become an unexpectedly complicated task of fulfilling his campaign pledge to create an administration that "looks like America."
 
Puzzling for Nominees
 Aides to the President-elect said that in some cases he had settled on some nominees, then changed his mind, holding a job up to each candidate like a suit of clothes that can be exchanged for a better fit. Even today, aides said Mr. Clinton had decided to pass over Senator Timothy E. Wirth, the early favorite for Energy Secretary, to select Hazel R. O'Leary, a Minnesota power company executive. [Page D11.] 
 The deliberative approach is typical of how Mr. Clinton has made tough choices as Governor and as a campaigner, and it provides an early look at how he will govern in the White House.
Some involved in the process have said they feel as if they have become caught in a maze without a map.
"They've got this puzzle, and I'm a player who can play a number of parts in the puzzle for them," said one potential nominee whose name surfaces regularly.
For Mr. Clinton, picking a Cabinet from the broad range of academics, politicians and intellectuals who are suddenly available for jobs in a Democratic administration after 12 years out in the political cold has been akin to turning a child loose in a candy store, his aides said.
"I didn't want a Cabinet of strangers," Mr. Clinton said at a news conference last week. "But neither did I want people whose only criteria for having a job was that they had somehow been involved with me before."
Such goals seem reasonable enough. But Mr. Clinton's desires to create an inclusive Administration while fitting all his appointees into the roles that would suit them best has created minor chaos behind the scenes.
Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee who was a valuable ally during the primary election process, had signaled the Clinton transition team that he wanted a foreign policy job, perhaps Secretary of State. Mr. Clinton was unwilling to give Mr. Brown that big a reward and instead discussed whether Mr. Brown would instead accept United States Trade Representative or United Nations Ambassador. They even briefly considered bumping the United Nations job up to Cabinet level.
But Mr. Brown settled for Secretary of Commerce instead, aides close to the process said, because he was assured that he would be part of the economic team. A Cabinet post also assured Mr. Brown that he would have a direct line to Mr. Clinton without having his suggestions vetted first by other officials.
A similar switch occurred for Robert B. Reich, the Harvard professor who has headed Mr. Clinton's economic transition team. Mr. Reich's name first surfaced to fill the newly created post of economic security adviser, and then as a potential choice to head the Council of Economic Advisers.
But there were two problems. Some business leaders on Wall Street expressed uneasiness at Mr. Reich's more liberal views. And other advisers in the transition process said that Mr. Clinton's chief adviser on economics should be a trained economist, which Mr. Reich is not. In the end, Mr. Reich ended up as Labor Secretary.
"A lot of it is instinct with him," one transition aide said of Mr. Clinton. "A lot of it is also wanting to mix things up so nobody feels too secure. I think the best executives keep in control."
Part of that process for Mr. Clinton is deciding when naked politics counts and when it does not.
Among Mr. Clinton's closest advisers will be a prominent and respected Democrat, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, who waited until the last possible minute in the primary campaign before he agreed to support or help raise money for Mr. Clinton, whose nomination was by then inevitable.
Some Clinton aides point to the selection of Mr. Bentsen to be Treasury Secretary as evidence that the President-elect prizes policy over politics. Mr. Bentsen helped Mr. Clinton formulate his position on the North American Free Trade Agreement, a stand that allowed the Governor to mollify organized labor, environmentalists and business interests.
"He's extremely analytical," one aide said. "He knows the difference between the process and the result."
In other cases, likely nominees were able to impress Mr. Clinton after they arrived for their interview in Little Rock. Such was the case with Representative Leon E. Panetta, whose stock rose as a candidate for director of the Office of Management and Budget after he and Mr. Clinton hit it off during three separate meetings.
Shortly after that, Alice M. Rivlin, who had been considered the leading candidate for the job before the Panetta interviews, was appointed deputy director of the budget office instead.
 
Indications of Leadership
 Mr. Clinton's methodical search for a Cabinet is sprinkled with clues to the way he will lead the nation. Early on, his campaign advisers gained a reputation as an unwieldy collection of political professionals. But they built a cohesive and focused working group by the time the campaign ended.
"What I've seen in the past is he will constantly share his tentative thinking," said Stan Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's poll taker. "He'll very self-consciously go out to a broad range of opinion makers and advisers. And if you think you know where he was at any given moment, you're wrong, because it's all a process for him."
One adviser tells of being called in to consult with Mr. Clinton, who asked him his opinion of a top Cabinet prospect. Before the adviser could construct an answer, he said, Mr. Clinton named two reasons why he would not choose the prospect.
The adviser left Mr. Clinton thinking the President-elect had nixed his leading choice. But days later the supposedly rejected candidate got the job.
Using this approach, Mr. Clinton surrounds himself with a range of seemingly dissimilar advisers whose primary allegiance is to the man who appointed them.
"I have taken a lot of time in this process because I'm trying to make sure the people I send up there share my vision," Mr. Clinton said Thursday. "Because I want a Cabinet with some greater diversity, and I'm working very hard on that, and because I want a personal relationship with my Cabinet members."

HEADLINE: EXPERTS SAY STORM LEFT COASTAL AREA HIGHLY VULNERABLE

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
A week after the worst flooding in 30 years clawed the New Jersey and Long Island coasts and leveled sand dunes, experts say the already precarious beaches are extremely vulnerable at many points, exposed to dangerous new flooding from even average winter storms.
From the Hamptons on eastern Long Island to Sandy Hook and Long Beach Island on the New Jersey coast, the four-day storm swept away millions of cubic yards of sand from beaches that had already been considered alarmingly narrow and undernourished for a decade or more. 
 And almost as soon as the seas calmed, the debate began along the 150 miles of coast line on how much should be done to restore the beaches and who should pay the price, which could run into the hundreds of millions of dollars. [A map and a town-by-town list of damage estimates are on page B6.]
 
Erosion Called 'Staggering'
 While homeowners desperately sought help to shore up their beaches, scientists and environmentalists said the storm presented an opportunity to consider which beaches could reasonably be saved and which could not.
"The extent of the erosion is staggering, and the news reports didn't prepare me for what I found when I walked the beaches," said Dr. Michael S. Bruno, director of the Davidson Laboratory at Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, where two of the largest wave tanks in the country simulate coastal engineering problems.
 
Homeowners Seek Protection
 "The New Jersey shore as most people know it isn't there any more," he said. "Boardwalks have been wiped away, dunes are gone and beaches are flat, roadways and sea walls have been undermined."
Individuals with beachfront homes now vulnerable to the next churning high tide are clamoring for municipalities and the Federal Government to quickly build a dune line to protect against a further battering by the ocean in the stormy months ahead.
Such an operation may be possible with a combination of Federal grants made available for disaster relief and 25 percent matching funds put up by local communities and the states.
But some doubt that such spending would be prudent.
"This was a benchmark storm," said Dr. Norman P. Psuty, associate director of the Institute of Marine and Coastal Sciences at Rutgers University.
"The barrier islands are in retreat from the ocean," he said, noting that the sea level has risen 16 inches along the Jersey Shore this century. "The islands are being slowly drowned and in some areas we may have to consider giving up property instead of pouring money and sand into the ocean."
Some homeowners, like William Warren, who has a beachfront, cedar-shake summer home in Mantoloking, N.J., expect most of the expense will come out of their own pockets.
"Private property owners just last spring paid to have the dunes pushed up higher," said Mr. Warren. On Saturday morning he and his wife, June Peel, inspected the wooden sun deck that was broken and split.
"Before you could barely see over the dunes to the beach from the deck," Ms. Peel said. Now they can look straight to the beach below.
 
Pilings Exposed
 Twenty-five miles to the south, another couple, Bob and Marion Norbe, watched as trucks dumped sand on the beach at Harvey Cedars on Long Beach Island to protect the homes from another assault. They and other homeowners are convinced that it will take a large-scale Federal and state effort to set up a new dune line along the beach to help them to get through the winter. The emergency sand-dumping was provided by state and county governments with the hope that the Federal Government would eventually help pay for some of the costs.
The 40-foot wide grass-covered dunes that once stood between the Norbes' house and the beach has simply disappeared. Moreover, the storm chewed away the firmly-packed sand beneath the ground level of the house, exposing nearly half the length of 25-foot pilings that anchored the house.
"Someone has to immediately do something -- the Army Corps of Engineers or someone -- to throw something up between us and the ocean before the next storm hits," Mr. Norbe said.
Mayor Harry Marti of Harvey Cedars said that it was possible that some of the beachfront homes buckled by the storm might not survive the winter, and that the houses behind them, in turn, would be endangered.
 
Infrastructure Damaged
 Experts agreed that the storm has ruthlessly imposed a timetable for critical decisions along the region's coastlines. They say it was a new warning that sooner or later the sea would claim some barrier beaches, no matter how high new dunes are bulldozed.
Dr. Bruno of the Stevens Institute and others also worried about damage to infrastructure abutting the beaches, like roadways and sewer lines.
Dr. Bruno argued that shore areas in the region were of such economic and recreational value that it was unthinkable not to spend public money to protect those beaches that could reasonably be spared further damage. "There are very few regions in the world where the beaches are more used and appreciated than in our area," he said. "In New Jersey, the Shore is part of the state's psyche. To see it so destroyed is shocking."
But some beaches, he acknowledged, may be too far gone to waste money propping up houses that sooner or later will be claimed by the sea.
 
A Protective Berm
 That opinion was shared by Dr. James R. Allen, a coastal geomorphologist for the National Park Service, who toured Fire Island on Thursday. He dismissed the idea, put forth by the Fire Island Association and other private groups, that the Army Corps of Engineers construct an emergency berm, or artificial dune, to protect structures in imminent danger of washing away.
Such measures were taken after a 1962 storm. But Dr. Allen and others noted that the 1962 storm struck in March and that the dunes were built in the spring. Summer is a time of natural accretion of sand on beaches in the Northeast, so the berm helped buy time until nature could help heal the wounds, they said.
But a normal winter may bring 8 to 10 more storms, they said, and if one or two hit at high tide or during a full moon, much of the new dunes could be washed away and millions of dollars in work lost.
Much of the sand lost in the storm was deposited offshore in sandbars, and smaller amounts were trapped by groins, jetties and other man-made structures. Wind and waves carried tons inland.
Just how much was carried away by the sea and deposited in ocean canyons too deep to yield their catch any time soon can only be guessed, said D. W. Bennett, director of the American Littoral Society, a national coastal study group in Sandy Hook.
"The ocean is fine, the fish are fine and the habitat is in good shape," he said. "The beach has just been moved around where the ocean wants it."
Perhaps this storm, he and others said, presented an opportunity to look beyond emergency measures and work on long-term solutions that will accept the fact that the sea is an inexorable force that will not be denied its progression against barrier islands. "One of our arguments is that if people in an oceanside community can't afford to pay for it themselves, then maybe it's time to let the ocean take some of the beaches it wants," he said.

HEADLINE: Economic Pulse: California;
California, Struggling in Slump, Faces High Hurdles to Recovery

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO

 BODY:
Economists say salvation for California's staggering economy lies in small entrepreneurial companies like the Invitrogen Corporation here. A maker of gene-isolation kits and other products for biomedical research, it has shrugged off recession, expanding from 20 employees in 1989 to 105 today in a 30,000 square-foot plant amid tall pines in the La Jolla area.
But now that Invitrogen stands ready to expand even further, its brash young leaders may move all or part of the company to Oregon or Washington State. And therein lies the major question facing once-booming California -- home for one in eight Americans -- as it struggles through its longest economic slump since World War II: Is it too late to recapture the spirit that made California golden and prevent even the few bright spots like San Diego's thriving biotechnology industry from going dim too? 
 Much as they love San Diego, with its splendid climate and proximity to top medical research units like the Salk Institute and the Scripps Research Institute, Invitrogen's owners say manufacturing has become almost prohibitive in California. They cite uncertain water supplies, strict car-pooling rules, growing crime, poor schools and the high costs of workers compensation and health insurance, waste disposal, taxes, housing and legal fees.
It is so expensive to dispose of radioactive waste here that the company has a scientist with a Ph.D. sort the garbage daily.
 
A Costly Life Style
 "The problem with Southern California as we move from the research phase to manufacturing is that the cost of the life style here is prohibitive to the people we need to hire," said Lyle C. Turner of Invitrogen, who, with shoulder-length blond hair over a tennis shirt, hardly looks like the president of a company with $8 million in annual sales.
As national economic signs, holiday retail sales and new jobs point to recovery in most of the rest of the country, California finds itself in the odd company of New York and New England -- excluded from recovery, with little hope of improvement for at least a year. Indeed, even as the national unemployment rate dropped to 7.2 percent in November, California's rose, from 9.8 to 10.1 percent, for the highest rate of any industrial state.
In all, California has lost 808,000 jobs in the last 29 months, many of them high-paying aerospace and military-related ones, according to the California Department of Finance -- and this when it would take a quarter of a million new jobs a year just to keep employment even. The state has lost about 25 percent of its aerospace-manufacturing and construction jobs, with the heaviest losses in Southern California. Forecasts are that employment in the aerospace and electronics industries will drop by an additional 8 percent or 10 percent during 1993.
California smugness has turned into alarm, prompting a rare degree of cooperation between business and government to try to create new industries, like electric vehicles, to replace the declining military industry.
The Speaker of the State Assembly, Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco, recently called for an economic conference of the state's business, political and academic leaders. Aides to Gov. Pete Wilson say the economy has become his chief priority, not least because he faces another $7.5 billion budget shortfall over the next 18 months.
"This is clearly one of the pivotal times in California's economic history," said Lee A. Grissom, senior economic adviser to Governor Wilson, a Republican. "I have traveled all around the state in the last few weeks. There are economic summits all over. They all ask the same thing: What can we do locally to keep things from getting worse?"
 
Problems
Flaws Masked By Prosperity

There are no ready answers. For California is struggling to overcome deep-seated problems that were masked by years of healthy economic growth, problems of deteriorating schools and roads and, at least in the opinion of many businessmen, environmental and other regulations that are oppressive. A kind of economic vertigo has set in whereby the forces that drove the California boom in the last decade, like its sizzling real estate market and immigration, have turned into negative factors.
"The California economy was like a beautiful house being undermined by termites," said Raymond Brady, research director at the Association of Bay Area Governments in San Francisco, "When an earthquake came, it began to collapse around us, and we couldn't figure out why."
Efforts to improve the economic climate have begun. For example, the San Diego City Council, in rare unanimity, recently approved an economic development package cutting the time needed to acquire permits for new and expanding businesses. In the troubled Los Angeles area, a venture called Calstart has been mounted to achieve the "conversion" from military to peacetime industry, so far an elusive notion. With the help of public agencies and major private companies, it is trying to create an electric-vehicle industry in Southern California to replace bomber manufacturing.
To the north, in the fiercely competitive cauldron of computer innovation known as Silicon Valley south of San Francisco, many companies have put aside their rivalries and antipathy to government to take part in "Joint Venture: Silicon Valley," a project to rescue the area from a decline in its international competitiveness.
The picture is complicated because it is uneven. Never having boomed during the 1980's like Los Angeles, the San Francisco Bay Area has weathered the recession better than more populous Southern California and appears better poised for recovery. Also, the agricultural Central Valley has fared comparatively well, except for the state capital of Sacramento, hit by salary reductions for state employees.
Hardest hit is the Los Angeles area, stunned by the combined forces of military cutbacks, a decline in Japanese investments, a downtown office vacancy rate of nearly 30 percent, the recent civil disorders and last June's earthquake in the desert. Bad times have washed over into the outer reaches of Los Angeles's economic orbit, into Orange County, the "inland empire" areas of Riverside and San Bernardino counties, and down to San Diego. Southern California has suffered 80 percent of the state's job losses. All of this has caused falling real estate values and therefore grave troubles for California banks.
 
Prospects
Some Envision National Recovery
 The election of Bill Clinton, who won California overwhelmingly, has stirred a measure of hope. His focus on promoting American technological prowess and emphasis on environmental technology plays to California's strengths, though his promise to cut military spending even further is ominous.
Some economists, particularly Stephen Levy and Robert K. Arnold of the Center for Continuing Study of the California Economy in Palo Alto, maintain that California's troubles are mainly tied to the national recession and military cuts rather than underlying flaws in California. They argue that a "vigorous" national recovery of 5 percent growth stimulated by the new President would bring full employment to California by the end of 1994.
But few other economists or executives are so optimistic. David Hensley, director of the Business Forecasting Project at the University of California at Los Angeles, sees continuing decline in California at least until next fall, and only "small growth" after that.
The president of the California Business Roundtable, Robert E. Wycoff, expects only a "modestly improved" state economy after two years. "And that's on the optimistic side," said Mr. Wycoff, who is president and chief operating officer of Los Angeles-based Arco. "Most see a long period of flatness of several years."
The San Francisco-based Roundtable, a nonpartisan group of top officers of major companies, recently issued a survey that found that executives and voters favored substantial reforms in the state's health insurance and workers' compensation rules.
The signs of troubles are obvious, in the acres of vacant office space in downtown Los Angeles, in the collapse of famed Los Angeles restaurants like L'Ermitage and Trumps, in the long rows of vacant storefronts in Hollywood and even Beverly Hills, in the ill fortune of people like Keta and Tom Nelson of Los Angeles. Ms. Nelson was recently laid off from her job as a bank clerk, her husband from his job as a service-station cashier, and they are preparing to leave for sunnier economic climes. "I don't think it's going to get any better," Ms. Nelson said. "Look around here and see how many people are out of work."
At the landmark Yamashiro Restaurant overlooking Hollywood, the owner, Thomas Y. Glover, says that business in November was down 30 percent from last November and that he was "doing very well" compared with other restaurants.
Even worse is construction. "You hear that employment is picking up, but our out-of-work lists are so long that you've got to lie down to read them," said Bill Perry of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, which represents about 45,000 carpenters in Southern California.
At a restaurant under construction on Melrose Avenue in West Hollywood, two men building a wooden floor said that they had resorted to buying old blue jeans and cowboy boots at garage sales and thrift stores and selling them to Japanese buyers in swap meets for five times the price. "Without my family's help, I'd be homeless," said one of them, Csaba Buzy, 25, laid off from his job as a Mercedes-Benz mechanic four months ago.
 
Bright Spots
Some Industries Are Growing
 But some light is emerging from all this darkness. Certain industries, like apparel design and manufacture, environmental services, foreign trade, motion picture and television production and health care have seen growth this year, much of it fueled by ambitious immigrants like Li-San Hwang, a Chinese civil engineer who is president of Tetra Tech of Pasadena. The company, which employs nearly 600 people and specializes in environmental cleanup of nuclear-weapons testing and production sites for the Government, grew by 30 percent this year and expects similar growth next year.
But economists say none of this will soon replace the hundreds of thousands of highly skilled engineering and technical jobs lost in the aerospace collapse.
To that end, though, an unusual effort has been mounted in an old plant where the Lockheed Corporation once assembled airplanes near Burbank Airport. Symbolically, the hangar has been converted into a laboratory for the emerging electric-vehicle industry led by Calstart, a nonprofit consortium of more than 40 companies and government agencies that hopes to gain $19.8 million in Federal and state grants over the next two years.
Calstart is premised on the notion that worldwide environmental demands for cleaner vehicles makes the Los Angeles area ideal to supply the parts and technology for such vehicles, using the idled expertise of aircraft and missile engineers. "We are taking what have been perceived as problems -- air pollution and the area's downturn -- and turning them into a competitive advantage," said Calstart's president, Michael J. Gage, a former deputy mayor of Los Angeles.
Calstart recently rolled out a prototype electric vehicle and is working on creating the framework for cleaner transportation, including building a network of charging stations, training mechanics and testing electric buses. The participants include all of California's major electric utilities and such companies as General Motors, Intel, I.B.M. and numerous small outfits making batteries, sensors and other components.
Nearly 400 miles to the north, another engine of California prosperity, the computer and semiconductor industry, remains relatively healthy compared to the slumping military production areas in Southern California. But even as demand for semiconductors and other products increases, high tech employment in the area has fallen by 42,000 jobs since 1987, partly because of higher productivity, partly because major companies like the Advanced Micro Devices Corporation of Sunnyvale, have placed their new chip-making plants in less expensive areas like Austin, Tex.
"We are creating manufacturing jobs for other regions," said Thomas C. Hayes, manager of corporate relations for Applied Materials of Santa Clara who is chairman of Joint Venture: Silicon Valley. It has taken advantage of hard times to bring together the valley's go-it-alone entrepreneurs who previously would have little to do with each other but who are now worried about what Mr. Hayes calls "this weird phenomenon of jobless economic growth."
With $1 million in seed money from the valley's corporate giants, Joint Venture has enlisted about 1,000 business executives and local government officials to hammer out solutions to the region's problems. "We are using a downturn like this to get things together that we could not have done in a go-go period," Mr. Hayes said. "These are maverick entrepreneurs, Somali warlords. Half did not know where City Hall was; now they do." The group is working on problems like traffic gridlock, housing and education problems.
Silicon Valley suffers not only from recession but also from dramatic changes in technological industries, said Douglas C. Henton, assistant director of the Center for Economic Competitiveness at SRI International, a Menlo Park research company engaged by Joint Venture. Companies are turning to machinery to raise productivity and buying components and business services elsewhere, often from distant locations in other states and foreign countries. Hence the seeming contradiction of higher sales and fewer jobs.
Mr. Henton said Silicon Valley was well poised to take advantage of the high-tech growth industries of the future, expected to be software development, bioscience, environmental technology and the application of digital technology to products like flat tubeless televisions.
"But we need to create a 21st-century infrastructure for that," he said, "the technical base, the work force, the regulatory environment." Joint Venture is exploring the possibility of wiring the entire valley with optic communications to ease connections between companies. "People are worrying now about the competitiveness of the region, not just their own firms," he said.
 
San Diego
Trying to Keep What It Has

1
Similar issues have begun to grip San Diego, with the fourth-largest concentration of biotechnology companies in the country. The 120 or so companies, mostly clustered in the Torrey Pines area near the University of California at San Diego, are one of the few sources of growth in an otherwise sagging local economy. Many are on the cutting edge of biomedical research, said Bryna W. Kranzler, associate director of Connect, a program set up by the university to ease contacts among the companies, government and research institutions.
But as they prepare to expand, to make money instead of burning it, she said these companies were looking elsewhere. "The C.E.O.'s enjoy the quality of life in San Diego, and the intellectual life," Ms. Kranzler said, but not the high housing costs and rents, water shortages, waste-disposal problems and insurance.
Consequently, other states have tried to lure away San Diego companies. One target is the Alliance Pharmaceutical Corporation, which is awaiting Federal approval to start production on its blood substitute for surgery, expecting to add 75 to 100 employees and 80,000 square feet of space. Company officials have been looking at sites in North Carolina, Texas, South Dakota and New York State. The company's executive vice president, Theodore D. Roth, said that he had not ruled out keeping production in San Diego but that he was dubious, considering the drought and other impediments.
"We are very dependent on water; our product is half water," he said, adding that insurance costs were 10 percent to 15 percent higher here than in other states and that the "general business climate" was often hostile. "There was always a perception in San Diego that people would come because it was California, that the weather and the Golden State were enough, that they did not have to try to attract business."
Responding to such complaints, the Mayor-elect of San Diego, Susan Golding, recently signaled her intention of keeping biotechnology companies by saying she favored financing manufacturing plants with the city's ability to issue bonds and giving guarantees of water to those companies in case of prolonged drought.
 
Entrepreneurs
Hoping to Nurture Creative Spirits
 Invitrogen, the research-kit maker, is the kind of company that has long flourished in the California entrepreneurial hothouse. It was started just five years ago by three friends, who furnished the first office in San Diego with carpet fished out of a disposal bin. Now they are doing $8 million annually in sales, projecting $60 million by 2000 -- and worrying about numbing matters like workers' compensation premiums and housing costs for new employees.
"Scientists take a significant hit in standard of living when they move here from the Midwest," said one of the founders, Joseph M. Fernandez. He added that the company was also having difficulty complying with car-pooling rules, in that scientists often worked odd hours and that the company had no regular shifts.
Still, Invitrogen is divided internally on whether to leave California. The production people want to move to Oregon or Washington State, while the researchers prefer to stay close to San Diego's biomedical nucleus. "From the research point of view, one of my major concerns is whether we can sustain the intellectual energy," said Invitrogen's research director, Malcolm J. P. Finlayson.
Some economists, like Mr. Arnold, argue that California can prosper even if manufacturing goes elsewhere, as long as companies like Invitrogen keep their research and administrative functions in the state. That view is not shared by Governor Wilson and his advisers, who have proposed a long list of reforms to change what Mr. Grissom, his economic adviser, calls "the whole arrogance California had manifested toward business."

Graphs/Map: "Looking for a Way Out"
 In the 1980's, California's economy was the picture of health. Unemployment kept pace with the national rate. Personal income, retail sales and construction grew steadily. But since 1990, unemployment has risen faster in California than in the nation and economic indicators have fallen.
