HEADLINE: MISSION TO SOMALIA;
Better Late Than Never, Aid Organizations Say

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

 BODY:
Moved by images of suffering in Somalia and confident that donations can make a difference now that United States troops are in the country, Americans are contributing generously to a blizzard of fund-raising appeals, relief officials say.
Yet with satisfaction has come soul-searching among relief officials about the tardy response to the crisis by some agencies, as well as ill feeling over the recent stampede into Somalia by groups that had no operations there until press attention made fund-raising lucrative. 
 "Some N.G.O.'s seem to be cashing in on the images of hunger," said Angela Raven Roberts, a British-born anthropologist who has lived and worked in Africa for 25 years, referring to nongovernmental organizations. "Some of the newer ones going in all anxious to help could have been there a year and a half ago. They're going because there is a need, but also because they can take advantage of the publicity."
 
The Public Needs Pictures
 Jim Newton, a spokesman for World Vision, an American organization rushing to establish operations in Somalia, said: "All humanitarian organizations have some regrets that we didn't move in sooner, but part of the problem was that we did not have the funds. One of the dilemmas is that the public does not respond until they see pictures. When the TV began to broadcast pictures, people began to respond."
Several relief officials said some potential donors had asked why new aid is needed, since relief supplies have been piling up on Somali docks in recent weeks amid the country's disorder. But Charles Planck, a spokesman for CARE, said that now that the military intervention has reopened distribution channels, huge quantities of food supplies will be needed for at least six months to prevent further starvation. The International Committee of the Red Cross estimated this month that 4.5 million of the country's 6.5 million people need food aid.
 
3 American Agencies
 Before Somalia made headlines in July, only three American relief agencies were working there, along with a handful of European groups. The three were World Concern, a Seattle group; International Medical Corps, based in Los Angeles, and CARE.
CARE, which has operated in Somalia for a decade, has 170 staff workers in the country. It has coordinated the unloading and warehousing of United Nations food in Mogadishu and handled the distribution of food airlifted into two Somali towns by the American military and the organization of convoys of food to other relief agencies, according to Mr. Planck.
CARE officials have sought to emphasize their central role in the Somalia effort in a drive that has raised nearly $1 million since September, much of it recently. Among those giving money last week was an economics professor at Columbia University who wrote a $10,000 check to CARE.
"I don't spend all my salary and Somalia is the part of the world where people are in the worst conditions now," the professor said. "So that's why I did it." Another donor gave $3,000 to CARE.
"It's hard not to be generous when you see these pictures of people starving," she said. Both donors asked that their names be withheld.
The International Committee of the Red Cross, based in Switzerland, has been directly feeding more Somalis than any other group, operating nearly 900 feeding centers. The American Red Cross has raised $2.4 million this year to support the International Committee's work. The money has paid for the operation of 42 of the International Committee's 900 feeding centers, according to John Thomas, an American Red Cross vice president.
A smaller group that has been working in Somalia for about 10 years is World Concern, based in Seattle. The group's staff of 12 Americans and 165 Somalis has set up 75 feeding centers in and around Mogadishu and the southern port of Kismayu, said Fred Gregory, the group's director.
Since the crisis reached the American public's attention this summer, eight American and several foreign relief agencies have approached World Concern with donations and requests to collaborate on Somalia projects, Mr. Gregory said.
"This is a new experience to have people come to us and ask if they can help out, and I'm delighted that the world is finally responding," Mr. Gregory said. "What is a sensitive issue, however, is the new players that come in and start acting like experts, especially the ones with high-profile P.R. efforts."
One group working to establish operations in Somalia is Food for the Hungry, based in Scottsdale, Ariz. It is still developing plans and has no permanent staff in Africa yet.
A spokeswoman, Karen Randau, said the group had recently sent $600,000 worth of supplies to Somalia for distribution by other agencies. But after another relief agency challenged that figure, Food for the Hungry lowered the estimate to $450,000 and conceded that some of the supplies may have gone to feed Somali refugees in neighboring Kenya.
 
New Drive Going Well
 Nonetheless, a new drive appears to be going well. Food for the Hungry has recently mailed out 50,000 solicitations on the Somali crisis, and Ms. Randau said donations were already 90 percent above what the group received during its major drive last year, which centered on the Kurds in northern Iraq.
Another group that has recently moved into Somalia and is raising money is World Vision of Monrovia, Calif. The agency has not worked in Somalia since 1983, though it has been financing World Concern's Somalia work for four years.
In September, World Vision opened six feeding centers in and around the Baidoa, and its staff of 7 Westerners and 193 Somalis is expanding, according to Mr. Newton. The group says it plans to spend $8 million in the country during the next five years.
World Vision has bought extensive advertising time on television and in newspapers, according to Gary Roebbelen, World Vision's communications manager. Since August, the Somali effort has raised $4.3 million, he said.
"We have to strike while the iron is hot, because when the crisis ends the donations will drop off," Mr. Roebbelen said. "We really are pulling out all the stops on Somalia."

HEADLINE: Isuzu's Cutbacks Cause New Problems for G.M.

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The decision by Isuzu Motors Ltd. to stop building cars may be good news for its rivals in Japan's overcrowded auto market, but it is another setback for the biggest American auto maker, the General Motors Corporation.
On Saturday, Isuzu confirmed widespread speculation that it was getting out of the car business, citing high costs and poor sales. Isuzu also announced an alliance with the Honda Motor Company, under which it would supply sports utility vehicles to Honda, which will provide cars for Isuzu to sell through its dealer network. 
 The departure of Isuzu, which made fewer than 100,000 cars this year, will help to ease oversupply in the crowded Japanese market, which is also suffering from a recession.
 
Creates Gap for G.M.
 But for G.M., which owns 37.2 percent of Isuzu, the Japanese company's decision is a blow to its Geo line of low-priced cars. Isuzu will stop supplying the Geo Storm model at the end of 1993, leaving a hole in G.M.'s lineup.
A spokesman for G.M. said the company would be forced to stop selling the subcompact car at the end of next year, though G.M. would later revive the name.
A spokesman for G.M., David Hudgens, said that "there will be a gap of two model years" with no Storm model.
Isuzu, meanwhile, outlined plans to expand the marketing of its successful four-wheel-drive recreational vehicles, including the Trooper and Rodeo, and its trucks. The expansion will be helped by the strategic alliance with Honda.
Isuzu will make the Rodeo for Honda to sell under its own name in the United States and Japan, and Honda will supply Isuzu with cars for its Isuzu dealerships.
Honda hopes to sell 20,000 of the Rodeo models a year, mostly in the United States. The Rodeos are made in Tippecanoe, Ind., by Subaru-Isuzu Automotive Inc., of which Subaru's parent, Fuji Heavy Industries, owns 51 percent and Isuzu 49 percent.
Isuzu now sells 50,000 Big Horns, known as the Trooper in the United States, each year. It hopes to raise annual sales to 100,000 by 1994-95, officials said.
 
Move Was Predicted
 Industry analysts have long speculated that Isuzu would be forced by its losses to cut models and form ventures with other auto makers.
Isuzu, which is scheduled to announce its 1992 results on Tuesday, is likely to report a loss of more than $100 million, analysts said. It posted a $393 million loss in the year ended October 1991. As Isuzu's biggest shareholder, G.M. is hurt by the losses.
But Isuzu said the strategic shift would help lift its results strongly by 1994-95, when it expects an operating profit of $300 million. Isuzu said it was not having talks to change its affiliation with G.M.
A G.M. spokesman, Ronald Theis, said the American auto maker did not take a lead role in Isuzu's decision not to remain in the car business. "That's a strategic decision arrived at by Isuzu," he said.
As recently as Thursday, the companies announced an agreement to assemble Isuzu medium-duty trucks at G.M.'s assembly plant in Janesville, Wis.
G.M. said Isuzu would continue to supply the Geo Storm through the end of the 1993 model year. Chevrolet-Geo will not have a 1994 or 1995 Storm model but plans to offer a new Storm model in 1996 supplied by another auto maker.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

BEACHES PRECARIOUS AFTER STORM
A week after the worst flooding in 30 years clawed the New Jersey and Long Island coasts and leveled sand dunes, experts assessing the damage agree that the already precarious barrier islands at many points are extremely vulnerable and exposed to dangerous new flooding from even average winter storms. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
SHOOTING CALLED SELF-DEFENSE
An off-duty transit police officer who shot and killed a man outside a Queens nightclub early Saturday fired his weapon in self-defense after the man, who was wielding a broken bottle, charged at the officer, the president of the transit officers' union said. The account of the union official differed sharply from that given on Saturday by a transit police spokesman, who had said that investigators believed the victim was apparently a bystander. B3.
 
CHURCH OF ST. AGNES TO REBUILD
The Church of St. Agnes in mid-Manhattan, where the Latin Mass still resonated among flickering candles and Gothic columns six-stories high, must suddenly bound from the 19th to the 21st century as the result of a disastrous fire earlier this month. But St. Agnes will remain, in one form or another, at 141 East 43d Street, where it has been since the foundations of the current church were laid in 1873. B3.
 
VIDEO STORE PROTEST
Chanting "shame on you," Chelsea residents demonstrated in front of seven pornographic video stores that have opened recently in their neighborhood and urged the authorities to close them. B5.
 
REGION
 
BLAME GAME OVER BLUE CROSS
With New York State's top insurance official threatening to approve a steep rate increase for 1.4 million customers of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Senate Republican leaders continue to accuse one other of sabotaging efforts to solve the company's financial problems. B5.
 
INTEGRATING HARTFORD'S SCHOOLS
The first witnesses in a lawsuit seeking to integrate Hartford's public schools with those of its suburban neighbors have painted a grim picture of conditions in the schools of Connecticut's capital. But what has also emerged are the contradictions in a trial in which the defendant, the state of Connecticut, supports its accusers' goals on integration and education and is fighting only to avoid having a judge order what the state believes it should do itself. News analysis, B14.
 
LONG ISLAND SOUND STATUS REPORT
The Long Island Sound is a vital but ecologically troubled estuary, threatened by pollution that pours into it every day from sewage-treatment plants, according to a preliminary report of a seven-year study of the Sound. The report recommends limiting the amount of nitrogen that flows from sewage plants into the Sound, a proposal that some say would stifle development in surrounding communities. Up to $8.1 billion may have to be spent to limit the nitrogen releases, the report says. B14.
 
A TOUGH LOOK AT HORSE RACING
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo plans to instruct his Commission on Racing in the 21st Century to focus on whether the New York State Racing Association and Off-Track Betting Corporations throughout the state could be transferred to private ownership, state officials said. Mr. Cuomo, who created the commission in an attempt to recast the structure of racing in the state, has made a target of the nonprofit racing association, saying, among other things, that the association's management is overpaid. B2.
 
CLINTON, CUOMO AND MIRROR IMAGES
One year ago yesterday, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo withdrew from the race for president. Judging by his tenure as President-elect, Bill Clinton, so far, is changing the Government largely the way that Mr. Cuomo might have. His choice of advisers and his economic and foreign policies are generally mirror images of Mr. Cuomo's. Metro Matters. B3.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Los Angeles Times Pulls Back From San Diego

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 20

 BODY:
While other cities have seen competition among newspapers disappear, this city, the nation's sixth largest, has the distinction of going from three daily metropolitan papers to one in 10 months.
On Friday, the San Diego County edition of The Los Angeles Times, begun in 1978, closed after its last press run. In February, two papers owned by Copley Press Inc. -- the morning San Diego Union and the afternoon Tribune -- were merged into The Union-Tribune. 
 The San Diego edition of The Times was gaining slightly in circulation and advertising, but not enough to keep it alive, said Phyllis Pfeiffer, the edition's general manager. The circulation of The Times in San Diego was some 60,000, while The Union-Tribune's daily average is 380,000.
"Our study of the long-term prospects showed we could continue to grow, but in small numbers," she said. "Otis Chandler's dream of being a newspaper from Santa Barbara to Tijuana isn't going to happen in this economy." Mr. Chandler, the noted former publisher of The Times, is now the chairman of the executive committee of the Times Mirror Company, which owns The Times.
Ms. Pfeiffer said that advertisers in Los Angeles were not interested in reaching readers in San Diego 100 miles away, and that when the military and aerospace industries in Southern California began to decline, so did advertising revenue.
The Times is now focusing its efforts on the San Fernando Valley and Orange County editions, where it competes more closely for readers and advertisers with The Daily News of Los Angeles and The Orange County Register. "These are bad days for the newspaper industry in general," said David Laventhol, publisher and chief executive of The Los Angeles Times and president of Times Mirror. "An industry evolution has been taking place since the advent of television, and we're seeing the end of head-to-head competition of metro dailies in most regions."
He said competition for advertisers and readers was now mainly between big metropolitan dailies and smaller local papers, with increasing pressure from more specific publications like "shoppers," free papers that consist largely of advertisements.
The Los Angeles Times expects to save about $8 million by closing its San Diego edition. "The view in 1978 was that there was an opportunity there," Mr. Laventhol said. "It turned out to be less so than we thought."
The Los Angeles Times does not release advertising figures on specific zoned editions, but overall ad linage for The Times has been falling quickly. The paper fell from 7.3 million inches of advertising in 1990 to 6.3 million in 1991. Figures for the period ended September show the decline continuing, The Times said. The Times's overall circulation is 1.1 million.
Russell Harris, acting editor of The Oceanside Blade Citizen, a 50,000-circulation paper in northern San Diego County, said that it was not just the economy. "The L.A. Times can't tell Oceanside readers what's going on in their neighborhoods," he said. "People still like to see their names in print."

HEADLINE: Job Growth in Region's Suburbs Outpaces Cities'

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
The dizzying boom of the 1980's dramatically and permanently shifted the economic geography of the New York region as the cities yielded to the outer suburbs their role as employment hubs, according to a new study by Rutgers economists and figures provided by state labor departments.
Not only have the suburbs outgrown the cities in absolute terms, they have also in most cases weathered the recession better. 
 In New Jersey, the trend toward employment sprawl found its starkest expression in the adjoining townships of Edison, Franklin and Piscataway. Together, the three townships support as many jobs, 115,129, as Newark, according to the Rutgers study. Newark, with 117,152, is still the state's leader in jobs, but with only half the number it had 40 years ago.
In New York State, Suffolk County added more jobs between 1979 and 1989 than Manhattan, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, and some of the sharpest growth of jobs by percentage was in upstate counties.
In Connecticut, the contrast was also stark: All of the net job growth in the state between 1979 and 1991 took place in towns of less than 50,000 population, which in the aggregate surpassed the state's larger cities as the place to find work, according to the State Economic Development Commission's figures.
 
'Greatest Deconcentration'
 "The decade of the 80's probably saw the greatest deconcentration of economic activity in the region's history," said James W. Hughes, a Rutgers economist and one of the report's authors.
"The dominant economic dynamic in the region took place in the suburban ring," he added. "That was where, clearly, the bulk of the job growth took place, where the bulk of the new office inventory was added and where the great majority of the retailing expansion came."
While the burgeoning job market in the suburbs meant stasis or decline for the region's cities, Dr. Hughes speculated that having the a broad range of suburban business campuses in addition to the core area in Manhattan is an advantage to the region that could benefit the cities.
"To some extent, it gives the regional economy a much greater diversity, and that will allow the region to compete more effectively," he said. "Some corporations clearly prefer a suburban option, so that if you combine our new suburbs with the unique centrality of Manhattan, you really have a wide set of options."
In New Jersey and Connecticut, the rising suburbs most brashly muscled the old cities aside in creating new service jobs in law, banking, insurance, retailing and real estate.
According to the Rutgers study, the strongest employment growth in New Jersey was in a widening arc of towns in Morris, Somerset and Middlesex Counties.
Meanwhile, the Connecticut figures disclose that, among cities of more than 50,000, heavy job losses in Bridgeport, East and West Hartford, New Britain, New Haven and Waterbury swamped gains in places like Stamford and Manchester.
The state's job growth was scattered over dozens of smaller suburbs, such places as Avon, outside Hartford; Branford, east of New Haven; Enfield, on the Massachusetts line, and Middletown, in the middle of the state.
On balance, Connecticut's cities of more than 50,000 lost 1,870 jobs from 1979 to 1989, less than 1 percent of their job total, while the rest of the state gained 157,000, an increase of 23.7 percent.
"These aren't just the suburbs anymore. These are the new, outer suburbs," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, head of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics' New York region. "Whoever heard of Hunterdon County in New Jersey? Yet it was the star of the decade in growth."
Dr. Hughes and his co-author, Joseph J. Seneca, also an economist, report in "The Suburban Employment Perimeter" that the growth of job centers represents the third stage of suburban development.
The suburbs' first flowering, as bedroom hamlets on commuter rail lines, began around the turn of the century. It was followed by the second phase, developing retail centers, after World War II, which set the stage for what came next, the authors wrote:
"The invasion of large-scale post-industrial corporate settlements, their service retinues and a complete roster of metropolitan functions marked the advent of suburbia's third generation. Added to the inventory of suburban functions in the 1980's was the role of primary work-place destination."
Of the five New Jersey municipalities with the greatest increase in jobs between 1982 and 1990, four are suburban: Edison, Secaucus, Franklin and Parsippany-Troy Hills. The exception, Atlantic City, was an anomaly, Dr. Hughes pointed out, since its growth resulted from the rise of legalized gambling.
Conversely, of the five biggest job-losers, four are cities: Newark, Linden, Hoboken and Elizabeth. The fifth is another anomaly: Lower Alloways Creek, in Salem County, made it to the list because it lost thousands of short-term jobs when a big electric generating plant was completed mid-decade.
In New York State, an old resort area, Saratoga County, registered the biggest percentage increase in jobs between 1979 and 1989, adding 16,000 jobs for a 66 percent increase. Putnam County was No. 2 in job growth, adding 5,800 jobs, while Staten Island was third with 23,000 new jobs for the decade. Tompkins County, in the Southern Tier upstate, was the fourth-fastest-growing job center, with 13,400 new jobs, and Suffolk, adding 146,000 jobs in the decade, was fifth in percentage increase but first in absolute numbers.
In June 1991, the last date for which figures are available, Manhattan had 1,744,601 jobs, and by any measure, Manhattan, is still the core of the state's jobs.

HEADLINE: Seeking a Moderate Image, Mormons Expel Extremists

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: MANTI, Utah, Dec. 18

 BODY:
In a move that underscores the desire of the Mormon Church to cultivate a more centrist image, the church has started to excommunicate many of its ultraconservative followers.
Some experts on the church describe the action as a purge, an effort to do away with extremists whose talk of conspiracies and impending world ruin do not square with a fast-growing faith eager to enhance its standing in the American mainstream. 
 The Salt Lake Tribune reported that hundreds of dissidents have recently been expelled in Arizona, Idaho, Nevada and Utah, perhaps the largest wave of excommunications in the church since the 1850's, when thousands of followers were ousted, including for reasons like poor hygiene and low church attendance.
 
'Grossly Exaggerated'
 The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints does not release information on excommunications, but a church spokesman, Don LeFevre, said the numbers had been "grossly exaggerated."
Michael Quinn, a former professor of history at Brigham Young University and an expert on the church, said: "The church clearly wants to distance itself from the right wing. But this is a witch hunt."
In this tiny town in the isolated Sanpete Valley, where 143 years ago Brigham Young directed pioneers to build a Mormon temple, a dozen or so of the excommunicated followers gathered recently to pray and commiserate.
"They call us apostates," said Steve McKinley, a 39-year-old carpenter. "But it's the church that has changed from early doctrine, not us."
The dissidents here claim church leaders kept them under surveillance and took the license plate numbers of cars parked at a house where ultraconservatives were meeting.
By some measures, the action seems to represent a stunning turnabout for an institution that has traditionally been regarded as a staunch ally of political hard-liners on the right.
Indeed, the church president, Ezra Taft Benson, was seen as a philosophical ally of the ultraconservative John Birch Society and a champion of right-wing causes before he became infirm. He is 93.
But others in the church hierarchy differed sharply with Mr. Benson, even before the decline of his health. And they apparently now hold greater sway on church positions.
Extremists have long been a source of embarrassment for the Mormon Church, which has 1.8 million members around the world. The rare, but highly publicized standoffs between police and Mormon survivalists or polygamists, for example, often resurrect a caricatured image of church members in the minds of people otherwise unfamiliar with Mormons.
"The last thing the Mormon leadership wants," one church expert said, "is another picture of some armed fanatic in a bunker."
 
Promoting Mainstream Image
 The church banned polygamy more than a century ago, but some groups of "traditional Mormons" live in plural marriages in Colorado City, Ariz., and Hilldale, Utah.
Experts say the church has long sought to promote a more mainstream view of the faith. The church pays for an extensive campaign of television commercials, for example, that deal with everyday issues, like the demands of parenting, rather than heavy-handed religious appeals.
Excommunications and lesser forms of reprimand are handled by bishops, who govern each congregation, or ward, and the presidents of each "stake," which has jurisdiction over several wards apiece.
There are generally only two grounds for excommunication: apostasy, or teaching false doctrine, and immorality.
"Excommunications are very rare," said Mr. LeFevre, the church spokesman, who disputed the idea that Mormons have been expelled for political beliefs. "It's neutral on politics."
He added: "But the church doesn't get into predicting the end of the world. And if somebody is doing that, they're off base."
Church leaders have recently warned Mormons in speeches against fundamentalist interpretations of Scripture or early church doctrine. In a recent speech, Elder Malcolm Jeppson urged followers "not to take out of context words and statements made by church presidents that were given at a different time and circumstance than the present."
And Boyd K. Packer, an apostle in the church, warned against "colonies of cults" who "tell of impending political and economic chaos."
One of the fears of the ultraconservatives is the emergence of a single world government, and they claim that President Bush tipped his hand after the Persian Gulf war by hailing "a new world order."
Ultraconservatives also express concerns about "the mark of the beast," a Satanic code that some say is inscribed in the lines on the bar codes used at grocery stores.
Linda Erickson, a divorced mother of eight, said she taught her children at home rather than expose them to the "anti-Jesus Christ teachings" of the public schools. She said a church official summoned her and demanded an explanation of her fears.
 
Expects to Be Excommunicated
 "He said, 'Are you telling me you think the children will be given the mark of the beast in school?' "
She said she replied, "I don't know; it could happen."
Ms. Erickson is scheduled to stand trial at church court later this month, and expects to be excommunicated.
Jim Harmston, a retired college professor, said he was excommunicated because he adhered to early church doctrine. "The church wants to be more acceptable to the rest of the world," he said. "This is all about image management."
Mr. Harmston and his wife, Elaine, said they were reported to church authorities by a woman who demanded to know their views on polygamy. Mr. Harmston said that while he did not practice polygamy he viewed it as a "true principle" that would someday return.
Mrs. Harmston said: "When she heard that, she got all bent out of shape. She said, 'I'm not going to be in any plural marriage.' "
The excommunications have set off a debate throughout Mormonism, and many liberals have come to the defense of the ultraconservatives.
"The church used to attack liberals and now it's attacking conservatives," said Mr. Quinn, who said he resigned from his job at Brigham Young University in a dispute over his research into Mormon history. "People think that's inconsistent. It's not inconsistent at all. The leadership just wants everybody to be in the center."
"I probably disagree on every political and religious point with those who were excommunicated," he added. "But I still think this is an outrage."

HEADLINE: New Bias Case Fuels Dispute With Dinkins

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
A 41-year-old black man told the police that he was severely beaten without provocation on a street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, early yesterday by 10 to 20 Hasidic men, some shouting racial slurs. The police listed it as a bias crime, and Mayor David N. Dinkins called it another case of racially motivated violence in a troubled city.
But later in the day the police said they were looking into reports by Hasidic community leaders that gave a different interpretation to the case. These suggested that the attack had stemmed from an attempt by the black man, Robert Johnson, to steal a car and that a group of Hasidim had chased and caught him and that he had been injured in their efforts to subdue him. 
 Mr. Johnson, who the police said is unemployed but sometimes pumps gasoline for tips at a Williamsburg service station, was released after treatment at St. Vincent's Hospital for facial cuts and body bruises. No arrests were made in the case, and detectives continued last night to refer to Mr. Johnson as a cooperating victim, not a suspect. But much about the matter remained in doubt.
 
Conflicting Versions
 With its racial overtones and conflicting versions from black and Jewish witnesses, with the Mayor's swift -- some said premature -- response even as crucial details were unfolding, the incident echoed the politically explosive case of Ralph Nimmons, a homeless black man who was beaten by 20 to 30 Hasidic men, some of them muttering racial slurs, in Brooklyn's Crown Heights neighborhood on Dec. 1.
Mr. Nimmons, 25, who had a record for burglary and other crimes, said he was rummaging for clothing in an alley. But Hasidic Jews said that he had tried to break into a Lubavitcher headquarters at the scene and that he had been injured when he resisted efforts by Hasidim to subdue and hold him for the police.
Mayor Dinkins, whose quest for re-election next year has become entangled in bitter controversy over his handling of the city's racial problems, was widely criticized for being too quick to denounce the beating of Mr. Nimmons as a racially motivated crime.
Yesterday, after initial police reports of the Williamsburg case went to City Hall -- reports calling it a bias crime and saying an independent witness had confirmed the victim's story -- the Mayor issued a statement denouncing the attack on the black man as well as an unrelated verbal assault on Saturday in which a white man reported that anti-Semitic slurs had been flung at him from a passing car.
"We cannot permit the few intolerant individuals to threaten the very fabric of our city's social life for the majority of New Yorkers," the Mayor declared. "We must work together to replace bigotry with benevolence, anger with acceptance, and hatred with humanity."
But later, after the police said they were looking into conflicting accounts in the beating, Rabbi David Niederman, executive director of the United Jewish Organizations of Williamsburg, called the Mayor's statement "very premature," and said official comments should be reserved until all facts had been established.
"The answer to crime is not violence, and we condemn racial or religious epithets under all circumstances," Rabbi Niederman said. "However, it is not clear at this moment that this incident was motivated by racial animus. It is premature to call it bias when there is other information that this is the result of someone committing a crime."
 
Tensions and Resentments
 Williamsburg, a community of tenements, factories, warehouses and industrial buildings bordering the old Brooklyn Navy Yard and the Williamsburg Bridge, has long been a setting of tensions between Hasidic residents on its north side and Hispanic residents on its south side, bordering the predominantly black Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood.
The Jews of Williamsburg are mostly Satmar Hasidim, who are distinct from, and sometimes rivals of, the Lubavitcher Hasidim of Crown Heights. But for all its tensions, resentments and misunderstandings, the area has seen no major racial or ethnic violence in recent years.
Little was known of Mr. Johnson, the focus of yesterday's incident, who gave his address as 153A Lexington Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, about 10 blocks south of the scene of the assault. A woman at that address, Ethelmal Dixon, said she and her two daughters lived with Mr. Johnson.
The police said the attack occurred about 1 A.M. at Wallabout Street and Franklin Avenue, an all-but-deserted intersection surrounded by warehouses and industrial buildings. Mr. Johnson told investigators he was walking by when he saw a white man and a black man by a parked car.
He said he spoke to them, learned that the car had stalled and offered to try to fix it in exchange for a ride home. The strangers agreed, he said. But as he leaned over to look at the problem, he said, the white man walked away and the black man ran away, behavior that appeared to suggest that the car had been stolen.
Suddenly, Mr. Johnson said, he looked up and found himself surrounded by 10 to 20 men in Hasidic garb. He said they punched him in the face, kicked him and shouted anti-black slurs. He said he was also struck by a car driven by one of the assailants, who then fled.
 
Call From a Witness
 The police said they received a call to 911 from a witness who described an assault against a black man by Hasidim in progress at the intersection. But when officers arrived minutes later, no one was there, the police said. Mr. Johnson was found two blocks away, bleeding from facial cuts. He was standing by a telephone booth and said he was about to call 911 to report the assault.
On the basis of Mr. Johnson's account, the police listed the case as a bias-related crime and Mayor Dinkins issued his statement, coupling the incident with another on Saturday in which unknown men in a passing car had shouted anti-Semitic remarks at a 33-year-old white man walking at 50th Street and 12th Avenue in Borough Park, Brooklyn.
The race of the men in the car was unknown, the police said. The complainant in the verbal assault, whose name was not released, was not physically injured, and police officials said they had no information on whether he was Jewish or, if so, had been identifiable to those in the car as Jewish.
 
A Different Account
 Hours after the Mayor's statement, members of the Hasidic community went to the 90th Precinct station and gave the police a different account of what had happened to Mr. Johnson. They said a group of Hasidic men, whom they did not identity, had seen him trying to break into a car and had chased, caught and subdued him.
Rabbi Niederman said that the police "have received and are investigating information that the victim was interrupted breaking into an automobile, by the vehicle owner, immediately before the incident occurred." He said he had no idea who inflicted the beating and he made no attempt to justify the violence.
But he said: "Not every incident involving people of different backgrounds is bias-related, and too-casual application of the term diminishes its value. We need all of the facts relating to the incident and the auto break-in reviewed by the District Attorney in a fair and complete way as soon as possible."
Lieut. Joseph Heffernan, commander of the 90th Precinct detectives, said last night that there were indications that a car break-in had preceded the assault, but he noted that Mr. Johnson was cooperating and that investigators were still trying to sort out the facts.
"We're trying to be fair to everybody," he said.

HEADLINE: Some Voices Missing At Clinton's Conference

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
After nearly 20 hours of talk in Little Rock, Ark., last week about the economy, the intriguing question is, "What wasn't said?"
Plenty, if you ask some economists who did not attend President-elect Bill Clinton's economic conference. 
 "People in Little Rock weren't a representative sample," said N. Gregory Mankiw, a Harvard professor. "Solow, Blinder and Tobin are great economists, but they are from the more Keynesian end of the spectrum." He was referring to Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate at M.I.T., Alan Blinder of Princeton and James Tobin, a Nobel laureate at Yale.
 
Expansion Is Dismissed
 Small wonder, said Professor Mankiw and others, that little was discussed at the meeting about the distinct likelihood that an economic expansion may already be under way. Several prominent economists who held forth at the conference, including Professor Tobin, pooh-poohed recent upbeat economic numbers and proposed going ahead with a large dose of added deficit spending.
Had Robert Lucas, an economist at the University of Chicago and one of the nation's most prominent anti-Keynesians, been there, he said he would have made a different point: "The economy's in much better shape than either side thought in the campaign. Why not move on to other issues?"
As it happens, many economists, especially younger ones, do not think that fiscal fine-tuning really does much to smooth out the ups and downs of the business cycle; they also believe that deficit spending aimed at getting the economy moving often ignites inflation.
"My view is that the short-run problem is a much smaller problem than the long-run," Professor Mankiw said. "If it diverts Clinton from the long-run issues, he shouldn't think about it at all. He should leave it to Alan Greenspan."
 
Costs Versus Benefits
 Another point of view barely heard in Little Rock last week was skepticism about big government in general and government intervention in business decisions in particular, a skepticism that became especially widespread among younger economists in the 1970's and 1980's.
"I'm skeptical of the benefits of all these new programs, not because we can't afford them," Professor Lucas said. "We're a rich country; we can afford anything. The benefits aren't as big as the costs."
The skepticism is most intense when it comes to industrial and trade policy.
"We want to encourage high-tech industries and trade," said Christina Romer, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley. "And there may be a role for government."
She continued: "What we didn't see at the Little Rock conference is a sense of caution about where government weighs in. Government may screw up. It may choose the wrong industry or encourage tons of lobbying. I'd be much happier with across-the-board research and development tax credits than with government setting up a bunch of Sematechs or saying one industry's R.& D. is the right kind of R.& D."
The most notable gap at Little Rock, however, was details on what economists like to call the hard choices -- the sacrifices necessary to achieve a goal, whether it's more public investment, higher savings or cheaper health care.
"The big thing that was not done in Little Rock was to address economic problems in terms of trade-offs," said Alan Meltzer, an economist at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh who heads the monetarist Shadow Open Market Committee.
"Everything pays for itself," he said. "We can have investment without saving. We can have protection without retaliation. We can have the expansion in all sorts of command-and-control regulation -- environmental, labor, whatever -- without any effects on the economy. That's baloney."
Vice President-elect Al Gore's suggestion that no tradeoffs were needed between environmental regulation and economic growth was also received skeptically by some economists.
"The rhetoric that's come out of this transition that suggests that strict environmental regulation is automatically free is just wrong," said Richard Schmalensee, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who served on President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers.
 
Global Well-Being
 Finally, what struck some economists was that despite an eloquent plea for more American leadership on behalf of the former Soviet Union, there was little sense in Little Rock that America ought to invest in economic security in the rest of the world.
"Clearly, we have to fix our own economy," said Stanley Fischer, an economist at M.I.T. and former chief economist at the World Bank, "but we simply will not be able to do that by taking a nice vacation from the troubles of Latin America and Eastern Europe.
"Neglecting Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union is very dangerous to us because we're all going on the assumption that the end of hostilities is a fact," he said. "It's not a fact. The end of hostilities depends on economic assistance which we haven't yet provided."
For all their skepticism about the Little Rock meeting, some economists regard it as an unqualified political success.
"After four years of watching the Bush team amateurs, it's fun to watch the pros play again," said Martin Anderson, President Ronald Reagan's economic and domestic policy adviser in 1981 and 1982. "Clinton has just done a brilliant political job of building support for whatever he wants to do."
